DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Taking Heat for Handling of Disasters, Blood Supply
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: In taking on the presidency of the American Red Cross, Elizabeth Dole is moving to the helm of an organization that has known controversy from the days of Clara Barton to the era of AIDS and the Loma Prieta earthquake. She isn't likely to face criticism for living in a tent and directing operations from the field, as Red Cross founder Barton did, but she could end up having easily as many battles on her hand as she did in President Bush's Cabinet. After a year in which it faced record disaster expenditures, the organization has taken heat not only for its handling of such emergencies but for its role as a supplier of blood for transfusions. ``Elizabeth Dole has the stature and talent to revitalize the national Rd Cross and make it the kind of modern helping force necessary for disasters in the 1990's,'' San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos said when the outgoing labor secretary was named to the new job. ``From our experience in the Loma Prieta earthquake, it is needed,'' Agnos added. Others echoed his view. ``When the national Red Cross has become involved in the past, there has been a letdown in coordination,'' said Carl Bradford, director of emergency services for West Virginia. ``The Red Cross seems to function very well at the local level, but when national comes in they do not work as well with state and local governments.'' Carol McArthur, press secretary to Oakland, Calif., Mayor Lionel Wilson, was so upset by the Red Cross' performance after the Oct. 17, 1989, earthquake in Northern California that she resigned from the board of the organization's Oakland and East Bay chapter. ``The local Red Cross was very, very efficient, but they had national representatives breathing down their necks,'' Ms. McArthur said. ``Mainly the problems had to do with individuals not understanding the varied needs of the ethnically diverse community we have here.'' Jim Cassell, a media associate at Red Cross headquarters, said the organization is making a study of its disaster services, due for completion in March. ``We will look at all disasters, including the major ones of last year, the earthquake on the West Coast and Hurricane Hugo in the East,'' Cassell said. He said the study was in large measure ``due to our own interest in always improving our services ... and not just in response to criticism from outside.'' Richard Smith, vice president and general manager at the organization's Eastern operations headquarters in Alexandria, Va., said, ``We have learned a lot of lessons we can put into our operational planning right away.'' ``Mostly our need is to try to streamline our training,'' he said. ``At a time when emotions and passions can run rather high, and then you bring augmented resources in from outside, it is very challenging to make sure you do that so that feelings don't get rubbed in the wrong way. Some people have worse skills than others in doing that and we sometimes have moments of tension.'' ``We had a difficult year, but all that assessment is being put to our improvement,'' said Smith. In a separate initiative, the Red Cross announced in August that it was substituting centralized management for its system of local control in each of 54 blood service regions, which supply blood to more than half the hospitals in the United States. The action followed months of scrutiny by the news media and the Food and Drug Administration. In 1988, the Red Cross acknowledged it distributed 24 pints of blood that had failed AIDS procedures but said none of the blood was used and none carried the AIDS virus. The FDA said the units were shipped by Red Cross centers in Washington and Nashville, Tenn. Brad Stone, an FDA spokesman, said, ``The purpose of those reforms is to help the Red Cross come into greater compliance with our standards. We have an ongoing system of inspections, and so we hope the improvements they are making will be reflected in those inspections. We are very encouraged by the steps they are taking.'' The American Red Cross is one of 150 national Red Cross and Red Crescent societies affiliated with the International Committee of the Red Cross, based in Geneva. In some countries, the society is an arm of the government, but in the United States it is a private organization supported by contributions. Congress gave the Red Cross a charter in 1918 to conduct disaster preparedness and relief. There is no congressioal oversight, however. The American Red Cross has around 2,700 chapters, a paid staff of 25,000 and more than 1 million volunteers. In 1989, it received a record $165 million in donations and spent $151 million, more than tripling the previous record. Its national office is in Washington. It has operational headquarters for the East Coast in Alexandria, Va., for the Midwest in St. Louis and for the West in Burlingame, Calif. Clara Barton, a former schoolteacher and government clerk who became a superintendent of nurses during the Civil War, founded the group as the American Association of the Red Cross in 1881 and became its first president. ``She was always very much hands-on when a big disaster struck,'' said James Perry, a National Park Service ranger at the Clara Barton House in Glen Echo, Md. ``She would personally lead the field operation.'' During the Johnstown, Pa., flood of 1889, Miss Barton was in the field for five months. Critics of her style of personal leadership forced her resignation in 1904 at the age of 83. Mrs. Dole, 54, will become president in January. She succeeds Richard Schubert, who resigned from the $185,000-a-year job more than a year ago. Smith, whose first disaster experience with the Red Cross was in the aftermath of Hurricane Camille in Louisiana in 1969, said the role of the Red Cross has changed since it was chartered by Congress in 1918. ``At that point, the federal agencies' role was much more in dealing with public utilities and infrastructure and much less with individual families, and so the Red Cross in those days took the primary job even of rebuilding people's homes and long-term recovery help,'' the Red Cross vice president said. ``As the federal government expanded its role to be more that of long-term recovery, the Red Cross withdrew from that and put more emphasis on short-term emergency response.'' Government disaster relief is now run by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, created during the Carter administration as a consolidation of several programs. Peg Maloy, assistant associate director for public affairs at FEMA, said, ``If the president signs a major disaster declaration, we become the coordinator. We also then give disaster money and temporary housing to the Red Cross for some of the work that they do. We have a memorandum of understanding with the Red Cross. We also sit on their national board.''

DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Voters Settle Three-Way Race For Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with Franks winning and figures, picks up dash material. ^By JUDD EVERHART
DOC.TEXT: Former Sen. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. on Tuesday became the first third-party candidate to win the Connecticut governor's office in 134 years. Gary Franks, a black Republican, was elected to the U.S. House. No black Republican has represented a U.S. House district since 1935. With 85 percent of precincts reporting, Weicker, running as an independent, had 379,335 votes, or 41 percent, to 337,173 votes, or 36 percent, for his nearest challenger, Republican John G. Rowland, a three-term congressman from blue-collar Waterbury. Democrat Bruce A. Morrison, a four-term congressman from the New Haven suburb of Hamden, had 195,137 votes, or 21 percent. Franks, one of three black Republicans running for Congress this year, won Rowland's 5th District seat over former U.S. Rep. Toby Moffett. With 93 percent of the precincts reporting, Franks had 90,084 votes, or 52 percent, to Moffett's 81,906 votes, or 47 percent. The state's voters had grown accustomed to electing Democratic governors over the past three decades. No third-party candidate had won the office since 1856. But Weicker, a Republican defeated in a 1988 re-election bid, roared back onto Connecticut's political scene in March, announcing he would run for governor as an independent and promising ``a hell of a race.'' ---
DOC.HEAD: Democratic fortunes, dash material
Gingrich Trails; Zell Miller Elected Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Gingrich imperiled. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Miller had...'
DOC.TEXT: Georgia's lone Republican congressman, Minority Whip Newt Gingrich, fell behind in the ballot counting Tuesday in a close race that overshadowed the election of Democrat Zell Miller as governor. With 76 percent of precincts reporting in the 6th Congressional District, Gingrich had 53,147 votes, or 50 percent, to 54,034 votes, or 50 percent, for Democrat David Worley, a Jonesboro lawyer. Gingrich, a diehard tax cutter, led the pack of conservatives who bucked President Bush's original deficit-reduction compromise with the Democratic leadership in Congress. Miller, the lieutenant governor for 16 years, rode voter enthusiasm over a state lottery to victory in the governor's race. With 88 percent of precincts reporting, Miller had 633,710 votes, or 54 percent, to 503,115 votes, or 43 percent, for Republican Johnny Isakson, a prosperous Atlanta real estate company executive and state legislator for 14 years. Miller had been a heavy favorite to keep the governor's office in Democratic hands. The incumbent, Joe Frank Harris, leaves office in January after the state limit of two consecutive terms. The state's 10 members of the U.S. House, nine Democrats and a Republican, all faced opposition Tuesday. Sen. Sam Nunn, a Democrat, had no opposition. Miller, 58, defeated four opponents, including former Mayor Andrew Young in an Aug. 7 runoff, to win the Democratic nomination for governor. Young since has campaigned for Miller but has said he may try again in four years to become the state's first black governor. Miller has said he will retire after serving a single four-year term. Isakson, 45, sought to neutralize the lottery as an issue by endorsing the proposal, himself, while differing with Miller on how the revenue should be used to enhance education.

DOC.HEAD: Richards Elected Texas Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Ann Richards' victory. Picks up at dash material.
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Ann Richards squelched millionaire Republican oilman Clayton Williams in Tuesday's gubernatorial race, a contest that set records for spending and mudslinging. Outspent by nearly 2-1 margin, Ms. Richards nonetheless closed the gap with Williams in the campaign's final days, helped by his admission last week that he had paid no taxes in 1986. With 67 percent of precincts reporting, Richards had 1,286,455 votes, or 52 percent, to 1,1176,405 votes, or 48 percent, for Williams. Texas voters gave Republican Phil Gramm a second term in the U.S. Senate. With 67 percent of precincts reporting, Gramm had 1,459,815 votes, or 60 percent, to 982,579 votes, or 40 percent, for his Democratic opponent, state Sen. Hugh Parmer of Fort Worth. With Democrats holding 19 of the state's 27 seats in the U.S. House, the GOP concentrated on unseating Democratic Rep. Bill Sarpalius of Amarillo. Republican challenger Dick Waterfield, a two-term state legislator, got all the help he could hope for from the party's big guns, including appearances by first lady Barbara Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle and Gramm. ---
DOC.HEAD: In the, dash material
Socialist Wins House Seat; GOP Governor Favored To Regain Office
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with Snelling win, and latest returns
DOC.TEXT: Bernard Sanders on Tuesday pushed Rep. Peter Smith out of the state's lone House seat to become the first socialist in Congress in more than 60 years. With 73 percent of the precincts reporting, the former mayor of Burlington had 71,119 votes, or 56 percent, to 51,273 votes, or 40 percent for Smith, a Republican. Sanders ran as an independent. In the governor's race, former Gov. Richard Snelling grabbed back the office, overcoming competition from Democrat Peter Welch, former president pro tem of the state Senate. With 73 percent of precincts reporting, Snelling had 66,642 votes, or 52 percent, to Welch's 59,388 votes, or 46 percent. Gov. Madeleine Kunin, a Democrat who succeeded Snelling in office in 1985, opted not to seek a fourth term. Snelling had decided to run when it still appeared that Kunin would seek re-election. He said he entered the race because he felt the state's fiscal affairs were a mess.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Czar to Resign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs
DOC.TEXT: William J. Bennett, who crafted the strategy for the Bush administration's war on drugs, will resign within a week, an administration source said Tuesday night. Bennett, 47, feels he has completed the task of designing a strategy for the drug war and that it is working, said the source. This source said personal reasons, including safety concerns for himself and his family, also played a part in his decision to resign as director of the Office of National Drug Control Strategy. The Washington Post reported on the resignation in Wednesday's editions. The White House has scheduled a ceremony to announce the resignation, and that ``could possibly be before Friday,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. No one has yet been tapped to replace Bennett, the source said. The source denied that Bennett was leaving because of boredom, even though Bennett has seemed testy in recent months over the relative lack of public interest in drug problems as the Persian Gulf and economic woes took center stage. ``It's not boredom,'' the source said. ``He set out to do a task. He's done it, and he's seeing the fruition of it. Now he's going on to the next phase of his life.'' Bennett does not have another job lined up, the source said. The personal reasons and security concerns have become increasingly important in the past few weeks, according to the source. ``There's been some threats, bomb threats, personal threats,'' the source said. On a recent swing through Alaska, where he campaigned for a ballot measure to re-criminalize marijuana, a third bodyguard was assigned to Bennett. The concerns, said the source, ``Have been building. I've seen it start to eat away at him.'' Bennett and his wife have two young sons. President Bush joined Bennett in September to mark the one-year anniversary of the drug strategy and to call attention to signs that the cocaine crisis appears to be abating. Such signs include higher prices and lower purity, slightly fewer emergency room cases involving cocaine, and surveys showing Americans of all ages turning against illegal drugs of all kinds. Bennett's job was created by Congress in 1988 to coordinate the efforts of several dozen federal agencies involved in the war on drugs. Congress created the post as a Cabinet-level job, but Bush decided not to include Bennett in his Cabinet, and Bennett said he did not mind.

DOC.HEAD: Democrat Andrus Wins Unprecedented Fourth Term
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Gov. Cecil Andrus earned an unprecedented fourth four-year term Tuesday, just seven months after he was targeted for defeat by outraged anti-abortion forces. Andrus, who interrupted his tenure as governor to serve as Jimmy Carter's interior secretary, was never really tested in the campaign by Roger Fairchild, a former state Senate Republican floor leader. With 18 percent of precincts reporting, Andrus had 23,383 votes, or 61 percent, to 14,934 votes, or 39 percent, for Fairchild. Idaho voters maintained their ticket-splitting tradition, re-electing five-term Republican Rep. Larry Craig, who defeated Democrat Ron Twilegar for the seat of retiring GOP Sen. James McClure. Republicans have held the seat for 40 years. Craig spent $1.5 million, three times more than Twilegar, to keep it that way. With 17 percent of precincts reporting, Craig had 24,192 votes, or 66 percent, to 12,680 votes, or 34 percent, for Twilegar. In the race to succeed Craig in the House, Republican state Sen. Skip Smyser was locked in a tight race with Democrat Larry LaRocco, one-time aide to Sen. Frank Church. Fairchild, 37, a populist businessman, spent $90,000 of his own money to win a lackluster three-way primary but was financially hamstrung during the general election campaign. He barely raised $50,000 against $1 million raised by Andrus, 59. Fairchild ran on an anti-abortion platform, reminding voters of the governor's March 30 veto of what would have been the nation's most restrictive abortion law.

DOC.HEAD: CNN's Election Coverage Shines, Networks Balance Races, Entertainment
DOC.TEXT: Television encountered the off-year elections Tuesday night like a doctor ordering a full set of tests to take a patient's temperature. ``It was the election of our discontent,'' CBS correspondent Bruce Morton said in the early going, before the nation's dreaded anti-incumbency mood stopped short of actually ousting any major rascals. It had fewer commercials. And, for the first time, Cable News Network and the Big Three broadcast networks pooled resources for election night exit polls and winner projections, in a collaborative effort called Voter Research and Surveys, or VRS. ``There are always problems the first time you do anything,'' said VRS spokeswoman Susan Morrison, adding that there were no big problems with winner projections or the state exit polls. There was a delay in national exit polls, which tended to arrive all at once, because VRS chief Warren Mitofsky wanted to ensure the ``weighting'' of 9,000 to 10,000 interviews accurately reflected the national trends. ``It worked very well for us,'' said CNN spokeswoman Melinda McIntire. By 9 p.m. EST, she said, VRS let the cable network project 38 governor and Senate races. ``It's been extremely helpful in our analyzing voters in geographic and demographic breakdowns.'' By midnight, VRS had issued 72 projected winners in senate, governor and referendum questions, Ms. Morrison said. ABC and NBC kept the first two hours of their prime time entertainment, coverage, dropping in brief spot reports until hourlong specials at 10 p.m. EST. CBS' coverage went the distance from 9 p.m. to 11. But NBC's one-hour special and CBS' two hours were ``sustaining'' - read ``unsponsored'' - programs which don't count in the November ratings ``sweeps'' that help local stations set their advertising rates. The overall ratings race is tight this year, and typically low election night ratings could pull down a network's overall numbers. Top-rated NBC quickly followed suit after CBS said it would air no commercials. CNN, which has no prime time entertainment programs, began its coverage at 6 p.m. EST as ``The World Today'' neatly capsulized key races. By 7 p.m., CNN's main coverage was in full swing. ABC and CBS led their nightly news shows with six-minute election reports; their second story was the assassination of radical Rabbi Meir Kahane. NBC led its news with nine minutes on the election before getting to the Kahane story. CBS' election night anchor, Dan Rather, spent the night in shirtsleeves, red tie and burgundy-striped suspenders. He also got off the best quote, early ``We're going to be all over these races like paint on a wall.'' And the graphics! ABC and CBS colored their Democrats blue and the GOP red; contrariwise, NBC made its Democrats red and the Republicans blue. ABC's ``The '90 Vote'' computer graphics screens had a traditional look to them. Candidate pictures, numbers, percentages, precincts reporting; and the network closed its main coverage with a roll of the winners. NBC's ``Decision '90'' graphics were busy and postmodern: the candidate pictures, superimposed on a split ppurple grid, beside human silhouettes extending across a red or blue bar to the numeric vote percentage. Then there were three diagonal red slashes pulsating across the lower left corner while a narrow blue bar descended down the screen. CNN listed the winners' names in gold, the losers in gray, declaring projected winners with a chubby little check mark on a bright red box. Unfortunately, CNN's party tags were donkey and elephant logos - with blue backgrounds and red frames. CBS had outstanding line-score graphic rundowns of the winners, picture, name, state, and a cute little logo of the state syumbol (Hint: Maine was a lobster, Tennessee a coonskin cap CBS graphics outdid all others. Its snazzy, computer-driven, green relief map of the United States giddily panned and tilted from state to state at breakneck speed until some high-strung producer probably told them to cut it out. CNN excelled with its team of four regional anchors who kept on top of various races. In addition, CNN political reporter Brooks Jackson covered the campaigns finances, coming up with some surprising insights, CNN also gave the last eight minutes of each hour to the verbal fisticuffs of ``The CNN Capital Gang,'' a four-member hodgepodge of righty and lefty political pundits Michael Kinsley, Mark Shields, Pat Buchanan and Robert Novak. After eight minutes, even the most casual viewer would want to review U.S. policy against peacetime use of nuclear weapons. Shortly before 9 p.m. EST, the gang cut back to the venerable CNN anchor Bernard Shaw, who looked bemused to the point of snakebite. ``Don't you just love them?'' Shaw said without a question mark in his voice.

DOC.HEAD: Democrat In Nevada Wins First Full Term
DOC.TEXT: Acting Gov. Bob Miller strolled to his first full term in office Tuesday in a campaign that hinged on taxes and abortion. Miller was challenged by Republican Jim Gallaway, a wealthy businessman and newcomer to Nevada politics who campaigned on a no-new-taxes platform and criticized Miller for his anti-abortion stand. With 10 percent of precincts reporting, Miller had 4,814 votes, or 63 percent, to Gallaway's 2,615 votes, or 34 percent. Miller, a Democrat elected lieutenant governor in 1986, became acting chief executive when former Gov. Dick Bryan won a U.S. Senate seat in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Gov. Romer Wins Second Term, Brown Hooks Senate Seat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with Brown winning Senate race, latest returns. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Roy Romer waltzed to a second term Tuesday, and Republican Rep. Hank Brown got a promotion to the U.S. Senate. A proposal to limit politicians' terms in office was approved, and voters also considered a controversial tax limitation amendment. Brown, 50, bested Democrat Josie Heath, a former Boulder County commissioner. He succeeds Republican Sen. Bill Armstrong, who is retiring. With 40 percent of precincts reporting, Brown had 206,303 votes, or 57 percent, to 157,767 votes, or 43 percent, for Heath. Romer, 62, who first won office in 1986, faced challenger John Andrews, an outside-the-mainstream Republican who alienated many party members with his adamant support for the tax amendment, which would put most tax and fee issues to a public referendum. With 40 percent of precincts reporting, Romer had 233,425 votes, or 66 percent, to 121,674 votes, or 34 percent, for Andrews. The other high-profile initiative would limit the terms of state elected officials and legislators to eight years, and congressional and U.S. Senate terms to 12 years. The measure's proponents said it was needed to inject new blood into Colorado's political leadership. One Colorado congressional race was close. The prize was Brown's former 4th District seat. State Sen. Wayne Allard, a Republican from Longmont, led in initial returns ahead of state Rep. Dick Bond, a Democrat from Greeley. With 44 percent of precincts reporting, Allard had 35,882 votes, or 54 percent, to 30,408 votes, or 46 percent, for Bond.

DOC.HEAD: Kansas Education Amendment Defeated
DOC.TEXT: Kansas voters refused Tuesday to shift much of the authority over schools from state education boards to the legislature. Late evening returns showed the proposed constitutional amendment trailing by 128,604 to 188,117 votes. The measure spurred serious opposition from education groups, while no organization promoted it. ``The voters are saying that they are not willing to give the legislature full authority over education,'' said State Board of Education Chairwoman Connie Hubbell of Topeka, who campaigned against its passage.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Daniel Akaka beat back a strong challenge from Rep. Patricia Saiki on Tuesday, denying Republicans a longed-for chance to grab a seat in this heavily Democratic state. Akaka had been appointed earlier this year to the seat of the late Sen. Spark Matsunaga and will serve the four years remaining in that term.
Here are some highlights of Tuesday's election.
DOC.HEAD: GOVERNORS RACES
DOC.TEXT: Three Republican incumbents lost as voters in 36 states elected governors. In Florida, Democrat Lawton Chiles unseated Republican Gov. Bob Martinez and Rhode Island Gov. Edward DiPrete was defeated by Democrat Bruce Sundlun. Democrat Joan Finney, an abortion opponent, ousted Republican Gov. Mike Hayden in Kansas. Democrat Ann Richards was the victor of the hotly contested Texas race, defeating Republican Clayton Williams. Former U.S. Sen. Lowell Weicker, running as an independent, won in Connecticut. In Georgia, Democrat Zell Miller grabbed the seat given up by a retiring Democrat. ---
DOC.HEAD: SENATE RACES
DOC.TEXT: Democrats retained control of the Senate as incumbents showed their strength. In the most closely watched contest, conservative Republican Sen. Jesse Helms of North Carolina defeated Democrat Harvey Gantt, a liberal and the first black mayor of Charlotte. In a surprisingly close race, Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley of New Jersey defeated Republican challenger Christine Todd Whitman, a virtual unknown in her first statewide bid. Democratic Sens. Paul Simon of Illinois and Carl Levin of Michigan fought off stiff challenges by Republican challengers. ---
DOC.HEAD: HOUSE RACES
DOC.TEXT: Four incumbent Republicans and two Democrats were unseated as the Democrats moved to strengthen their control of the House of Representatives. Voters elected the first socialist to the House since 1929 and the first black Republican since 1935. In Vermont, socialist Bernard Sanders defeated GOP Rep. Peter Smith and Connecticut Republican Gary Franks, who is black, dashed the comeback hopes of former Democratic Rep. Toby Moffett. Virginia GOP Rep. Stan Parris lost to Democrat James Moran, and in Florida, Democrat-turned-Republican Bill Grant was soundly defeated by Democrat Pete Peterson. Maryland Democratic Rep. Roy Dyson, troubled by character questions, was ousted by Republican Wayne Gilchrest. Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga. faced a surprisingly stiff challenge from Democrat David Worley.

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta Suburbs Rejecting Rapid Transit Link
DOC.TEXT: Voters in suburban Gwinnett County were rejecting a $681 million extension of Atlanta's rapid transit system in early election returns Tuesday. With 24 of the county's 78 precincts reporting, the vote was 70 percent to 30 percent against extending a line of the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority into the area northeast of Atlanta. The extension would be financed by a 1 percent sales tax. County Commissioner W.J. Dodd had predicted his constituents would reject the proposal because they feared ``the minorities.'' Blacks and other minorities comprise 6.4 percent of Gwinnett's 355,000 residents, while they make up 66 percent of Atlanta's 425,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Fire Breaks Out At Universal Studios
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with detais. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto pursuing
DOC.TEXT: A fire raced through Universal Studios on Tuesday night, burning down street sets where movies and TV shows are filmed and forcing an evacuation of the studio and its amusement park. Witnesses said the blaze, fanned by gusty winds, overran the sprawling back lot of the 420-acre studio located 10 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles. The futuristic town square built for the filming of ``Back to the Future, Part II'' was among the areas burned, officials said. About 200 people, most of them studio and amusement park employees, were evacuated. No evacuation was called at the nearby Universal Hilton, where Republican gubernatorial candidate Pete Wilson has his headquarters. Flames were reported at 7:18 p.m. and one ambulance was dispatched to the scene. There were no immediate reports of injuries, said police Sgt. Richard Thomas. The fire's cause was being investigated. ``From our vantage point the fire is burning in the center of the studio where our major facades are located,'' said Joan Bullard, president of public relations at Universal. The fire raged in a ``sound stage area'' to the rear of the studio lot, said Fire Department spokesman Pat Marek. At least 24 engines were sent to the blaze. A cloud of smoke hovered over the back lot where fake buildings used as background for filming are constructed. The fire is not the first to strike Universal. In 1987, a stage used for the 1959 epic ``Spartacus'' erupted in flames, causing $2.5 million in damage. The facades burning included streets sets where the studio films its New York street scenes and Sting Street, where the famous Paul Newman and Robert Redford film was shot. The studio features a seven-hour tour attraction, which includes a guided tram tour that takes viewers through film sets and a simulated earthquake. ``The tour will be affected, but we have no information on how at this time,'' Bullard said. Universal Studios was founded by Carl Laemmle in 1912. It did not gain recognition until the 1920s, when it produced several now-classic silent films, including ``The Phantom of the Opera,'' and ``The Hunchback of Notre Dame.'' Universal Studios is one of the older Hollywood lots and home to such film classics as ``Psycho,'' by Alfred Hitchcock, ``The Sting,'' ``Jaws'' and ``To Kill A Mockingbird.'' Current television shows shot at Universal include ``Major Dad,'' ``Murder She Wrote,'' ``Quantum Leap'' and ``Matlock.''

DOC.HEAD: Missouri Voters Reject Streams Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Missouri voters on Tuesday overwhelmingly rejected a streams protection proposal that opponents painted as a government land grab. Rural counties rolled up margins as high as 10-to-1 against Proposition A, known as the Natural Streams Act. With 73.7 percent of the precincts reporting, the unofficial vote ran 76.9 percent against the proposal. The act would have created a five-member state commission to approve management plans for 52 scenic waterways, primarily in the Ozarks. Backers said the commission was needed because voluntary protection of waterways was not happening.Foes said it would create a dictatorship that could mandate unreasonable regulations and steal rights of property owners.

DOC.HEAD: Precede RESTON, Va.
At Least 20 Dead In Major Quake In Southern Iran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruou7t with Iranian news agency reporting 20 dead, other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake struck a mountainous area of southern Iran on Tuesday night, killing at least 20 people and heavily damaging at least a dozen villages, Iran's official news agency reported. The U.S. Geological Survey in Golden, Colo., said initial readings put the quake's magnitude at 7.0 on the Richter scale. Iran's Geophysics Center of Tehran University said it measured 6.6. An earthquake of that magnitude is capable of widespread, heavy damage. A quake measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale struck northern Iran on June 21, killing an estimated 50,000 people. Tuesday's quake struck at 9:47 p.m. and was centered in Fars province near the city of Darab about 600 miles southeast of Tehran, the Islamic Republic News Agency said. IRNA said at least 20 people were killed and more than 60 injured. It quoted Darab Gov. Yahya Hashemi as saying at least 12 villages were heavily damaged. Earlier reports from the region told of 100 casualties - dead and wounded - counted an hour after the quake struck, said Alirez Jafarzadeh, the Washington, D.C.-based spokesman for The People's Mujahedeen of Iran. Jafarzadeh, whose group seeks to overthrow the Tehran government, said he had no breakdown of dead and wounded. The quake, centered 50 miles east of the city of Darab, hit the route that connects Darab with the port city of Bandar-Abbas on the Strait of Hormuz, said Jafarzadeh. ``This is a mountainous area,'' Jafarzadeh said. ``The casualties are high because it occurred late at night when most villagers are at home, so that's real unfortunate.'' In the two counties of Forg and Abshour, he said, ``there were a total of 20 villages damaged 50 to 80 percent,'' he said. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. An increase of one number on the scale means a ground motion increase of 10 times.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with latest results throughout; picks up 22nd graf, a0910
DOC.HEAD: Ann Richards Takes Texas, Chiles Wins Florida as GOP Ousted in 3 States
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Lawton Chiles unseated Florida's Gov. Bob Martinez, and Ann Richards won in Texas as Democrats wrested two big states from GOP control Tuesday in elections that saw incumbents struggle for political survival. Democratic challengers ousted Republican governors in Rhode Island, Kansas and Florida. Richards' defeat of Republican Clayton Williams in Texas' bitter and tumultuous governor's race capped a remarkable come-from-behind race. Williams, a blunt-spoken Texas millionaire, squandered a big lead in the polls through a series of verbal campaign gaffes. The GOP losses in Texas and Florida were stinging defeats for President Bush, who visited Florida three times to stump for Martinez and spent the last three days of the campaign in his adoptive home state of Texas campaigning for Williams. Democrats were quick to point to the results as spelling political trouble for the president. ``To the degree that George Bush was a factor, he was a burden,'' said Ohio's retiring Gov. Richard Celeste, head of the Democratic Governors Association. ``We have an opportunity to do what was inconceivable six months ago - that is defeat a Republican president.'' Republicans scored gains too, however, and recaptured the governorships in Vermont and Ohio, where Democrats are retiring. Republican Gov. Ed DiPrete lost the Rhode Island statehouse he had held since 1984 to Bruce Sundlun, a Democrat he had defeated twice before. Democrat Joan Finney defeated first-term Republican Gov. Mike Hayden in Kansas. Maine's Republican Gov. John McKernan held a slim lead over Democratic challenger Joseph Brennan, a former governor who led in initial returns. Nebraska's Republican Gov. Kay Orr narrowly trailed her Democratic challenger, Ben Nelson, with three-quarters of the votes in. The Republican incumbents found themselves the victims of voter anger over tax increases and regional economic downturns, as well as various local issues. Abortion was a factor in several races, with victories by both supporters and opponents of abortion rights. New England's recession hurt most of that region's incumbents, and DiPrete suffered from scandals surrounding his family and political allies. The GOP governors in Kansas and Nebraska were in hot water over local property taxes. Some Democrats faced stiff challenges, too. Michigan Gov. James Blanchard, bidding for a third term, narrowly trailed Republican John Engler in incomplete returns. Republican George Voinovich won in Ohio, giving the GOP Celeste's statehouse office. Celeste called it ``my special disappointment.'' An independent, former GOP Sen. Lowell Weicker, won a three-way race in Connecticut, where the Democrat also is retiring. In the Democratic bastion of Massachusetts, Republican William Weld held the slimmest of leads over outspoken conservative Democrat John Silber. Republican hopes were boosted by Democratic divisions in the state where former Democratic presidential nominee Michael Dukakis is retiring as governor in the depths of recession-inspired unpopularity. In Illinois, a state in GOP hands for more than a decade, Democrat Neil Hartigan and Republican Jim Edgar were locked in a virtual tie with more than half the vote in. Both parties had focused on the big-three states - California, Texas and Florida - where governors will influence new congressional district maps to be drawn next year. GOP Sen. Pete Wilson held the lead over Democrat Dianne Feinstein in early returns from California. Democrat Barbara Roberts held a small lead in Oregon. With returns still far from complete, Democrats had scored a net gain of four seats. They captured six governorships previously held by Republicans: Florida, Oklahoma, Rhode Island, New Mexico, Texas and Kansas. And they led in several more, including Illinois and Maine. Republicans won in two states now in Democratic hands, Ohio and Vermont, and were leading in several others. They included Massachusetts, Michigan and Minnesota. Martinez, who failed in his bid to become Florida's first two-term Republican governor, called Chiles to concede defeat as Chiles's substantial lead held up in incomplete returns. ``He was very, very gracious and said he wanted to help us with the transition,'' said Chiles, who called the campaign ``the most glorious, glorious time of my life.'' Chiles' support for abortion rights was a significant factor in the race, according to network television voter interviews. The ex-senator also had refused to accept contributions over $200. Both Chiles and Connecticut's Weicker are former senators. Weicker, defeated two years ago after three terms as a Senate Republican, becomes the first independent governor elected since Maine's James Longley in 1974. The Michigan race was a special target of abortion groups, as Blanchard supported abortion rights and Engler opposed them. The Kansas race was a victory for abortion opponents as Finney, the Democrat, was an abortion foe and Hayden, the GOP incumbent, had supported abortion rights. Guy Hunt, Alabama's first Republican governor in this century, withstood a strong challenge to win re-election over Democrat Paul Hubbert. Democrat David Walters won in Oklahoma, where the Republican incumbent was retiring. Georgia Democrat Zell Miller defeated Republican Johnny Isakson. Democrats recaptured New Mexico, where the Republican incumbent was retiring. The winner, Bruce King, is a former governor. Another former governor, Republican Richard Snelling, won in Vermont. Republican governors winning re-election included Carroll Campbell in South Carolina, Judd Gregg in New Hampshire, Tommy Thompson in Wisconsin, George Mickelson in South Dakota and Terry Branstad in Iowa. Democratic incumbents re-elected included Ned Ray McWherter in Tennessee, William Donald Schaefer in Maryland, Robert P. Caey in Pennsylvania, Bob Miller in Nevada, John Waihee in Hawaii, Cecil Andrus in Idaho, Colorado's Roy Romer, Arkansas' Bill Clinton and Wyoming's Mike Sullivan. Branstad's victory came despite a determined effort by abortion-rights supporters; Andrus won despite stirring the wrath of abortion foes by vetoing a bill that would have restricted legal abortions. Voinovich won over Ohio Democrat Anthony Celebrezze in a race where abortion-rights forces strongly backed the Democrat. Celebrezze was a strong abortion opponent until last December when he switched positions, drawing the enmity of his former allies and earning a flip-flopper's tag that he never overcame. In Minnesota, two-term Gov. Rudy Perpich was locked in a close race despite turmoil and scandal that engulfed his GOP opposition. Republican Arne Carlson got on the ballot only last week after Jon Grunseth stepped aside amid charges of sexual impropriety.
DOC.HEAD: California was: 22nd graf, a0910
BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Republican Rep. Denny Smith, tarnished by links to the savings and loan scandal, was turned out of office Tuesday, falling to Democrat Mike Kopetski in a rematch of their race two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Read Voters' Lips: No New Taxes
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Updates throughout
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Read their votes: no new taxes are likely to escape unpunished at the polls. That was among the voter messages Tuesday night in off-year elections that hit Republicans where it will hurt for a decade, costing them governors just as the states get ready to draw new lines for their congressional districts. Democrats were gaining reinforcements for their House majority - a gain of about 10 seats was in prospect as the ballot count moved westward - but their biggest prize was increased control in the redistricting process that will be a major factor in shaping congressional elections for the rest of the century. Republicans lost in Texas, a state in which their candidate for governor was the early favorite. Democrat Ann Richards, the state treasurer, won instead. In Florida, Lawton Chiles, a former senator, was elected governor over a one-term Republican. The biggest GOP gubernatorial gain: Ohio, where former Cleveland Mayor George Voinovich takes over after eight Democratic years. In competition for the Senate, there was no party turnover in the partial count Tuesday night, and incumbents who ran won, including North Carolina Sen. Jesse Helms, the conservative Republican whose seat had seemed at risk. Democratic control never was in doubt. And House incumbents were, once again, proving their staying power. More than 95 percent of those who sought new terms got them. At midnight, the partial count showed that five House incumbents had lost, with a handful more in jeopardy. But in New Jersey, a Democratic state tax increase put a surprising dent in the campaign of Sen. Bill Bradley, who had to struggle to a narrow win over a Republican challenger who had not looked like a serious threat. It wasn't a good night for the two-term senator who ranks among the 1992 Democratic presidential prospects and was sure enough of his own prospects to do some campaigning for candidates in other states. Bradley apparently was caught in the undertow of resentment over taxes that Gov. James J. Florio pushed through the legislature, after ruling out increases during his 1989 campaign. And a hairline re-election edge is hardly good advertising for a presidential campaign. Numbers were no problem for Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, who ranks atop most lists of 1992 Democratic prospects for the White House. He won towering re-election. So did Sens. Sam Nunn of Georgia, unopposed, and Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, another Democrat who's had presidential ideas, won easy re-election, too. But Clinton returns to office pledged to serve his full four-year term, which may rule him out of 1992 competition. The tax issue dogged President Bush after he scrapped his ``read my lips'' 1988 pledge against new taxes, saying as he campaigned that congressional Democrats made him accept increases as the price of a budget deal. It showed in his slumping polls. Some Republican candidates tried to edge away from the administration late in the campaign. That didn't always succeed. Rep. Peter Smith of Vermont trumpeted his differences with Bush when the president came to campaign for him. Tuesday night, Smith lost to Socialist Bernard Sanders, former mayor of Burlington, who ran narrowly behind him two years ago. Sanders would vote with the Democratic majority in the House. In Rhode Island and Kansas, tax-troubled Republican governors lost. Another Republican governor was locked in a tight struggle in Nebraska. Republican Gov. John McKernan led narrowly in Maine, where he had been deemed a likely loser. Massachusetts Democrats had trounced the establishment in their primary, ousting Democrats linked to outgoing Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who pushed through a massive state tax increase earlier this year. But the voters there spurned a ballot measure that would have rolled back $2.6 billion in state taxes. Democrat John Silber and Republican William Weld were matched in a close count for governor there. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Rep. Robert Kastenmeier, a veteran of 32 years in Congress, was upset Tuesday by Republican Scott L. Klug, a former television news reporter who called Kastenmeier ``torn, worn and outdated.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry Loses Bid for City Council, Jackson Elected Shadow Senator
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with final vote totals, homeless referendum defeated
DOC.TEXT: District of Columbia voters denied scandal-scarred Marion Barry a city council seat Tuesday and replaced him in the mayor's office with Sharon Pratt Dixon, a Democrat who promised to clean house in the troubled capital. Jesse Jackson also won his first elected office, an unpaid, non-voting ``shadow'' Senate seat from which he will attempt to persuade Congress to make the District of Columbia a state. Dixon became the first black woman elected to lead a major American city. She led former police chief Maurice T. Turner, the Republican, 86 percent to 12 percent. Civil rights activist Eleanor Holmes Norton was elected non-voting House delegate, defeating Republican Harry Singleton despite revelations that Norton and her husband, Edward, had paid no local taxes for seven years, beginning in 1983. Norton received 59 percent of the vote, compared to 30 percent for Singleton. Jackson won an 11-candidate ``shadow'' Senate race with 44 percent of the vote. Voters narrowly rejected a referendum that would have restored a comprehensive overnight shelter law that required the city to provide refuge to any homeless person that demands it. The city council gutted the law earlier this year amid complaints that housing the homeless had become too expensive. The measure to restore the original law failed by a margin of 51 percent to 49 percent. But the day belonged to Dixon, who rode her reformist platform into the office Barry has held since 1978. Dixon was swept to victory with her pledge to root out corruption and waste within the city government. Chief among her promises has been to cut 2,000 middle-level managers from the city payroll, a move she has said will save $95 million. Turner hit Dixon for her lack of experience and said her plan to immediately cut the district's work force was inhumane. Barry failed in his bid to win a city-wide council seat, despite his claim to have rebounded from the personal woes that led to his drug conviction and sentencing to a six-month prison term. He is free while appealing. The mayor finished third behind Democratic nominee Linda Cropp, who had 39 percent of the vote, and the incumbent, Statehood party nominee Hilda Mason, who had 30 percent of the vote. Barry had 19 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Akaka, Saiki in Tight Senate Race
DOC.TEXT: Incumbent Democrat Daniel Akaka fended off Republican challenger Patricia Saiki on Tuesday in a down-to-the-wire race for a U.S. Senate seat. Democratic Gov. John Waihee triumphed over Republican challenger Fred Hemmings. In the Senate contest, with 72 percent of precincts reporting, Akaka had 69,947 votes, or 54 percent, to 57,326 votes, or 45 percent, for Saiki. In the governor's race, with 72 precincts reporting, Waihee had 76,489 votes, or 62 percent, to 46,638 votes, or 38 percent, for Hemmings. Two Democrats, former Rep. Neil Abercrombie and interim Rep. Patsy Mink, were favored to win their respective races for the state's two U.S. House seats. Akaka was appointed to the Senate last May after the death of Sen. Spark Matsunaga. Mink won a special election Sept. 22 to fill the remaining months of Akaka's House term. The main issue in the Senate campaign was which candidate would be most effective in Washington. Akaka cited ties to the Democratic majority, while Saiki cited her ties to the Bush administration. Abercrombie, who served a brief stint in the House in 1986 after Rep. Cecil Heftel resigned to run for governor, was opposed in the contest for Saiki's old seat by Republican state Rep. Michael Liu. Mink, who previously served 12 years in the House, was opposed by Republican Andrew Poepoe.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Republican Rep. Chuck Douglas failed in his bid for a second term Tuesday, losing to Democrat Dick Swett, an architect who criticized the conservative incumbent's ``wacko lifestyle,'' a reference to Douglas' three divorces. It marks the first time since 1912 that the state's 2nd District, which reaches into the conservative north, has sent a Democrat to Congress.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sen. Mark Hatfield won a fifth term Tuesday, surviving a surprisingly strong challenge from free-spending Democratic businessman Harry Lonsdale, who campaigned as a political outsider.

DOC.HEAD: Republican Governor Defeats Rancher for Second Term
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. George Mickelson defeated a rancher Tuesday to take his second term, and GOP senator Larry Pressler slid past two contenders for a third term. With 29 percent of precincts reporting, Mickelson had 43,752 votes, or 59 percent, to 29,955, or 41 percent, for Democrat Bob Samuelson. Pressler defeated Democrat Ted Muenster, a Sioux Falls businessman, and independent candidate Dean Sinclair of Sioux Falls. With 29 percent of precincts reporting, he had 39,656 votes, or 53 percent, to 32,889 votes, or 44 percent, for Muenster, and 1,807, or 2 percent, for Sinclair. Democratic Rep. Tim Johnson beat Republican challenger Don Frankenfeld to win a third term as South Dakota's lone member of the U.S. House.

DOC.HEAD: Staten Island Takes First Step Toward Secession
DOC.TEXT: Staten Island took a first step toward seceding from New York City as voters overwhelmingly endorsed a secession referendum on Tuesday's ballot. With 95 percent of the precincts reporting, 82 percent of the voters supported the referendum, while 18 percent were opposed. The vote total was 53,370 for and 11,992 against, with 240 of the borough's 253 precincts reported. The measure's success does not mean an immediate withdrawal from the Big Apple. It simply authorizes a three-year state-funded study on the fiscal and political ramifications of secession.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 23,500.25, down 465.50 points, or 1.94 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Joan Finney, Ann Richards Win; Among the Big Races Involving Women
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material in grafs 5 to 7 to update with Saiki loss in Hawaii, Roberts ahead in Oregon; inserts 1 graf with reaction to Gantt loss, after 14th graf, A Gantt; and subs grafs 18-19 to update, Rep. Pat
DOC.TEXT: Ann Richards won her rough-and-tumble fight for governor of Texas and another Democratic treasurer, Joan Finney, captured the governor's mansion in Kansas as a record number of women and blacks sought state and national posts Tuesday. Connecticut voters elected conservative businessman Gary Franks as the first black Republican member of the House since the Depression. But Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., turned back Harvey Gantt's bid to become the first black senator from the South since Reconstruction. In New Jersey, Republican challenger Christine Todd Whitman gave a scare to Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley before losing. The little known ex-utility commissioner raised a fraction of Bradley's $12 million warchest, but capitalized on antitax fervor. Democrat Barbara Roberts was leading in Oregon's gubernatorial race. But women lost seven of their eight senate races, with only incumbent Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., in the victory column. Women challengers lost to incumbent male senators in New Jersey, Hawaii, Illinois, Rhode Island, Delaware and Wyoming, and Democrat Josie Heath was defeated by Rep. Hank Brown for an open Senate seat in Colorado. But Nebraska Gov. Kay Orr was fighting for her political life in a tight race against Democrat Ben Nelson. Finney, 65, Kansas treasurer for the past 16 years and an abortion opponent, toppled pro-choice Republican Gov. Mike Hayden, whose campaign foundered over taxes. Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill., who staked her campaign on an adamant stand against tax hikes, lost her bid to unseat Illinois Sen. Paul Simon, a Democrat. Another GOP congresswoman, Claudine Schneider, was soundly defeated by Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell in Rhode Island. Richards, 67, defeated Clayton Williams, an oilman and political neophyte whose joke about rape cast a cloud over his campaign. Jane Danowitz, executive director of the Women's Campaign Fund, called it ``an exciting night'' for women candidates. The fund supports pro-choice candidates in both parties. ``Most of (Richards') last-minute strength from women voters came on the abortion issue - or the combination of abortion and sexism on his part,'' Danowit said. South Carolina Gov. Carroll A. Campbell, a Republican, easily turned back a challenge from Democratic State Sen. Theo Mitchell, who had hoped to become the state's first black governor. A Gantt win would have given the Senate its first black member since Edward Brooke, R-Mass., was defeated 12 years ago. Eddie N. Williams, president of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a black political think tank, said, ``We've seen the triumph of racism over reason in North Carolina. ... It's sort of Willie Horton all over again.'' Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic former mayor of San Francisco, was challenging Sen. Pete Wilson for the governorship in California. Overall, there were eight women running for governor - four from each party - and eight women vying for Senate seats, all but two of them Republicans. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., easily won re-election. The Senate's only other incumbent woman, Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., was not up this year. Despite a recent campaign foray to Hawaii by President Bush, Republican Rep. Pat Saiki failed in her bid to unseat Sen. Daniel Akaka, the Democrat appointed to the Senate after Sen. Spark Matsunaga died earlier this year. Williams' center predicted the 24-member Congressional Black Caucus would gain one to three members. New Orleans was electing a black Democrat to succeed retiring Rep. Lindy Boggs in an open runoff pitting attorney Marc Morial against state Sen. William Jefferson. Franks, a Yale-educated businessman and alderman in Waterbury, Conn., won an open seat race against former Democratic Rep. Toby Moffett. The last black Republican to serve in the House was Oscar de Priest from Illinois in 1935. Liberal Democratic activist Rosa De Lauro won another open House seat in New Haven, Conn. The nation's two other incumbent women governors, Madeline Kunin in Vermont and Rose Mofford in Arizona, chose not to run for re-election. Women were vying for 66 House seats and eight Senate seats. In two House races, both candidates were women. There are currently 29 women in the House and two in the Senate. The House has 24 blacks, 13 Hispanics and one American Indian.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Tax Increase Fails in Marlboro Country
DOC.TEXT: Montana voters refused Tuesday to adopt the highest cigarette tax in the country, a measure both sides agreed was aimed at reducing tobacco use. With 54 percent of precincts reporting, the initiative was failing 59 percent to 41 percent. The measure would have imposed a tax of 43 cents per pack on cigarettes, up from 18 cents, and doubled the tax on other tobacco products. The tobacco industry spent more than $1.1 million to defeat the measure, saying the tax revenue would be used only to hire more bureaucrats.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Voters Approve Eliminating Welfare Programs
DOC.TEXT: Oregon voters approved a measure Tuesday to shut off welfare payments to the poor and offer low-paying jobs instead. Incomplete, unofficial returns showed 57 percent of voters favoring it. The measure would establish a three-year pilot program in six counties that eliminates food stamps, federal aid to families with dependent children and unemployment benefits. However, the proposal cannot go into effect unless Congress waives a number of federal laws and regulations. Under the plan, people who are eligible for public assistance would be assigned to jobs with public or private employers and would be paid at 90 percent of the state's minimum wage, currently $4.25 an hour. Opponents said the measure offered little more than slavery.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Republican William Weld edged Democrat John Silber on Tuesday in a battle of political newcomers for the Massachusetts governorship. Both men had promised to rebuild the state from the ashes of what only two years ago Gov. Michael S. Dukakis ballyhooed as a miracle economy.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Elects First Black Congressman Since Reconstruction
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana on Tuesday elected its first black congressman since Reconstruction. State Sen. William Jefferson defeated Marc Morial, the son of the late New Orleans Mayor Dutch Morial. Both Jefferson, 43, and Morial, 32, are black Democrats. Jefferson will succeed Democratic Rep. Lindy Boggs, who is retiring after 17 years in the House. With all precincts reporting, Jefferson had 55,371 votes, or 52 percent, to Morial's 50,197 votes, or 48 percent. The election had no effect on the makeup of the state's congressional delegation - four Democrats and four Republicans. It was the only congressional race left unresolved in Louisiana. All the incumbent representatives won re-election in the Oct. 6 primary. Sen. Bennett Johnston, D-La., also won re-election in the primary, turning aside a widely publicized challenge by former Ku Klux Klan grand dragon David Duke.

DOC.HEAD: St. Louis County Residents Vote Against Dioxin Incinerator
DOC.TEXT: The government's plan to build a dioxin incinerator at Times Beach was dealt at least a minor setback by St. Louis County residents voting on an advisory referendum Tuesday. The vote, with 60 percent of the ballots counted, was 95,845 against building the incinerator and 81,708 in favor. Opponents of the incinerator, who sponsored the non-binding referendum, hoped that a resounding `no' vote would convince state leaders, particularly Gov. John Ashcroft, to stop the project. The incinerator would burn dioxin-tainted soil from Times Beach and 27 other eastern Missouri sites. Opponents say it would be unsafe in a heavily populated area such as St. Louis County and that it should not be built in a flood plain.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hatfield, Weld win; Kastenmeier loses; fresh reaction.
DOC.TEXT:
Democrats wrested governorships from the GOP in Texas, Florida and four other states on Tuesday in midterm elections that sealed a season of Republican disappointment. Democrats also expanded their dominion of Congress in returns that heavily favored the incumbents. North Carolina GOP Sen. Jesse Helms won re-election in the most closely watched Senate race of 34 on the ballot. Democrats elected Ann Richards as governor of Texas and Lawton Chiles in Florida, giving them the last word in redistricting that will add House seats to both Sunbelt states for the next decade. ``I'm sorry I let you down,'' Williams said in his concession speech. President Bush had spent the final weekend of the campaign in Texas and Williams defeat just punctuated a painful autumn for Bush. Republicans looked to Pete Wilson to hold the California governship in his race against Dianne Feinstein, and he was leading. If voters were trying to express any discontent, it certainly did not affect the Senate, where 30 out of 31 incumbents were being reelected. The lone endangered senator was Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota; a victory by Paul Wellstone would pad the Democrats' current 55-45 majority. Upsets were few and far between, but Wisconsin's Democratic Rep. Robert Kastenmeier fell after 15 liberal terms in the House. House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich was in a shocker, barely winning a 50-50 Georgia race. Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley survived a surprise close call, winning re-election with 52 percent of the vote against a little-known opponent who campaigned against tax increases engineered by a Democratic governor. Mark Hatfield won a 5th term as Republican senator from Oregon in a close race. Democrats renewed control over the House and aimed to improve their 259-176 majority, although the modest additions were not much to brag about. The GOP got good news in Ohio, where George Voinovich won a Democratic governorship, and in Massachusetts, where William Weld will succeed Michael Dukakis. Republicans were ahead in races to retain the statehouse in Illinois and Maine. In Connecticut, Gary Franks became the first black House Republican since 1935. Sen. Lowell Weicker vexed the GOP again, this time as an outsider, with an independent victory for governor of Connecticut. Republican Gov. Kay Orr was trailing, barely, in Nebraska. Vermont sent Socialist Bernie Sanders to the House - in place of a Republican. But former GOP Gov. Richard Snelling won his old job back, and with it, the statehouse for his party. The polls were still open in half the nation when the Democrats proclaimed victory and pointed the voters toward the 1992 presidential race. ``I couldn't feel better,'' said Ron Brown, chairman of the Democratic National Committee. ``Both Republicans and Democrats ran against George Bush.'' Charles Black spoke for the Republican National Committee, telling reporters, ``It appears to be more of an anti-incumbent trend than a partisan trend.'' He called the midterm results ``an anti-Congress trend rather than an anti-president trend,'' even though incumbent members were being reelected at a substantial rate. Well after midnight, there was no shortage of close statehouse races: - John Engler was battling Democratic Gov. James Blanchard in Michigan. - GOP Gov. John McKernan clung to a lead over former Gov. Joseph Brennan in Maine. - Illinois GOP Secretary of State Jim Edgar led Neil Hartigan. - Democrat Rudy Perpich trailed Arne Carlson in a tough Minnesota race marked by Republican turmoil. Carlson was on the ballot only because Jon Grunseth dropped out in late October over allegations of sexual improprieties. Helms bested Harvey Gantt in his marquee race for reelection in a contest that pitted one of the nation's best known conservatives against a former black mayor. ``I'm sorry I'm so late,'' he told supporters, ``but I've been home watching the grieving face of Dan Rather ... the liberal politicians and editors and commentators and columnists have struck out again.'' Appointed Democratic Sen. Dan Akaka won re-election in Hawaii, dashing the Republicans only serious hope for a Senate takeover. Three GOP representatives were elected to open Republican senate seats: Bob Smith in New Hampshire, Hank Brown in Colorado and Larry Craig in Idaho. Alabama GOP Gov. Guy Hunt won a close race for re-election. More than 6,100 legislative races crowded the ballots, and voters in 43 states and the District of Columbia decided ballot issues. Massachusetts rejected a proposed tax rollback. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo won in a possible prelude to a 1992 Democratic presidential campaign. Besides Bill Bradley, two other potential challengers to President Bush won easy Senate reelection - Al Gore in Tennessee, Sam Nunn in Georgia. Bush voted in his home state of Texas after an energetic yet awkward campaign for GOP candidates, then returned to the White House to read the returns. Bush sparked a Republican rebellion when he broke his memorable 1988 campaign pledge and embraced an October deficit-reduction plan that raised tax rates. ``George Bush obviously has had a little setback on the polls but he's still the most popular president going into midterm elections in modern times,'' said Ed Rollins, the top political adviser to House Republicans. All in all, the first election of the 1990s came at a time of extraordinary volatility - with the nation on the verge of recession and on the edge of war in the Persian Gulf. Other issues emerged in scattered races - abortion, crime, the savings and loan crisis and ethics scandals among them. The pollsters agreed the voters were unhappy with the government and pessimistic about the economy, but that failed to translate into widespread anti-incumbency. In Florida, Chiles won handily over first-term Republican Gov. Bob Martinez. Democrat David Walters grabbed the open Republican governorship in Oklahoma. Bruce Sundlun wrested the governorship from Republicans in hard-times Rhode Island, ousting Edward DiPrete. Former Gov. Bruce King's successful comeback returned New Mexico to the Democratic column, and Joan Finney ousted GOP Gov. Mike Hayden in Kansas.
A Democratic: picks up 1st add a0506

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Republican Jim Edgar outlasted Democrat Neil Hartigan on in a hard-fought contest for Illinois governor Tuesday, maintaining the GOP's control over the statehouse.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Post Impressive Gains In Redistricting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6 and 9 to show GOP winning governor's races in Vermont and Illinois, bgng.: The Ohio
DOC.TEXT: Democrats on Tuesday padded their overwhelming control of political redistricting, plucking the potent Florida and Texas governorships from GOP hands and adding Rhode Island, Oklahoma and New Mexico to their remapping monopolies. The Florida and Texas defeats were disastrous for Republicans, and Democrats were in the running for the only remaining major GOP redistricting weapon - the California governorship. Democrats clearly will have a huge edge when lines are drawn for 1992 congressional races, all but cementing the Republicans as the House minority for another decade and perhaps far longer. And Democrats were calling the Texas and Florida victories a boost for their 1992 presidential hopes. ``We feel better about the prospects of fair districts when the pen is in Democratic hands,'' said Democratic National Committee political director Paul Tully. ``These are not only net victories but victories in places that because of their population growth will grow more important to the future of this country and also to the presidential race.'' In all, eight states will gain and 13 will lose seats when House districts are reapportioned to reflect population shifts of the 1980s, according to preliminary census data. Democrats will control the process outright in at least five of the states gaining House seats. The Ohio governorship was the only significant redistricting victory for Republicans as results from gubernatorial and legislative races trickled in. So frustrating was the GOP's night that the only redistricting monopoly the GOP gained was in Vermont - which has only one House seat anyway. Despite the millions spent on oft-ignored state races with the post-Census redistricting in mind, it appeared but a few of the dozen targeted chambers would change hands. The GOP turned back Democratic efforts to take over the New York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Senates. Redistricting power in all three states, which will lose House seats in 1992, will be shared. Republicans failed in their bid to wrest the Illinois Senate from Democrats but won a close governor's race to keep a say in redistricting there. The GOP was trailing in bids to win over the Democratic Florida Senate and Pennsylvania House. Early returns showed control of the Oregon House within reach. The Indiana House was likely to go from GOP hands to the Democrats. Other Democratic targets were the state senates in Indiana, Michigan and Washington and both chambers in Arizona. The GOP suffered a big loss when Democrat Lawton Chiles unseated Florida's Republican governor, and things would only get worse. The Rhode Island, Oklahoma and New Mexico governor's offices went from Republican to Democratic hands and then Texas was seized by the Democrats too. Democrats now will have sole power over the remapping in those states. Florida is likely to gain four House seats and Texas three. The House delegations in Rhode Island, Oklahoma and New Mexico won't change, but control of redistricting should allow Democrats to draw districts that protect their House incumbents and perhaps endanger GOP lawmakers. Another victory for Democrats came in Kansas, where by unseating a Republican governor the party went from being shut out of the process to having veto power in redistricting. Kansas will lose one House seat. The Republicans' last hope was California, which will get seven of the 19 shifting seats. But even with a win in the governor's race there the GOP would only share the power with the Democratic legislature. Democrats, with huge majorities in many legislative chambers, were virtually assured a redistricting voice in all the battleground states even before the polls opened Tuesday. The day began with Democrats controlling 69 of the nation's 99 legislative chambers and 29 of the 50 governorships. More than 6,100 legislative races were decided across the country, but the focus of national party organizations was about 50 races in 10 states in which chambers are held by narrow majorities. Even with California undecided, the Democrats were in position to draw districts that in 1992 likely would pad their majority in the House, now at 258-175, by a dozen seats or more beyond whatever gains they made in Tuesday's elections. Preliminary census data suggest the remaining five House seats that shift will go to Virginia, North Carolina, Georgia, Washington and Arizona. Among those states, redistricting control was a serious question only in Arizona. Democrats already had a redistricting monopoly in Virginia and kept hold of their sole control in North Carolina and Georgia. A nonpartisan commission draws the map in Washington. Democrats were facing uphill odds in their effort to erase the Arizona GOP's 17-13 Senate and 34-26 House majorities. But Democrat Terry Goddard was leading in early returns in the governor's race . If elected, he could veto any redistricting plan drawn by a possibly Republican legislature. Among the 13 states losing seats, New York will suffer the most - giving up three. Gov. Mario Cuomo was headed to easy re-election and the New York Assembly had a 92-58 Democratic majority entering Tuesday's voting. Results were slow to come in, but Democrats conceded they would not capture the Senate, where they had hoped to wipe out a five-seat Republican majority and gain a redistricting monopoly. Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan and Illinois are to lose two seats each. Losing one will be Massachusetts, New Jersey, West Virginia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Iowa, Kansas and Montana. Democrats control the process in New Jersey, West Virginia, Kentucky and Louisiana. In Massachusetts, Iowa, Kansas and Montana the power will be shared.

DOC.HEAD: California ``Big Green'' Losing; Tax Revolt Set Back in Massachusetts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES and RECASTS throughout; no pickup ^By LEE MITGANG
DOC.TEXT: The environmental movement suffered major setbacks Tuesday in California, Oregon and Missouri, while taxing and spending limits in Massachusetts and a half dozen other states also fared poorly at the polls. Voters backed liberal abortion laws in Oregon and Nevada. But residents in California, Colorado and Kansas City vented their anger at incumbents by approving limits on the number of terms politicians can serve. California Proposition 128, known as ``Big Green,'' was trailing badly: with 11 percent of the vote in, 71 percent were against it. The measure, one of 28 on California's heavily-loaded ballot, would phase out many pesticides, ban oil development in state waters, ban chemicals that harm the ozone layer, and require a dramatic reduction in emissions of gases that contribute to global warming. A proposed $1.97 billion environmental bond in New York was trailing by a 51-49 percent margin with 97 percent of the vote in. In Oregon, voters turned down tough recycling regulations and rejected a proposed shutdown of the state's only nuclear plant. Missourians defeated a ``Natural Streams'' measure protecting scenic waterways in the Ozark Mountains by a 75-25 percent margin, with 99 percent of the vote in. And Washington state residents were soundly rejecting, by a 74-26 percent margin, an initiative that would have required the state to set up boards mandating local land use planning. Early returns showed a South Dakota measure that proposed limits on Black Hills mining was trailing narrowly, but a second one imposing limits on garbage dumping was ahead. Among the anti-taxing, anti-spending measures on a half dozen state ballots, Massachusetts voters defeated Question 3, which would have reduced taxes by $2.6 billion in fiscal 1992. It would have been the nation's largest voter-initiated state tax cut in history. In Montana, voters rejected a novel proposal that would have replaced all state sales, income and property taxes with a one percent charge on all financial transactions. Montanans also voted against a proposition boosting their cigarette tax to the highest levels in the nation. Nebraskans trounced a proposed two percent lid on state and local spending by a 69-31 percent margin. And in Utah, voters turned down a measure that would have eliminated the sales tax on most food. Tough anti-taxing, anti-spending limits appeared on other state ballots including Colorado, California, and Oregon. In another key contest considered crucial by the nation's education community, Oregonians rejected a sweeping ``choice'' initiative that would have allowed parents up to a $2,500 tax credit to educate their children in any public or private school they wish, including parochial schools, or even at home. The measure lost by a 69-31 percent margin with 20 percent of the vote counted. Among the 236 ballot measures voters confronted in 43 states confronted on Election Day: - Oregon voters turned aside by a 2-1 margin a measure that would have banned most abortions except to save the life of the mother. They also rejected a second measure requiring parental consent for abortions on minors. And with 41 percent of the vote counted, Nevada residents were favoring by a 61-39 percent margin a measure protecting that state's liberal law from legislative tampering. - Oregon voters also decided to make it illegal not to buckle up in their cars. - With 42 percent of precincts counted, 84 percent of Florida voters favored a constitutional amendment requiring a three-day wait on hangun purchases. - A Colorado proposal limiting terms of politicians, including U.S. senators and congressmen, won easily. With 48 percent of precincts reporting, 70 percent voted in favor, 30 percent against. In California, a conservative-backed measure limiting terms on state politicians led by a wide margin in early returns. A rival measure that also included ethics reform and public campaign financing appeared headed for defeat. With 99 percent of the vote in, Kansas City, Mo., residents passed a limit on the number of terms city council members can serve. - On Staten Island, voters overwhelmingly approved a referendum to start a process that could lead to secession for the smallest of New York City's five boroughs. - InKansas, residents defeated a proposed amendment that would shift much of the authority over schools from existing state education boards to the legislature. - Washington, D.C., voters were rejecting by a 54-46 percent margin a referendum restoring the right of homeless to overnight shelter, a right eroded by the city council earlier this year. - In Maine, a ballot measure abolishing the state's tough blue laws, which force most big retailers to close on Sundays was narrowly leading with 27 percent of precincts counted. Voters in predominantly black Boston neighborhoods decided whether to launch studies on possible secessions from their respective cities. On the education front, Nebraskans considered repealing a school tax reform package featuring higher sales and income taxes in order to ease reliance on property taxes. Arizona Proposition 103, the Classroom Improvement Initiative, was losing by a 65-35 percent margin with 15 percent of the vote in. It would require the legislature to increase public school spending by $100 per pupil in each of the next 10 years. The pricetag has been estimated at up to $6 billion. A second Arizona measure making Martin Luther King's birthday a state holiday held a slight, 51-49 percent lead with 16 percent of the vote counted. At stake on Alaska's ballot was the nation's most liberal marijuana law. A proposal would recriminalize private possession of pot. Among other notable local contests, a proposal in Santa Clara County, Calif., to finance a new stadium to lure the San Francisco Giants was trailing badly in early returns. Sacramento voters were deciding on a city-county merger that would make it the nation's seventh largest city. In Seattle, voters considered a measure repealing spousal benefits for live-in companions of municipal employees. San Franciscans considered a less sweeping ``domestic partners'' measure which would allow non-married live-in couples, including homosexuals, to register their relationships with city officials but without conferring formal benefits.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Californians Reject `Big Green'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES Grafs 1-2 with returns showing `Big Green' defeated; picks up 3rd graf pvs, ``Calling it...''
DOC.TEXT: Californians overwhelmingly rejected the sweeping ``Big Green'' initiative Tuesday, an environmentalist's dream list of strict controls on emissions, pesticides, offshore drilling and logging. With 23 percent of precincts reporting, Proposition 128 was losing by a 2-1 margin. Surveys of voters exiting polling places indicated the measure would lose decisively. Calling it the most comprehensive environmental initiative ever proposed, conservation groups spent $4.5 million campaigning for Proposition 128 as a national model for environmental protections. A long list of Hollywood celebrities lent support, including Jack Lemmon, Gregory Peck, Robert De Niro, Kirk Douglas, Harrison Ford, Robert Redford, Meryl Streep, and Barbra Streisand. Industry foes, who spent $10 million to defeat the measure, argued it would cost several billion dollars annually in higher gas, electricity and food prices. Supporters said it would save several billion dollars a year in energy and health costs. Opponents also disparagingly dubbed it the ``Hayden Initiative'' after supporter Tom Hayden, a state assemblyman whose name still stirs strong emotions as a symbol of '60s protests. ``Big Green'' called for $300 million in bond funds to buy and preserve ancient redwood forests, try to slow global warming by curbing auto and other emissions, limit oil development in state waters, and bar pesticides suspected of causing cancer. It also set up an elective post of environmental czar. Supporters said the measure was a patchwork of legislation rejected by lawmakers under pressure from special interests. Some of the lanuage, particularly sections dealing with pollution from refrigeration systems, is nearly identical to the Clean Air Act passed by Congress last week.

DOC.HEAD: `Cheers' Ratings Make NBC Smile Again
With PM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: ``Cheers'' last week was the most-watched show on television for the fifth time this season, while The Cos beat little Bart again. ``Cheers,'' the barroom comedy that marks its 200th episode o Thursday, averaged a 22.4 rating, helping NBC win the week with an average prime-time rating of 13.5, the A.C.
