Nielsen Co. reported Tuesday. CBS, whose ``60 Minutes'' and ``Murder She Wrote'' each had its highest ratings of the season, was second with a 12.6. ABC had an 11.9. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. NBC rolled out a special hour version of ``The Cosby Show'' go up against Fox Broadcasting's ``The Simpsons'' on Thursday, and Bill Cosby won easily against Bart Simpson and his cartoon family. ``Cosby'' received an 18.6 to a 15.8 for the Fox show when the two competed for 30 minutes, and drew a 20.2 rating for the full hour. In the news ratings, ABC and Peter Jennings won for the 43rd consecutive week. It averaged an 11.4. CBS and Dan Rather had a 10.0, NBC and Tom Brokaw a 9.5. The week's top 10 list was dominated by old reliables, save for the hit movie ``Three Men and a Baby'' on NBC and ABC's new ``America's Funniest People.'' They were fourth and 10th, respectively, with a 19.9 and an 18.0. After ``Cheers,'' the other top-rated shows, their network and their ratings were ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 21.4; ``Cosby,'' NBC, 20.2; ``Designing Women'' on CBS and ``Roseanne'' on ABC, tied at 19.1; ``Murder She Wrote'' and ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' tied at 18.8, and CBS' ``Murphy Brown,'' 18.7.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: David Letterman, whose house has been broken into six times by a fan, called police when he found a pair of autograph seekers waiting in his driveway. No charges were filed in the incident, which occurred about 2 a.m. Saturday, authorities said. Police said they didn't know if the fans got the talk show host's autograph. Margaret Ray of Crawford, Colo., was sentenced to a year in prison after breaking into Letterman's home for a sixth time in March. She told authorities at one point that she was Letterman's wife. --- EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill. (AP) - Phil Donahue heads to this once-prosperous Mississippi River town to ask, ``Can Anything Be Done to Save This Dying City?'' The ``Donahue'' show will be taped Monday at a high school here. The New York-based syndicated program will look at the transformation from a national rail and stockyard center to ``a desolate and dying city,'' said spokeswoman Alyssa Schwartz. ``Thousands of jobs have gone with the closing of factories, leaving the city a pocket of hopeless poverty, trash-strewn vacant lots, block after block of boarded-up houses, and crime and drugs running rampant,'' Schwartz said. No date has been selected for the segment to air nationally. --- ASHLAND, Ky. (AP) - Naomi and Wynonna Judd will return to their hometown for the renaming of the 16th Street Plaza in their honor. The mother-daughter singers, recipients of the Country Music Association's Duo of the Year award for seven straight years, will be honored Nov. 20. The plaza will be renamed Judd Plaza. The pair, whose hits include ``Mama, He's Crazy'' and ``Grandpa,'' also will serve that day as grand marshals of a Christmas Parade. Naomi Judd has announced plans to retire after their latest concert tour because of hepatitis. Her daughter will continue a solo career. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Grand Ole Opry humorist Jerry Clower will be grand marshal of the 38th annual Christmas Parade here on Dec. 2. ``I think parades are wonderful,'' he said. ``They bring a town together and give folks a chance to laugh, smile and enjoy themselves immensely.'' Clower has recorded 20 albums during a 20-year performing career and has also written three books. --- BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. (AP) - Filmmaker Oliver Stone, author Norman Cousins and actor Dennis Weaver received the Inside Edge Humanitarian Awards for helping ``stretch their concept of what's possible.'' The awards were given Tuesday by the Inside Edge Foundation, a group of 500 Southern California leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Band Together, Sometimes Forming Separate Society
LaserPhoto BX5
DOC.TEXT: Andrew J. Willett knew just what his constituency would be doing on Election Day. Willett is ``mayor'' of the Grate Society, as he and 15 to 20 fellow homeless people call themselves in a grim parody of the social welfare experiment of the 1960s that aimed to wipe out hunger and poverty. On Election Day, as on most other days, Willett and others hang out near the Boston Public Library. In the morning they wash up at a transit stop, then panhandle long enough to get money for food, cigarettes and alcohol. They sleep on grates to stay warm, avoiding shelters as too dangerous or too rigid. ``I would rather stay outside,'' said Willett, who also acts as the group's ``banker,'' keeping track of the money earned by panhandling, or ``stemming, until there is enough for ``a run'' - usually to the liquor store. Two years after President Bush called for a kinder, gentler nation, the homeless are as much a part of the urban landscape as graffiti and traffic. They are also among society's most vulnerable citizens and could be among the most affected by efforts in Massachusetts to get the budget under control. Willett, a 39-year-old Vietnam veteran with a heavy limp, a useless left hand and a fondness for ginger brandy, said most of the day is spent stemming. In the language of the street, pennies are ``goobers'' and ``dumpster-diving'' is searching for food in the garbage. Nights are the most difficult because of the danger of being robbed. Members of the Grate Society sleep in shifts. ``Just like society at large, some homeless prey on each other,'' said police Sgt. John Devaney. ``They steal their liquor, their money.'' On the streets, loyalty is paramount, Willett said. When Michael S. Hathaway, 20, began living on the streets three years ago, Willett took him under his wing. ``If it wasn't for Andrew Willett, I would be deceased today,'' Hathaway said. ``I'd do anything for Andy. We're like a family.'' Hathaway said Willett, who has been on the streets about two decades and is known to the Grate Society as its mayor, found him walking around Copley Square and showed him where to sleep and get free clothes and free food. ``I know so much about the streets now that I could teach someone else,'' he said. Hathaway said he repays Willett by watching out for him. No one knows how many street people are in Boston. The Emergency Shelter Commission counted 3,830 in shelters and on the streets in December 1989. Paul Koegel, an anthropologist working for the psychiatry department at the University of California at Los Angeles, found that 28 percent of the nation's homeless suffered from severe, chronic mental disorders and 46 percent were chronic substance abusers. Both conditions are likely to be worsened by homelessness, he found. ``A very significant minority experienced their alcohol problems after their first episode of homelessness,'' said Koegel. Rob Smith, 27, may be one of that minority. He sits near the Grate Society along with Lisa Fuller, 37, and Reggie Hammond, 31. Every day at 8 a.m., they meet outside a liquor store near Boston Common. ``I wasn't drinking before. Now I'm drinking like crazy,'' said Smith, who was evicted from his apartment over the summer. ``You got to drink to survive,'' said Hammond. ``You drink all day and sleep all night. You've heard of false courage. Drinking gives you false courage so you don't worry.'' Hammond's brother saw Smith through his first night of homelessness. ``It was scary. I didn't know what to expect,'' Smith said. But now he's a pro. Recently he reasoned that Logan International Airport would be a good place to sleep because air travelers need comfortable seats. So he went there one day after a restless night and slept four blissful hours. Smith said he has had no luck getting a job, in part because he has no phone. ``Where they gonna call you at?''

DOC.HEAD: University Offers $1 Million Settlement to Former President
DOC.TEXT: American University is offering a settlement of more than $1 million to former president Richard Berendzen, who pleaded guilty to charges he made obscene telephone calls, according to a published report. The Washington Post, quoting unnamed sources, reported today that in return, the university's board of trustees would ask Berendzen to sever his ties with the university. Since resigning as president, Berendzen has continued to draw a salary as a tenured physics professor, although he has not worked on campus. According to the newspaper's sources, university trustees authorized the proposed settlement, which is not final, during a closed meeting Friday. Sources said the decision followed an acrimonious debate in which several trustees argued that the payment was too expensive while others said Berendzen should not be forced to relinquish his university affiliation. Berendzen quit as university president in April, saying he was exhausted after 10 years in the job. Later that month, he acknowledged that he actually had resigned because trustees learned he was under police investigation for allegedly placing obscene telephone calls to a woman who ran a day-care service. Susan Allen of Fairfax County, Va., said that in repeated phone calls to her, he graphically discussed fantasized sexual relations with children. Berendzen pleaded guilty to two charges of making the telephone calls. Alen has sued him, seeking $2 million in compensatory damages and $2 million in punitive damages. Lawyers for the university and for Berendzen were negotiating how the payments would be made, the Post said. The paper quoted one source as saying the proposed payment ``was in the ballpark'' of $1 million, and another said the figure exceeded $1 million. Berendzen declined comment to the newspaper, saying, ``I really just don't want to get into anything dealing with contracts.'' University spokeswoman Anita Gottlieb told the Post, ``after January, there will be no continuing relationship with Dr. Berendzen and the university.''

DOC.HEAD: Airborne Lights Up Practice Range With Missiles, Machine Guns
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pvt. Alonzo Range made his first shot with a Dragon wire-guided, anti-tank missile a good one. He obliterated a practice target from 500 yards away. Fellow troopers of the 82nd Airborne Division whooped and cheered when the missile found its target Tuesday and exploded in a ball of flame and thunder. ``Beautiful! Airborne!'' the soldiers yelled. The Dragon is shoulder-fired, but the gunner must keep the target in its sight to guide it on its path. The naked eye can follow the missile as it dips and weaves down range. ``It's effective against any armor, including the T-72,'' said Range, 21, of New York City. He was referring to the top-of-the-line Soviet model tank that the Iraqis have in their arsenal. ``I'm fairly confident we can take them out,'' Range said. He was jubilant about his success. ``It was better than sex - almost,'' Range quipped. Elements of the 1st Battalion, 505th Paratroop Regiment took to the firing range for drills with machine guns, rifles, shotguns, grenades, anti-tank rockets and trench warfare. ``We given them challenging training to give them a focus,'' said battalion commander Lt. Col. John Schmader. ``We're training for our worldwide contingency mission.'' A major concern is that troops may get careless by sitting around. So far, 43 military people have died in accidental deaths during Operation Desert Shield. During a practice run on taking an Iraqi-style trench, Lt. Dean Shultis of Billings, Mont., offered a six-pack of non-alcoholic beer to the first machine- gun crew to wipe out a bunker. The winners opted for Pepsi instead of near beer, the closest thing to beer in alcohol-free Saudi Arabia. ``It's like kissing your sister,'' said Sgt. Ben Perkins, 23, of Greeley, Colo. When asked about his company's state of preparedness, Perkins said, ``We're ready to do what we got to do.'' Troops of the 82nd said they have kept their sharpness three months after Desert Shield's first ground force arrived. ``The only way you lose your edge is if you sit on your butt and don't train,'' said Sgt. Maj. J. R. Kendall of Bravo Company. ``We keep from getting bored by training hard,'' said Kendall, carrying a shotgun during a trench warfare exercise. ``If the decision is made to go offensive, these paratroopers are ready.'' Elements of the 82nd Airborne were the first American ground forces to arrive in Saudi Arabia after President Bush drew ``a line in the sand'' on Aug. 7, five days after Iraq's lightning conquest of Kuwait. About 220,000 troops are now in the region and more may be sent.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Events in Rabbi Meir Kahane's Life
With PM-Kahane Assassination, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of major events in the life of Rabbi Meir Kahane, who was assassinated in New York: Aug. 1, 1932: Martin David Kahane is born in Brooklyn, the son of a Zionist rabbi who emigrated from Palestine and his Latvian immigrant wife. 1946: Joins Betar, a militant Zionist youth group. 1947: Packs guns for Betar in Hoboken, N.J., and pelts British Foreign Minister Ernest Bevin with eggs during a demonstration. Kahane is clubbed by police during that demonstration - his first fight with police. 1948: Participates in Zionist demonstrations at United Nations during debates that end in recognition of the state of Israel. 1955: Marries his wife, Libby. Around this time, he begins using his Hebrew name, Meir. 1956: Obtains degree from New York Law School but either doesn't take or doesn't pass the bar exam. 1957: Is ordained an Orthodox rabbi after studying at a yeshiva in Brooklyn. 1963: Makes first trip to Israel, serves for three months as a rabbi on a kibbutz. Soon after his return, he begins writing column for the Brooklyn-based Jewish Press under the byline Michael King. Mid-1960s: Under the King pseudonym, works for various U.S. government agencies as a researcher and consultant. He works to marshal support for the Vietnam War, believing widespread Jewish opposition to the war jeopardized U.S. aid to Israel. 1966: His alleged mistress, a Christian named Gloria Jean D'Argenio, jumps to her death from a New York City bridge in despair over the relationship. 1968: Through his Jewish Press column, founds the Jewish Defense League with the slogan ``Never Again.'' The group organizes karate and weapon training classes for members and patrols high-crime neighborhoods to protect Jews. July 1971: Is fined $5,000 in New York on charges of conspiring to manufacture explosives. September 1971: Emigrates to Israel to organize a JDL faction there. 1972: The JDL is linked to the firebombing of the offices of impresario Sol Hurok, in which one person was killed and 13 injured. But the group drops most of its activities after Kahane moves its base to Jerusalem. 1972: Kahane becomes an Israeli citizen, while retaining his American citizenship. 1984: Is elected to Israel's parliament, the Knesset, as head of the Kach (Thus!) Party, which calls for the deportation of all Arabs. 1985: Resigns as head of the JDL, in part because he could not devote enough time to it. 1985: His American citizenship is revoked on the grounds that he took a seat in a foreign legislature. He appeals to the U.S. courts and wins in 1987. 1988: Renounces his U.S. citizenship to comply with an Israeli law prohibiting Knesset members from being citizens of other nations. But later that year, Israel's highest court rules that his militant anti-Arab Kach Party is racist and therefore ineligible to participate in parliamentary elections. April 1990: Goes on trial in Israel for sedition for calling Arabs a ``cancer spreading in our midsts'' at a rally protesting a bloody 1989 attack on Israelis. The case is dropped on a legal technicality. June 1990: Goes back to court in the United States seeking to win back his U.S. citizenship. The case had been pending. September 1990: Goes on trial in Jerusalem on charges of disturbing public order for leading an anti-Arab rally after the stabbing deaths of two Israelis in 1989. The next hearing had been set for December. Nov. 5, 1990: Is assassinated by a lone gunman during a Zionist conference at a New York City hotel.

DOC.HEAD: Presidential Field Cut to 14 With Disqualification Of Duvalierists
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - The field of presidential candidates stood at 14 today, with a leftist champion of the poor favored, after the Electoral Council barred former President Leslie Manigat and 11 others from running. Among those disqualified from the Dec. 16 elections was Dr. Roger Lafontant, the former chief of the Tonton Macoute militia, the private army of the brutal Duvalier family dictatorship. Lafontant claimed he was wrongfully eliminated and would appeal to the Supreme Court. An outstanding warrant charges Lafontant with conspiring against national security. The army, long the country's leading political force, has never served the warrant. The Tonton Macoutes terrorized this impoverished Caribbean nation of 6 million people for 29 years until a popular uprising forced Jean-Claude Duvalier, son of the late Francois Duvalier, into exile in 1986. But the country has been plagued by political turmoil and violence ever since. The caretaker government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, appointed in March, is the fifth since Duvalier's ouster. Another former Duvalier official disqualified from running for president was Claude Raymond. The former army chief of staff has been publicly accused of participating in the massacre of voters that thwarted 1987 general elections. In the massacre, armed thugs in collusion with troops killed at least 34 people. Twelve Duvalierists had been barred from running for president in that balloting. A new constitution drafted earlier in 1987 barred criminal supporters of past dictators from running for office until 1997. The Electoral Council said the 10 candidates disqualified Monday, including Lafontant and Raymond, failed to comply with filing procedures. It said Manigat, disqualified Tuesday night, was barred under a constitutional article that specifies the ``president may not be re-elected'' unless five years have passed between terms. Manigat, who was widely viewed as a puppet of the military, gained the presidency in a controversial election in January 1988 and was ousted six months later in a coup. The council on Tuesday night also disqualified Duvalierist banker Clemard Joseph Charles, saying he was wanted as a fugitive in the United States but giving no details. The Rev. Jean Bertrand Aristide, a leftist priest, spokesman for the poor and ardent foe of Haiti's dictatorships, is given the best chance of winning the Dec. 16 vote - if it is free and fair. Dr. Louis Roy, chief of the Council of State that rules alongside Ms. Pascal-Trouillot, said Aristide's campaign may lose momentum with Lafontant's disqualification - ``But he remains the leading contender because he enjoys the backing of the impoverished masses.'' Also still in the running are major candidates Marc Bazin, a former World Bank official; former preacher Silvio Claude, and businessman Louis Dejoie Jr. The council's disqualifications this week were welcomed by many leading Haitians. ``I foresee a relatively normal unfolding of the electoral process now,'' said Jean-Claude Bajeux, a human rights activist and leader of the Congress of Democratic Movements, a socialist party. About 800 observers from the United Nations and the Organization of American States will monitor the vote.

DOC.HEAD: Biden Keeps Senate Seat
DOC.TEXT: Voters gave Democrat Joseph R. Biden Jr. a fourth term in the U.S. Senate and he gave them his gratitude for ignoring his opponent, a poliical novice and former prosecutor who campaigned on Biden's mistakes. In balloting Tuesday, with 99 percent of precincts reporting, Biden had 111,191 votes, or 62.5 percent, to Republican M. Jane Brady's 63,962 votes, or 36 percent. Biden thanked voters for ``their willingness to look not only beyond the negatives, but to examine the distortions and to make some fundamental judgments about me.'' Biden, 47, dropped his bid for the 1988 nomination for president after it was revealed he paraphrased part of a speech by British Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock, was accused of improper footnoting and asked to repeat a course in law school, and exaggerated his academic record. Democrat U.S. Rep. Thomas R. Carper was also re-elected, to a fifth term.

DOC.HEAD: Lowell Weicker: From Watergate To Connecticut Governor
DOC.TEXT: Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a former Republican senator known as a maverick, maintained that reputation with his successful bid for governor as an independent. ``We didn't ask or bequeath any particular party to run our business for us,'' Weicker said after his victory. ``We can run it better than anybody else can.'' Weicker lost his Senate seat in 1988 when he sought a fourth term. He said at the time that there would be ``no comebacks.'' After that defeat, the 59-year-old Greenwich millionaire, whose grandfather helped found the E.R. Squibb pharmaceutical corporation, worked for a foundation promoting medical research. Then, eight months before Election Day, Weicker announced he would return to politics as an independent candidate for governor. From the beginning, Weicker led Republican John G. Rowland and Democrat Bruce A. Morrison in public opinion polls, despite the fact that Connecticut had elected nothing but Republican and Democratic governors since 1856. ``Aside from the fact that we're going to put the state back on its feet, I hope we send a message that dirt is out of politics in the state of Connecticut,'' Weicker said, referring to the often-bitter campaign. Weicker's independent attitude was best demonstrated in 1973-74, when as a member of the Senate Watergate Committee he was one of President Nixon's most outspoken critics. He battled his party at home, too, but was elected and re-elected, enjoying strong support from Democrats and unaffiliated voters in a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans by a margin of about 3-to-2. During his 20 years in Washington - 18 in the Senate and two in the House - Weicker was an advocate for the rights of children, the handicapped, AIDS patients and the politically oppressed. He was arrested outside the South African embassy in Washington during an anti-apartheid protest. He faced a serious intraparty challenge for his Senate nomination in 1982 from Prescott S. Bush Jr., brother of President Bush. Bush eventually dropped his challenge and Weicker was narrowly re-elected. Six years later, Weicker was upset by then-Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman, a Democrat, who won by 10,000 votes - a margin of less than 1 percent - after a bitter campaign. Before being elected to Washington, Weicker served a term as Greenwich first selectman and two terms in the state House of Representatives. He made a brief bid for the 1980 Republican presidential nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Florida's Lawton' Chiles, Burned Out Two Years Ago, Is Back in Spotlight
DOC.TEXT: Two years ago, Lawton Chiles complained of ``burnout'' - later diagnosed as depression - when he retired after three terms in the U.S. Senate and 30 years in government. On Tuesday, the veteran Democrat roared back into political life, riding a populist campaign to the governorship of the nation's fourth-largest state and easily defeating one-term incumbent Republican Bob Martinez. Chiles, 60, who once expressed his frustrations at the inability of politicians to get things done, invoked the optimistic political spirit of the early 1960s in his acceptance speech. ``Camelot is a state of mind and if you have it and I have it, we can start bringing Camelot back,'' he told cheering supporters in Orlando, referring to the nickname admirers gave President Kennedy's administration. For the self-described ``cracker'' from mostly rural Polk County, the victory was the result of a return to the down-home political style that first sent him to the Senate in 1970. He earned the nickname ``Walkin' Lawton'' when he walked the length of Florida during that first Senate campaign. His comeback bid against Martinez, only the state's second Republican governor since Reconstruction, was equally unorthodox. Chiles voluntarily limited individual contributions to $100 each, allowing Martinez's campaign to outspend him by more than 2-1. Limiting contributions, he said, would mean he wouldn't be beholden to special interests as governor. ``What we're saying is the way you campaign tells a lot about the way you will govern,'' Chiles said. The Chiles campaign often seemed almost intentionally inefficient, disdainful of photo opportunities, live TV news events and massive rallies. Instead, Chiles concentrated on visiting day-care centers, recycling plants, senior citizens' homes, drug treatment centers and schools. Martinez tried to blunt his opponent's folksy image with charges that Chiles was really a Washington insider and liberal. Slowed by a 1985 quadruple heart bypass operation and depression tendencies controlled by the drug Prozac, Chiles quit politics in 1988. Republican Connie Mack went on to win his Senate seat in a razor-thin election over Rep. Kenneth ``Buddy'' MacKay. Chiles, with MacKay as his lieutenant governor running mate, easily won the Democratic primary in April. But then he saw an early lead over Martinez of up to 30 percentage points evaporate in the face of the incumbent's well-funded, vigorous re-election campaign. Chiles and MacKay say they will work together like a corporate team of top executives, and there is wide speculation that Chiles will step aside after one term so that MacKay can seek the governorship in 1994.

DOC.HEAD: Miller Used Lottery To Campaign As Familiar Face With New Ideas
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Zell Miller, Georgia's lieutenant governor for 16 years, used a single issue - legalizing state lotteries - to portray himself in the governor's race as a familiar face with new ideas. Miller, 58, presiding officer of the state Senate, seized the issue early, championing it unsuccessfully for two years in the Legislature. Then he employed it to dominate two campaigns this year. First, he used the issue to vanquish four challengers for the Democratic nomination, including former Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young. Young's bid to become the state's first black governor brought international notice to the campaign. He pressed the issue again in the general election campaign against Republican Johnny Isakson, who sought to neutralize Miller's advantage by endorsing the lottery himself. Silver-haired with sharp, hawk-like features, Miller's nasal, country twang reflects his heritage in the North Georgia mountains. The son of an educator, Miller grew up in Young Harris, Ga., served a stint in the Marine Corps and then spent three decades in politics. He has been a state senator, an aide to former Gov. Lester Maddox, a member of the Board of Pardons and Paroles, and lieutenant governor. At various times along the way, he has run unsuccessfully for Congress. In 1980, he lost a bid to unseat then-Sen. Herman Talmadge in the Democratic primary. Talmadge subsequently lost to a Republican. Some of the sharpest fighting of this year's general election campaign came when Isakson, seeking to gain the upper hand on the lottery question, advanced what he termed a better plan for targeting lottery profits to education. Both campaigns, armed with paid media consultants and professional pollsters in the most expensive campaign in state history, fired off television commercials arguing whose distribution formula was best, and argued the issue in person in several debates. Race became an issue late in the campaign, although both candidates were white. During one of several debates, Miller accused Isakson of hiding behind his father to escape charges that the real estate firm he heads - previously run by his father - was charged with racial discrimination in the past. Isakson countered that Miller ran a segregationist campaign during an unsuccessful bid for Congress 26 years ago. Newspaper clips produced later disclosed Miller condemned then-President Lyndon Johnson as a turncoat for pressing the landmark Civil Rights Act of 1964.

DOC.HEAD: Joan Finney Has Made Career of Upsetting Expectations
DOC.TEXT: Joan Finney has made a career of confounding pollsters, pundits, legislators and bureaucrats. The state treasurer was supposed to lose the Democratic gubernatorial primary in August to former Gov. John Carlin by as much as 20 percentage points. She won a narrow victory. She defied expectations again Tuesday by winning the general election. Republican Gov. Mike Hayden spent about $2 million in his re-election campaign, six times as much as Mrs. Finney and the most ever for a Kansas candidate. President Bush, Vice President Dan Quayle and first lady Barbara Bush have campaigned for Hayden, as have other prominent Republicans. ``This is a game of hardball,'' Mrs. Finney said before the election. ``I know I'll have all of the big guns coming out after me, but I'm used to it.'' Mrs. Finney, 65, has spent the past 16 years as state treasurer, winning five elections. In 1985, she created a program of making idle state funds available for low-interest loans for farmers, and she has made a crusade out of her office's efforts to find the owners of unclaimed property. But she also has come under fire for her administration. Repeatedly, state audits criticized her management. Hayden has pointed to a 1976 incident in which a Topeka boy found a $2 million state check in an alley - something she blamed on a careless bank runner. Mrs. Finney began her political career in 1953, when she joined the staff of U.S. Sen. Frank Carlson. Mrs. Finney worked for Carlson, a revered figure in the Kansas GOP, until he retired in January 1969. ``I didn't want to go on, but after a few months I was back into it,'' she said. ``It gets into your blood.'' In 1972, Mrs. Finney began receiving encouragement to run for the 2nd District seat in the U.S. House. She did and lost the primary. Two years later, Bob Brock, the Topeka hotel magnate and prominent Democrat, urged her to change parties to run against the incumbent state treasurer. She thought about it for a month. ``All the old Carlson people were retired, so I called Brock and said, `Let's go!' '' she said. That time, she won. Mrs. Finney speaks frequently about bringing government back to the people and has advocated a proposal to amend the state constitution to allow voters to put laws and amendments on the ballot without going through the Legislature. ``Never overestimate the amount of information people have but never underestimate their intelligence,'' she has said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Democrats Could Extend Their Control To Bigger Margin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 5 grafs, INSERTS new 19th graf, with Buechner loss.
DOC.TEXT: Democrats strengthened their majority in the House of Representatives in Tuesday's elections even as voters tossed out several entrenched incumbents in both parties. The majority party wrested 10 seats from the Republicans and threatened to take four more. GOP candidates captured three previously Democratic seats and led in another three. The Democrats had won 253 seats and were leading in 14 for a possible majority of 267 - compared to 258 seats going into Election Day. Republicans had won 155 and led in 12. That would give them 167, compared to their previous 175. There had been two vacancies, one from each party. Voters elected the first socialist to the House since 1929 and the first black Republican since 1935. Incumbents were turned out in Missouri, New Hampshire, Florida, Virginia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Oregon, Wisconsin and Vermont. But the re-election rate for House members still hovered around 96 percent. ``Even though a lot of incumbents are not being defeated, they're being scared,'' said Republican campaign chief Ed Rollins. ``They're not getting the 60 percent margins they had two years ago.'' And House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., claimed victory for the ``fairness'' theme his party had pursued through the election season. ``The results are clear: George Bush cannot win the Congress and must no longer rule by veto,'' Gephardt said. ``Next year, he must come to Capitol Hill with an action plan for reviving the economy and reworking the system to the benefit of working families.'' Rep. Newt Gingrich, the combative No. 2 House Republican leader, barely survived his rematch against Democrat David Worley in a suburban Atlanta district. Gingrich had led the opposition to the bipartisan budget deal reached by President Bush and Congress. In Vermont, freshman incumbent Republican Peter Smith was ousted in favor of Bernard Sanders, the socialist former mayor of Burlington. Sanders will become the first socialist in the House since Victor Louis Berger of Milwaukee, Wis., six decades ago. Sanders handily defeated Smith, who had created an awkward situation when he publicly distanced himself from President Bush while standing at Bush's side during a presidential trip to Vermont to stump for the GOP candidate. Voters in Connecticut elected the first black Republican to serve in the House since Oscar De Priest of Illinois during the Depression. Waterbury Alderman Gary Franks dashed the comeback hopes of former Democratic Rep. Toby Moffett in a seat vacated by a Republican. For the first time since 1912, the year the Titanic sank, voters in New Hampshire's 2nd District elected a Democrat. Dick Swett, an architect, defeated incumbent Republican Chuck Douglas. And 32-year veteran Democrat Robert Kastenmeier of Wisconsin was defeated by a 37-year-old former Madison newscaster, Scott Klug. Kastenmeier was chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on courts. In Oregon, an incumbent tainted by the savings-and-loan scandal also went down to defeat. Five-term Rep. Denny Smith was defeated in his second round with Democrat Mike Kopetski, who had narrowly lost to Smith two years ago. Conservative Republican Stan Parris decisively lost his seat in the Virginia suburbs of Washington to former Alexandria Mayor James Moran, who had made Parris' anti-abortion stand a major issue. In Florida, Democrat-turned Republican Bill Grant was soundly defeated by Democrat Pete Peterson, a retired Air Force colonel who made Grant's 1989 party-switch an issue. And Maryland voters evicted five-term Democrat Roy Dyson, who had been plagued by character questions, choosing instead Republican Wayne Gilchrest, a high school teacher who has never held public office. In the St. Louis suburbs in Missouri, two-term Republican Jack Buechner was edged out by Democrat Joan Kelly Horn. Buechner said he would request a recount in light of the 52-vote victory margin. Republicans also lost open-seat races in Utah, Illinois, Rhode Island, Arkansas and Hawaii, where GOP incumbents had retired or left to seek higher office. In Illinois, John W. Cox Jr. won the seat vacated by Rep. Lynn Martin, and the traditionally Republican Utah 3rd District went to a Democrat, Bill Orton. In Rhode Island, Democrat John F. Reed defeated Trudy Coxe for the seat vacated by Republican Rep. Claudine Schneider. In Little Rock, Ark., former Rep. Ray Thornton succeeded in a comeback bid against Republican Jim Keet. And there was another comeback in Hawaii, where Neil Abercrombie recaptured the seat left by Patricia Saiki. And in an affluent suburban Pittsburgh district, attorney Rick Santorum shocked seven-term Democratic Rep. Doug Walgren by hitting anti-incumbent themes like the congressional pay raise and special-interest political money in his campaign. A member of the Armed Services Committee, Dyson had barely survived a challenge by Gilchrest in 1988 when Dyson was hampered by accusations of conflict-of-interest involving defense contractor campaign money. This year, it was revealed that Dyson had escaped service in the Vietnam War by claiming conscientious objector status - in contrast to his hawkish defense views since entering the House. Several other incumbents were in extremely close races to hang onto their jobs, including several not previously thought to be in danger. The list included Reps. John Hiler, R-Ind., Olympia Snowe, R-Maine, Chester Atkins, D-Mass., and James McClure Clarke, D-N.C. In Kentucky, three-term Rep. Carl Perkins narrowly survived a scare from Republican Will T. Scott, a former circuit judge, eking out a 2,000-vote victory. Going into Election Day, analysts on both sides were predicting Republicans would slip further into the minority, losing from six to 12 seats, despite reported widespread voter disaffection with the Democrat-controlled Congress. Additional GOP losses would further hamper President Bush's ability to push his legislative agenda through Congress. The Democrats have controlled the House since 1954. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., said he believed the outcome could help Democrats prevail on closely divided issues, including some override votes on Bush's vetoes. He cited as an example the civil rights bill, which was vetoed in the waning days of the 101st Congress. The House vote to pass the bill had been 273 to 154, 17 votes short what would have been needed to override the president's veto. Foley said the measure would be pressed again when the 102nd Congress convenes in January. A bolstered Democratic majority will also carry a mandate to undertake ``a serious review of our national health delivery system,'' Foley said. The change also could affect perennially close votes on issues such as the budget and abortion. Even with the ouster of some incumbents, the re-election rate appeared to be near the 98 percent rate of the past two elections. In Louisiana, New Orleans sent a black Democrat - state Sen. William Jefferson - to Washington. It was the last majority black congressional district in the nation still represented by a white.
DOC.HEAD: Democrats had 25th graf a0915, which first graf of dash matter
Dallas Neighborhood Threatening to Secede
DOC.TEXT: Complaining of unfinished parks and libraries and just plain second-class treatment, a section of Dallas comprising one-third of the city's population is threatening to dissolve an 87-year-old bond and secede. Oak Cliff would become Texas' seventh-largest city and reduce Dallas in area by half if allowed to become independent, as it was until 1903. A referendum to decide the issue could be on the ballot by 1992, and the new city could be in operation by 1993, the secessionists say. ``If Dallas doesn't change its way of doing business, it will lose Oak Cliff,'' said Bob McElearney, president of the Oak Cliff Chamber of Commerce. The community on Dallas's south side has 310,000 people, evenly divided among blacks, whites and Hispanics. It has pockets of affluence but is largely in decline. The north side of Dallas is more prosperous. ``We don't want to de-annex; we want to improve the quality of life in the southern half of Dallas,'' said City Councilman Charles Tandy of Oak Cliff. ``That includes direct city services like trash pickup, code enforcement, street repairs, things like that. ``We have libraries that were promised eight to 10 years ago that were never built and parks that were initially approved 15 years ago that were never completed.'' City officials have said budgetary constraints have stopped projects all over Dallas, not just in Oak Cliff. In addition, they say, Oak Cliff depends more on libraries and recreation programs than the north side, where people can afford travel and other diversions. Political underrepresentation has been blamed in part for Oak Cliff's problems. The community has a third of the population but only one member on the 12-person City Council. A referendum in December would reorganize the City Council to address the disparity. The roots of the Dallas-Oak Cliff split are deep. Oak Cliff joined Dallas by a margin of 18 votes and a decade later secession already was being discussed. On June 1, the secession movement created 19 committees with 130 people to study the possibility of a breakup and its effects. Three city accountants have been working full-time to analyze projections on revenue and expenses. At a meeting last month where Oak Cliff residents voted overwhelmingly to proceed with a referendum on secession, Mayor Annette Strauss was shouted down by a crowd of almost 2,000. ``We are one family,'' she pleaded. ``That's the way it's been, and that's the way it's got to continue to be.'' Oak Cliff is home to some of Dallas' largest hotels and warehouses. But 80 percent of city bond money is spent outside Oak Cliff, said Tandy. And Louis Salcedo, an Oak Cliff engineers, said city contracts have traditionally gone to businesses on the north side. ``It is easy to drive around Oak Cliff and see areas that have been neglected,'' he said. West Jefferson Boulevard was the former city's downtown section. But some businesses have closed in the last decade and thrift shops are now numerous. ``I grew up in Oak Cliff and I have seen its condition grow worse for many years now,'' said Theresa Floyd, who runs a clothing shop. ``It used to be pretty nice, but now it's going straight downhill.'' Other residents aren't sure secession is the right course. ``There are just as many greedy people in Oak Cliff as in Dallas. I can see taxes going up in Oak Cliff if it becomes a city,'' said Ed Johnson Crna, an anesthesiologist.

DOC.HEAD: Homebrew Craze: For Some, Best Beer Is Made in Kitchen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY312 of Nov. 2
DOC.TEXT: The Outlaws had made a sizeable dent in the evening's beer supply by the time Charlie Papazian rose to deliver the invocation. He raised a glass of frothy ale, grinned through his beard and led the crowd in the familiar chant: ``RELAX! DON'T WORRY! HAVE A HOMEBREW!'' Up went a hundred glasses and down went the beer. Down went Sal Pennacchio's BME Porter, a rich, black ale with a toasty aroma, and down went John Quinn's Spiced Brown Ale, redolent of chocolate and cinnamon. Down went a nutty German-style ale and a malty, golden Pilsener, and down went several other brews that will never be found at your neighborhood tavern. The beers were the star attraction at the annual dinner of the Outlaws of Homebrew, one of a growing number of clubs around the nation devoted to home beer brewing. The dinner (the food was bratwurst and sauerkraut) drew more than 100 people to Brooklyn Brewery's distribution warehouse on a dark industrial block in Brooklyn. It's estimated that somewhere between 500,000 and 1 million people in the United States brew their own beer. Homebrewing has been legal since 1978, and by all accounts is in the midst of a heady spurt of growth. ``I think people are paying more attention to what they're putting down their mouths,'' said Papazian, whose book, ``The Complete Joy of Homebrewing,'' is the hobby's bible. Membership in the American Homebrewers Association, which Papazian founded in 1978, is up 41 percent in the past year and is expected to top 10,000 by year's end. There are at least 150 homebrew clubs in the country and 1,200 retail supply shops. ``It's growing tremendously,'' said Seth Schneider, the general manager of Crosby & Baker, a brewing supply manufacturer and distributor in Westport, Mass. ``We're still on the steep part of a growth curve.'' The growth in homebrewing has mirrored the development of microbreweries - small breweries that typically devote themselves to full-bodied, high-quality beers. These beers account for a microscopic .15 percent of the national market, but loom large in the world of homebrewers. There is a strong symbiotic relationship between homebrewers and microbrewers. Homebrewers are microbrewers' most loyal customers; microbrewers frequently sponsor the homebrewers' organizations and events. The Outlaws of Homebrew dinner, for instance, was sponsored by Brooklyn Brewery, which provided the warehouse and two varieties of its own beer. Company founder Steve Hindy is himself a homebrewer who likes to tinker with recipes in his kitchen before trying them out in the brewery. ``Actually, right now I'm brewing something I call a chocolate stout at home,'' he said. The attractions of homebrewing are several. Foremost is the ability to make good beer; quality has improved mightily in the past decade as homebrew suppliers have become increasingly sophisticated. ``A homebrew rivals the best beer you've ever had,'' said Schneider. ``It hasn't traveled, it has more body, it hasn't been filtered ... and you can make it exactly to your taste.'' Some of those tastes are exotic - some would say bizarre. Homebrewers have been known to toss all manner of ingredients into their brew. Spruce beer, cherry beer and ginger beer are among the more common of the strange brews. Sal Pennacchio, treasurer of the Outlaws of Homebrew, recalls what happened last November when his wife was about to toss out the Halloween pumpkin. The result was his Pumpkin Ale, which won third prize in a national homebrew competition; it tasted, he said, ``just like pumpkin pie.'' ``I think that's the great thing about homebrewing,'' Pennacchio said. ``With a little experience, you can create anything you want.'' Not everyone wants a Pumpkin Ale, of course, but a more run-of-the-mill brew is a simple thing to make. Beer essentially consists of malted barley, yeast, hops and water. With those ingredients and a few rudimentary pieces of equipment - a bucket, some plastic tubing, a siphon, an air-lock valve, a capping tool and caps and bottles - anyone can make beer in their kitchen. Equipment for a novice costs about $45. Ingredients for two cases of beer run about $15, or roughly 35 cents a bottle. But that can vary widely depending on the kind of beer being made. A survey a few years ago by the American Homebrewers Association found that the overwhelming majority of homebrewers were white males, somewhat to the chagrin of those who champion the hobby. Brewers also tend to be married, well educated and divided almost evenly among cities, suburbs and small towns. ``The glibbest generalization,'' said Schneider, ``would be adult males with facial hair.'' Beyond that, he said, he's noticed that homebrewers are frequently computer buffs. Indeed, one of the busiest meeting places for homebrewers is on CompuServe Information Service's beer ``forum'' - a sort of electronic saloon for personal computer owners. The fact is, brewers are a gregarious lot. They are in their element at an event like the Outlaws dinner, drinking beer and swapping brewing notes with abandon. ``We're out for a good time,'' said Pennacchio, ``and to have good beer.''

DOC.HEAD: Buy This Box and Save the Earth: Some Green Claims Draw Scrutiny
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Every new, improved product on the supermarket shelf these days seems to be Greener than Green. Environmentally conscious shoppers are being offered more ways to preserve the planet while stocking up on cleansers, paper towels, plastic bags or disposable diapers. Unfortunately, some of the assertions sprouting on the new ecology-friendly packages are misleading, confusing or possibly even fraudulent. ``So many of these claims don't mean anything,'' says Joel Makower, publisher of the monthly Green Consumer Letter. ``Consumers are becoming discouraged early on. I'm afraid we're losing them before we get them firmly in the green consumer fold.'' Makower says shoppers who bought supposedly degradable plastic trash bags were turned off when they learned the bags will not really decompose in landfills, which is where they are likely to wind up. Similarly, consumers picked up supposedly earth-friendly aerosols only to find that the ozone-destroying chlorofluorocarbons have been replaced by other suspect chemicals. Or they purchased ``recyclable'' plastics, then found no recycler would accept them. Much of the confusion about marketing claims may be traceable to underlying policy questions that have not been settled. What is the best way to deal with solid waste? Should we make biodegradable products, even if they can't be recycled? Push recycling to the limit, accepting that nothing decomposes in a landfill anyway? Or reduce packaging to a minimum, even if what's left is neither recyclable or biodegradable? Meanwhile, federal and state investigators are looking into whether consumers are being deceived by some advertising or packaging asserting environmental benefits. ``We're very concerned with the number of claims that we're seeing,'' said Julie Vergeront, assistant attorney general in Minnesota, one of 10 states that formed a task force this year to work together on cases involving environmental products. Seven of the states filed suit against Mobil Corp., saying its Hefty trash bags, advertised as biodegradable, would not break down in landfills. The suit has been settled in Texas but is still pending in the other six states. In another case, the maker of Bunnies disposable diapers agreed to stop claiming the product was biodegradable. The diapers could degrade under the right circumstances, but not in landfills, which is where nearly all the diapers end up. The manufacturer, American Enviro Products of Placentia, Calif., also agreed to redesign the diapers to use thinner plastic and cotton in place of paper. The new package will say using Bunnies instead of other disposable diapers saves trees. ``They let us off the hook because they thought we were moving in the right direction environmentally,'' said Robert Chickering, the company president. ``We're going to give up on biodegradability,'' he said - even though he still believes there may eventually be an environmental benefit to having degradable wastes in landfills. The Federal Trade Commission is pursuing at least a dozen investigations into environmental product claims, but can't discuss the details yet, said Barry Cutler, director of its consumer protection bureau. Cutler said the commission was trying to make sure its enforcement did not give an unfair advantage to paper products over plastic, or vice-versa. To help puzzled shoppers and to verify product claims, two rival certifying agencies have sprung up. The first to begin operations is Green Cross Certification Co., based in Oakland, Calif. Since June, it has authorized 60 products to use its logo with specific statements of environmental virtue. Renew brand trash bags, for instance, are certified to contain at least 80 percent recycled plastics. Clorox 2 bleach comes in a box which Green Cross has verified was made from 81 percent recycled paper fibers. ``We're very specific with our claims,'' said Stan Rhodes, president of Green Cross. ``We really need to clean up the confusion in the marketplace.'' A competing outfit, Green Seal Inc., is planning more ambitious endorsements and hoping to announce early next year the first products that have met its standards. ``We're trying to identify products that over their entire life cycle are better for the environment,'' said Norman Dean, executive director of Green Seal, which is based in Washington, D.C. ``We think consumers want to know about the overall impact on the environment.'' Cutler said the FTC is watching the environmental certification groups closely, worried that over-broad endorsements could add to consumer confusion rather than clear things up. Much of the bewilderment, he said, doesn't really stem from advertising claims or scientific uncertainty but to the unsettled policy questions. ``The real issue is having an environmental policy about the best way of disposing of solid waste,'' Cutler said. ``The real issue is what we do with the garbage itself, not what we put on the box.''

DOC.HEAD: Political Significance of Throne Grows as Coronation Nears
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Fear that politicians are manipulating the throne for their own ends has arisen again, more than 40 years after Allied occupation forces rewrote the constitution to prevent it. This time, the warnings come from within Japan's own society as the nation prepares for the coronation Nov. 12 of Emperor Akihito, the first monarch to be enthroned under that constitution. ``I am very worried that the palace is being used for political purposes just as the military used the late Emperor Showa (Hirohito) before the war,'' Minoru Hamao, a former imperial chamberlain, said in an interview. Hamao, who directed the education of the Akihito and his sons for 20 years, said conservatives who would return to the old imperial system are a minority within the governing Liberal Democratic Party and lack public support. He added, however, that there was increasing evidence of attempts by politicians ``to align themselves with the emperor because they feel that will get them prestige and votes.'' The Chrysanthemum Throne has been politically important throughout Japanese history, but has had little to do with day-to-day policy. It was used as a justification for their own power by feudal samurai leaders, political reformers at the turn of the century and militarists in the years leading up to World War II. Today, the Liberal Democrats, who have governed since their conservative party was formed in 1955, use a logo similar to the imperial chrysanthemum. According to Hamao, links between the palace and party were relatively weak until Yasuhiro Nakasone, prime minister in the mid-1980s, tried to strengthen his control of the Imperial Household Agency that manages palace affairs. ``The Imperial Household Agency is officially under the supervision of the prime minister's office, and since Nakasone they have used their control over personnel (appointments) to gain power,'' Hamao said. He expressed particular concern about politicians being involved in an enthronement rite called the Daijosai, or Great Food Offering Ritual. ``It is very inappropriate for the prime minister and other government leaders to attend the Daijosai because of its religious nature,'' Hamao said. ``Having the politicians there is an imposition, and not in line with the constitution.'' Hamao said the palace could not have kept politicians off the guest list, which was strongly influenced by the prime minister's office. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's government has acknowledged the religious nature of the Daijosai, in which a new emperor has his first communion with the gods of Shinto, Japan's state religion until the war ended. It also has described the rite as an ancient tradition and denied that state funding violates constitutional bans on government support of religious activities. In Hamao's view, the decision to follow prewar precedent for Akihito's coronation is an attempt to free the government and Liberal Democrats from constitutional constraints on political manipulation of the throne. If politicians are allowed to ignore those restraints for the coronation, he said, they may seek to use the emperor in pursuing their goals. Sadao Yamahana, a legislator and and senior member of Japan's largest opposition party, the Socialists, said he believed the handling of the coronation reflected a desire by conservatives to restore some degree of the throne's old status. Yamahana said members of his party would not take part in the Daijosai, ``a rite that is intended to make the emperor closer to a god.'' The Japan Federation of Bar Associations, several teachers' unions and the National Christian Council of Japan have announced their opposition to state support for the Daijosai. In the constitution, written by the U.S.-led occupation authorities who ran Japan's government for seven years after the surrender in 1945, the emperor is defined as the ``symbol of the state and the unity of the people.'' This largely ceremonial figure was to replace a sovereign called ``sacred and inviolable'' in the imperial charter of 1889. ``Most Japanese support the monarchy as it is in the constitution, but because of memories of the war, we also have rather complex feelings toward it,'' Yamahana said. About 2,500 dignitaries, including Vice President Dan Quayle and Prince Charles of Britain are expected to attend the main coronation ceremony. While Yamahana acknowledged the need to guard against possible attacks by leftist radicals, he also said extreme security could be a means of expanding police powers. ``Police are planning what can only be seen as excessive security, and in this way, too, though subtly, they are saying that the emperor is not a regular person, he is like a god that needs special treatment,'' he said. Before the war, Yamahana said, the police and government used such thinking to justify silencing dissent. He added that his father, a social activist, was arrested dozens of times ``in the emperor's name.'' Radicals have declared they will use whatever means available to disrupt the enthronement, including violence. Tokyo police are believed to be planning Japan's largest security operation, possibly involving tens of thousands of officers. Two Cabinet ministers have suggested invoking a law that would allow the government to force violent, anti-social groups to disband. The law, never used for that purpose, has been criticized as a threat to freedom of speech and association. Political analyst Asao Yamaguchi said he did not expect a serious effort by Prime Minister Kaifu to use the throne for political ends. ``Really trying to redefine the role of the monarchy would require a strong political foundation,'' he said. ``Kaifu hasn't got that.''

DOC.HEAD: Earth Work Begins For New Round of Corrosion Tests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic Nov. 6.
DOC.TEXT: Excavation has begun on nine buried sections of the trans-Alaska oil pipeline for corrosion rechecks after charges the original inspectors were poorly trained or worked under the influence of drugs or booze. In all, 19 sections of the approximately 800-mile line are to be re-inspected for rust or cracks. A federal criminal investigation, meanwhile, is under way into accusations by a former corrosion inspector that his employer ignored drinking and drug use on and off the job. ``The quality of information related to the corrosion repair work along the pipeline is in question,'' said Mike Mengle, federal pipeline officer for the U.S. Bureau of Land Management. The 48-inch-diameter line carries a quarter of the nation's domestic crude oil production from wellhead at Prudhoe Bay to a marine terminal at the ice-free port of Valdez. The renewed concern comes at a time when President Bush has ordered domestic oil production increased because of the Persian Gulf crisis. But state and federal officials won't agree to increase the pressure in the line until the inspection issues are settled. Digging began Friday on a section in the Brooks Range, about 170 miles south of the start of the line at Prudhoe Bay, and the Alyeska Pipeline Service Co. hopes to finish the re-inspections by mid-December. Alyeska is the oil company consortium that operates the pipeline. Initial results Monday from a 76-foot section of pipeline showed no cracking or corrosion problems, officials said. Thorpe Technical Services is the Alyeska contractor that conducted the original inspection at sites where corrosion or other problems were suspected. The company has been doing the testing since 1988. State and federal agencies ordered the second look for corrosion or cracks that could lead to leaks after Edward William Thompson, 26, of Fairbanks, wrote a 16-page letter last month accusing Thorpe of submitting flawed work. Thompson alleged that Thorpe inspectors were poorly trained or supervised and that drug and alcohol use was widespread among workers. The company denies the allegations. Dave Vickery, a spokesman for the Bureau of Land Management in Anchorage, confirmed that a criminal investigation was under way into Thompson's allegations about drug use on federal land. He said he did not expect a report from investigators until mid-November. ``Alcohol and drugs were widespread on the job and after work hours,'' Thompson said in a telephone interview from Fairbanks. ``I can't say if that affected their work. ``I also wasn't comfortable with the level of training we had. I had received some schooling - about two weeks' worth - in ultrasonics. But prior to starting magnetic particle inspection I'd received no training. I learned on the job.'' Ultrasonic testing is designed to turn up internal corrosion; magnetic particle testing is used to find stress cracks, officials said. Thompson claimed in his Oct. 3 letter he never used drugs or alcohol. But court documents show he was arrested for driving while intoxicated last year, and in 1985 was convicted of cocaine possession after failing a drug test at his probation officer's office. Questioned about his criminal record, Thompson responded that his past is not the issue. Dan Claeys, Thorpe vice president for operations, denied Thompson's accusations about drug and alcohol use and inadequate training. ``We have done random screening since the incident,'' Claeys said. ``We did it immediately and everything seemed to be in order. ``We've also had federal authorities and Alyeska authorities gather up training documentation to show our people were trained and competent to do the job,'' he said. ``They have interviewed all our employees.'' Alyeska said it expects to spend from $600 million to $800 million by 1993 on corrosion detection and repair. The company has inspected about 8,000 feet of pipe above and below ground, officials said. It has dug up 30-foot to 100-foot sections at 138 sites to repair corrosion damage by placing steel sleeves over the original pipe. No cracks have been detected, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Lots of Flesh Pressing at Convention of PR Execs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report; longer version on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: They're the folks who tried to tell you Exxon did a decent job cleaning up the Valdez oil spill, Perrier is safe to drink again and McDonald's cares as much about the environment as it does making money. What happens when you set 2,500 of them loose on each other for a four-day annual convention at a posh hotel in Manhattan's theater district is in itself a metaphor for the public relations industry. These experts at putting corporate America's best foot forward practiced their craft - even when they weren't practicing it at the convention's beehive of workshops, seminars and speeches. They pressed flesh under bright chandeliers, dined together and swapped tips with colleagues. They honed their flair for dramatization, bragging about how they helped so-and-so company get free press in national newspapers. Aware of the value of free publicity, many speakers spoke without charging the Public Relations Society of America, which organized the event that ends Wednesday. PR specialists themselves, society aides armed with walkie-talkies roamed four floors of the Marriot Marquis, partly to ensure that visiting reporters were shown the conference's best face. While public relations professionals are among the first layoff victims during an economic downturn, attendees couldn't resist the urge to tell reporters their business was performing quite well, thank you, despite widespread job losses elsewhere. The conference's official theme was ``Our World in Transition,'' or how public relations firms can adapt to the changing needs of a market becoming more global in character. But a more timeless notion seemed to dominate as attendees sat through the clattering of fine silverware at a Monday afternoon award luncheon: how to balance image-polishing roles with the need for honesty. Several pointed to Perrier's handling last spring of its tainted water as an example of poor crisis management and insisted that public pressure eventually forces a company to tell the whole truth - no matter how well it tries to conceal it. After all, it was Perrier's corporate communications department that initially insisted the discovery of benzene in bottles of the spring water resulted from a filtering equipment malfunction. Later, they conceded the carcinogen for years has occurred naturally in France's underground source for the global drink. ``If I tell this lady here that I love her and punch her in the jaw, she is more likely to believe the punch in the jaw,'' said Larry Newman, owner of a PR firm in Columbia, S.C., pointing to a kindly-looking white-haired lady seated nearby. ``The truth is always the ceiling above which no amount of terrific public relations can rise,'' said James E. Arnold, chairman of the conference and president of a New York consulting firm. On the other hand, many praised McDonald's PR coup last week, when the fast-food giant announced it would abandon foam packaging for environmentally friendly paper containers. Indeed, PR proponents insisted it is a profession with high ethics. ``I don't take any clients where I don't believe they are right or the case for them can't be proven,'' said Newman, recalling that he didn't take the Shah of Iran in the 1970s because ``I thought the shah was a crumb bum.'' It became clear at the convention that PR workers consider themselves a vastly misunderstood bunch bravely trying to earn respect from the very newspapers and broadcast stations they help supply news to. In their minds, they are crucial links in a complex world, helping everyone from businesses to non-profit groups communicate with a doubting American public. Indeed, at an event where you'd think nary a disparaging word could be heard about the industry, at least one workshop, moderated by Fordham University business school professor William J. Small, was self-deprecating: ``How to Spend a Billion or Two and Still Get a Black Eye in Public: The Exxon-Valdez Story.''

DOC.HEAD: 1990 Election in Brief
Promises, Promises....
DOC.TEXT: Don Frankenfeld won't get a chance to fulfill his promise to leave Congress after eight years if elected. Frankenfeld, a Republican, lost in a landslide to two-term Democratic Rep. Tim Johnson for South Dakota's at-large seat. A financial planner, Frankenfeld tried a variety of approaches to attract attention during his campaign. One of them was to sign contracts with people who would give him a $1 campaign contribution promising that he would not serve more than four two-year terms. If he broke the promise, he said he would pay $10,000 in damages to each contributor. ---
DOC.HEAD: Cowabunga! Bart Simpson Out in Texas
DOC.TEXT: Bart Simpson got the boot in Texas. That's Bart Simpson the candidate, not Bart Simpson the pint-sized cartoon character. Simpson, a 24-year-old Republican businessman, lost to Democrat Leticia Van de Putte in the race for state House District 115 for San Antonio. The incumbent, Orlando Garcia, a Democrat, opted to run for state appeals court. Democrats accused the GOP of running Simpson because his name was the same as the bratty, underachieving star of the hit TV show ``The Simpsons.'' But Simpson, whose full first name is Barton, said he always had gone by Bart and that he always wanted to be a politician. Ms. Van de Putte, a pharmacist, said before the election that her six children would get a kick if she beat Simpson. ``I think they'll be quite impressed that I could even run against a celebrity,'' she said. ``After all, I'm just `Mom.' '' ---
DOC.HEAD: Abortion, Sex Education Spice Connecticut Races
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A legislative candidate who proposed public humiliation for women who have multiple abortions was defeated. In another race, an incumbent who spoke out in favor of masturbation won. Democratic State Rep. John D. Mordasky on Tuesday beat Republican challenger Robert Bechta. During the campaign, Bechta said he supports a woman's right to abortion and supports state-funded abortions, but doesn't think abortions should be used as a primary means of birth control. ``Public degradation, I think, would probably be the best way'' of deterring people from having multiple abortions, he said. Mordasky opposes all abortions, except in cases of rape, incest or risk to the mother's life. In another race, Democratic state Rep. Lynn Taborsak defeated Republican challenger Alex Nahas, who had criticized her for proposing legislation encouraging young people to masturbate to avoid sexually transmitted diseases and unwanted pregnancies. ``The Bible says cast your seed into the belly of a whore rather than onto the ground,'' Nahas said during the campaign. Taborsak's measure was intended to counter a Republican amendment requirng that students be taught abstinence from premarital sex as the ``expected norm.'' Neither measure became law. ---
DOC.HEAD: Judge with Unpopular Name Retained
DOC.TEXT: A county judge's worry was all for naught. Voters kept him in office and didn't confuse him with an unpopular federal judge. Jackson County Circuit Judge Thomas C. Clark had run radio ads urging voters not to ``vote against the wrong guy.'' Clark had worried that voters would confuse him with U.S. District Judge Russell G. Clark, who angered many residents when he ordered taxes raised to desegregate Kansas City schools. ``I have a job,'' said Thomas Clark. ``I'm gratified.'' The county judge broke with tradition and launched a campaign to keep his bench. Missouri judges usually avoid politics and run on their records. ``I had reservations about doing it, but my friends convinced me it was a question of not capitulating,'' Clark said.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Barbara Roberts defeated moderate Republican Dave Frohnmayer in the governor's race Tuesday, aided by the candidacy of independent anti-abortion candidate Al Mobley, who apparently took critical support from the Republican.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Turnout Helps Helms Win Fourth Term
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Jesse Helms spurred his loyal supporters to line up at the polls in a plentiful turnout that gave the conservative Republican a fourth term and vanquished Democratic challenger Harvey Gantt. ``Well, there is no joy in Mudville tonight,'' Helms told cheering supporters late Tuesday. ``The mighty ultraliberal establishment, and the liberal politicians and editors and commentators and columnists have struck out again.'' With 93 percent of precincts reporting, Helms had 996,082 votes, or 54 percent, to 865,240 votes, or 46 percent, for Gantt, a former Charlotte mayor. Helms, 69, attributed his victory to an embrace of ``North Carolina values.'' Gantt, whose supporters hoped to enshrine him as the first black elected to the Senate from the South since Reconstruction, ran as an unabashed liberal and attacked what he called Helms' lying and distortion. Gantt, 47, said he did not regret his campaign, which focused on education, the environment and social issues. ``I'm still smiling from way down deep, even though I hurt a little bit,'' Gantt said. ``I hurt quite a bit because we gave our best.'' Voter turnout approached 55 percent, unusually heavy for an off-year election. ``The Helms campaign got out the people who they had to get out,'' said Thad Beyle, a political science professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Judges in Durham and Greensboro extended voting hours because of long lines and problems with voting machines. Other urban areas also reported long delays at voting places, but did not extend their hours. Helms, who campaigned full-time for only eight days after the late adjournment of Congress, relied on a barrage of television ads that raised racial issues. Helms attacked quotas and accused Gantt of running a ``secret'' campaign on black radio stations. Campaign finance reports as of two weeks ago showed Helms had spent $10.8 million and Gantt $4.6 million, giving North Carolina the nation's most costly Senate race. State voters kept Democrats in control of their legislature, where incomplete returns showed Republicans in danger of losing several seats. Seven Democrats and three Republicans kept U.S. House seats. In North Carolina's fickle 11th District, Democratic Rep. James McClure Clark had 50 percent of the vote in a race too close to call.

DOC.HEAD: The Cost of Victory - and Defeat
DOC.TEXT: Money isn't everything, although it certainly can help, election results show. Some candidates who raised and spent millions still lost in Tuesday's balloting. Perhaps most notably, Republican Gov. Bob Martinez lost re-election in Florida despite raising about $10.6 million to $5.2 million by Democrat Lawton Chiles, the winner. Not all the races were costly. In Utah, Republican Mary J. Wilder spent $750 to unseat Democrat Dennis D. Ewing as Tooele County clerk - all but $25 of it her own money. Ewing, who has held the office for 17 years, spent $1,500. The Federal Election Commission reported that more than $350 million was raised and more than $300 million spent by congressional candidates in the 1990 election. Here are recent campaign finance figures in major races for governor, Senate and House:

Texas: Republican Clayton Williams spent $20.4 million; his winning opponent, Democrat Ann Richards, spent $11 million. Massachusetts: Democrat John Silber, in a losing effort, took in $3.1 million, including $450,000 in personal loans; winning Republican William Weld collected $2.74 million, including $1.19 million in personal loans. Rhode Island: Democrat Bruce Sundlun spent $4 million and ousted Republican Gov. Ed DiPrete, who spent $2 million. Alabama: Republican Gov. Guy Hunt built a $5.46 million war chest in his successful re-election; Democratic opponent Paul Hubbert raised $4.93 million.

North Carolina: Victorious Republican incumbent Jesse Helms spent $10.8 million, Democratic challenger Harvey Gantt $4.6 million. Texas: Republican incumbent Phil Gramm, a winner, spent $7.8 million to Democrat Hugh Parmer's $1.6 million. Hawaii: Democratic incumbent Daniel Akaka spent $1.3 million to defeat Republican Patricia Saiki, who also spent $1.3 million. Massachusetts: Winning Democratic incumbent John Kerry spent $4.9 million, Republican challenger James Rappaport $3.6 million.

Washington: Democratic Rep. Jolene Unsoeld spent $1 million to $541,000 for Republican challenger G. Robert Williams. Maryland: Democratic incumbent Roy Dyson, an upset victim, spent $598,000; Republican challenger Wayne Gilchrest spent $100,200. Illinois: Democratic Rep. Frank Annunzio, narrowly a winner, spent $686,700; Republican Walter Dudycz spent $246,600. Minnesota: Republican Rep. Arlan Stangeland spent $342,600, Democrat Collin Peterson spent $216,800.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Sweep U.S. House Races
DOC.TEXT: Democrats swept four contested races to maintain their monopoly on Mississippi's U.S. House delegation. Voters on Tuesday also approved six amendments removing antiquated sections of the state's 100-year-old constitution. Among the dropped provisions were requirements that state prison inmates be separated by race and that the governor and treasurer count state revenues by hand twice a year. Voters rejected an amendment that would have repealed the requirement that each of the state's 82 counties be divided into five districts. U.S. Sen. Thad Cochran, R-Miss., won a third term unopposed. Incumbent Reps. Jamie Whitten, Mike Espy, Mike Parker and Gene Taylor were big winners. Democratic Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery was unopposed. Whitten, first elected a month before Pearl Harbor, won a 25th term, while freshman Taylor defeated Shelia Smith, widow of former Congressman Larkin Smith.

DOC.HEAD: Bush-Helped Candidates Fall; Chiles To Usher in `Camelot?'
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Lawton Chiles, ``burned out'' when he resigned from the U.S. Senate last year, said he regained voters' trust to oust Republican Gov. Bob Martinez in one of the big prizes of the 1990 electio60, said he was ``burned out'' when he left the Senate in 1989, but joined the governor's race last April to start what he hopes will become a revolution against modern politics. ``There really is nothing like success. Politicians like what works. You might really get some changes,'' he said. Chiles - who restricted campaign contributions to $100 - raised $5.2 million with donations from a record 75,000 people. Martinez, 55, was only the second Republican governor in Florida since Reconstruction, and the second to lose a bid for a second term. Martinez's campaign raised $10.6 million. Bush's son Jeb was Martinez' campaign chairman, the president campaigned for him three times, and first lady Barbara Bush made a campaign commercial. Democrat Douglas ``Pete'' Peterson upset U.S. Rep. James W. ``Bill'' Grant, a recent convert to the GOP who was targeted by the national Democratic Party for defeat in north Florida's 2nd District. With 100 percent of precincts reporting, Peterson had 101,615 votes, or 57 percent, to Grant's 76,518, or 43 percent. Bush also campaigned for Grant. The president has been criticized lately for his approval of higher taxes, but Martinez campaign manager J.M. ``Mac'' Stipanovich said he did not think Bush' support hurt. ``The president didn't lose the race for us. We lost it,'' he said. Democrats held off a Republican bid to take control of the state Senate and will control redistricting in 1992, when Florida is expected to gain three U.S. House seats. Democrats also control the state House. Voters in the crime-beset state heavily approved a constitutional amendment mandating a three-day waiting period for handgun purchases.

DOC.HEAD: Winners & Losers: The Race Ends When Everyone Has Crossed the Finish Line
DOC.TEXT: ``When the One Great Scorer comes to write against your name - ``He marks - not that you won or lost - but how you played the game.'' - Grantland Rice, noted sports columnist ---

Whether in victory or defeat, to be dignified was the final challenge. So as the returns rolled in, candidates across the nation were mindful that gracious winners don't gloat and graceful losers never whine. They stood tall before their boosters and smiled beneath campaign 1990's last spotlight. When the spotlight finally dimmed, today was here. The battle was done. ``You fought nobly,'' Republican Pierre Rinfret said as Gov. Mario Cuomo breezed to a third term Tuesday. ``We have not seen the end of each other.'' Applause sputtered quickly into silence. The controversial millionaire's staffers hung in when his caustic style split the GOP and his coffers ran dry, but this was the end of the line. Stacks of blue-and-white placards lazed against the walls like decommissioned soldiers, crumpled soda cans were piled high and half-eaten bags of chips were already growing stale. One campaign worker turns to another: ``So what's next for you?'' Before 7 p.m., Rinfret's staffers had pulled on their jackets and disappeared into the Manhattan night. They couldn't hear Republican Jim Keet, a 2nd District congressional candidate down in Arkansas: ``Why are you looking so glum? It ain't over 'til it's over,'' Keet reminded his staff at 9:15 p.m. ``You do not have permission to go home.'' Their spirits lifted slightly by the pep talk and a late surge in the polls, the troops stayed on until 11:20 p.m. - when Keet conceded victory to Democrat Ray Thornton. ``Losing is difficult for me,'' Keets said after the race was called. ``But the political risk is secondary ... Participating in the American political process is much more important. We will begin again tomorrow.'' Gov. Mike Hayden of Kansas sounded a similarly stalwart note in conceding Democrat Joan Finney's upset victory: ``As tough as it is and as hard as it is, there'll be another day.'' Then there was Michael Tobias, a 19-year-old poltiical neophyte from Portland, Ore. In volunteering to work for GOP Sen.
