Mark Hatfield, she signed on with a winning campaign on her first time out - and it felt good. ``It's fun being in politics,'' Ms. Tobias said. ``I'm not sure what party I'm in, but I'm interested in ... like, maybe becomeing secretary of state. What's his name?'' Suddenly whoops go up around the television monitors at Hatfield's headquarters. Latest returns? Nope. The Portland Trailblazers just scored against the Los Angeles Lakers. There's politics, and then there's basketball. Of this Sen. Bill Bradley was reminded uncomfortably late in the game. The Democratic incumbent nearly lost one to the New Jersey voters. ``What can I say? It's been a few years since I was in a double overtime,'' Bradley said running down Republican opponent Christine Todd Whitman's early lead. Manny Minelli briefly dances the fox trot, then pauses to reflect. The 65-year-old has over the decades watched his old friend, Gov. Edward DiPrete of Rhode Island, move from school council to city council to the statehouse. On Tuesday, Democratic challenger Bruce G. Sundlum ended the Republican governor's three-term reign. ``He will be depressed,'' Minelli said. ``Of course he will be.'' And the band played on, filling a downtown Providence ballroom with Dixieland jazz and the occasional Gershwin ditty. In West Virginia, things were less melancholy. Millionaire Sen. Jay Rockefeller's $2.7 million campaign staged a party far different from that hosted by GOP challenger John Yoder, who ran on a $20,000 budget. But the yuks were bipartisan. While the incumbent celebrated his victory at a packed reception room stocked with free munchies and a cash bar, Yoder spent the night in a $35 motel room off the West Virginia Turnpike. Rockefeller supporters watched returns on big-screen TVs. A cash bar offered mixed drinks at $3 each, wine for $2 and beer for $1.75. Soft drinks were free. At Yoder's hotel, visitors were welcome to purchase Smoothies for 50 cents and soft drinks at 55 cents a can. ``If I were a Rockefeller, it would not be a cash bar,'' Yoder said. ``Considering I'm not, it's BYOB for anybody who comes by.'' But, deadpanned Yoder's wife, ``He's pretty tight even when he has money.'' A fire raged at the Universal Studios complex not a mile away, but Republican gubernatorial candidate Pete Wilson's boosters still rolled into campaign central along with favorable returns against Democratic contender Dianne Feinstein. Said candidate Wilson to his supporters: ``Happily, there seems to be only property damage.'' Among the clear winners Tuesday evening was Sen. David Pryor of Arkansas. Minutes after the polls closed, the Democratic incumbent heaved a sigh of relief in an interview with a Little Rock television station. ``I was very fortunate. The people of our state were very kind to me this year,'' Pryor said humbly. ``I didn't think this would happen to me.'' The two-term senator had no Republican rival.

DOC.HEAD: Walters Wins on Second Try for Oklahoma Governor
DOC.TEXT: Democrat David Walters said his crushing defeat of Republican Bill Price in the governor's race means Oklahomans want change, especially in public education. ``And ladies and gentlemen, I'm here to tell you, we're going to change Oklahoma,'' Walters told cheering supporters Tuesday night. Democratic Sen. David Boren, chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, breezed to a third term, winning over Republican Stephen Jones. With 98 percent of precincts reporting, Boren had 714,976 votes, or 83 percent, to Jones' 143,611, or 17 percent. In the governor's race, with 98 percent of precincts reporting, Walters had 512,691 votes, or 64 percent, to Price's 287,617, or 36 percent. Walters, a 38-year-old Oklahoma City businessman, will succeed Republican Henry Bellmon, who is retiring. Bellmon defeated Walters in 1986. Walters had criticized Price's plan to repeal a $223 million school reform and tax bill enacted at a special legislative session this year. Walters also was pro-choice, while Price, 42, a former federal prosecutor from Oklahoma City, took an anti-abortion stand. It was the most expensive race ever in Oklahoma. Walters spent an estimated $2.5 million, a record, and about $1 million more than Price. In the U.S. House, Democrats retained a 4-2 edge over Republicans, with all incumbents re-elected.

DOC.HEAD: Bruce King: Rancher, Conciliator, Record-Setting Governor
DOC.TEXT: Bruce King, who has served longer than any governor in New Mexico history, says on-the-job training won't be necessary as he returns to the office after an eight-year hiatus. A bearlike man known for his friendly, folksy ways, including a lot of elbow-nudging and back-slapping - usually accompanied by a ``How's it goin'? Fine, fine'' - King has become famous for his ability to track and follow the political winds. ``If you have a problem, I have an open door, and we will work with you,'' he told campaign audiences. The 66-year-old Stanley rancher beat Republican Frank Bond on Tuesday, earning a third four-year term, with the chance to seek re-election in 1994. He first was elected governor in 1970 and again in 1978, and holds the record for the longest tenure in the state's top office - eight years. Voters in 1986 approved a state constitutional measure allowing governors elected from 1990 on to seek a second consecutive term. Previously, governors could not run for re-election. A force in New Mexico politics for most of four decades, King also has served as a county commissioner and in the Legislature, where he was elected Speaker of the House. Getting along with dissonant interest groups, legislators of diverse political stripes and bureaucrats of every type is his forte. Rarely one to challenge political adversaries, he usually brought them all in to work out a compromise for the benefit of all. As governor, King met regularly with legislative leaders. He has said he used the Legislature ``very much as a board of directors, with myself being the CEO.'' His ability to bring people together also has helped King refine a difficult tightrope act. For example, King often described himself and his lieutenant governor running mate Casey Luna as the ``businessman team'' that understands business. However, as governor, King often sided with labor, twice vetoing right-to-work legislation, which would prohibit union membership as a condition of employment. And as a rancher, King leases public land. Yet he was endorsed by an environmental coalition, which included some who want to ban cattle from public land. King and his wife of 43 years, Alice, who have two grown sons, worked side-by-side in the campaign. Mrs. King served as de facto campaign manager, scheduler and adviser, and King said she would head a task force in his administration that would study the state's children and family programs. He still lives near his parents' 1917 homestead on the edge of the Great Plains.

DOC.HEAD: For Ann Richards, Campaign Was a Beating
DOC.TEXT: After a grueling 18-month gubernatorial campaign in which she was dogged by personal attacks, Democrat Ann Richards says she wouldn't be surprised if her own children don't recognize her. Ms. Richards, who on Tuesday overcame millionaire Republican oilman Clayton Williams, knew what was coming when she ran for governor of a state where she describes politics as ``a very tough contact sport.'' ``I think it's an awful thing for anybody to have to go through,'' she said during the campaign's final week. ``I had to tell the kids when we made the decision, `You're not going to recognize your mother by the time they get through with me.' '' Ms. Richards, 57, entered the race after soaring to national fame as the keynote speaker at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. There, she claimed a lasting reputation with her line about George Bush's sometimes mangled syntax: ``Poor George. He can't help it. He was born with a silver foot in his mouth.'' In the campaign, she found herself recalling her divorce, talking about her history as a recovering alcoholic, disputing accusations of drug use and facing attacks that she was a liberal and defender of gay rights. A poll in the fall of 1988 showed more than half of Texas voters could identify her and only 14 percent didn't like her. A week before the election, a Gallup Poll put her unfavorable rating at 53 percent. Bemoaning the negative tone, she called her race a ``no-win situation'' and said candidates are afraid to even make a joke for fear of it becoming front-page news. Born and raised near Waco, Ms. Richards received a bachelor's degree from Baylor University. She was married for 30 years to civil rights lawyer David Richards. The two were divorced in 1984, and have four children. Her politicking began in the late 1950s, when she volunteered in the gubernatorial campaign of Henry B. Gonzalez. Ms. Richards first ran for public office in 1976, winning a seat as a county commissioner. She won terms as state treasurer in 1982 and 1986. Humor always has been an essential ingredient in her politics, and that was a key reason then-Democratic Party boss Paul Kirk tapped Ms. Richards to keynote the Atlanta convention. Ms. Richards said she still isn't sorry about poking fun at Bush, although Williams used it against her. Candidates, she said, must be willing to laugh at themselves. ``I wanted that speech to say that this is fun, that politics is a great thing,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Voinovich Says Ohio Government Needs Business Sense
DOC.TEXT: Gov.-elect George Voinovich remembers a question his late father asked him as he was embarking on his political career. ``Kid, are you sure you want to be a Republican?'' asked the elder Voinovich, an architect and a Democrat. Voinovich supplied that answer long ago and defeated Democrat Anthony J. Celebrezze on Tuesday. ``I don't believe government by itself solves problems,'' he said. ``But government working with other governmental agencies and the private sector can solve problems. That was, frankly, my ticket to success in Cleveland.'' The 54-year-old Voinovich was mayor of Cleveland for 10 years. He is credited with leading the city out of default after taking over from Democrat Dennis Kucinich, who left Cleveland $111 million in debt, and with helping to revitalize its downtown. Voinovich, who cited his experience in Cleveland throughout his gubernatorial campaign, said he would find ways to cut state spending through a management audit of state government. He said that after eight years of a scandal-plagued Democratic administration of Gov. Richard Celeste, the state needs to ``work harder and smarter'' in controlling costs. Some state agencies during Celeste's administration were investigated for awarding state contracts that were Snelling, who was governor 1977-85, decided to seek the office again because he believed his successor, Gov. Madeleine Kunin, a Democrat, had mismanaged the state's finances. Kunin did not seek a fourth term. With 260 of 262 precincts reporting, Snelling had 106,274 votes, or 52 percent; Welch had 93,725 votes, or 46 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Pennsylvania Democratic Incumbent Governor Wins Second Term in Landslide
DOC.TEXT: Voter interest was low in Pennsylvania, but those who did turn out favored Democratic incumbent Gov. Robert P. Casey by a landslide. He piled up the largest victory margin ever in a Pennsylvania gubernatorial race to claim a second term in Tuesday's voting. Casey garnered 2,045,464 votes, or 68 percent, compared to Republican challenger Barbara Hafer's 975,583, or 32 percent. He captured 66 of the state's 67 counties, winning in staunch Republican areas that hadn't supported a Democratic gubernatorial candidate in this century. ``This is a great night,'' Casey told supporters in Scranton, his hometown. ``A night that defies description.'' Casey, 58, ran on his record of avoiding new taxes while pushing education, environmental and economic programs. Hafer, 47, the state's auditor general, lagged far behind Casey in fund raising, and her abortion rights stand hurt her chances of massing the GOP vote against him. With Casey running way ahead throughout the campaign, just 53 percent of registered voters cast ballots in the gubernatorial race. Meanwhile, one incumbent congressman, Democrat Doug Walgren of Pittsburgh, was ousted, the first time in six years a Pennsylvania congressman was denied a re-election bid. At the state Capitol, Democrats tightened their hold on the House, boosting their 103-99 margin to 108-95. Republicans' margin in the Senate dropped from 27-23 to 26-24. A wave of anti-incumbent sentiment helped unseat 13 state House members. Two ballot questions also were approved Tuesday: a $25 million expansion of loans for volunteer fire and rescue companies and $200 million in state loans for county prison renovations and expansions.

DOC.HEAD: TV Election Coverage Doesn't Need Ballots
With PM-ELN--Election Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Forget counting ballots. At the top of CBS' election special, Dan Rather began announcing the winners of the nation's 35 Senate races. In shirt-sleeves and suspenders, Rather didn't use the words ``projection'' or ``exit polls.'' He declared ictors. Small problem. Some of the polls on the East Coast were still open. And no bureaucracy, not even CBS, can count that fast. Forty minutes into Tuesday's prime-time CBS election special, Rather finally told viewers that ABC, CBS, NBC and CNN were using a first-ever, joint venture called Voter Research and Surveys, which projected all Senate, House and gubernatorial races based on exit polls. CBS did place a tiny ``CBS News Estimates'' in the left-hand corner of the screen when it moved on to the governors' races across the country. But the premiere of VRS - as those in TV news refer to it - served only to heighten the networks' preoccupation with providing instantaneous election results while most of the nation's ballots are still in boxes. Cable News Network, in its comprehensive and ambitious coverage that lasted six hours, used the word ``estimate.'' NBC and Tom Brokaw ``called'' races. ABC and Peter Jennings ``projected winners.'' On CBS, it was hard to tell what was a prediction and what was a pronouncement. Network election coverage hype was heightened by a ploy to boost ratings during the November ``sweeps'' period. CBS and NBC said days before the election that both would carry no commercials during their special coverage. It was not an altruistic move. The A.C. Nielsen Co. does not include prime-time programs without advertisements in its ratings. And election specials are not known for drawing huge audiences. Thus, when CBS and NBC affiliate stations set advertising rates based on the number of November sweeps viewers, neither network will lose money because of lower election night ratings. This, however, did not stop CBS from running in-house ads promoting shows such as ``Uncle Buck'' and a network premiere of the movie ``Fatal Attraction.'' While CNN provided the most up-to-date, detailed coverage of the country's far-ranging ballot measures and candidates, it was not immune from the dreaded malady of live news coverage: inane chatter. Bernard Shaw seemed to take a fancy to CNN reporter and former Texas judge Catherine Crier, who was covering the ugly Lone Star race for governor between Democrat Ann Richards and Republican Clayton Williams. ``I'd like to sit with you behind the camera and find out what you really think about that race,'' a smiling Shaw told Crier. On CBS, Charles Kuralt chatted with Newsday editorial cartoonist Doug Marlette about whether it's difficult to draw cartoons when the nation appears headed for recession with ``war clouds looming.'' Rather, in declaring Democrat Joan Finney the upset winner of the governor's race in Kansas, blurted, ``Hey, Mabel, come in from the kitchen. Finney wins Kansas.''

DOC.HEAD: Food Tax Issue Leads Utah Ballot
DOC.TEXT: Voters decided to keep a state sales tax on food, going along with officials who said the repeal would cost as much as $90 million in lost revenue. The food-tax referendum took center stage after the Independent Party of Utah gathered 75,000 signatures to place on the ballot a measure calling for the 6.25 percent tax to be repealed. With 97 percent of precincts reporting Tuesday, 185,465, or 44 percent, voted to repeal the tax; 234,057, or 56 percent, voted to keep the tax. With Gov. Norm Bangerter and other Republicans in opposition, the measure was given little chance of passage. For the U.S. House seat from the conservative 3rd District, Democratic tax attorney Bill Orton defeated former Republican state Sen. Karl Snow to replace retiring four-term GOP Rep. Howard Nielson. With all precincts counted, Orton had 78,431 votes, or 58 percent, to Snow's 50,090, or 37 percent. Rep. Wayne Owens, a three-term incumbent, preserved Democratic representation in the 2nd District. It is the first time since 1974 that Utah has had more than one Democrat among its three congressman.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0662; fixes category code.
Republicans Put Their `Spin' on Election Results
DOC.TEXT: Republicans who saw their mid-term election hopes fizzle along with President Bush's promise not to raise taxes were in no mood to put their feelings on display as voting returns rolled in. In contrast to past elections, the GOP declared Tuesday night's celebration at its national headquarters off-limits to reporters and television cameras. Also closed to the media was a downtown hotel ballroom where the National Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee was holding its customary post-election party. A small press room was set up one floor above. Sen. Don Nickles, R-Okla., the committee's chairman, along with a GOP spokesman and pollster were escorted to the room to put their spin on the results. But no other mingling was allowed. ``Maybe we learned something from 1986,'' said one young GOP campaign worker, referring to the last mid-term election when Republicans lost their six-year reign over the Senate. With Republican Senate candidates faring better than the party's gubernatorial and House hopefuls, Nickles was given the task of being the GOP's main spokesman on the election results. ``We got into a real debacle over the budget,'' Nickles said. ``It hurt President Bush; it hurt Republicans. Three or four months ago, we were hoping to gain two, three or four seats. Right now I think we'll be satisfied if we can hold our own.'' Just wait until 1992, he said, when ``we have a lot of senators in trouble on the Democratic side'' up for re-election. Charles Black, a spokesman for the Republican National Committee, said the results indicate ``more of an anti-incumbent trend than a partisan trend,'' a view echoed by Ed Rollins, co-chairman of the GOP's House campaign committee. ``When it's all over, you're going to see four or five incumbents on our side and four or five incumbents on their side going down to defeat,'' Rollins said. ``Even though a lot of incumbents are not being defeated, they're being scared. They're not getting the 60 percent margins they had two years ago.'' Anti-incumbency has ranked only slightly behind anti-taxes, anti-government and anti-spending in recent years as a cause for Republicans, who have not controlled the House since 1954. Asked if an anti-incumbent trend might hurt Bush's re-election in 1992, Black said, ``it's an anti-Congress trend rather than an anti-president trend.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0681; fixes category code
Campaign's Climax Yields Bumper Crop of Political Rhetoric
DOC.TEXT: Here are notable quotes from the election winners and losers, party officials and others: Florida Gov.-elect Lawton Chiles: ``Camelot is a state of mind and if you have it and I have it, we can start bringing Camelot back.'' Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C.: ``There is no joy in Mudville tonight. The mighty ultra-liberal establishment, the liberal politicians and editors and commentators and columnists have struck out again.'' Democrat Harvey Gantt, who lost to Helms: ``I'm still smiling from way down deep even though I hurt.'' Eddie N. Williams, president of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a black political think tank: ``We've seen the triumph of racism over reason in North Carolina.'' Republican Pete Wilson, who tapped millions of absentee ballots in California's governor's race: ``We have created a monster. It is called the absentee vote. It's the right kind of monster to have.'' Texas Gov.-elect Ann Richards: ``They want a governor that gets up and goes to work every morning.'' Minnesota Independent-Republican Arne Carlson: ``I feel like Lazarus tonight.'' Carlson was on the gubernatorial ballot only because Jon Grunseth dropped out in late October over allegations of sexual improprieties. Democratic National Committee Chairman Ron Brown: ``If the election for president were tonight, George Bush would lose.'' Richard Viguerie, a right-wing Republican fund-raiser: ``It's a wake-up call for George Bush and the country club Republicans who populate the White House.'' Retiring Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste, head of the Democratic Governors' Association: ``To the degree that George Bush was a factor, he was a burden.'' Republican National Committee spokesman Charles Black: ``It appears to be more of an anti-incumbent trend than a partisan trend.'' House Majority Leader Dick Gephardt: ``The results are clear: George Bush cannot win the Congress and must no longer rule by veto.'' Ed Rollins of the National Republican Congressional Committee: ``Even though a lot of incumbents are not being defeated, they're being scared. They're not getting the 60 percent margins they had two years ago.'' Rep. Stan Parris, R-Va., who lost to Democrat James Moran: ``In 1974 I got run over by a train called Watergate. Now it very much appears the same train 16 years later is going to run over me again.'' Democrat Joe Grandmaison, who lost to Republican Gov. Judd Gregg in New Hampshire: ``The truth of the matter is, I ran against a very popular incumbent governor who had more money than God to spend.'' Republican Rep. Bob Smith, who defeated Democrat John Durkin in New Hampshire's open Senate race: ``I'm a common man with common sense. I share common values with a lot of common people.'' Gov.-elect Lowell Weicker: ``I hope we sent a message that dirt is out of politics in the state of Connecticut.'' Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I.: ``The harder the fight, the sweeter the win.'' Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass.: ``Today in Massachusetts, we have proven that money can't buy you a U.S. Senate seat.'' Rep. Tom Tauke, R-Iowa, whose hard-core anti-abortion stand cost him heavily in his losing his bid to unseat Sen. Tom Harkin: ``We presented to the people of Iowa a real choice. We didn't waffle.'' Democrat Joan Finney, the first woman ever elected governor in Kansas, referring to her husband, Spencer: ``We're going to put his picture in Cedar Crest with the first ladies.'' Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., the former pro basketball star whose reelection was by an uncomfortably tight margin: ``What can I say? It's been a few years since I was in a double overtime.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Inches Up, Stocks Slide
DOC.TEXT: The dollar inched up against the Japanese yen today, while Tokyo share prices fell further as the Middle East situation discouraged investors, traders said. The dollar closed at 127.55 yen, up 0.35 yen from Tuesday's 127.20-yen finish, but down from 128.15 yen in New York on Tuesday. It opened at 128.10 yen and ranged between 127.30 yen and 128.50 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 465.50 points, or 1.94 percent, closing at 23,500.25. The benchmark index lost 419.58 points Tuesday. The dollar, boosted by a rise on overseas markets, opened stronger then fell on profit-taking, said Kohei Kuroda, an analyst with Fuji Bank. ``The U.S. elections (Tuesday) little affected the market,'' Kuroda said, as initial reports indicated moderate gains for the Democrats. Some market players had said an unexpected victory by the Republicans might trigger a rush to buy dollars. Spot transactions totaled $12.646 billion, up from Tuesday's $11.251 billion. On the stock market, lingering worries over the Middle East situation discouraged buying, said Toshiyuki Nishiguchi, a dealer with Daiwa Securities. ``A wait-and-see attitude prevailed because of concerns about the Persian Gulf crisis and a quarterly bond auction in the United States later this week,'' Nishiguchi said. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Nikkei index has fallen 6,744,93 points, or 22.3 percent. Volume on the first section was estimated at 330 million shares, up from 295 million shares Tuesday. Declining issues outnumbered gainers 816 to 176, while 94 others remained unchanged. The benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds were quoted at 84.59 points, down from Tuesday's 84.77-point finish. Their yield was 7.800, up from 7.755. Dubai crude oil for December delivery was valued at $27.45 to $27.55 a barrel, unchanged from late Tuesday's levels in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Democrat Cuomo Captures Third Term; Republicans Hold State Senate
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo walked away with a third term but not without a few blisters that could make it uncomfortable to break into a run for the 1992 Democratic presidential nomination. Cuomo failed to lead Democrats to control of the state Senate in Tuesday's election, and he lost his battle for approval of a $2 billion environmental bond act. Cuomo also fell far short of the 65 percent of the vote he racked up four years ago. ``This guy gets 52, 53 percent of the vote and he's going to be a presidential contender?'' state GOP Chairman J. Patrick Barrett said. ``Mario Cuomo ran against himself and lost.'' With 99 percent of precincts reporting, Cuomo had 2,097,394 votes, or 53 percent; Republican Pierre Rinfret had 850,764 votes, or 21 percent; and Conservative Party challenger Herbert London had 814,036 votes, or 21 percent. At Cuomo's victory party early today, about 250 AIDS activists from the group ACT UP staged a raucous protest that delayed and cut short the governor's acceptance speech. ``What these people are proving is that this is a very hard time to govern,'' Cuomo said to supporters. ``But with your help, we're going to do it better the next four years than it's ever been done before.'' Rinfret, a millionaire economist who had demonstrated an ability to insult Republicans almost as often as Democrats, made no public appearance after suffering the worst defeat in state history for a Republican gubernatorial candidate. Barrett said London's strong showing pointed up a need for the Republican Party to ``get back together (and) restore our historical conservative base.'' Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion, said Cuomo was hurt by having to announce that the state faced a potential budget deficit of $824 million despite his approval earlier this year of a record $1.8 billion tax increase package. However, all of New York's 34 U.S. House members, 21 Democrats and 13 Republicans, were re-elected. On Staten Island, voters overwhelmingly approved a referendum to start a process that could lead to secession for the smallest of New York City's five boroughs.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbent Montana Senator Crushes GOP Opponent
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Sen. Max Baucus said he prepared for a tough race, but ended up with a pushover, downing Republican Allen Kolstad by a better than 2-to-1 margin. With 92 percent of precincts reporting, Baucus had 201,489 votes, or 70 percent. Kolstad, Montana's lieutenant governor, had 85,787, or 30 percent. Baucus returns to Washington for his third term. He said he focused his campaign on convincing voters he was working to lessen unemployment. Kolstad said he ran a hard, honest campaign but was outgunned by Baucus' $3 million campaign fund. Kolstad also castigated Baucus for running a deceptive campaign. Meanwhile, Montana voters on Tuesday defeated an initiative that would have increased cigarette taxes by 25 cents a pack. Voters also re-elected the state's incumbent congressmen - one Democrat and one Republican.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Voters Reject Massive Tax Rollback
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts voters were in the mood for change, but not enough to adopt what would have been the biggest voter-initiated state tax rollback in history. Bay Staters rejected the multi-billion-dollar measure Tuesday, apparently satisfied with ousting incumbents and relying on new officeholders to carry out their mandate. One political analyst said the tax rollback was too dramatic, even for the frustrated and cash-strapped Massachusetts electorate. ``They wanted change but (the measure) went too far,'' University of Massachusetts political scientist Paul Watanabe said after the election. Crafted by Citizens for Limited Taxation in response to four tax increases in the past two years, it was defeated 60 percent to 40 percent, with 85 percent of the precincts reporting. The measure called for cutting state taxes and fees to 1988 levels. It would have slashed $1.3 billion from the state's $13.4 billion budget in the second half of the current fiscal year, and cut $2.6 billion in fiscal 1992, which begins next July. Recent increases in the state income, sales and gas taxes would have been rescinded. ``After a decade in which the public was told to feel good in the Reagan years, and to feel angry by talk-show hosts, the voters decided to speak for themselves and recognize reality,'' said James Braude, the initiative's leading opponent. He and other opponents had argued the measure could almost shut down the state, which raised fees in recent years as it tried to keep pace with a failing economy and cover the costs of an escalating budget. ``I'm mad but I'm not crazy,'' was the slogan of the initiative's opponents. Said Barbara Anderson, executive director of Citizens for Limited Taxation, ``It was a great fight and we certainly made them work for every penny they're going to take from us.'' The financially ailing Massachusetts government has the lowest state bond rating in the country. Bond rating agencies warned that passage of the measure could drop the state's rating from its current level of Baa to junk bond status.

DOC.HEAD: Gun Supporters Battle for House Seat
DOC.TEXT: Freshman U.S. Rep. Jolene Unsoeld fought for her job in an election with an unusual twist. The campaign was fought over gun control, an issue on which both candidates seemingly agreed. Unsoeld, a Democratic protege of House Speaker Tom Foley, was challenged Tuesday by conservative Republican Bob Williams, a former state legislator, for the 3rd District seat. With 56 percent of precincts reporting, Unsoeld had 38,520 votes, or 53 percent, to 34,205 votes, or 47 percent, for Williams. Unsoeld, a gun-control advocate in the Legislature, was rapped for championing a key amendment sought by the National Rifle Association and later accepting campaign cash from the group. Otherwise, the race was a classic contest between liberal and conservative. Foley easily won re-election, and the rest of the House delegation was heavily favored. An Unsoeld victory would leave the delegation at five Democrats and three Republicans. Washington voters rejected a slow-growth initiative. Seattle voters approved continuing to allow city government workers to take sick leave to care for live-in partners, and Tacoma residents considered a gay-rights ordinance.

DOC.HEAD: Alabama's Hunt Re-Elected Governor; Sen. Heflin Wins 3rd Term
DOC.TEXT: Guy Hunt, Alabama's first Republican governor in more than a century, narrowly won re-election despite a virtual sweep of top state offices by Democrats and Democratic U.S. Sen. Howell Heflin's big margin. Hunt, a preacher and farmer who blended folksy appeal with a hard-hitting campaign, turned back the challenge of state teachers' union leader Paul Hubbert in Tuesday's vote. Hubbert delayed any concession speech until today, saying there remained the possibility of error in the unofficial count. With 98 percent of precincts reporting, the unofficial tally showed Hunt with 619,108 votes, or 52 percent, to Hubbert's 574,213 votes, or 48 percent. Heflin, chairman of the Senate Ethics Committee and a frequent swing vote on the Senate Judiciary Committee, won a third term over Republican Bill Cabaniss. With 98 percent of precincts reporting, Heflin had 697,458 votes, or 61 percent, to Cabaniss' 454,298 votes, or 39 percent. Democrats won every statewide office on the ballot and maintained their 5-2 edge in congressional seats. The 57-year-old Hunt, who first was elected in 1986, won by splitting most of the rural vote with Hubbert and building solid leads in urban centers around Birmingham and Huntsville. Hunt's victory made him the only person other than George C. Wallace to win successive four-year terms as governor of Alabama. ``I think it shows the power of incumbency and Hunt's own personal appeal,'' said University of Alabama political analyst Patrick Cotter. Hubbert, 54, who was making his first run for statewide public office, said his strong challenge showed Alabama is ``ready to join the ranks of the New South.''

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake In Southern Iran Kills At Least 20; 12,000 Homeless
DOC.TEXT: At least 20 villagers were killed, scores injured and more than 12,000 left homeless by a powerful earthquake that jolted a mountainous region of southern Iran, Tehran's official media reported today. They reported a dozen villages damaged, two of them completely destroyed, in the temblor in Fars province on Tuesday night. The Islamic Republic News Agency said 21 people were killed, 80 injured and 12,105 rendered homeless. Tehran Radio said 22 were killed and 100 injured. The radio, monitored in Nicosia, said most of the victims were children who were sleeping when the quake struck at 9:47 p.m. The U.S. Geological Survey said initial readings put the magnitude of the quake at 7.0 on the Richter scale. Iran's Geophysics Center of Tehran University said it measured 6.6. An earthquake of that magnitude is capable of widespread, heavy damage. A quake measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale struck northern Iran on June 21, killing about 50,000 people and rendering half a million people homeless. Tuesday's quake was centered near the city of Darab about 600 miles southeast of Tehran, IRNA said. It quoted Darab Gov. Yahya Hashemi as saying at least 12 villages were heavily damaged. Two of the villages, IRNA said, were razed. It identified them as Qareh-No and Do-Borj-E Fourk, both in the Fourk county, which have a combined population of just over 6,300 people. IRNA reported a series of aftershocks well after the earthquake, including a powerful one that hit this morning and measured 5.6 on the Richter scale. IRNA said helicopters, ambulances, fire engines and civil defense teams were dispatched to the area. The rescuers, it said, worked all night in search of victims. The helicopters lifted blankets and tents to the area, and flew casualties to hospitals. President Hashemi Rafsanjani dispatched Vice President Hamid Mirzadeh to the region after allocating $13 million to the stricken area. Mohammad Parham, the head of Iran's Red Crescent, the Moslem equivalent of the Red Cross, also flew to Fars to supervise relief operations. Alireza Jafarzadeh, the Washington, D.C.-based spokesman for The People's Mujahedeen of Iran, said information from the area indicated the quake hit the route that connects Darab with the port city of Bandar-Abbas on the Strait of Hormuz. Jafarzadeh, whose group seeks to overthrow the Islamic government in Tehran, said ``This is a mountainous area.'' He said, ``the casualties are high because it occurred late at night when most villagers are at home, so that's real unfortunate.'' The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. An increase of one number on the scale means a 10-fold increase in ground motion.

DOC.HEAD: Walters' Road to Governorship a Rocky, Muddy One
DOC.TEXT: David Walters may have defeated his GOP gubernatorial opponent, but he hasn't seen the last of him: Walters is fending off a libel lawsuit filed by his foe. Republican Bill Price filed the suit after Walters alleged he was involved in oil price gouging. Walters, who chopped cotton on the family farm as a boy before going on to earn a Harvard education, first ran for the state's top office in 1986, showing promise by upsetting front-runner Mike Turpen, then the state's attorney general, in the primary. It was his first run for political office, but the Oklahoma City businessman quickly made points with his campaign energy and mastery of political rhetoric. Walters' primary victory then was tarnished by questions over the legality of a $162,500 loan from five people who already had contributed the maximum $5,000 allowed by law. Controversy over the loan was a major factor in Republican Henry Bellmon's defeat of Walters in 1986 and was the subject of negative television ads by Price in this year's elections. Bellmon is retiring. Walters countered with his own allegations, including those of oil price gouging. Walters, 38, relied heavily on voter dissatisfaction with government in overcoming his own negatives. He raised more than $2.3 million, a record, for the campaign. He defeated two strong contenders in the Democratic primary: seven-term U.S. Rep. Wes Watkins and sitting House Speaker Steve Lewis. As in 1986, he hammered on the theme that he was an outsider battling career politicians, calling himself a businessman who wanted to bring a fresh approach to government. Walters was associate provost at the University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center, located only a few blocks from the Capitol, before he quit to go into private business a few years before his first race for governor. In the runoff campaign with Watkins, Walters repeatedly ran television ads supporting a proposal to make Oklahoma the first state in the nation to limit legislative terms. He won a close runoff race with Watkins, and the legislative tenure plan was adopted overwhelmingly. Walters was born and raised in Canute, a small community in southwestern Oklahoma. He and his wife, Rhonda, have four children.

DOC.HEAD: Ann Richards Says Money, Bush's Help Failed to Help in Texas
DOC.TEXT: Ann Richards, who roared from 15 points behind in the polls only six weeks ago to capture the governor's mansion, derided Republican Clayton Williams' millions and the help he got from President Bush. ``I've always believed in people politics more than money politics,'' the Democratic state treasurer said after becoming the first woman to win a Texas governor's race since Miriam ``Ma'' Ferguson in 1932. With 97 percent of the vote counted, Richards received 1,862,705 to 1,756,634 for Williams, or 51 percent to 49 percent. The victory for the 57-year-old Richards was a major embarrassment to Bush, who calls Texas home and campaigned with Williams all day Monday. Texas voters gave Republican U.S. Sen. Phil Gramm a second term. With 95 percent of precincts reporting, Gramm had 2,161,422 votes, or 61 percent, to 1,360,731 votes, or 39 percent, for his Democratic opponent, state Sen. Hugh Parmer of Fort Worth. Democrats retained 19 of the state's 27 seats in the U.S. House. A jubilant Richards held aloft a T-shirt that said, ``A woman's place is in the dome'' as her supporters cheered Tuesday night. She said the vote showed that average Texans didn't want another millionaire as governor. Millionaire incumbent Bill Clements, a Republican, is retiring. ``They want a governor that gets up and goes to work every morning,'' she said. ``They want a governor that isn't going to be distracted by other business. They want their children educated ... They want something done about their insurance rates, and they want a governor that's going to do that.'' Richards also said her abortion rights position was well-received by voters. ``They want a governor who is committed to the freedom of the people of this state and who is not going to allow government to interfere in their private lives,'' she said. Williams, who spent $8 million of his own money on the race that cost him over $20 million total, hushed supporters who booed at Richards' name. ``To Ann Richards and to those who voted for her and worked long and hard and ably for her, I say congratulations,'' he said. In defeat, Williams acknowledged his various verbal gaffes throughout the campaign and the resultant damage. ``The fact that I didn't win is no reflection on the values that we believe in,'' he said. ``Maybe I'm a little too open, maybe straightforward.'' Besides setting a spending record, their race also gained national notoriety for mudslinging. Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, found herself dogged by questions about drug use after refusing in the primary to answer ``yes'' or ``no'' to a debate question on whether she had ever used illegal drugs. Williams' problems stemmed from his gaffes. He was sharply criticized after likening bad weather to rape and joking that if it were inevitable, ``just relax and enjoy it.'' He also admitted visiting prostitutes as a youth, saying that's how young men got ``serviced.'' When told that Ms. Richards had said she was catching up, Williams cracked: ``I hope she didn't go back to drinking again.''

DOC.HEAD: Hank Brown: Congenial, Competent, Conservative
DOC.TEXT: Hank Brown's methodical rise to the Senate befits his image as a competent, easygoing and articulate man who has represented Colorado's agricultural flatlands in Congress for the past decade. Brown, a Republican, cruised by Democrat Josie Heath of Boulder on Tuesday, a victory expected ever since he announced in 1989 that he would seek the Senate seat being left vacant by Republican Sen. Bill Armstrong, who retired. During his campaign against Heath, Brown enhanced his reputation as a campaigner, projecting an unflappable demeanor in public. Brown, 50, a fifth-generation Coloradan from Greeley, had represented Colorado's mainly agricultural eastern plains in Congress since 1980, winning 70 percent or more of the vote in each outing. He came to the job with an agricultural background of sorts, having worked for a meatpacker, Monfort of Colorado Inc., from 1969 to 1980. He was a vice president during his later years there. While serving on the House Ways and Means Committee, Brown became one of the most effective Republican critics of a welfare reform package backed by committee Democrats. He is credited with getting the House to endorse a version that produced the workfare reform that was signed into law in 1988. Brown sought tougher child support enforcement mecha said, summing up his political creed and campaign theme. Cut spending, hold the line on taxes, ensure a strong national defense and execute the most heinous of criminals - those have been the hallmarks of Craig's five-term congressional career. They were also the theme of the campaign that earned Craig the seat of retiring GOP Sen. James McClure over Democrat Ron Twilegar. Republicans have held it for 40 years. ``I've never voted to raise your taxes, and I'm not about to start,'' Craig told voters throughout the campaign. He stood firmly against President Bush and the budget deficit packages the administration backed because they included higher taxes. He is perhaps best known for sponsoring a proposed balanced budget amendment to the U.S. Constitution. Craig, 45, is Idaho's third straight 1st District congressman to join the Senate. McClure held that House seat for three terms before winning a heated 1972 campaign to succeed retiring Sen. Len Jordan. Conservative Steve Symms took over the district in 1972 and then passed the mantle to Craig eight years later when he defeated longtime Democratic Sen. Frank Church in 1980. Craig attended the University of Idaho, where he was student body president and a champion debater, and later worked on the family's Midvale ranch in western Idaho's Middle Valley while he polished his Republican credentials. In 1974, at 29, he began a political career that has yet to be tarnished by defeat at the polls. He was elected to the first of three terms in the state Senate, serving part of that time with Twilegar. He was generally viewed as moderate by his colleagues in the Legislature. His move to the right began with his decision to run for Congress in 1980. A relatively low-profile lawmaker on the national scene, Craig was never really challenged at the polls. His last three re-election campaigns produced two-thirds majorities. Democrats lost two of their challengers to fatal accidents. During his congressional service, Craig has run up high ratings from conservative groups and low assessments from most environmental organizations. A man of modest means, Craig saw an investment in a Boise doughnut shop go sour early in his congressional career. During the agricultural depression of the mid-1980s, his family ranch was forced into farm bankruptcy and eventually old. Seven years ago, he married Suzanne Scott, and the couple has three children from his wife's previous marriage.

DOC.HEAD: Democrat Retains Governor's Seat in Maryland
DOC.TEXT: Maryland's Democratic incumbent dispatched a Republican husband-wife team, but the GOP gained a congressional seat. The ticket of Gov. William Donald Schaefer on Tuesday topped Republicans William Shepard and his wife Lois, who ran for governor and lieutenant governor. With 94 percent of precincts reporting, Schaefer had 593,101 votes, or 61 percent, to 382,418, or 39 percent, for Shepard. Republican Wayne Gilchrest, a school teacher and part-time house painter, ousted incumbent U.S. Rep. Roy Dyson, who was hurt by lingering ethical questions concerning campaign contributions from defense lobbyists. With 98 percent of the vote counted, Gilchrest led the five-term Democrat 56 percent to 44 percent. The other House incumbents, five Democrats and two Republicans, were easily re-elected.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Sweep Rhode Island From Governor's Mansion on Down
DOC.TEXT: Republicans were swamped by Democrats as millionaire businessman Bruce G. Sundlun dumped incumbent Gov. Edward D. DiPrete and the Legislature lost its GOP leadership. Sen. Claiborne Pell held off Republican Rep. Claudine Schneider as Democrats captured every statewide race but one, with freshman GOP Rep. Ronald K. Machtley winning re-election. The election night parties staged by the two parties were studies in contrast. Democrats were festive and numerous; Republicans were sedate. Many of the Democratic victories were by wide margins. With all but three precincts reporting, Sundlun wiped up DiPrete 74 percent to 26 percent. The challenger had 255,495 votes to DiPrete's 87,961. ``The voters obviously have been very supportive and have heard our message,'' Sundlun said Tuesday night. DiPrete said his party faces a difficult, but attainable, challenge. ``We've built it up beore, we'll build it up again,'' he said. With all but three precincts counted, Pell outpolled Miss Schneider 62 percent to 38 percent. The incumbent had 216,253 votes, Scheider tallied 133,552. Democratic state Sen. John F. Reed tallied 59 percent to Republican Trudy Coxe's 41 percent. With all precincts reporting, Machtley beat Democrat Scott Wolf 55 percent to 45 percent. Senate Majority Leader Robert D. Goldberg of South Kingstown was beaten by Democrat Walter J. Gray - by a 142-vote margin. In the House, the minority leader's spot was vacated and the No. 2 Republican, Minority Whip Arthur M. Read II of Barrington, was trounced by Democrat Sandra M. Barone, 60 percent to 31 percent.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. John R. McKernan staved off a challenge Tuesday from his Democratic predecessor, U.S. Rep. Joseph E. Brennan, after a neck-and-neck finish to a contentious, year-long race. Brennan had accused McKernan of mishandling the state's economy, but McKernan said Maine was doing better than its economically depressed neighbors.

DOC.HEAD: As Ever, Americans Vote Their Pocketbooks
DOC.TEXT: Voters ousted two Republican governors associated with tax hikes and nearly threw out a senator to show their fury at a governor who recently raised their taxes but was not on the balot this year. If they sent a clear message on tax matters, voters were less definitive on abortion. Pro-choice stands helped some candidates and proved irrelevant in other cases, and top targets of abortion rights groups lived to serve another term. In other trends, widespread public dissatisfaction with Congress translated into only a handful of surprise defeats. And though voters rated the Persian Gulf standoff one of the most important issues facing them and the country, it did not influence contests one way or another. ``It's the forgotten issue,'' said Frank Newport, editor-in-chief of the Gallup Poll. ``But looking ahead, something is going to happen there and that's going to set the agenda for the months to come. Even if nothing happens and our troops just sit there, it's a very significant issue that may dwarf the others.'' The overriding themes in Tuesday's races were economic. Taxes in particular were at issue in Florida and Kansas, where Democratic gubernatorial challengers won at least in part by tying the incumbents to tax increases. Some said the chickens of the past decade came home to roost on people who were not at fault. ``The real reason this is happening to the governors has got to be traced to the Reagan administration,'' said Benjamin Page, a public opinion expert at Northwestern University. ``The cuts in federal aid to the states put tremendous pressure on finances and that's why these people have been raising taxes without adding services. ``We're having the morning after,'' he said. ``We're having our hangover.'' One near-casualty of the anti-tax revolt was Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., thought to be popular and heavily favored yet barely holding his seat. Most analysts blamed his problems on Democratic Gov. Jim Florio, who was elected last year and promptly raised taxes. ``New Jersey is a real solid example of what happens with people who try to raise taxes,'' said Newport. He said state executives are taking the hit now and ``you can extrapolate and say President Bush raised taxes, where will he end up in 1992? We're going to poll on that.'' In the sagging economic climate of New England, retirements and challenges resulted in an almost complete turnover in governor's mansions. And in another variation on economic concerns, Democrats in Texas and Florida made effective use of a populist pitch fueled by Bush's waffling on whether to raise taxes on the rich. ``You've got a resurgence of the Democratic fairness theme and the notion that the Republican Party has served the interests of the well-to-do,'' said Bruce Buchanan, an analyst at the University of Texas. ``People are tired of it.'' In Texas, he said, Democrats swept all major statewide offices. And in Florida, winning challenger Lawton Chiles exploited ``the idea of taking the power back to the people, away from the elements of privilege and big money,'' Buchanan said. Chiles also benefited somewhat from his pro-choice abortion stand, as did Jim Moran, a Virginia Democrat who unseated Rep. Stan Parris. But being pro-choice didn't help Kansas Gov. Mike Hayden or North Carolina Senate candidate Harvey Gantt, both of whom lost. Rep. Craig James, R-Fla., survived though he was a top target of abortion rights forces, and Idaho Gov. Cecil Andrus won another term after vetoing a restrictive abortion bill and enduring the wrath of the anti-abortion movement. And voters in Iowa delivered a mixed verdict, re-electing a pro-choice senator and an anti-abortion governor. ``Where abortion was a fundamental issue, it cut for the pro-choice candidate,'' said analyst Larry Sabato of the University of Virginia. ``But where other issues took precedence, then pro-life candidates were able to win. In Iowa, lots of people voted simultaneously (for both candidates) so obviously abortion was not the motivator.'' A poll taken Election Day found voters giving Congress an 18 percent approval rating. But the discontent translated largely into unexpectedly close races for some incumbents - and not actual losses except in a very few cases. ``The voters wanted to send a message without killing the messengers,'' Sabato said. ``The re-elect percentages are down. A lot of incumbents have been given scares.''

DOC.HEAD: 1990 Election in Brief
Mink's Temporary Congress Seat Now Permanent
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Patsy Mink will have a leg up on other newly-elected members of the U.S. House. Mink has been in Congress since late September, serving the remaining months of the term of Daniel Akaka. Akaka gave up his seat to succeed Sen. Spark Matsunaga, who died last April. Tuesday, Mink defeated Republican Andy Poepoe for a two-year term. Actually Mink is no stranger to Congress. She served from 1964 to 1976, when was defeated by Matsunaga in the Democratic primary for the U.S. Senate. Since then, Mink has served as an assistant secretary of state in the Carter administration and four years on the Honolulu City Council, and has made unsuccessful bids for governor and mayor of Honolulu. ---
DOC.HEAD: Candidate Found Nude in Store in 1978 Defeated
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer who was found nude in a drug store in 1978 lost his bid for a circuit court judgeship. Richard Hopewell failed Tuesday to unseat Circuit Judge Gene Paul Kean. Last month, Hopewell admitted that he was found nude in a drug store 12 years ago. He said someone drugged him without his knowledge. Also, a state bar panel said Hopewell made unethical statements about Kean during the campaign. Hopewell could be censured, suspended, removed or retired by the state Supreme Court because of the statements. ---
DOC.HEAD: Heart Transplant Patient Votes in Hospital, Then Dies
DOC.TEXT: An ailing heart transplant patient who insisted on voting died two hours after casting a ballot from his hospital bed. J.D. Livingston, 65, ``never willingly missed an election,'' said Lucille Livingston-Fricker of Costa Mesa, one of his three daughters. She said if the story of Livingston's death ``gets one more person out there to vote, my dad will be happy.'' Livingston, a retired real estate developer and dairyman from the Sun Valley section of Los Angeles, signed his absentee ballot at noon Tuesday in his room at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He went into cardiac arrest 30 minutes later and died, said another daughter, Aneta Adams of Bakersfield. Before he died, ``he said it's so valuable to be an American and be able to vote,'' she added. ---
DOC.HEAD: Woman Criticized by Father Loses
DOC.TEXT: A candidate whose father publicly opposed her bid for the state legislature lost to the incumbent. Cliessa Nagle's father sent letters to suburban Philadelphia newspapers criticizing his daughter's stand on abortion and claiming she exaggerated her credentials as an account, a charge her employer refuted. Nagle, 31, is an abortion rights advocate. The Democrat lost to Republican state Rep. Robert Godshall, who voted for the state's abortion law. Nagle said she and her father had been estranged for 14 years. ---
DOC.HEAD: Florida Supreme Court Justice Retained in Abortion Fight
DOC.TEXT: Abortion opponents failed in their attempt to oust the chief justice of the Florida Supreme Court. Voters supported Justice Leander Shaw in a retention election Tuesday. Shaw overcame opposition from nti-abortion and crime groups upset with decisions he wrote. Florida Right to Life was angry about an opinion overturning a law requring minors to get parental permission for abortions. Shaw said the groups wanted to set a national example. ``If they could have toppled me, I think they would take my scalp around the nation and say, `Look what we did in Florida,''' Shaw said.

DOC.HEAD: All in the Political Family
Chiles Wins But Son Loses
DOC.TEXT: Lawton Chiles' coattails failed to help son Ed Chiles win a seat in the Florida Senate. Lawton Chiles was elected governor, but his son lost in Senate District 24 on the state's southwest coast to businessman John McKay. ``I feel like a winner,'' said Ed Chiles, like his father, a Democrat. ``I just don't feel like a loser.'' He said he was pleased with the 48 percent of the vote he received in the heavily Republican district. Ed Chiles, a restaurant owner from Holmes Beach, said he may not be coming to Tallahassee as a senator, but plans to visit the governor's mansion. ---
DOC.HEAD: Sen. Chafee's Son Loses Warwick Mayoral Bid
DOC.TEXT: The famous Chafee name wasn't enough to sway voters. They turned down a bid by Sen. John H. Chafee's son to be mayor. Lincoln D. Chafee lost in a three-way race to Democrat Charles Donovan. Chafee, the city's only Republican councilman, blamed his defeat on the state's economic problems that led to a Democratic sweep of most major offices. During the campaign, he tried to play down his father's influence, but acknowledged that it was a ``big, big help.'' Chafee, 37, who quit his job as a planner at Electric Boat so he could campaign full time, said he did not know what he would do now. ---
DOC.HEAD: Taft Name a Winner
DOC.TEXT: A member of the political Taft family won a statewide election for the first time in 20 years. Robert Taft II was elected Ohio secretary of state Tuesday. Taft defeated Democratic incumbent Sherrod Brown, who was seeking his third four-year term. The 48-year-old Hamilton County commissioner in Cincinnati had campaigned for the governor's office but dropped out before the filing deadline at the urging of Republican Party officials. Taft's victory came 20 years after his father, Robert Jr., was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1970 after three terms in the U.S. House. He was defeated in a re-election bid in 1976. Taft's grandfather, Robert A., was known as ``Mr. Republican'' while serving in the Senate. His great-grandfather, William Howard Taft, was president from 1909 to 1913 and then became Supreme Court chief justice. ---
DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker's Wife Fails to Take Over His Seat
DOC.TEXT: Pamela McWilliams wanted her husband's job. But the voters said no, preferring to keep the eastern Texas House district in the hands of a Democrat. They gave her husband's seat to Paul Sadler. Mrs. McWilliams, unlike her husband, Jim, is a Republican. ---
DOC.HEAD: Another Udall Wins New Mexico Post
DOC.TEXT: Tom Udall is following his father and uncle into public office - but in another state. Udall, a Democrat, won the New Mexico attorney general race on Tuesday, defeating Republican Bill Davis. Udall is a two-time loser for a New Mexico congressional seat. Udall, 42, is the son of former Arizona congressman and Interior Secretary Stewart Udall and the nephew of Arizona congressman Morris Udall. ``I'm excited about being in public office for the first time,'' Udall said. ``I think it's a great challenge.''

DOC.HEAD: Akaka Wins Senate Seat in Democratic Sweep in Hawaii
DOC.TEXT: Interim Sen. Daniel Akaka, persuading voters that influence in the Democratic majority was more valuable than access to President Bush, beat GOP Congresswoman Patricia Saiki in the U.S. Senate race. Akaka will serve the four years remaining in the term of Democratic Sen. Spark Matsunaga, who died in April. Democrats, long dominant in Hawaii, now hold all four seats in the state's U.S. congressional delegation. Democratic Gov. John Waihee was also re-elected. Former interim Rep. Neil Abercrombie and interim Rep. Patsy Mink, both Democrats, won the two U.S. House seats. With 97 percent of precincts reporting, Akaka had 113,859 votes, or 55 percent, to Saiki's 90,413, or 44 percent. With 72 percent of the precincts reporting, Abercrombie had 34,463 votes, or 58 percent, to Republican state Sen. Mike Liu's 24,459, or 42 percent. With 56 percent of the precincts reporting, Mink had 70,043 votes, or 67 percent, to Republican Andy Poepoe's 31,228, or 30 percent. With 97 percent of the precincts reporting, Waihee had 123,480 votes, or 62 percent, to Republican challenger Fred Hemmings' 74,354, or 38 percent. Akaka was appointed to the Senate seat and Mink won a special election to finish out his term. Saiki resigned her House seat to run for the Senate. Akaka, a Congressman for 14 years before joining the Senate, stressed his part in the Democratic majority, while Saiki cited her ties to Bush and urged voters in this heavily Democratic state to cross over.

DOC.HEAD: New Hampshire Republicans Easily Capture Senate, Governor Elections
DOC.TEXT: Republican Rep. Bob Smith hailed his election to the U.S. Senate as a victory for fiscal responsibility and common sense. Smith, who campaigned on a platform of financial tight-fistedness, trounced former U.S. Sen. John Durkin by a margin of more than 2-1 Tuesday, while Republican Gov. Judd Gregg also coasted to an easy victory over his Democratic opponent, Joe Grandmaison. In the Senate race, Smith had 183,960 votes, or 67 percent, to Durkin's 88,574 votes, or 33 percent, with 98 percent counted. ``This victory reaffirms my belief that the people of New Hampshire want spending cuts, they want fiscal responsibility and they want this federal deficit reduced, and indeed eliminated,'' Smith said. With 98 percent of precincts counted in the governor's race, Gregg had 172,886 votes, 64 percent, to 99,014, 36 percent, for Grandmaison. Durkin, a senator from 1975-80, focused his campaign on Smith's acceptance of more than $500,000 in campaign contributions from political action committees. But he wound up apologizing for using the racial slur ``Japs'' in attacking a $350,000 ad campaign against him that was funded by a Japanaese automobile PAC. In other races, retiring U.S. Sen Gordon Humphrey won a seat in the state Senate and innkeeper Bill Zeliff, a Republican and protege of former Gov. John Sununu, won Smith's open House seat. Dick Swett, 33, an architect and political newcomer, became the first Democrat elected in the 2nd Congressional District since former President Theodore Roosevelt split the GOP vote with his ``Bull Moose'' party in 1912. Swett defeated freshman Republican Chuck Douglas 75,802 votes, 53 percent, to 66,764, 47 percent, with all votes counted.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Wally Hickel reclaimed the statehouse Tuesday in a three-way race in which he ran as an independent. Hickel defeated Republican Arliss Sturgulewski, a veteran state senator, and Democrat Tony Knowles, a former Anchorage mayor.

DOC.HEAD: Peacetime Army Healthy Alternative to Civilian Life, Study Suggests
DOC.TEXT: If you can stay out of battle, the Army can be a pretty healthy way of life. Military researchers found that soldiers died at half the rate of their civilian counterparts during the peacetime year of 1986. The lead researcher, Joseph M. Rothberg, a mathematician in military psychiatry at Walter Reed Army Institute of Research, said the most important factor in the difference is the screening of Army enlistees, all of whom are volunteers, have high school degrees and are healthy enough to pass a physical. The Army also provides housing, food, meaningful work and ``lots of fresh air and exercise,'' as well as controlling substance abuse and regulating firearms, Rothberg said in a telephone interview Tuesday from Bethesda, Md. Further study is needed to determine how much of a contribution to longevity is made by exercise and by recently introduced Army programs in nutrition, smoking reduction and stress reduction, the reserachers said. The researchers compared death rates among all 781,000 Army troops and civilian counterparts of the same age, race and sex in 1986. The study, reported in today's Journal of the American Medical Association, did not give actual death rates. But Rothberg said in an interview that soldiers overall died at a rate of 109 per 100,000, while comparable civilians died at a rate of 215 per 100,000. Sam Sarkesian, a political science professor at Loyola University in Chicago, objected that figures from a peacetime yaer like 1986 fail to reflect the dangers of serving a nation that goes to war about every 10 years. He added that being a soldier still means ``you have to be ready to give up your life.'' Even in non-war years, military personnel die violently, such as in the 1983 Beirut bombing, when 237 were killed; in the 1985 Gander, Newfoundland, plane crash, when 248 died, and in the 1989 Panama invasion, when 23 died. ``From 1945 on, if you'd put all those together and compare it to the equivalent in civilian life, I think you'd get a totally different picture,'' Sarkesian said. In the military study, the greatest disparity in death rates involved homicides, which were almost six times less common among soldiers. Deaths by disease or suicide were also lower. The most striking difference was among black men, who died in homicides almost 12 times less often in the Army than in the population at large. The homicide rate among black male soldiers was nine per 100,000, compared with 100 per 100,000 for black male civilians, Rothberg said. Army women, who make up 10.2 percent of soldiers, died at about three-quarters the rate of civilian women of the same age overall. Black women soldiers died at 39 percent the rate of comparable civilians. But white women soldiers died at 139 percent the rate of white women civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Gore Looks at '92 Presidency; McWherter Also Wins
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Albert Gore Jr. says his landslide re-election has him thinking about another run for the Democratic presidential nomination. Democratic Gov. Ned McWherter and all nine incumbent U.S. representatives - three Republicans and six Democrats - also were re-elected. Among those returned to the U.S. House was Democrat Harold Ford, who is under indictment on charges he sold political influence to two crooked bankers. ``Now that it's over, I'll sit down and think about running, but I don't have any plans,'' said Gore, who sought the nomination in 1988. ``I haven't ruled it out at all.'' With 100 percent of precincts reporting, Gore had 528,196 votes, or 68 percent, to Republican William Hawkins' 229,792, or 30 percent. Hawkins, a freelance writer, did almost no campaigning. Also with 100 percent reporting, McWherter had 474,653 votes, or 61 percent, to Republican Dwight Henry's 286,694, or 37 percent. The GOP's heavy funding of state legislative races paid off, apparently netting them the largest number of Senate seats in state history. Two races were still undecided early today, but it appeared there would be 19 Democrats and 14 Republicans in the state Senate. In the House, Republicans won six seats from Democrats, but lost five that had been held by the GOP.

DOC.HEAD: Hickel Finds Following on Fourth Comeback Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Wally Hickel has tried to get back to the governor's mansion ever since he moved out in mid-term more than two decades ago. On his fourth long-shot attempt, he succeeded. Entering the race just hours before the deadline on a third-party ticket, the conservative Hickel was condemned by some Republicans as a spoiler. But the self-described ``independent Republican'' attracted a following that by late October had pushed him ahead of his Republican and Democratic rivals in the polls. Hickel, 71, had to attract support from a large percentage of voters who were children or not even born when he was at his political zenith. While his campaign slogan was ``For a Bright Future,'' Hickel often cited achievements from two decades ago and spoke longingly of restoring Alaska's ``lost spirit.'' Hickel associates call him an energetic man of limitless optimism and belief in his own abilities. ``I'm not one to study things to death,'' he said. ``I get things done.'' He arrived in Anchorage in late 1940, a boxer from Kansas with 37 cents in his pocket, as he tells it. He went on to make a fortune in construction and real estate, and his holdings now include hotels and shopping centers. In 1966, Hickel defeated Democratic Gov. Bill Egan to become Alaska's second governor. During his two years in Juneau he approved construction of an ice road from Fairbanks to Prudhoe Bay that allowed expanded oil exploration on Alaska's North Slope. When summer turned the road to mud, it became known as ``Hickel's Ditch.'' President Nixon called Hickel to Washington, D.C., as Interior Secretary in 1968, three days before the Santa Barbara oil spill. After initial criticism, Hickel won praise for writing regulations to control offshore drilling and make the oil industry financially liable for well blowouts. Nixon fired Hickel in 1970 in response, Hickel says, to industry pressure. Hickel also had written Nixon a letter chiding him for failing to listen to America's youth protesting the Vietnam war. In 1974, Hickel ran for governor but lost the GOP primary to Jay Hammond. He tried again in 1978 and lost to Hammond by 98 votes. Hickel then ran a write-in campaign as an independent in the general election and lost. In 1986, Hickel ran again but lost the Republican primary to Arliss Sturgulewski. Hickel supporters promoted him as a write-in candidate in the general election; he got less than 3 percent of the vote. This year, Hickel headed the Alaskan Independence Party ticket. His campaign stressed independence from the federal government, reduced state spending and protecting the family. Hickel is married and has six grown children.

DOC.HEAD: Hickel Reclaims Governor's Seat in Alaska
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Walter Hickel, a tough-talking conservative, swept past the two major party candidates to recapture the statehouse as an independent. ``I think Alaskans just want a change - they want to have more of a say in government,'' Hickel said after voting Tuesday. ``It's sort of an anti-government feeling out there.'' Republican Sen. Ted Stevens had no trouble defeating Democratic businessman Michael Beasley. With 83 percent of the vote counted, Hickel had 46,799 votes, or 38 percent, to 39,150, or 32 percent, for Democrat Tony Knowles. Republican Arliss Sturgulewski was third with 31,649 votes, or 26 percent. With 83 percent of the precincts reporting in the Senate race, Stevens had 78,941, or 66 percent, to 38,615, or 32 percent for Beasley. Alaskans also approved a referendum making the private use of marijuana a crime once again. With 89 percent of the precincts reporting, the measure passed by 75,829 votes, or 55 percent, to 62,942, or 45 votes. Hickel, 71, is a longtime Republican who was elected the state's second governor in 1966. He entered the race just six weeks ago on the Alaskan Independence Party ticket and quickly passed the major party candidates in the polls. His victory is believed to mark the first time in American history that two independent governors have been elected at the same time. Former Connecticut Sen. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. was elected governor there Tuesday as an independent. ``Those people that voted for us, thank God. Those people that didn't, we'll welcome them. Let's build a great Alaska,'' Hickel said in a victory speech. Sturgulewski she her campaign was hurt by Hickel's entry into the race. ``I feel we've run a wonderful campaign with wonderful people around the state,'' she said. ``But I do think it's unfortunate that we had someone come in at the last minute with a lot of money and who's not subject to public scrutiny.'' Hickel supporters said he offered the only conservative alternative to the moderate Sturgulewski and to Knowles.

DOC.HEAD: MOSCOW: of people.
DOC.TEXT: Vozianov said no one appeared to have been hit by the shots. He said he was standing 10 yards away from the gunman. The man carried a shortened, double-barrelled hunting rifle and was marching as part of a delegation from the Bauman region of Moscow that marched through Red Square as part of the pro-Communist demonstration, the TV correspondent said. Moscow police and KGB spokesmen could not immediately confirm the report. Cable News Network said without attribution that the man was immediately arrested. It was the most dramatic and dangerous incident falling on the Soviet Union's most important holiday, celebrating the 73rd anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution. Thousands of anti-Communist demonstrators filled Moscow streets, already packed with Communist supporters.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Generally Reject Tax Changes
DOC.TEXT: In a nation of people who complain about taxes, a funny thing happened Tuesday when voters got a chance to change the laws. Mostly, they didn't. Down went a $2.6 billion tax rollback in Massachusetts, which would have been the largest voter-initiated state tax cut in the nation's history. Down went a 2 percent limit on annual state and local budget increases in Nebraska. Montanans refused to scrap their state income, property and sales taxes in favor of a ``transaction charge'' of 1 percent on all financial dealings. Neither backers nor opponents seemed sure whether it would have raised or lowered taxes. And Colorado voters narrowly rejected a measure requiring voter approval for any state or local tax increase. A similar proposal was soundly defeated in 1988. An exception to the trend appeared in Oregon, which passed a limit on property taxes of 1.5 percent of assessed value. The measure would cut property taxes by almost 50 percent. In unofficial returns today from 82 percent of the precincts, 52 percent voted for the Oregon measure. Don McIntire, chief proponent of the new limit, said he thinks Oregonians are frustrated with state government's inability to tackle the property tax question. ``People are realizing the political system is paralyzed,'' McIntire said. ``They (state leaders) just can't deal with this subject responsibly.'' But John Marshall of the Oregon School Boards Association warned that school programs face ``major amputation'' as a result of the vote. The Massachusetts measure would have shrunk state taxes and fees to 1988 levels. It would have slashed $1.3 billion from the state budget in the second half of the current fiscal year and $2.6 billion in the fiscal year starting next July. The state's current budget is $13.4 billion. It also would have rescinded recent increases in the state income, sales and gas taxes. Opponents had charged that the cuts would hamper such state services as day care, elderly programs, and police and firefighter training. Officials said the measure could shut down college campuses and bankrupt some school districts. One political analyst said the tax rollback was too dramatic, even for the frustrated and cash-strapped Massachusetts electorate. ``They wanted change but (the petition) went too far,'' said University of Massachusetts political scientist Paul Watanabe. James Braude, the leading opponent of the initiative, said, ``After a decade in which the public was told to feel good in the Reagan years, and to feel angry by talk show hosts, the voters decided to speak for themselves and recognize reality.'' Californians rejected two measures that would have increased the state tax on alcohol. In Utah, voters refused to abolish the state sales tax on food. Although Montanans preserved their income, property and sales taxes, they decided in another vote to put the lid on. They snuffed out a measure to boost the state cigarette tax 140 percent to 43 cents a pack, the highest in the nation - a device that had been expected to cut tobacco consumption.

DOC.HEAD: Wilson Clings to Narrow Lead for California Governor
DOC.TEXT: Republican Pete Wilson clung to a narrow lead over Democrat Dianne Feinstein early today in the California governor's race, and the Big Green environmental initiative was defeated. A proposal that would throw every current member of the state Legislature out of office before the decade's end led by a narrow majority, and two propositions to raise alcohol taxes lost by substantial margins. Wilson, a U.S. senator, led Feinstein, a former San Francisco mayor, by about 58,000 votes out of 5.8 million counted. Some 2 million more votes, including about 500,000 absentee ballots, still remained to be counted. With 87 percent of California's 26,060 precincts reporting, Wilson led Feinstein, 2,953,854 to 2,896,178, or 48 percent to 47 percent. Minor party candidates divided the remainder. Proposition 128, dubbed the Big Green initiative, trailed with 35 percent voting yes and 65 percent no. Penny-a-drink and nickel-a-drink alcohol tax propositions were both defeated; 58 percent opposed the former and 69 percent the latter. A strong anti-tax, anti-spending tide swept through other ballot measures. Twelve of 14 bond statewide bond issues and seven of 12 county sales tax hike proposals were trailing. Three of four Santa Clara County proposals to raise local utilities taxes to finance a stadium to lure baseball's San Francisco Giants to Santa Clara also were trailing. Proposition 140, the more drastic of the two anti-incumbent term limit initiatives on the Tuesday ballot, was leading with 52 percent of the vote, and the more moderate Proposition 131 term limits initiative was defeated by a 3-2 margin. With 82 percent of the votes counted in the hotly contested race for attorney general, Democrat Arlo Smith led Republican Dan Lungren, 2,627,123 to 2,509,998, or 48 percent to 45 percent. Incumbent Democratic Lt. Gov. Leo McCarthy defeated Republican state Sen. Marian Bergeson, 3,008,556 to 2,325,391, or 53 percent to 41 percent. A key issue in the race for governor was which party would occupy the office when new congressional and legislative district lines for 1992 are drawn. That's when California's congressional delegation expands from the current 45 to 52 or more seats. Democrats have controlled the Legislature for 20 years, and Republicans felt their only hope to prevent a Democratic gerrymander of those districts was the threat of a GOP governor's veto. Big Green was a sweeping plan to phase out cancer-causing pesticides, ban chemicals that harm the ozone, and reduce emissions of gases that contribute to global warming. It was supported by every major environmental group in the state, but was opposed by water, timber, agricultural and manufacturing groups and tracked closely by business groups nationwide as another potential California trend-setting political movement.

DOC.HEAD: Arkansas Voters Re-Elect Democratic Incumbent Governor
DOC.TEXT: Voters rejected Republican challenger Sheffield Nelson's campaign argument that 10 years was enough and re-elected Democratic Gov. Bill Clinton to a fifth term. In the U.S. Senate race, incumbent Democrat David Pryor easily turned back his independent write-in opponent. Pryor has been a senator since 1979. Anti-incumbent sentiment wasn't much in evidence in Arkansas congressional races either. Office-holders were easy winners in three congressional districts, and a former congressman was elected in a fourth district. With 94 percent of precincts reporting, Clinton had 368,610 votes, or 57 percent. Nelson had 275,056 votes, or 43 percent. The incumbent did surprisingly well in several Republican-dominated counties. ``I have been astonished with the votes in western Arkansas in those big Republican counties,'' Clinton said. ``They just had us outmanned,'' Nelson said. ``I don't think it would have made any difference who was against him.'' The win gives Clinton another four-year term, which if completed would make him the state's longest-serving governor at 14 years. Orval Faubus served 12 years. In the Senate race with 89 percent of precints reporting, Pryor had 393,265 votes, or 99 percent. Independent write-in candidate Betty White had 2,755 votes.
