Voters also passed a bill to strip from the state's constitution a relic of its racist past. Amendment 3, which would repeal a 1956 anti-desegregation statute, passed with 51 percent of the vote.

DOC.HEAD: Devout Moslem Alleged Assassin
With PM-Kahane Assassination, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Neighbors described the alleged assassin of Rabbi Meir Kahane as a devout Moslem who showed no interest in Arab political activity. ``It's a surprise to us, to everybody,'' said Debra Ragab, 39, of Jersey City, N.J., where the suspect, El-Sayyid A. Nosair, a 34-year-old Egyption immigrant who repaired air conditioners for the city of New York, lived until recently. The FBI, New York City and Bergen County police on Tuesday removed a file cabinet, several boxes and a target drawn on sheetrock from Nosair's house in Cliffside, N.J., where he has lived for the past six months, authorities said. Nosair, who was charged with murder, was in serious condition today at Bellevue Hospital. He was shot while fleeing the scene of Kahane's shooting. Kahane, an anti-Arab extremist whose political party was outlawed as racist in Israel, was shot to death Monday night after a speech to a Zionist group at a New York City hotel. He was the founder of the radical Jewish Defense League. Ragab, who grew up with Nosair's American wife in Pennsylvania, said Caren Nosair called her after hearing about the shooting on the news. ``She's devastated,'' said Ragab. ``She had no idea this was going to happen. ... She doesn't know what happened, why it happened.'' Born in Port Said, Egypt, Nosair entered ,146 votes, or 13 percent. In the Senate race, Hatfield captured 466,551 votes, or 53 percent, to Lonsdale's 407,691, or 47 percent. Republican Rep. Denny Smith was defeated by Democrat Mike Kopetski in his bid for a sixth term in Congress. Voters rejected measures to close the Trojan nuclear plant in northwestern Oregon and give tax credits to parents who send their children to private schools. They approved a measure to limit property taxes to 1.5 percent of assessed value. Democrats retained their majority in the state Senate, but appeared to be losing control of the House. Unofficial results indicated Republicans would control the House 32-28. Lonsdale, who largely bankrolled his own campaign, had led in some October polls after criticizing Hatfield as a Washington insider who had allowed overcutting of Oregon's old growth forests. But Hatfield, who has never lost an election since voters first sent him to the Oregon Legislature in 1950, launched a strong counterattack on Lonsdale in the final weeks of the campaign. ``In the last few weeks we've been tough as nails when we had to be, but we were always truthful,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Single Digits in Northern Plains; Snow in Northern Michigan
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures dipped into single digits in the northern Plains early today and snow fell in northern Michigan. Sunshine and cool weather were the forecast for most of the nation, with only the Great Lakes, Southwest and Pacific Northwest looking for precipitation. Cold air was expected to bring showers to the Great Lakes. Rain and sleet were predicted for the Texas Panhandle and New Mexico. Snow was expected in the mountains of New Mexico, and snow and high winds were the forecast in Arizona. Showers were predicted for Washington state and Idaho. Temperatures were expected to reach the 30s in the central Plains and regions looking for snow, the 40s in New England, the northern Plains and the Pacific Northwest, the 50s in the Middle Atlantic states and the Ohio Valley, the 60s in the Mississippi Valley, the 70s in the Southeast and Northern California and the 80s in Southern California. Four Florida cities tied at 87 degrees for Tuesday's high temperature in the nation: Fort Myers, Lakeland, Miami and West Palm Beach. Other reports at 5 a.m. EST: -East: Albany, N.Y., 35 fair; Atlanta 45 fair; Boston 43 fair; Buffalo 37 cloudy; Charleston, S.C., 51 fair; Chattanooga 36 fair; Cincinnati 33 foggy; Cleveland 40 cloudy; Detroit 37 cloudy; Hatteras 60 fair; Jacksonville 48 foggy; Key West 71 fair; Knoxville 37 foggy; Macon 42 foggy; Miami 69 fair; New York 43 fair; Philadelphia 38 fair; Pittsburgh 30 fair; Portland, Maine, 33 fair; Richmond 37 fair; Tampa 62 partly cloudy; Washington, D.C., 40 fair. -Central: Birmingham 40 fair; Bismarck 13 fair; Chicago 37 cloudy; Denver 15 partly cloudy; Des Moines 22 fair; Fort Worth 53 partly cloudy; Indianapolis 38 cloudy; Kansas City 34 cloudy; Little Rock 41 fair; Louisville 36 fair; Memphis 42 fair; Nashville 39 partly cloudy; New Orleans 41 foggy; North Platte 09 fair; Oklahoma City 40 windy; Omaha 17 fair; Rapid City 14 fair; St. Louis 43 cloudy; Minneapolis-St. Paul 22 fair; Sault Ste. Marie 32 snow; San Antonio 63 cloudy. -West: Albuquerque 33 windy; Anchorage 13 windy; Boise 28 fair; Casper 03 fair; Fairbanks 02 partly cloudy; Great Falls 27 windy; Honolulu 78 fair; Las Vegas 48 fair; Los Angeles 64 fair; Medford 35 partly cloudy; Pendleton 41 cloudy; Phoenix 55 fair; Portland, Ore., 45 rain; Reno 27 fair; Salt Lake City 29 fair; San Diego 57 fair; San Francisco 58 fair; Seattle 45 rain; Spokane 33 cloudy. -International: Calgary 41 windy; Montreal 32 cloudy; Ottawa 27 partly cloudy; Regina 14 fair; Toronto 36 cloudy; Winnipeg 10 fair; Merida 77 fair; San Juan 73 fair.

DOC.HEAD: Strom Thurmond Re-elected to Senate From South Carolina
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Strom Thurmond and Gov. Carroll Campbell were easily re-elected, but upset victories by two other Republicans had state GOP officials rejoicing today. ``Yesterday was a historic day for the Republican Party,'' said Tony Denny, executive director of the South Carolina Republican party. Thurmond, 87, the Senate's oldest member, easily beat back a challenge by Democrat Robert Cunningham, while Campbell trounced state Sen. Theo Mitchell to win a second term. Republican Barbara Nielsen won an upset victory over Education Superintendent Charlie Williams, a 12-year incumbent, and Jim Miles ousted three-term Democratic Secretary of State John Campbell. Overall, however, Democrats held their more than 2-1 edge in the state House, which had 48 of its 124 seats up for re-election. Only three of the 40 incumbent state House members lost re-election bids. Thurmond, first elected to the U.S. Senate in 1954, had 473,097 votes, or 66 percent, to 240,453 votes, or 34 percent, for Robert Cunningham, a retired CIA official, with 98 percent of the precincts reporting. Campbell got 495,876 votes, or 70 percent, to 197,107, or 28 percent, for Mitchell, who was trying to become the state's first black governor. He pledged to use the mandate to push for government reforms during his second four-year term. ``As far as I'm concerned, it's an overwhelming victory,'' Campbell said. ``It's certainly more than we anticipated that we might have gotten.''

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Make Gains in Post-Dukakis Massachusetts
DOC.TEXT: Vanquished gubernatorial hopeful John Silber said voters weren't angry with his blunt remarks but with incumbent Gov. Michael Dukakis when they chose their first Republican governor in 20 years. Voters in overwhelmingly Democratic Massachusetts preferred mild-mannered former federal prosecutor William Weld to Silber, a Democrat but conservative in many ways, by 51 percent to 49 percent on Tuesday. Silber, whose fiery nature had become a major issue in the race, blamed his defeat on the withering of the Massachusetts economic ``miracle'' that Dukakis had touted during his futile presidential bid in 1988. ``I think there was a very anti-Democratic spirit running in this state,'' said Silber. With 90 percent of precincts reporting, Weld had 1,027,184 votes to Silber's 972,050. But Democrats won other closely watched races: Sen. John Kerry, a former lieutenant governor under Dukakis, won a second term solidly, as did U.S. Rep. Barney Frank, reprimanded by the House earlier this year for his activities with a male prostitute. Voters elected a Republican state treasurer, Joe Malone, to succeed Democrat Robert Q. Crane, retiring after 26 years. And the state's sole GOP congressman, Silvio Conte, won re-election easily. But none of six Democratic congressmen in contested races was repudiated. Four other Democratic incumbents ran unopposed. In the Senate race, with 90 percent of precincts reporting, Kerry had 1,155,686 votes, or 57 percent, to 866,828 votes, or 43 percent, for James Rappaport, a Republican mutimillionaire businessman. ``Twenty-five years ago some of us my age jumped around to a song with the title `Money Can't Buy Me Love' and today in Massachusetts we have proven that money can't buy you a United States Senate seat,'' Kerry said in his victory speech. The results of the governor's race buoyed state Republicans, outnumbered 3-1 by Democrats among registered voters. There are several thousand more independents than Democrats, however. By a 3-2 margin, voters rejected a $1.2 billion tax rollback that Weld had supported and Silber opposed. ``I don't believe government should be in the miracle business. I believe government should do a very few things, but do them well,'' Weld said. During his primary campaign, Silber, on leave as Boston University president, uttered a series of blunt statements - dubbed ``Silber shockers'' - on women, immigrants and welfare mothers. His tone was quieter in the general election campaign, though he tried to attack Weld's image as a wealthy descendant of Boston's old ruling class. Weld replied that Silber lacked the temperament to govern. Silber frequently complained he was quoted out of context. Both candidates tried to appeal to both right and left. Weld, 45, a former U.S. attorney for Massachusetts, stressed his progressive views on social issues, including abortion, and conservative fiscal beliefs. Silber, 64, a philosophy scholar from Texas and BU president since 1970, acknowledged voting for President Bush over Dukakis in 1988 and blamed Dukakis for the state's fiscal mess.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Re-Elect Dorgan, Reject Gambling Initiatives
DOC.TEXT: North Dakota's newly elected labor commissioner was the first Republican to snatch an office from a Democrat since 1980, but the Republican challenger to U.S. Rep. Byron Dorgan couldn't accomplish that feat. Dorgan, first elected to the House in 1980, has regularly rolled up more than 70 percent of the vote against Republican challengers. He beat Ed Schafer Tuesday to win his sixth term. With 96 percent of precincts reporting, Dorgan had 142,268 votes, or 65 percent, to Schafer's 76,083, or 35 percent. Voters rejected eight ballot measures, including an initiative to make insurance rebating legal and three proposals to allow privately run gambling for the first time in state history. In state office races, Craig Hagen also made history as North Dakota's youngest labor commissioner. He is 25, the legal minimum for the office. Hagen succeeds Democrat Byron Knutson, who failed to qualify in the June primary to run for a second term. Hagen defeated S.F. ``Buckshot'' Hoffner, 66, a former state legislator.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Condemn Assassination, Despite Political Differences
With PM-Kahane Assassination, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jewish leaders condemned the assassination of Rabbi Meir Kahane while taking pains to distance themselves from his extreme anti-Arab views and support of violence. ``We always condemned Kahane and the anti-Arab racist views he espoused,'' said Arden E. Shenker, head of the National Jewish Community Relations Advisory Council. ``We nevertheless are shocked by this cold act of political violence.'' Kahane, founder of the radical Jewish Defense League and a former member of Israel's Parliament, was shot to death Monday after a speech to a Zionist group at a New York hotel. His alleged assassin, a naturalized Egyptian, was shot and wounded. Followers of Kahane vowed revenge on Tuesday. Arab spokesmen and mainstream Jewish leaders counseled against further violence. ``I hope this is just hyperbole, more rhetoric,'' Dr. M.T. Mehdi, president of the American-Arab Relations Committee, said of the threats of reprisals. ``This is not the time to be speaking of revenge,'' said Rabbi Marc D. Angel, president of the Rabbinical Council of America. ``It is the time to be speaking of peace and reconciliation. This cycle of violence must be ended.'' Mehdi said he had debated Kahane numerous times and found him to be honest, courageous and decent - despite Mehdi's beating by JDL members in 1974. ``We disagreed 100 percent with his basic assumptions, which was that God has given Palestine to the Jews,'' he said. ``But now I feel the attack upon him is not only an attack upon Rabbi Meir Kahane, but also an attack on the First Amendment.'' ``It is an endeavor to shut up a voice, a disagreeable voice,'' Mehdi said, ``and we have condemned the alleged assassin, whoever he is.'' Zaheer Uddin, president of the New York unit of the Islamic Circle of North America, condemned the assassination and said, ``We hope that it will be the last act in the cycle of violence and counterviolence.'' Sholom D. Comay, president of the American Jewish Committee, said, ``Despite our considerable differences, Meir Kahane must always be remembered for the slogan `Never Again,' which for so many became the battle cry of post-Holocaust Jewry.''

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Movement Suffers Blow with `Big Green' Defeat
DOC.TEXT: The environmental movement suffered a blow at the polls on Tuesday, led by the firm defeat of California's sweeping ``Big Green'' initiative. ``Big Green'' would have stiffened regulation of emissions, pesticides, offshore oil-drilling and logging. It trailed by a margin of about 2 to 1 as late results came in early today. California voters also appeared to be rejecting environmentalists' Proposition 130, ``Forests Forever,'' a ban on clear-cutting of forests. Two industry countermeasures to ``Big Green'' and ``Forests Forever'' were soundly rejected. From the Pacific Northwest to Missouri to New York, other environmentalist-backed measures also were voted down. ``Big Green'' would have provided $300 million in bond funds to buy and preserve ancient redwood forests, tried to slow global warming by curbing auto and other emissions, banned oil development in state waters, and barred pesticides suspected of causing cancer. It would also have created an elected post of environmental czar. ``I don't think that anybody who voted against `Big Green' voted for polluted air or cancer-causing chemicals,'' Sierra Club official Bob Hattoy said. Voters apparently were swayed by broadcast commercials paid for by oil and chemical companies, he said. California Attorney General John Van de Kamp, a primary sponsor of the measure, said voters were conservative when it came to spending money on new programs because ``of a confluence of events.'' ``I think the invasion of Kuwait, the beginning of the recession, the national budget crisis, the state budget crisis - all those things have scared people,'' he said. Proponents, who spent $4.5 million to boost the initiative, said it would have saved Californians several billion dollars a year in energy and health costs. Corporations, including major oil companies based outside the state, spent $10 million in a campaign condemning the measure as a potential economic disaster. Foes said the controls would have increased gas, electricity and food prices while falling short of environmental cleanup goals. Elsewhere, two environmental measures did pass. South Dakotans approved an initiative requiring legislative approval for large-scale garbage dumps. And Arizonans voted to spend $20 million a year in state lottery receipts on wildlife habitat protection, parks, trails and other environmental endeavors. But these environmental measures were defeated: -A Washington initiative to create regional boards to oversee and enforce land-use planning at the local and regional levels. -An Oregon initiative to require recycling standards for all food and product packaging. -A Missouri initiative to protect 52 natural waterways, mainly in the Ozarks, by banning new dams and restricting landfills and dumping, septic tanks and structures near the waterways. -A limitation on large-scale gold or silver mining in the Black Hills of South Dakota. -A $1.975 billion bond issue in New York to be used for environmental protection.

DOC.HEAD: 50 Saudi Women Detained In Pro-Driving Protest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with police detaining, then freeing the women. Pickup 14th graf `The driving ...' ^With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Police early today released about 50 Saudi women they detained for a daring protest - driving their normally chauffered cars around Riyadh to demand that they be given the right to take the wheel. The women, many supported by their husbands, called Tuesday's unprecedented protest a practical matter, saying any Saudi involvement in a Persian Gulf war could leave them without male drivers for their luxury sedans. ``This has nothing whatsoever to do with politics,'' one said. ``If a crisis erupts, we must drive for the sake of our families. We cannot stay immobile like sitting ducks.'' The protest was a startling act of defiance in this conservative, male-dominated Moslem country. Under Saudi Arabia's strict Islamic code, women cannot drive, mingle with men in public or expose their skin to public view. Many women in the kingdom speculate, however, that Saudi Arabia could finally be ready to make some tentative first steps toward allowing women greater freedoms. They think the arrival of tens of thousands of women drivers among Kuwaiti refugees and in the U.S. military could help spur such change. Tuesday's women drivers, many of them completely veiled except for their eyes, piled into 15 cars and took a 30-minute drive through the capital. All the women who took part were experienced drivers, having learned the skill outside of Saudi Arabia. They included businesswomen, houswives and a woman who was eight months pregnant. They met in a supermarket parking lot and revved their engines in excitement just as the meuzzin's call signaled the end of the afternoon prayer. Husbands, brothers, and a crowd of Filipino drivers stood watching with open admiration. Passing motorists stared in disbelief as the women drove expertly down Riyadh's highways. Most of the women previously had only rode in the back seats of their cars, which usually are driven by foreign chaffeurs. Some people joined the convoy and pulled over to the side of the road after 30 minutes when the women were finally stopped by the police, who blocked observers trying to speak with the women. ``We don't know what will happen next,'' said a woman in one of the cars. ``This is just the first little bit of freedom.'' They parked in row alongside the road for several hours until the policemen drove the women's cars to a police station. The women said the episode ended at 4 a.m. today when they were all released to the custody of their relatives. ``We didn't like it, but there was no alternative,'' one woman said. Like others interviewed, she spoke on condition of anonymity. The women's closest male relatives were summoned to the station to witness as they signed a statement that the protest would not be repeated, participants in the demonstation said. The driving ban has been a topic of heated debate, with conservative citizens arguing that the Islamic prohibition against men and women mingling in public included women drivers. Others have pointed out that women were allowed to lead camels in the era of Prophet Mohammed, the founder of the Islamic faith, so modern women should be able to drive cars. Having a chauffeur, especially a foreigner, was a form of mingling with strange men, they point out. One informed source told AP that the women had written a letter to Riyadh governor Prince Salman bin Abdel-Aziz informing him that the ``drive-in'' protest would take place, but not revealing the date or place. With the onset of the Persian Gulf crisis, King Fahd had instituted a program opening the way for Saudi women to volunteer for nursing and first aid.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Republican Pete Wilson scraped past Democrat Dianne Feinstein to capture California's governor's seat, the biggest prize in Tuesday's elections. His victory gives the GOP an edge in next year's reapportionment battles, and could make a difference in as many as a dozen House seats.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Trounce Slow-Growth Initiative; Re-elect Incumbents
DOC.TEXT: Washington voters overwhelmingly rejected a sweeping environmental measure because they feared losing control over community issues, the proposals' opponents say. Proponents blamed ``scare tactics'' and foes' huge bankroll. All eight incumbent U.S. representatives - five Democrats and three Republicans - were re-elected Tuesday. House Speaker Tom Foley, a Spokane Democrat, retained his 5th District seat by a margin of more than 2-1. His protege, U.S. Rep. Jolene 5,
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This is another take in the running series.
DOC.TEXT: Here is a partial list of candidates who have won their races in the general election.
BULLETIN: (AP) - Wilson, GOP, elected Governor, California.

DOC.HEAD: Women Capture Three Governorships; Minority Results Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Feinstein losing to Wilson. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, Nebraska Gov.
DOC.TEXT: Jubilant feminists say Ann Richards' triumph in the hard-fought Texas gubernatorial race shatters a ``glass ceiling'' for women candidates. Joan Finney captured the governor's mansion in Kansas and Barbara Roberts triumphed in Oregon's statehouse race. But Dianne Feinstein lost a very close race in California and women went down to a string of senatorial defeats. Nebraska Gov. Kay Orr was losing to Democrat Ben Nelson in her re-election bid. The results were mixed, too, for black candidates. The most prominent, Democrat Harvey Gantt, suffered a stinging defeat at the hands of Sen. Jesse Helms in a racially charged contest in North Carolina. But in Connecticut, black conservative Garry Franks won election to the House, the first black Republican to serve there since Illinois' Oscar De Priest in 1935. Gantt, an architect and former mayor of Charlotte, saw his lead slip away against Helms' charges that the Democrat favored hiring quotas. ``We've seen the triumph of racism over reason in North Carolina,'' said Eddie N. Williams, president of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a black think tank. ``It's sort of Willie Horton all over again.'' Williams said President Bush's veto of a job discrimination bill helped doom Republicans in the governors' races in Texas and Florida. New Orleans elected a black Democrat, state Sen. William Jefferson, to succeed the retiring Rep. Lindy Boggs. All three Republican congresswomen who ran for the Senate were defeated - Lynn Martin in Illinois, Claudine Schneider in Rhode Island and Pat Saiki in Hawaii - and their old House seats went to Democratic men. But Richards' come-from-behind victory against GOP good-ole-boy Clayton Williams prompted cheers in women's political circles. ``We broke the glass ceiling'' that blocked political advancement, said Jane Danowitz, executive director of the Women's Campaign Fund. She credited the Richards victory to women voters, who favored Richards 61-39, according to CBS exit polls. Two black women, California Assemblywoman Maxine Waters and Detroit Councilwoman Barbara-Rose Collins, won the seats vacated by retiring black congressmen Augustus Hawkins and George Crockett. Despite personal tax troubles, Democrat Eleanor Holmes Norton captured the non-voting delegate seat from the District of Columbia. The black caucus will have 25 voting members in the 102nd Congress, up from 23 this year. Sharon Pratt Dixon also won election as mayor of Washington, D.C., the first black woman to take the helm of a major city. There will be 28 women in the House, one fewer than this year. The Senate remains all white with two women, following the re-election of Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan. Democrat Rosa De Lauro, a liberal activist from New Haven, Conn., won an open seat. She is a former executive director of EMILY's List, which provides seed money for Democratic women candidates. Wendy Sherman, her successor at EMILY's List, said there has been ``a sea-change'' in the caliber of women running for high office. ``These were no tokens. They are all competent, savvy, serious candidates,'' she said. Despite being outspent more than 10-1, Republican challenger Christine Todd Whitman gave a scare to Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley before losing narrowly. Women challengers also lost to incumbent male senators in Hawaii, Illinois, Rhode Island, Delaware and Wyoming, and Democrat Josie Heath was defeated by Rep. Hank Brown for an open Senate seat in Colorado. Finney, 65, Kansas treasurer for the past 16 years and an abortion opponent, toppled pro-choice Republican Gov. Mike Hayden, whose campaign foundered over taxes. South Carolina Gov. Carroll A. Campbell, a Republican, easily turned back a challenge from Democratic state Sen. Theo Mitchell, who is black. Besides Nebraska's Orr, the nation's two other incumbent women governors, Madeleine Kunin in Vermont and Rose Mofford in Arizona, chose not to seek new terms.

DOC.HEAD: Colorado Voters Express Disaffection; Re-Elect Romer, Other Familiar Faces
DOC.TEXT: Colorado voters expressed a disaffection for politicians by overwhelming approving a referendum to limit their terms, but they re-elected Gov. Roy Romer and sent Rep. Hank Brown to the U.S. Senate. And although a tax-limitation amendment was rejected Tuesday, it gathered significant support and was seen as a signal that tax reform can no longer be ignored. With 99 percent of precincts reporting, Democrat Romer had 623,835 votes, or 63 percent, to 362,157 votes, or 37 percent, for GOP candidate John Andrews. Brown defeated Democrat Josie Heath in the race to succeed the retiring Bill Armstrong in the U.S. Senate, 567,062 to 424,482, or 57 percent to 43 percent. Veterinarian Wayne Allard edged Dick Bond to claim Brown's old seat in the 4th Congressional District. All five incumbent U.S. House members - including Patricia Schroeder - prevailed. Brown, a former state legislator who went on to win five consecutive terms in Colorado's 4th District, said voters showed that the nation's strength ``comes from working men and women up, and not from Washington down.'' Heath, in conceding, said: ``I got into this race because I believed I could make a difference. First there were a dozen of you, then 100, and then a thousand and now hundreds of thousands (of voters) who have said it is time for a new agenda.'' Romer, 62, said he felt honored - and humbled - by his re-election. ``You don't go through this process without understanding who you are, your possibilities, and your limitations,'' he said Tuesday night. Voters in a mood for change approved four of Colorado's five ballot issues, including the term-limitation measure and a proposal to establish casino gambling in three small mountain towns. The term-limiting amendment would make Colorado the first state to limit congressional terms. However, questions linger about whether it would withstand a constitutional challenge. The measure would limit U.S. senators and representatives to 12 years of consecutive service and would cap terms for state officeholders and lawmakers to eight years at a time. The tax-limitation amendment was the only one to fail.

DOC.HEAD: Former Spy Chief Says He Plans To Return to Germany After Elections
DOC.TEXT: A legendary former chief of East Germany's Stasi secret police who is wanted in Germany says he plans to return after all-German elections in December, a magazine reported today. The weekly news magazine Stern quoted Markus Wolf as saying, ``I have no intention of going into exile'' and that he would at some point return to Germany ``when things quiet down after the Dec. 2 elections.'' Wolf, under investigation in connection with wrongdoings by Stasi, did not specifically say he would turn himself in. But the former spymaster said he expected to be dealt with under existing German law. Stern did not say where it tracked down Wolf, who disappeared after German unification on Oct. 3. In the interview that will appear in Stern's Thursday editions, Wolf also was quoted as saying he advised Erich Honecker last year that the Communist leader's anti-reform policy had no support. ``The DDR (East Germany) was on the way to becoming a second Albania,'' Stern quoted Wolf as saying. After his talk with Honecker, Wolf said ``I gave up the last hopes that he would change,'' the magazine reported. It is virtually impossible to determine the accuracy of Wolf's statement that he was against the policies of Honecker, who was toppled Oct. 18, 1989 by reformist Communists who permitted free elections. Since the collapse of the Communist regime in East Germany many of the country's former leaders and top officials - including Honecker - have given interviews trying to put their personal roles into the best light possible. In another report, the newspaper Bild Zeitung said it has learned from security sources that Wolf is at a Hungarian spa for treatment of a slipped disc. Wolf, who served as the head of East German espionage from 1952 to 1986, became legendary because of his agents' success in infiltrating West German intelligence and obtaining important NATO secrets. The Stasi, the name for the old East German Ministry for State Security, included domestic and foreign intelligence agents.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Paul Wellstone, a political science professor who ran a low-budget, humorous campaign, knocked off Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, the only incumbent senator to lose in Tuesday's elections.

DOC.HEAD: GOP's Edgar Elected Governor, Democrat Simon Returned to Senate in Illinois
DOC.TEXT: Rising GOP star Jim Edgar squeaked to victory in the governor's race while veteran Democrat Paul Simon was easily re-elected to the U.S. Senate. Both men credited outspokeness for their victories. Edgar, who campaigned in favor of making a temporary 20 percent increase in the state income tax permanent, gained 51 percent of the vote in Tuesday's election to edge Democrat Neil Hartigan, the two-term state attorney general. ``The voters have sent a message throughout Illinois and across the country that politicians can be candid with voters about taxes and still win,'' he told cheering supporters early today. Hartigan opposed extending the two-year tax, but Edgar said it was necessary to provide needed revenues for schools. With 98 percent of the precincts reporting, Edgar, the 44-year-old Illinois secretary of state, had 1,633,330 votes, or 51 percent, to Hartigan's 1,535,514, or 48 percent. Solidarity Party candidate Jessie Fields had 35,501 votes, or 1 percent. Simon, seeking election to a second six-year term, had 2,075,145 votes, or 65 percent, to Rep. Lynn Martin's 1,119,949, or 35 percent. Simon said his victory was an endorsement of his call for government to take a greater role in tackling the nation's top issues. ``We want a nation that sees its security in education, health care and a clean environment ... as much as in weapons systems,'' he said. ``We want a nation that is firm on the international scene but that is also sensitive to human rights and the suffering of people of other nations.'' In other major races, Republican Lt. Gov. George Ryan was elected to the secretary of state post being vacated by Edgar, but Democrat John Cox defeated Republican John Hallock to capture the Congressional seat Martin is vacating. State Rep. Hallock had been favored until he was battered by publicity about a child-support dispute and a ticket for driving 107 mph. Democratic victories in state legislative races also gave the party a veto-proof 73-45 majority in the state House of Representatives with reapportionment to be considered next year. Two congressional Democrats, veteran Frank Annunzio of Chicago and freshman George Sangmeister of Mokena, also survived stiff challenges as their party widened its majority in the state's congressional delegation to 15-7.

DOC.HEAD: Narrow Win Could Tarnish Bradley's Presidential Stature
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 4th pvs, `Bradley has...' to UPDATE with comments about closeness of race; picks up 5th graf pvs. INSERTS 5 grafs after 7th pvs, `An unpopular...' with Whitman strategy, Bradley comments and state poll; picks up 8th graf pvs, ``He and...'
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bill Bradley, who began his bid for a third term with polls showing him 47 points ahead of GOP unknown Christine Todd Whitman, ended the contest by eking out a two-point win. ``What can I say? It's been a few years since I was in a double overtime,'' the former New York Knicks basketball star said early today when he finally was able to give a subdued victory speech. With 99 percent of precincts reporting, Bradley had 964,309 votes, or 50 percent, to 909,694 votes, or 48 percent, for Mrs. Whitman. Bradley has been widely named as a Democratic presidential prospect. But he has insisted he will concentrate on serving New Jersey for the next six years, and that promise may be easier to keep following the razor-thin win. Voters turned to his opponent to show their disapproval of new federal and state taxes, along with general concerns over the lagging economy, he said. ``I think it was close because people were frustrated and angry,'' Bradley said. ``For all of those of you who are dissatisfied with government ... even for those who voted against me as a sign of protest, I hear your voices too,'' he said. ``I know you don't distinguish between federal, state or local taxes ... I know that all of you want a chance to be free of the constant financial pressure. ... And I finally know that you don't think politicians have much to offer.'' Some observers suggested the squeaker catapulted Mrs. Whitman, a former president of the state Board of Public Utilities, into the front-runner's spot in the 1993 race against Democratic Gov. Jim Florio. Mrs. Whitman's response to the speculation: ``Who knows?'' An unpopular $2.8 billion tax package that Florio unveiled after his election gave Mrs. Whitman an opportunity to attack Bradley for refusing to comment on his fellow Democrat's policies. Mrs. Whitman hit Bradley over his refusal to comment on the widely hated tax plan, saying it was a sign that he was out of touch with New Jersey taxpayers. ``That's the thing he missed by not being in the state enough these past years,'' she said. This morning, Bradley acknowledged the Florio tax plan was ``clearly an element of the mix,'' but he defended his refusal to debate the plan with Mrs. Whitman, who has repeatedly denounced it. ``I didn't comment because it is essentially not my responsibility,'' he said. Polls showed that a majority of New Jersey voters believed Bradley should have addressed Florio's tax plan. ``He and his friends can forget about any national aspirations they ever had,'' said Joseph Sullivan, Mrs. Whitman's finance director. However, Anita Dunn of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee said a weak showing by all incumbents was expected, in light of the messy budget process in Washington. ``Especially in New Jersey, where the state budget is an especially volatile issue,'' she said. ``It's not a key indicator of anything beyond what's going on in the internal politics of your own state.'' In House races, Democrats kept control of eight of 14 seats in New Jersey's delegation, the same share they had before Florio vacated his seat upon election as governor.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon School Choice Measure Rejected
DOC.TEXT: Oregonians strongly rejected a pioneering measure that would have given tax breaks to parents who send their children to private schools or educate them at home. Unofficial results showed Measure 11 rejected by a margin of 67 percent to 33 percent Tuesday. The national education community watched the measure closely, and Vice President Dan Quayle came to Oregon to campaign for it. Measure 11 would have allowed tax credits of up to $2,500 for sending children to private schools, including religious ones, or for schooling them at home. The proposal also would have let parents send children across district lines to any public school in the state. Foes said the plan would mainly have helped the wealthy and amount to state aid to religion. ``I'm delighted,'' said Karen Famous, president of the Oregon Education Association, the state's largest teachers' union. ``I think it shows Oregon voters do not want public tax dollars diverted to private education.'' Ed Marihart, a spokesman for the campaign to pass the proposal, said confusion probably helped defeat it. ``It was a relatively new concept that people misunderstood,'' he said. ``Some people thought it would increase the costs and take away control from public education.'' He said backers of the measure might continue their campaign in the 1991 legislature or launch another initiative drive for the 1992 election.

DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Elects Independent for Governor
DOC.TEXT: Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the former Republican U.S. senator whose maverick ways made him a marked man in the GOP, capped a political comeback by winning the governor's office as an independent. Connecticut voters also made history Tuesday by sending a black Republican, Gary Franks, to Congress in the 5th District. Weicker, 59, a Paris-born millionaire from Greenwich whose family helped found the Squibb pharmaceutical corporation, is the first third-party candidate to win Connecticut's governorship since 1856. ``We don't have any money in the pot to do what we'd like to do,'' Weicker said in an appeal for unity in the face of a state budget deficit that could reach $1.5 billion next year. ``So we need your brains and we need your hearts,'' he told supporters in Simsbury. ``This state badly needs you as it never needed you before - Republicans, Democrats, independents, regardless of where you come from.'' Weicker narrowly edged Republican John G. Rowland, 40 percent to 38 percent. Democrat Bruce A. Morrison came in a distant third with 21 percent. Unofficial returns gave Weicker 455,430 votes, Rowland 423,101 and Morrison 232,077 Weicker was first elected to the U.S. Senate in a three-way race in 1970, when he ran as a Republican. After losing his U.S. 50 percent

DOC.HEAD: Andrus Wins Landslide To Lead Major Democratic Gains
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Gov. Cecil Andrus won a landslide victory for an unprecedented fourth term, leading his party to major gains statewide just months after being targeted for defeat by outraged anti-abortion forces. Andrus, 59, who interrupted his tenure as Idaho's chief executive to serve as Jimmy Carter's interior secretary, claimed two of every three votes against underdog Republican Roger Fairchild, 37, a populist businessman who raised $50,000 to contest the governor's $1 million war chest. Ticket-splitting voters did chose five-term GOP Congressman Larry Craig over Democrat Ron Twilegar to succeed retiring Republican U.S. Sen James McClure. The party has held that seat for 40 years. But Democrat Larry LaRocco replaced Craig as the 1st District congressman, putting that seat in the Democratic column for the first time in 24 years and giving Idaho a solid Democratic delegation in the House for the first time in over a quarter century. Democrats also won the attorney general's office for the first time 16 years and made major gains in the Legislature. ``The Democratic party is here to stay,'' Andrus declared. ``No longer can they say to us this is a Republican state.'' Fairchild emphasized his anti-abortion stand in the face of the governor's March 30 veto of what would have been the nation's most restrictive state abortion law. But it never energized his campaign in the face of pro-choice activism.

DOC.HEAD: Wellstone Used No-Frills Campaign in Race Against Boschwitz
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Paul Wellstone rode a repainted, back-firing converted school bus nicknamed the ``Magellan II'' to defeat the big-bucks campaign of 12-year Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz. The bus, named after the campaign train Harry Truman took on a whistle-stop train tour in 1948, became a symbol of the political science professor's low-budget, volunteer-driven campaign against Boschwitz's multimillion-dollar war chest. Wellstone, 46, bunked with supporters while on the road and once borrowed campaign money from his wife. ``I've only stayed in a hotel once,'' said Wellstone, whose campaign raised $800,000 to Boschwitz's $6.2 million. Once called a ``leftist hustler'' and an ``Abbie Hoffman-like character'' by Boschwitz's campaign secretary, the unabashed liberal said he wanted to go to Washington ``to shake things up.'' ``I'm not going to be one of the inner club,'' he said. Wellstone took a leave of absence at the elite Carleton College to run for against Boschwitz, a self-made millionaire. He said he'll return to teaching when his political career is over. Wellstone was chairman of the Jesse Jackson campaign in Minnesota in 1988, and later was state co-chairman of the Michael Dukakis campaign. An unsuccessful candidate for state auditor in 1982, he was elected to the Democratic National Committee in 1984 and re-elected in 1988. He was a spokesman for farmers who opposed the Reagan administration policies, and has written two books on community organizing. Wellstone refused to accept campaign contributions from political action committees unless they have some ``affiliate or some membership connection'' with Minnesota, saying he doesn't want to be beholden to wealth special interests. Wellstone said his low budget forced his campaign to come up with creative TV commercials to catch voters' attention. He gained national attention for his infrequently broadcast, two-minute ``Looking for Rudy'' ad that showed him in a madcap effort to engage Boschwitz in a debate. The ad was a takeoff of the 1989 documentary ``Roger and Me,'' in which a filmmaker tries to track down General Motors Chairman Roger Smith. Throughout the campaign, Wellstone called for a shift of the S&L bailout costs to the rich, tougher environmental standards, guaranteed health care and affordable day care. He supports abortion rights and opposes nuclear power and says Minnesota's law requiring a seven-day waiting period for handgun purchase should be a model for the nation. Wellstone was raised in the Washington, D.C., area and earned a doctorate at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. He moved to Northfield in 1969, where he still lives with his wife, Sheila. The couple has three children.

DOC.HEAD: Man Fires Shots Near Gorbachev, Anti-Government Protests Abound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with man firing two shots near Gorbachev. Pickup 12th pvs, `Gorbachev took...'
DOC.TEXT: A marcher fired shots on Red Square not far from Soviet leaders during today's Revolution Day parae, and thousands of angry citizens held the first protests ever sanctioned in Moscow on the major Soviet holiday. During the traditional parade, a man fired two shots from a sawed-off shotgun about 80 yards from Lenin Mausoleum, where President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other leaders were watching, a Tass correspondent said. No one appeared to have been hit and police quickly grabbed the unidentified man, said correspondent Sergei Vozianov, who witnessed the incident. Voizanov said it was not clear if he was aiming at anyone. The incident occurred on what was already the most unruly Revolution Day ever, with alternative demonstrations bemoaning the legacy of the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution given official sanction in Moscow. In the independence-minded Baltic republics, authorities told residents to boycott the holiday by going to work. Even official media questioned the wisdom of holding a celebration amid mounting political, economic and ethnic turmoil. Moscow's streets became forums for celebration by Communist Party supporters and denunciation by radicals who contend the 1917 revolution served only to throw Russian civilization into decline. Revolution Day has been the biggest holiday on the Soviet calendar, focusing until Gorbachev came to power on the Red Square parade during which the military always showed off its latest hardware. Gorbachev took the traditional Soviet leader's position atop the Lenin Mausoleum in flag-draped Red Square today and opened the official celebration with a sober assessment of the state of the nation. ``It's not the fault of previous generations that the goals they dreamed of were not fulfilled,'' he said, referring to what he called ``distortions of socialist ideas.'' Speaking behind a row of microphones and wearing a gray wool coat, Gorbachev also acknowledged that shortages of goods, a breakdown of law and order and ethnic strife had worsened in recent years. A few blocks away, at least 2,000 people gathered near Communist Party headquarters for a counter-demonstration. Two sound trucks played funereal music as people unfurled banners from different regions and political groups. ``Genocide is the gift of the Leninist Leaders to the People,'' read one. ``Countrymen, how long will we endure hypocrisy, lies, demagoguery, violence and theft from the Mafia-Communist Party?'' read another. Similar rallies were held in Leningrad, Kiev and other cities. Gorbachev spoke for 15 minutes, flanked by critical and supportive leaders, including Russian republic President Boris N. Yeltsin and Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. An army band played the national anthem. Red flags hung from street lamps and fluttered on buses across a capital covered by a thin layer of the season's first snow. After rows of armored personnel carriers, tanks and rocket launchers passed, Gorbachev, anti-establishment Mayor Gavriil Popov and other leaders filed down the front steps of the mausoleum to lead a people's parade. The official news agency Tass said it was the first time Soviet leaders had walked with the people on Revolution Day. Gorbachev was followed by thousands of people carrying official banners touting his reform program. Gorbachev and the others broke off from the parade and laid red carnations at the base of the mausoleum before going back on top to watch the parade. Banners the marchers carried reflected criticism of Gorbachev. ``Gorbachev, Take Your Eyes Off Foreign Affairs and Pay Attention To The Country,'' read one banner, carried by a branch of Moscow's city Communist Party organization. ``CPSU, Get Out Of Your Coma,'' read another, referring to the party. In the Baltic republics, authorities declared today a working day, although pro-Moscow groups planned traditional parades. In the Caucasian republic of Georgia, where non-Communists prevailed in recent elections, the military parade was moved from the center of the capital of Tbilisi to an army base. In Kiev, radical students and nationalists occupied central Pobeda Square, vowing to block the official celebration and military parade. On Tuesday night, 5,000 people gathered for an anti-Communist rally in another square, according to the independent news agency Interfax. In the Siberian city of Omsk, anti-Communist protesters from the Democratic Union today held banners near an official demonstration that read, ``History Will Not Forgive the Crimes of the Communist Party,'' a local journalist reported. Morning newspapers were filled with reports, some glowing and some critical, of anniversary plans. Tass noted the ``complex situation'' the nation faces: ``The economy is in throes, discord is tearing ethnic minorities asunder and various social forces are in confrontation. ``It is no wonder that some politicians have called into question the advisability of holding celebrations at all,'' Tass said. Ethnic bloodshed forced cancellation of parades in Kishinev, the capital of Moldavia, and in Nagorno-Karabakh, the mountainous region coveted by both the republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan. In Moscow on Tuesday night, knots of people holding candles gathered after nightfall at a new monument to victims of Communist repression, said Galina Starovoytova, a Russian member of Parliament. The monument, erected outside KGB headquarters in Dzherzhinsky Square, was unveiled last week and been heaped with flowers ever since. Ms. Starovoytova appealed to other legislators taking part in the celebrations to, ``after seeing the military power, turn your faces to look at the misery and poverty our country is facing.'' ``Society is falling apart,'' said Gleb Yakunin, a Russian Orthodox priest leading one of the counterdemonstrations. ``It is a day of mourning, the day of the most tragic event in our history.''

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Rejects King Holiday
DOC.TEXT: Arizona voters rejected two proposals to honor Martin Luther King Jr. with a state holiday, and waited for the other shoe to drop: a move by the National Football League to yank the 1993 Super Bowl out of the state. Proposition 301, which would have created a paid King holiday but eliminated a paid Columbus Day, was rejected Tuesday by a 3-to-1 margin. Proposition 302, which would have given state workers both days off, was defeated by fewer than 15,000 votes out of about 1 million cast. The NFL awarded the 1993 Super Bowl to suburban Tempe earlier this year, but Philadelphia Eagles owner Norman Braman promised to lead a drive to reverse the decision if the state failed to enact a King holiday. It was with that threat in mind that the Legislature ended nearly two decades of divisive debate over the issue last year by passing a bill creating Martin Luther King-Civil Rights Day in Arizona. But opponents, led by impeached Gov. Evan Mecham, circulated petitions to force a referendum on the issue. Arnie Zaler, one of the leaders of the King Day campaign, said there probably will be a renewed effort next year to create the holiday in honor of the slain civil rights leader. ``This is going to be a test of our leadership and our belief in Dr. King's dream,'' Zaler said.

DOC.HEAD: Ticket-Splitting Iowa Voters Re-Elect Harkin, Branstad
DOC.TEXT: Tom Harkin said his support for abortion rights helped him become the first Iowa Democrat to win a second U.S. Senate term. Republican Gov. Terry Branstad, meanwhile, said voters who swept him to a third four-year term Tuesday gave him a clear mandate for his policies. He also retains veto power over congressional redistricting approved by the Democratic-controlled state House and Senate. Harkin, 50, had been a target for the GOP since he ousted Republican Sen. Roger Jepsen in 1984 and became a persistent, vocal administration critic. He faced GOP U.S. Rep Tom Tauke in a two-year fight that was the most expensive political race in Iowa's history at $11 million in combined spending. Harkin drew a sharp distinction with Tauke's anti-abortion stance, and groups on both sides of the issue targeted the race. ``People knew where we stood on the issue,'' Harkin said. ``I didn't say it was a key issue, but it was an important issue.'' Tauke had said he would ban abortion even for rape and incest victims. President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle campaigned repeatedly for him. With 99 percent of the state's precincts reporting, Harkin collected 518,109 votes, or 54 percent, to 441,456, or 46 percent, for Tauke. With 98 percent of the votes counted in the governor's race, Branstad had 61 percent, or 575,437 votes, to Avenson's 39 percent, or 370,430 votes. ``It's clearly a mandate for the policies that I've established,'' Branstad said. ``I've never won by that kind of a margin in the governor's race.''

DOC.HEAD: Spousal Benefits Victory Hailed as Triumph of Tolerance in Seattle
DOC.TEXT: Tolerance triumphed as city voters upheld the extension of spousal benefits to unmarried partners of municipal employees, supporters of the benefits said. ``I think this is a city that doesn't want to exclude anybody,'' said Pam Weeks, co-manager of the No on Bigotry-No on 35 campaign. With 99 percent of he precincts reporting, the vote on Initiative 35, a move to repeal the benefits, was 81,638 no and 58,510 yes. Seattle is the largest city in the nation to extend medical and dental coverage to live-in companions of municipal employees, along with compassionate leave for employees whose unmarried partners are sick or die. Julia Fogassy, who ran the Initiative 35 campaign, said, ``If people had truly understood the issue, I don't think we would have lost.'' An ordinance extending funeral and sick leave in the case of unmarried partners was adopted by the City Council last year after a ruling by the municipal Human Rights Department. By eliminating registration of non-marital partnerships under that ordinance, Initiative 35 also would have eliminated a second ordinance that extended optional health and dental coverage to unmarried partners of municipal workers last spring, Fogassy said. Initiative 35 was the nation's first ballot proposal for eliminating an established bereavement and sick leave program for unmarried partners. San Franciscans passed a measure Tuesday allowing unmarried couples to register non-marital relationships but without conferring formal benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Sen. Simpson, Gov. Sullivan Re-elected in Wyoming
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mike Sullivan's accent on optimism and a brighter future for Wyoming led to a landslide that set a state victory-margin record. ``I stressed a positive campaign in every respect, and that's what the people of Wyoming want to see,'' he said. U.S. Sen. Alan Simpson also coasted to victory Tuesday, winning a third term in office, and U.S. Rep. Craig Thomas - elected in 1989 to fill the seat vacated by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney - won his first full term in Congress. Throughout the gubernatorial campaign, Republican Mary Mead attacked Sullivan's leadership and maintained that the state's economy was ``lousy.'' But the Democratic incumbent pointed to the state's reviving econony, including coal, tourism and agriculture. Unofficial returns from 458 of the state's 471 precincts gave Sullivan 100,473 votes, or 65 percent, and Mead 53,262, or 35 percent. The late Gov. Ed Herschler had held the victory-margin record, whipping Republican Warren Morton in 1982 with 63 percent of the vote. Simpson, the Senate minority whip, easily won a third term, garnering 96,772 votes, or 64 percent, while Democratic challenger Kathy Helling received 54,330, or 36 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Wellstone Upsets Boschwitz; Carlson Running Strong
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Paul Wellstone, who ran his campaign on a shoestring and a laugh, defeated Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz in a fitting conclusion to Minnesota's strange political season. The wild gubernatorial race between Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich and Republican challenger Arne Carlson was still too close to call today. Returns were slow because Carlson's last-minute substitution for GOP candidate Jon Grunseth required votes to be counted by hand. Grunseth dropped out of the race a little over a week ago following allegations that he had gone skinny-dipping with teen-age girls and cheated on two wives. With 83 percent of precincts reporting today, Carlson held a slim lead over Perpich, the Democrat-Farmer-Labor incumbent who was trying for an unprecedented fourth term. Carlson had 565,045 votes in unofficial returns to 564,962 for Perpich. ``I feel like Lazarus,'' Carlson told supporters. Wellstone, a political science professor who decided to test his theories outside academe, had 608,377 votes, or 51 percent, to Boschwitz's 577,377, or 49 percent, with 83 percent of precincts reporting. ``With this victory, politics will never be the same in Minnesota,'' Wellstone told cheering supporters. ``With every ounce of energy that I have, I'll do everything I can to represent Minnesota well in Washington.'' Boschwitz left his campaign headquarters shortly before midnight and said he was going to bed. Campaign aides refused to concede the race. However, his campaign manager, Tom Mason, said there had been ``a clear negative move away from the Republicans and Rudy in general.'' Boschwitz was the only incumbent senator to lose in Tuesday's elections. Republican Arlan Stangeland, who had been hounded by questions about late-night telephone calls to and from a Virginia woman's home, lost his U.S. House seat to DFL challenger Collin Peterson. The governor's race appeared headed for the closest finish since 1962, when DFLer Karl Rolvaag won a 91-vote recount victory over Republican Gov. Elmer L. Andersen in a race that wasn't decided until March 1963. Carlson, 56, had finished second in the Republican primary. He had already begun a write-in campaign for the general election when Grunseth dropped out of the race and a reeling Republican Party quickly made Carlson its official candidate. Perpich, 62, had been considered easy to beat earlier in the year, when he was dubbed ``Governor Goofy'' for a series of odd statements. But the Republican disarray allowed him to bounce back. Boschwitz blamed Grunseth for his own political problems, saying he had cast the entire party in a bad light. Wellstone, 46, a Carleton College professor who campaigned in a ramshackle bus, gained recognition with a series of humorous television ads - one of which showed him ``looking for Rudy'' in a takeoff of the documentary film ``Roger and Me.'' His shoe-leather campaign spent about $1 million to $7 million for Boschwitz.

DOC.HEAD: Finney Win's Governor's Race, Democrats Apparently Control House
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Joan Finney's victory in the governor's race over incumbent Republican Mike Hayden headed a surprising Democratic surge that included a possible triumph in the party's battle for control of the state House. Finney became the first woman governor of Kansas, garnering 49 percent of the vote to Hayden's 42 percent. With virtually all of the vote counted early today, Mrs. Finney had 380,649 votes to Hayden's 331,744. Independent candidate Christina Campbell-Cline trailed with 68,856 votes, or 9 percent - more votes than any independent candidate for governor since John R. ``Doc'' Brinkley in 1932. Unofficial returns showed Democrats with a one-seat edge over Republicans in the state House of Representatives. But two of the Democrats' victories came by margins of only four and six votes - meaning recounts could reverse those outcomes and keep Republicans in charge. At the congressional level, Republicans their ground. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, as expected, easily defeated Democratic challenger Dick Williams, ringing up 73 percent of the vote. The GOP also kept its 3-2 advantage in the state's U.S. House delegation as banker Dick Nichols won the 5th District seat vacated by Republican Bob Whittaker. Nichols got 59 percent of the vote over Democrat George Wingert. Four incumbent congressmen - including Democrats Jim Slattery and Dan Glickman, and Republicans Pat Roberts and Jan Meyers - all won re-election with majorities ranging from 60 percent to 71 percent. Voters rejected for the third time a proposed constitutional amendment that would have restored full policy control over education to the Legislature.

DOC.HEAD: Rhode Island Governor Is Hard-Driving Manager with New Deal Touch
DOC.TEXT: Bruce G. Sundlun, the voters' overwhelming choice over Republican Edward D. DiPrete in the Rhode Island governor's race, is a hard-driving businessman with the touch of a New Deal Democrat. A quintessential state political insider, the 70-year-old millionaire triumphed in his third challenge of DiPrete for possession of the highest office in the nation's smallest state. Along the way, the candidate, who smiles easily in private but had a stiff and sometimes brusque public persona, softened and seemed to enjoy campaigning. ``I think it's because I have learned, not 100 percent, but I have learned to be a public person,'' Sundlun said. After his victory, he said the voters also caught on. ``I think...the voters of Rhode Island said `he's been out there twice and he's been right on all the issues,' '' Sundlun said. The former Outlet Co. chief executive twice fought DiPrete when the Republican was at the height of his popularity. This year he took umbrage when two primary challengers, sensing a weakened DiPrete, stepped in. ``I put the food on the plate and they want to eat it, and at that point my competitive hackles start to rise a bit,'' Sundlun said before the primary. Sundlun went public with a 61-page homily called ``Hope,'' in which he described himself as a formerly shy Jewish kid who grew up on Providence's East Side during te Depression and admired President Franklin D. Roosevelt. ``I learned early on that you have to help people, and I learned early on that the government is a good vehicle for helping people in times of crisis,'' he wrote. Sundlun promises to do it with a businessman's touch, offering incentives to firms that provide services like day care and promising time off for juvenile prisoners who complete classes. The Harvard-educated lawyer became a federal prosecutor in 1949 but returned to private practice five years later. He participated in Tennesee Sen. Estes Kefauver's 1956 campaign and helped John F. Kennedy's presidential run in 1960. Sundlun says he's made the transition from uptight executive to at-ease public official. ``I know exactly when and where I crossed it,'' he said. It was just before a television interview when his campaign manager told him to ``be a governor, not a candidate, and I understood exactly what he meant.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor's Race on Hold, Exon Wins Third Senate Term
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Ben Nelson held a 4,000-vote lead over Republican Gov. Kay Orr today in his quest to deny a second term to the state's first woman governor. With 98 percent of precincts reporting, Nelson had 281,982 votes to Orr's 277,914. An automatic recount was likely. ``Well, I know I can live through a recount if I have to,'' Nelson said today. ``Heck, I can live through several of them.'' U.S. Sen. Jim Exon retained his seat after a nasty race against Republican Hal Daub. With 98 percent of precincts reporting, Exon had 337,624 votes, or 59 percent, to Daub's 233,861 votes, or 41 percent. While campaigning for Daub, Sen. John Tower of Texas said he heard rumors that Exon was ``one of the two or three biggest boozers'' in the Senate. Exon denied the rumors, then alluded to rumors of domestic violence in Daub's family. Exon claimed his win sent a message ``that there's no chance for winning in Nebraska with character assassination techniques'' like the ones Daub used against him. In the 3rd District, Republican state Sen. Bill Barrett kept the seat in the party by defeating Democrat Sandra Scofield to succeed retiring U.S. Rep. Virginia Smith. Republican Rep. Doug Bereuter coasted to an easy seventh-term victory in his 1st District race. Democratic Rep. Peter Hoagland defeated Republican Ally Milder in the 2nd District. Also Tuesday, voters rejected a proposed constitutional amendment to limit state and local spending increases to 2 percent annually and defeated a move to repeal a school financing law that boosted sales and income tax rates.

DOC.HEAD: Tax Revolt, Environmental, Anti-Abortion Forces Suffer Setbacks
RETRANSMITTING to change category code to p.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, A proposal ..., to update with King holiday losing; SUBS 16th graf, Residents of ..., to update with Giants stadium losing; SUBS 24th graf, In California ..., to update with term limits passing.
DOC.TEXT: Tax rebels and the environmental movement were snubbed by the nation's voters, but so were ballot measures calling for higher taxes. Gun control forces won a victory in Florida, and supporters of limiting politicians' time in office triumphed in California, Colorado and Kansas City, Mo. In Tuesday's most closely watched ballot initiative, Californians rejected Proposition 128, a far-reaching lineup of environmental regulations dubbed ``Big Green'' by supporters who included a galaxy of Hollywood stars. Opponents, led by industrial companies, marshaled $10 million in their campaign to defeat it. Measures backed by environmentalists to regulate land use and pollution also lost in Washington, Oregon and Missouri. A $1.97 billion bond issue to py for environmental projects failed in New York. Citizen initiatives calling for drastic tax cuts or limits on government spending lost in Massachusetts, Nebraska, Colorado and Utah. But in Oregon, an initiative to limit property taxes to 1.5 percent of assessed value passed narrowly. Florida voters amended the state constitution to require a three-day wait on handgun purchases. In other voting, a pair of anti-abortion proposals lost in Oregon, while Nevadans made it harder to change that state's liberal abortion law. A proposal to make Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday a holiday in Arizona lost by fewer than 15,000 votes out of 1 million cast, leaving the state as one of three without a formal holiday honoring the slain civil rights leader. Voters in Oregon defeated a plan to give tax credits to parents who send their children to parochial or other private schools, and Arizonans rejected a proposal to increase spending on education by about $6 billion over 10 years. The Massachusetts tax initiative would have repealed two income tax increases and rescinded fee increases since 1988, costing the state's government $2.6 billion in its next fiscal year. It lost by a 3-to-2 margin. The measure would have been the biggest voter-initiated state tax rollback in history. But with the state's economic woes, voters apparently were worried about the impact, said Paul Watanabe, a political scientist at the University of Massachusetts. ``They wanted change but (the measure) went too far,'' he said. Nebraskans voted 2-to-1 against the ``Two Percent Solution,'' which would have capped growth in local and state government spending at 2 percent a year. Utah voters turned down a measure that would have eliminated the sales tax on most food, and Coloradans narrowly defeated a requirement for voter approval for tax increases. Voters weren't sending a welcoming message to higher taxes, however. Montanans voted against a proposal to make the state cigarette tax the highest in the nation in an attempt to reduce smoking. Californians rejected two proposals to increase liquor taxes, while voters in Nevada defeated a corporate profits tax and upheld a constitutional ban on personal income taxes. Residents of Gwinnett County, Ga., defeated a 1 percent sales tax to finance a suburban extension of Atlanta's rapid transit system. A 1 percent utility tax increase to finance a stadium for baseball's San Francisco Giants lost narrowly in Santa Clara County, Calif. The nearly 2-to-1 defeat of California's ``Big Green'' was a big setback for environmentalists. The measure would have imposed a wide range of controls on emissions, pesticides, offshore oil-drilling and logging. Business groups argued it would cost several billion dollars annually in higher gas, electricity and food prices. Supporters said it would save several billion dollars a year in energy and health costs. State Attorney General John Van de Kamp, a primary sponsor of the measure, said voters had become conservative about spending money on new programs. ``I think the invasion of Kuwait, the beginning of the recession, the national budget crisis, the state budget crisis - all those things have scared people,'' he said. Voters in Washington rejected a sweeping measure to control development in environmentally sensitive areas and mandate land-use planning throughout the state. In Oregon, voters defeated strict recycling rules and a proposal to shut down the state's only nuclear power plant. Missourians said no to a ``Natural Streams'' initiative to regulate development along scenic waterways in the Ozark Mountains. In South Dakota, a measure to limit mining in the Black Hills lost, but a proposal to regulate large-scale garbage dumps won. Colorado voters easily passed a far-reaching measure to limit the number of terms served by politicians. The limits would even apply to U.S. senators and congressmen, one aspect that may run afoul of the U.S. Constitution. In California, a measure limiting politicians to two terms and ending state contributions to officeholders' pensions passed 52 percent-48 percent. Voters in Kansas City, Mo., limited the mayor and city council members to two terms. And in Arizona, voters rejected a pay raise for legislators. Elsewhere: -Alaskans voted to again make the private use of marijuana a crime. -Washington, D.C., voters turned back an attempt to restore the right of homeless people to city-financed overnight shelter. -Arizonans defeated a 20 percent cut in auto insurance rates. -Maine voters abolished the state's tough blue laws that force most big retailers to close on Sundays. -Oregonians made it illegal not to use seat belts in cars. They also voted to experiment with replacing welfare benefits with low-pay jobs, but the program would require approval from Congress. -Voters in the Staten Island borough of New York City approved a referendum to start a process that could lead to secession from the city. Voters in predominantly black Boston neighborhoods also considered a secession study, but vote totals had not been released. -Seattle voters retained spousal benefits for unmarried companions of municipal employees. San Franciscans passed a less sweeping measure allowing unmarried couples to register their relationships with city officials but without conferring formal benefits. -Residents of Sacramento, Calif., and surrounding Sacramento County rejected a merger that would have created the nation's seventh-largest city.

DOC.HEAD: Thompson Re-elected Governor, Congressional Veteran Kastenmeier Ousted
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, whose campaign by buoyed by a stong economy, promised to make Wisconsin recession-proof after his election to a second term. Thompson crushed his Democratic opponent, state Assembly Speaker Tom Loftus, in Tuesday's election. Democratic Rep. Robert Kastenmeier, a 32-year veteran of Congress, lost a close race to Republican Scott Klug, a political newcomer and former TV news reporter. With 99 percent of the state's precincts reporting, Thompson had 797,234 votes, or 58 percent, to Loftus' 574,313, or 42 percent. With all ballots counted, Klug had 96,603 votes, or 53 percent, to Kastenmeier's 85,011, or 47 percent. Wisconsin has one of the nation's lowest unemployment rates at 3.8 percent, and Thompson, 48, said strong economic conditions will continue. ``We will make jobs available for all of our people, will make opportunity what it should be, and make education No. 1 because I strongly believe Wisconsin can become the No. 1 state in the nation,'' he said. Kastenmeier, 66, had previously found strong support for his pro-civil rights, anti-nuclear and anti-war positions in the congressional district that includes traditionally liberal Madison. He said anti-incumbent sentiment did him in this time. The 37-year-old Klug agreed. He had called for limiting congressional service to 12 years and had criticized congressional pay raises during his campaign. ``It made people angry. They wanted a change,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman in Close Race; 14 Legislators Ousted
DOC.TEXT: Missouri voters, unreceptive to more government, rejected a new agency to oversee state waterways and ousted 14 state legislators. Republican U.S. Rep. Jack Buechner was trailing by 52 votes early today in his bid for a third term. The state's eight other congressmen won re-election. The Natural Streams Act, criticized as a bureaucratic land grab, was rejected by 75 percent of the voters. The act would have created a state commission for governing 52 scenic waterways. Kansas City voters approved limiting City Council members to two four-year terms, while a non-binding St. Louis County vote opposed federal dioxin burning in Times Beach. Republican State Auditor Margaret Kelly eased to a second four-year term, beating Democratic novice Connie Hendren in the only statewide race on Tuesday. Buechner trailed Democrat Joan Kelly Horn by 52 votes out of 188,548 cast in St. Louis and St. Charles counties. Buechner noted that some absentee ballots might not be counted for days. Buechner was talking to lawyers about a recount, ``which is mandatory when the difference is less than 1 percent.'' ``Missouri seems to have been swept by a wave of anti-incumbency,'' said Buechner, a suburban St. Louis congressman.

DOC.HEAD: California, Colorado, Kansas City Limit Terms for Officeholders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with California approving limits, and ADDS comments on California and Colorado votes.
DOC.TEXT: Voters in California, Colorado and Kansas City, Mo., slapped limits Tuesday on how long politicians can hold office. Californians imposed a lifetime cap on an individual's service, granting a total of six years - three terms - for Assembly members and eight years - two terms - for state senators. The eight-year limit also applies to statewide officers. The change will rock the ``careerists'' in the state legislature, said Lewis Uhler, co-sponsor of the proposition. ``It demonstrates the depth of feeling on the part of the people and helps to launch a national crusade,'' he said. The measure also eliminated the legislature's pension program and cut its operating budget about 40 percent. Californians defeated another measure, backed by consumer advocate Ralph Nader and Common Cause, to limit statewide officers to eight consecutive years and allow legislators only 12 consecutive years in each house. The Colorado measure, the biggest vote-getter on the state ballot, imposed a limit of eight consecutive years for holding a single state office. It applies to the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, treasurer, attorney general and seats in the state legislature. It also would limit members of the U.S. Senate and House to 12 years in office, but such state limits on federal offices may be vulnerable to a constitutional challenge. The measure won support from 71 percent of voters. The vote signaled that voters support sweeping reform, said state Sen. Terry Considine, the driving force behind Amendment 5. ``On Amendment 5, it came as no surprise to me there was such an overwhelming number supporting it,'' he said. ``Colorado has set an example that will be imitated all across our country. People from 30 states worked with me on this, and I think we can get reforms in Congress.'' Kansas City residents limited city council members and the mayor to two consecutive four-year terms. Council members can run again after sitting out a term. The measure, which passed 36,596 to 31,379, prevents nine of the current 13 council members from seeking re-election in the spring. ``Eight years is enough,'' said Henry E. Lyons, a real estate developer who was behind the move to get the proposal on the ballot. Apart from Tuesday's contests, efforts are under way to limit terms of office in Florida, Illinois, New York and Ohio. Several states are also considering constitutional amendments to limit terms in the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives. In another measure of voter sentiment, Arizona defeated a proposed pay raise for legislators by a margin of 2 to 1.

DOC.HEAD: King Wins Third Term as New Mexico Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with King victory, new vote totals
DOC.TEXT: Former two-time Democratic Gov. Bruce King regained the office Tuesday, giving his party power to dominate next year's reapportionment. King defeated Republican Frank Bond. Popular incumbent Republican Pete Domenici won a lopsided U.S. Senate race over Democratic challenger Tom Benavides, an Albuquerque state senator. With 57 percent of precincts reporting, King had 116,858 votes, or 55 percent, to 96,194 votes, or 45 percent, for Bond. With 57 percent of precincts reporting in the Senate race, Domenici had 151,147 votes, or 72 percent, to 58,112 votes, or 28 percent, for Benavides. The GOP's 2-1 edge in the U.S. House was not threatened, as one Republican was unopposed and the incumbent Republican and Democrat in the other two districts were expected to win. King, 66, and Bond, 47, vied to succeed Republican Garrey Carruthers, who was prohibited by law from seeking re-election. However, a change in the state constitution will allow the winner to seek re-election in four years. King, a Stanley, N.M., rancher, served as governor longer than anyone in state history. He was governor from 1971 to 1974 and again from 1979 to 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon `Workfare' Plan Approved But Future Not Guaranteed
DOC.TEXT: Oregon voters approved an experiment that would substitute low-paying jobs for welfare payments, but the plan will require the approval of Congress. Measure 7, which passed 57 percent-43 percent Tuesday, calls for a three-year test in six counties that would eliminate food stamps, federal aid to families with dependent children and unemployment benefits. People eligible for public assistance would be assigned to jobs with public or private employers and be paid at 90 percent of the state's minimum wage, now $4.25 an hour. The proposal could not go into effect unless Congress waived a number of federal laws and regulations. ---
DOC.HEAD: City-County Merger Fails To Create Nation's 7th-Largest City
DOC.TEXT: Voters rejected a proposal to merge the city and county of Sacramento, which would have created the nation's seventh-largest city. The proposal lost by 58 percent to 42 percent in Sacramento County and by a margin of 51 percent to 49 percent inside the city. The county has just over 1 million residents. About 350,000 of them live in the city of Sacramento. Passage of the proposal would have created a city ranking above Dallas and below San Diego in population. The measure was supported by large developers and a variety of environmental, good-government and business groups. Independent developers opposed the measure. ---
DOC.HEAD: Atlanta Suburbs Reject Rapid Transit Link
DOC.TEXT: The Atlanta suburbs of Gwinnett County voted against a 1 percent sales tax to finance a $681 million extension of the city's rapid transit system. Voters rejected the plan 70 percent to 30 percent Tuesday. County Commissioner W.J. Dodd had predicted his constituents would reject extending a line of the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority because they feared ``the minorities.'' Blacks and other minorities comprise 6.4 percent of the county's 355,000 residents, and 66 percent of the 425,000 people living in Atlanta. ---
DOC.HEAD: Santa Monica Rejects Measure Seen Aimed at Homeless
DOC.TEXT: Voters in this coastal community rejected a ballot measure seen as aimed at the city's benign stance toward homeless people. The measure, which lost by a nearly 3-to-2 margin Tuesday, would have made the city attorney an elected rather than appointed post. Supporters of the proposal argued that City Attorney Robert Myers encouraged criminal and mentally ill homeless people to settle in Santa Monica by refusing to enforce such minor ordinances as a ban on sleeping in parks. Myers called the initiative ill-conceived. ``I think what it (the election result) shows is that voters are not ready to adopt extremist measures in dealing with a national tragedy,'' he said. ``Homelessness is not caused by the city attorney of Santa Monica. It is caused by forces operating throughout the nation.'' ---
DOC.HEAD: Santa Clara Voters Nix Financing Ballpark for the Giants
