DOC.TEXT: Voters in Santa Clara County narrowly rejected a plan to build a stadium for the San Francisco Giants, raising questions about the baseball team's future in Northern California. A 1 percent utility tax to finance the ballpark lost by less than 3,000 votes out of nearly 257,000 cast in five communities Tuesday. A separate, equally essential measure to approve the city of San Jose's participation in the project failed 49 percent-51 percent. The 45,000-seat, $153 million stadium was planned to open in 1994, replacing aging, windswept Candlestick Park, about 40 miles to the north in San Francisco. Giants owner Bob Lurie has said he will move the team unless a new stadium is built. Voters in San Francisco have twice narrowly defeated proposals to build a downtown stadium in their city. ---
DOC.HEAD: Voters Approve Purchase of Monarch Butterfly Habitat
DOC.TEXT: Residents of ``Butterfly Town USA'' mustered the two-thirds majority needed to buy a pine and eucalyptus grove where tens of thousands of migrating monarch butterflies spend the winter. The 2.7-acre grove, which will be purchased for $1.2 million, is one of the few remaining places in the western United States where Canadian monarchs can seek refuge from the cold. ``I just can't image Butterfly Town USA without butterflies,'' said Ro Vaccaro, member of the Friends of the Monarch. On the second Saturday of each October, Pacific Grove schoolchildren dress as butterflies and march through town spreading colorful wings to usher in the fall butterfly season. The grove had been slated for housing.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Rights Preserved in Oregon, Nevada
DOC.TEXT: A measure in Oregon that would have established the most restrictive anti-abortion law in the United States was rejected by a 2-1 margin. The law would have banned abortions except in cases of rape or incest or to prevent a woman's death. A second measure that would have required doctors to notify a parent at least two days before performing an abortion on a minor was also defeated, by a smaller margin. In Nevada, voters approved a measure to protect abortion rights. The measure prohibits any change in the state's abortion rights law except by direct vote of the people. Diane Linn, head of the Oregon chapter of the National Abortion Rights Action League, said, ``We're extremely excited that we were able to defeat both an easy and a very tough measure.'' Cindy Rahm, spokeswoman for United Families of Oregon, which sponsored the measure, said her group knew it faced an uphill battle from the start. ``We recognized from the very first that this is going to be a hard-fought battle,'' she said. ``Oregon legalized abortion before the Roe vs. Wade decision and it's always considered itself among the strongest states in advocating abortion.''

DOC.HEAD: Election Results Send Ambiguous Message
DOC.TEXT: Kentucky voters sent an ambiguous message by throwing out 11 state lawmakers - seven who voted for a $1.3 billion tax increase and four who did not. U.S. Sen. Mitch McConnell won another term. Kentucky's congressional delegation emerged unscathed. Two Supreme Court justices also were re-elected, and two new justices were selected to replace retirees. Of 11 state legislators who lost, seven were in the House and four in the Senate. Eight were Democrats and three were Republicans. All the defeated state senators voted for the $1.3 billion tax increase passed by the 1990 General Assembly. But four of the seven defeated House members voted against it. Republican McConnell won 53 percent of the vote, to 47 percent over Democrat Harvey Sloane. With all but 16 of 3,231 precincts reporting, McConnell received 474,672 votes to 428,781 for Sloane. An amendment to the state constitution to exempt religious institutions from virtually all property taxes was overwhelmingly approved. The turnout approached 50 percent of the state's 1.8 million voters, larger than most predictions.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbents Largely Avoid Voters' Wrath
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs `It means ...' with 2 grafs to ADD Wellstone quotes. Picks up 5th graf pvs `Democratic hopes ...
DOC.TEXT: Senate incumbents overcame widespread voter disenchantment as 31 of 32 lawmakers won re-election. The only loser was two-term Republican Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota. With 88 percent of precincts reporting, Boschwitz lost to college professor Paul Wellstone, a political neophyte, by a 52-48 margin. Wellstone's victory boosted Democrats' majority in the Senate to 56-44, a one-seat gain from the 101st Congress. ``I think the main thing was that people are kind of angry at Washington, don't feel represented and want to see some real change,'' Wellstone said today on NBC. ``We focused on issues and people. And it captured the imagination of people in Minnesota.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Democrats' success Tuesday ``means that the Republican chances of taking control in 1992 are much diminished and I think we will retain control in '92,'' Democratic hopes of picking up another seat in North Carolina were dashed as Republican Sen. Jesse Helms turned back a tough challenge from former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt. Meanwhile, some Democrats touted as possible contenders for President Bush's job in 1992 shored up their political standing with easy wins in Tuesday's election. The lone surprise was New Jersey Sen. Bill Bradley's slim victory over unheralded GOP challenger Christine Todd Whitman. Feeling the heat of anti-government anger prompted by Democratic Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase, Bradley managed a 52-48 percent victory. The margin was far below predictions of a 35 percent-plus victory for Bradley. Republican dreams of capturing the Senate seat in Hawaii disappeared as appointed Democratic Sen. Daniel Akaka withstood a stiff test from Rep. Pat Saiki and won his first full term. Wellstone, a liberal activist who traversed Minnesota on a green bus, stopped Boschwitz from returning to the Senate for a third term. ``If present trends continue, that bus is going to take a U.S. senator from Minnesota to Washington, D.C.,'' Wellstone told his backers Tuesday evening before he was declared the winner. Boschwitz, who hoped to receive a boost when Bush visited the state to campaign for him, told supporters he did not expect the race to be so close. Bradley, one of 14 Democratic incumbents who retained their Senate seats, expressed similar disbelief. ``What can I say? It's been a few years since I was in a double overtime,'' said the former Princeton University and New York Knicks basketball star. Republicans contend that Bradley's narrow victory could hurt his presidential aspirations. ``Senator Bradley might be off the charts now,'' said Charles Black, the communications director for the Republican National Committee. Democrats, however, said the final outcome was merely a reflection of the electorate's discontent and will have no bearing on a possible bid for the White House. The major Democratic target was Helms, the 69-year-old champion of the right wing who was pitted against Gantt. Helms, who had contended in the closing days that Gantt favored racial quotas, relished his victory. ``There is no joy in Mudville tonight,'' the senator said. ``The mighty ultra-liberal establishment, the liberal politicians and editors and commentators and columnists have struck out again.'' Democrats also hoped for a gain in Oregon, but four-term Republican Mark Hatfield outdistanced businessman-scientist Harry Lonsdale. Republicans retained control of the three open Senate seats. Rep. Robert Smith defeated former Sen. John Durkin in New Hampshire, while Rep. Hank Brown won in Colorado and Rep. Larry Craig was the victor in Idaho. Democratic incumbents Claiborne Pell in Rhode Island, Carl Levin in Michigan and Paul Simon in Illinois won surprisingly easy victories over well-financed Republican House members. Sen. J. James Exon, D-Neb., beat former Republican Rep. Hal Daub. Other incumbents of both parties won with ease. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, won unopposed. Sens. Thad Cochran, R-Miss., and David Pryor, D-Ark., also had no contests. Sen. Alan K. Simpson, R-Wyo. won easily. In South Dakota, Republican Sen. Larry Pressler gained a third term. Other senior incumbents returned to office were Sens. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., at 87 the Senate's oldest member; Howell Heflin, D-Ala.; John Warner, R-Va.; David Boren, D-Okla.; Pete Domenici, R-N.M.; William Cohen, R-Maine; Ted Stevens, R-Alaska; and Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va. Nunn and Bradley were two of several possible future presidential candidates who won re-election to the Senate. Others who won re-election were Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., and Phil Gramm, R-Texas, both with ease. Other winners were Sens. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan.; Mark Hatfield, R-Ore.; Joseph Biden, D-Del.; Dan Coats, R-Ind.; John Kerry, D-Mass.; and Max Baucus, D-Mont.

DOC.HEAD: No Link Between Hostage Release and Failed Troop Bill, Japan Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs to UPDATE with 74 Japanese hostages leaving, embassy officials saying three opted to stay behind. Pickup 13th, `Nonetheless...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japanese officials today heatedly denied any link between Iraq's release of more than 70 Japanese hostages and the Tokyo government's decision to drop its proposal to send troops overseas. Seventy-four Japanese nationals flew to freedom today with Japan's former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who secured their relase during a five-day mission to Iraq. The Iraqis had announced that 77 Japanese were free to go, but Japanese Embassy officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said three of them decided to stay in Baghdad to finish their businesss. The embassy officials denied that the Iraqis had refused to give exit visas to some of the Japanese. ``The Iraqis did not change their mind, the three businessmen did,'' said one of the officials. The departure of the 74 freed hostages leaves 237 Japanese in Iraq and occupied Kuwait, of whom 119 are held at strategic sites as ``human shields.'' In Tokyo, Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto told reporters ``it is unthinkable that there was any linkage'' between the release and other issues. ``America, Britain, and the European Community have taken the position that they will not directly negotiate over the hostages, and our government has followed the same basic position,'' Sakamoto said. But some analysts feared the timing of the two events would create the impression that Japan had succumbed to Saddam Hussein's apparent strategy to divide the international alliance against Iraq. They also worried that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's embarrassing setback in Parliament over the troop bill has further undermined his weak administration, particularly since he was shown up the same day by a powerful former prime minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone. The Iraqi News Agency reported that Nakasone had assured Saddam in a meeting Sunday that the troop deployment proposal was unlikely to succeed. On Tuesday, Iraq announced its hostage-releasing plan. On the same day, Kaifu and the governing Liberal Democratic Party abandoned the troop deployment proposal, which faltered against powerful opposition in Parliament and strong public opinion that it violated Japan's constitutional ban on using force overseas. The bill, which would have sent up to 2,000 troops to the Persian Gulf in a non-combat role, was also harshly criticized in recent weeks by other Asian countries fearful of a resurgence of Japanese militarism. Japan has already pledged $4 billion in aid for the multinational deployment and for refugees of the crisis. Japanese government officials could not confirm today whether Nakasone had made any assurances to Saddam. They said Nakasone's mission was unofficial. But Sakamoto said today that Nakasone pledged before his departure that he would demand the unconditional release of Japanese and all other hostages. Nonetheless, analysts said the timing of Nakasone's visit was unfortunate. It underscored the perception that Japan's Persian Gulf policy, never firm, was disintegrating in the hands of a weak prime minister upstaged by party elders. ``Even if this release was not related to the abandonment of the bill in the Diet (parliament), I would say criticism of Mr. Nakasone would be likely to come from Washington'' and other Western countries, said Masashi Nishihara, a politics expert at the Defense Academy. The bill was criticized by many Japanese as a cave-in to U.S. pressure to participate in the gulf. ``My concern is the lack of power of Mr. Kaifu,'' said Nishihara. By inviting Nakasone to visit, ``Iraq seemed to think that Kaifu is just no good and Nakasone would do a better job.'' Kaifu visited the gulf region early last month but was unable to obtain any solid results. Japan imports 70 percent of its oil from the gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Denies Reports He Gave Iraq an Ultimatum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with more background on Qian Qichen visit with Baker, fixe style on his name. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III today denied reports he gave Iraq an ultimatum to get out of Kuwait in the next two weeks. Reports by Israel army radio and stations in Luxembourg and Monte Carlo said Baker had asked his Chinese counterpart, Qian Qichen, to tell Saddam Hussein that U.S. forces would attack if he didn't comply. Baker met with Qian in Cairo, Egypt, on Tuesday. The Israeli report cited unidentified diplomatic sources in Cairo. RTL Plus television, a private station in Luxembourg, carried a similar story without citing a source. Radio Monte Carlo also reported a Baker ultimatum. Asked to comment on the reports, Baker told reporters in Turkey: ``The fact is I did not have such a conversation with the Chinese foreign minister.'' Baker stopped in Turkey on his weeklong tour of the Persian Gulf region to cement support for the anti-Iraq forces and to discuss military options. In its report, RTL Plus said of the reported ultimatum, ``Within 14 days Iraq must pull out of Kuwait. If not, the United States together with Saudi Arabia want to attack the gulf state.'' Qian indicated to Baker on Tuesday that Beijing would not stand in the way of any U.N. vote authorizing a military strike to force Iraq out of Kuwait, U.S. officials said. China is one of the five U.N. Security Council members with veto power over resolutions. But Qian, who met for two hours with Baker, did not explicitly approve sending troops into action and expressed hopes a peaceful settlement could be rached. ``We'll have to wait and see,'' he told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Repeal of Segregation Statute Holds Narrow Lead in Arkansas
DOC.TEXT: A proposal to strip Arkansas' constitution of a relic from its racist past appeared to have won voter approval - barely. Amendment 3, to repeal a 1956 anti-desegregation statute, held a 51-to-49 percent margin in unofficial returns from Tuesday's voting. With 2,580 of 2,696 precincts reporting, the amendment was leading 262,679, or 51 percent, to 250,946, or 49 percent. The 1956 law instructed state officials to ``take appropriate action and pass laws opposing in every constitutional manner the unconstitutional desegregation decisions of May 17, 1954 and May 31, 1955 of the United States Supreme Court.'' It was enacted the year before federal troops thwarted Gov. Orval Faubus' attempt to keep nine black students from enrolling at all-white Little Rock Central High. State officials have ignored the statute, and last year it was declared unconstitutional. But a federal district court mentioned it in orders that assigned the state liability for desegregating the Pulaski County schools. State leaders had said Arkansas surely would face national ridicule if the proposal failed. ``It would be a tremendous embarrassment if we don't vote this thing out. We need to clean up the constitution for our children,'' said Rep. Ben McGee, the first black legislator from eastern Arkansas since Reconstruction.

DOC.HEAD: Maine Governor Re-elected; Sunday Sales Referendum Tight
DOC.TEXT: Maine voters re-elected Republican Gov. John R. McKernan in a tight race that pushed Democratic U.S. Rep. Joseph E. Brennan from elective office for the first time in more than a decade. A referendum on a plan to repeal Maine's ``blue laws'' and allow large stores and supermarkets to do business on Sundays throughout the year appeared to be passing but was too close to call early today. Republican U.S. Sen. William Cohen won a third term handily, defeating state Rep. Neil Rolde, a Democrat. With 94 percent of the precincts, Cohen had 294,663 votes, or 61 percent, to Rolde's 185,189, or 39 percent. State Sen. Thomas Andrews of Portland was elected to fill the 1st Congressional District seat being vacated by Brennan. GOP Rep. Olympia J. Snowe, who is married to McKernan, clung to a slender lead over her Democratic challenger, state Rep. Patrick McGowan. With 96 percent of precincts reporting, Snowe had 112,494 votes to McGowan's 107,663 - a 51-to-49 percent margin. The outcome of the three-way gubernatorial race remained in doubt until shortly before daybreak today, although McKernan had expressed increasing confidence through the night that he had won a second four-year term. Returns from 94 percent of the precincts showed McKernan with 225,238 votes, or 47 percent, and Brennan with 211,677, or 44 percent. Independent candidate Andrew Adam maintained a 9 percent margin. Brennan served two four-year terms as governor, stepping down in 1987 because of a constitutional provision that barred him from a third successive term. In the 1986 election, he traded jobs with McKernan, who had held southern Maine's 1st Congressional District seat for two terms. With 82 percent of the precincts reporting in the Sunday sales referendum, the pro-repeal forces were leading by a 53 percent to 47 percent margin.

DOC.HEAD: Republican Wins U.S. Senate Seat, But Democrats Run Strong in State
DOC.TEXT: Republican Dan Coats won election to Dan Quayle's old U.S. Senate seat, but Indiana Democrats pronounced their party alive and well after winning several other key races. Coats, appointed to the Senate after Quayle was elected vice president, won the right Tuesday to serve the final two years of Quayle's term by defeating Democrat Baron Hill. In other races, however, Democrats held their seven U.S. House seats and took one of three away from the Republicans. Democrat Joseph Hogsett also defeated Republican William H. Hudnut for secretary of state in a hotly contested battle that may have an influence on the state's 1992 gubernatorial race. Hogsett had 702,746 votes, or 52 percent, to Hudnut's 662,022, or 48 percent, with about 92 percent of the vote counted early today. Hudnut, a four-term mayor of Indianapolis, was widely expected to run for governor in 1992 if he had won Tuesday's election. ``I think it's an important victory because what it firmly establishes is there is a healthy, competitive, two-party system in Indiana,'' said Hogsett, a protege of Democratic Gov. Evan Bayh. In the Senate race, Republican Coats, a four-term congressman, had 790,872 votes, 54 percent, to 682,131, 46 percent for state Rep. Hill, with 99 percent of the vote counted. But Democratic challenger Tim Roemer squeaked by incumbent Rep. John Hiler 51 percent to 49 percent in the 3rd District congressional race. With all votes counted, Roemer had 80,422 votes, to Hiler's 77,616. Republicans blamed the losses on low voter turnout. ``We are disappointed with the Republican turnout. There may be a number of factors for this, including the budget debate in Washington,'' said state Republican Chairman Keith Luse.

DOC.HEAD: Smith Takes Senate Seat With A Conservative Platform
DOC.TEXT: Republican Bob Smith says he's just a ``common man'' who will push conservative issues as a U.S. senator, such as maintaining the defense budget and supporting the ``Star Wars'' program. Smith made fiscal conservatism the overriding theme of his campaign to replace retiring Republican Sen. Gordon Humphrey. He voted against the recent federal budget compromise because it contained tax increases, which he said could be avoided. Despite that, President Bush campaigned in New Hampshire for Smith, who stayed in Washington because of House votes. Smith says one of his greatest accomplishments in three terms in the House was his leadership last year in defeating the 50 percent congressional pay raise, a claim derided by his Democratic opponent, former U.S. Sen. John Durkin. ``I'm a common man, representing common people with common goals and values and a whole lot of common sense, and I'm real proud of that,'' says Smith, 49. Born in Trenton, N.J., Smith lives in Tuftonboro. A veteran who served on a Navy supply ship during the Vietnam War, Smith was a high school history teacher and real estate agent before being elected to Congress in 1984. He consistently supports defense spending, including for the Strategic Defense Initiative, or ``Star Wars,'' program, and says any defense spending cuts due to improved relationships with unfriendly countries should be gradual. Smith opposes abortion except to save the life of the mother, but says he would support an exception for rape and incest if it meant enactment of federal anti-abortion legislation. He easily won the GOP Senate nomination in September over a pro-choice opponent. He opposes the Equal Rights Amendment and favors the death penalty for violent criminals. Smith served on the House Armed Services and Veterans Affairs committees. He and his wife, Mary Jo, have three children.

DOC.HEAD: Jefferson Says He'll Seek Predecessor's Advice
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana's 2nd Congressional District has been predominantly black since 1982, and this year voters elected a black congressman. Democratic state Sen. William Jefferson, a Harvard-educated lawyer, was elected Louisiana's first black congressman since Reconstruction on Tuesday when he defeated political newcomer Marc Morial. Congressmen in Louisiana's other five districts ran unopposed, as did U.S. Sen. J. Bennett Johnston. Complete unofficial returns showed Jefferson with 55,371 votes, or 52 percent, to Morial's 50,197 votes, or 48 percent. Jefferson, 43, succeeds retiring U.S. Rep. Lindy Boggs, 74. Boggs, a popular Democrat, served 17 years in Congress. She was re-elected three times even after reapportionment changed the racial makeup of her district. Morial, 32, is the son of New Orleans' first black mayor - the late Dutch Morial. He had hoped to capitalize on his father's popularity in the district, which encompasses almost all of the city. Boggs had stayed neutral during the race, but was at Jefferson's side during his victory speech late Tuesday. ``She has set the standard by which all great congressmen and women may be rightly judged,'' said Jefferson.

DOC.HEAD: Nevada Elects Anti-Abortion Governor; Approves Abortion Rights Measure
DOC.TEXT: Acting Gov. Bob Miller easily won election to a full four-year term, trouncing Republican Bob Gallaway by a more than 2-1 margin. With 99 percent of the vote tallied, Miller had 207,320 votes, or 65 percent; Gallaway had 95,649 votes, or 30 percent. Liberal Party candidate James Frye had 8,041 votes, or 3 percent. Miller became acting chief executive two years ago when Dick Bryan won a U.S. Senate seat. Gallaway, a wealthy businessman and newcomer to Nevada politics, campaigned unsuccessfully on a no-new-taxes platform and criticized Miller for the governor's anti-abortion stand. Voters also gave strong approval to Question 7, which makes it tougher to change the state's current law allowing abortions in the first six months of pregnancy and in the last three months if the mother's life or health is in danger. Sixty-three percent approved the abortion rights measure, with 37 percent opposed. In Nevada's two U.S. House contests, Democrat Jim Bilbray, and Republican Barbara Vucanovich easily won re-election. Bilbray had 61 percent of the vote to Bob Dickinson's 34 percent. Mrs. Vucanovich had 59 percent to Democrat Jane Wisdom's 34 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Fires Shots on Red Square During Holiday Celebration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 5-9 bgn, `Vozianov said...' with 8 grafs to UPDATE with details from KGB spokesman. Pickup 10th grafs pvs, `The incident ...'
DOC.TEXT: A marcher in today's Revolution Day parade fired two shots into the air in Red Square about 80 yards from where President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders were standing, reports said. No one appeared to have been hit by the shots and the man was immediately arrested, said Sergei Vozianov, a correspondent of the official news agency's video branch who witnessed the incident. He said by telephone that he could not determine whether the gunman fired at the Lenin Mausoleum, from which Gorbachev and the other leaders were watching thousands of marchers. The Tass news wire quoted KGB officials as saying the man fired into the air with a sawed-off shotgun and that no one was hurt. It said the gunman was from Leningrad but gave no further details. But Moscow KGB spokesman Andrei Oligov said the 38-year-old suspect fired a double-barreled hunting rifle that was shortened to be more easily concealed. The weapon is readily available on the thriving Soviet black market, and is often used by Soviet criminals. Oligov said the suspect, whose name was not immediately released, was questioned by authorities. Vozianov said the shots were fired about five seconds apart and that he was standing 10 yards from the gunman. The shooting occurred five minutes after Gorbachev, Russian President Boris Yeltsin and other officials returned to the mausoleum after talking with some demonstrators in another part of the square. Journalists standing near the mausoleum heard the shots over the sound of music playing through loudspeakers. Vozianov said about a dozen auxiliary police and KGB plainclothes agents immediately grabbed the gunman, knocked the shotgun to the ground and carried the man into the huge GUM department store, which is opposite the mausoleum. A videotape of the incident, recorded by the Tass video service, showed a plainclothes agent picking the gun off the gray cobblestones and putting it in his overcoat. The TV correspondent said the man was marching as part of a delegation from the Bauman region of Moscow that marched through Red Square as part of the pro-Communist demonstration. But Oligov said the suspect is not a Communist Party member, he said. The man wore brown shoes, a blue coat and carried a plastic bag, Vozianov said. The incident occurred on the Soviet Union's most important holiday, which celebrates the 73rd anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution. Thousands of anti-Communist demonstrators filled Moscow streets, which were already packed with Communist supporters.

DOC.HEAD: Was Balloting a Measure of Bush? It's Sure Shook Up His Veto Margin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs `It all ...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with Democrats gaining on seat in the Senate
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: It's getting lonelier at the top, where President Bush has seen his House veto margin shaken in off-year elections that also turned down Republican governors in two of the states he campaigned hardest to hold. Bush waged the most extensive midterm campaign of any president - a year-long effort that included 115 stops for Republicans and helped them raise more than $80 million. But he didn't have much to show for it. Republican Sen. Pete Wilson won the biggest of the off-year prizes, governor of California. That job is vital to Republicans, who a decade ago watched helplessly as Democrats carved up congressional districts to their advantage. With a Democratic legislature, only a GOP governor could block a replay, this time for a House delegation growing to 52 seats. But Democrats will succeed Republican governors in Florida, which is gaining four seats in the reapportioned House, and Texas, which picks up three. Bush made three campaign stops for Gov. Bob Martinez in Florida. And he spent the last three days in his Texas home base, stumping for Clayton Williams, the Republican gubernatorial nominee who lost to Democrat Ann Richards. Richards, the state treasurer, was the 1988 Democratic convention speaker who had taunted Bush as a man ``born with a silver foot in his mouth.'' Offsetting these Sun Belt setbacks, Republicans gained governors in Ohio and in Massachusetts and held on to Illinois. Those states, too, will draw new House districts next year, because of population shifts that cost them seats. For all the poll findings of voter frustration and disenchantment, incumbent members of the Congress proved, again, to be almost impervious to challenge. More than 95 percent of them were returned to Congress. Charles Black, spokesman for the Republican National Committee, said he saw ``more of an anti-incumbent trend than a partisan trend ... an anti-Congress trend rather than an anti-presidential trend.'' It all added up to a likely Democratic majority of 267-167 in the House, not counting socialist Bernie Sanders of Vermont. In the Senate, Democrats gained one seat as college professor Paul Wellstone ousted incumbent Republican Rudy Boschwitz. Those numbers are well below the average midterm losses of the White House party. But it's the mirror image of a 1988 presidential election in which the GOP lost congressional strength while the Bush ticket was winning. And even marginal losses could jeopardize Bush's ability to withstand the two-thirds votes it takes to override a presidential veto, a tool he has used 16 times so far. ``George Bush cannot win the Congress and must no longer rule by veto,'' said Rep. Richard A. Gephardt, D-Mo., the House majority leader. Other Democrats turned instantly toward the next election, with the White House at stake. ``We have an opportunity to do what was inconceivable six months ago - that is to defeat a Republican president,'' said Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, chairman of the Democratic Governors' Association. ``If the election for president were tonight, George Bush would lose,'' claimed Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman. But Edward J. Rollins, who manages the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee - and drew White House wrath by advising GOP candidates that they shouldn't hesitate to oppose Bush on tax increases - said he now thinks ``the president is doing fine.'' Democratic leaders who rank among the likely prospects to run against him in 1992 were re-elected on Tuesday. Among them are New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, Georgia Sen. Sam Nunn and Tennessee Sen. Albert Gore, who won in landslides, and Sen. Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who didn't. Bradley got a surprising challenge from a Republican woman whose chances against the two-term Democrat had seemed slim to none. She got little party support, financing was scanty, and she made the tightest of races out of it before Bradley edged by with 52 percent of the vote, his showing apparently dragged down by an unpopular Democratic state tax increase. The senator, who came to politics from professional basketball, said: ``It's been a few years since I was in double overtime.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Arrests Members Of Yahweh Sect in Racketeering Indictment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: News conference scheduled for 10 a.m. EST. Will be led.
DOC.TEXT: FBI agents swept through the temple of the controversial black religious sect known as the Yahwehs today and arrested several members on a racketeering indictment accusing them of murder, extortion and bombings. The sect leader, Yahweh ben Yahweh, was arrested in New Orleans, according to his Miami attorney, Ellis Rubin. A top lieutenant, Judith Israel, was taken into custody in Atlanta. Seven members were taken into custody at the Miami temple, he said, and others were being sought. The FBI confirmed the Yahweh sweep but would release no further information; a news conference was scheduled for later today. ``They chose to do this in the middle of the night,'' Rubin complained. ``I feel this is a grandstand act by (Miami U.S. Attorney) Dexter Lehtinen.'' Rubin said his client had appeared voluntarily before the grand jury investigating the Yahwehs, and had agreed to surrender himself when charges were brought. The 54-year-old Yahweh ben Yahweh, who has said he considers himself the son of God, was arrested at 3:30 a.m. in New Orleans, said Rubin. The Yahwehs, known for their flowing white robes, have been the subject of controversy for years in the Miami area. Some ex-followers have been murdered, and other have accused the sect of hounding former members who broke with the group. The Yahwehs have received strong support from many in the black community, however, because of their strong stand in favor of family and against drugs. The number of followers has been estimated at about 10,000. The groups owns several businesses and properties in inner-city Miami neighborhoods, and once took over a drug-infested housing project using clubs and guns to drive away residents. One Yahweh was arrested in that incident and convicted on charges related to the shooting of a resident. Rubin has accused the government of persecuting the sect.

DOC.HEAD: Tuesday's Voter Turnout Near Lowest in Nearly 50 Years
DOC.TEXT: Voter turnout in Tuesday's elections appears close to that of 1986, the lowest in nearly a half-century, voting analyst Curtis Gans said today. In the 1986 midterm election, 36.4 percent of eligible voters went to the polls, the fewest since 1942. ``If there are 3 million votes yet to be counted it will be slightly under 1986, if there are 4 million more it will be a little over,'' Gans said. ``Democrats stayed about the same in turnout, Republicans declined by very little and there was an increase in voting for third parties and others,'' said Gans, director of the nonpartisan Committee for the Study of the American Electorate. The vote for independents was boosted by the election of independent governors in Alaska and Connecticut and an independent House member in Vermont. While voting totals were still incomplete, Gans said he expected the final result to show slight increases in turnout in 23 states and slight declines in 23 others.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Still Top Foreign Customer of American Farmers
DOC.TEXT: Japan will continue as the No. 1 foreign customer of American farmers at least through the turn of the century, maintaining its lead over the European Community, according to Agriculture Department trade analysts. In the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, Japan once again topped foreign buyers of U.S. agricultural products at an estimated $8.3 billion, compared with the EC's imports of $7 billion. Emiko Miyasaka of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service said she expects Japan to maintain its lead over the 12-nation EC ``at least in the 1990s.'' Miyasaka said Tuesday in a telephone interview that Japan's top ranking as a foreign buyer of agricultural products appears solid through the turn of the century despite the EC's plan to unify economically by the end of 1992. Beyond the 1990s, however, she said the situation is too uncertain for predictions at this time. Miyasaka was asked to elaborate on a report by her agency last week which said Japan ``is likely to be among the strongest export growth markets'' for U.S. farmers. ``This optimism is based on the expectation that Japan's economic growth, while slowing, is expected to be the strongest of all industrialized countries, fueling consumer demand,'' the report said. Further, there has been some liberalization of Japan's agricultural imports through the current Uruguay round of negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. ``Since 1964, when it emerged as Asia's first billion-dollar market for U.S. farm products, Japan has steadily expanded its agricultural imports,'' the report said. Japan moved in front of the EC as the top U.S. farm market in 1988. Bulk commodities such as corn, soybeans, wheat, cotton, tobacco and logs are the big-ticket items, but Miyasaka and other analysts believe there are greater market opportunities for high-value products like beef, vegetables, citrus fruit, fruit juices and processed wood products. In 1988, the U.S.-Japan Beef Agreement opened the door to growing sales of beef - from a value of $556 million in 1987 to $1 billion last year. U.S. exports of fresh, frozen and prepared vegetables rose to $253 million by 1989, the report said. Sales of french fries, for example, rose to $79 million from $37 million in 1983. A thorn in this trade development has been Japan's rice policy, which effectively bars imports, part of a national policy to protect domestic growers. The United States has called on Japan during the GATT negotiations to ease the restrictions. Miyasaka noted that the U.S. position on Japanese rice is part of an overall bid under GATT to reduce trade restrictions all over the world. In any case, she said, whatever Japan does about its rice policy will not keep that country from continuing as the leading foreign market for American farmers. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - A plan calling for modest cuts in farm payments has been approved by the European Community, but U.S. farm organizations are watching closely to see what happens when it goes before international negotiators. ``It's a step,'' said Dave Lane of the American Farm Bureau Federation's Washington, D.C., office. ``But it'll still probably go right down to the wire.'' The Uruguay round of negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is scheduled to conclude Dec. 31 in Geneva. Late Tuesday, in Brussels, Belgium, the 12-nation EC endorsed a carefully worded proposal that sought to soothe fears of governments that their farmers would be hurt by reductions. At issue was a proposal to pare farm subsidies by 30 percent over 10 years, starting in 1986. Some reductions have already been made. The EC proposal, which had been due Oct. 15, will be submitted to the trade talks as the community's opening position in the final round of bargaining. Meanwhile, a coalition of 29 U.S. farm organizations and commodity groups on Tuesday released a letter to U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter declaring that no GATT agreement on agricultural trade would be preferable to one that ``papers over'' fundamental differences with the C. The American farm groups have bitterly attacked the EC's system of export subsidies and certain other practices that bear on world agricultural trade. ``As the deadline approaches without any encouraging sign from the EC that problems dealing with market access, export subsidies, and health and sanitary issues are truly negotiable, we are becoming increasingly concerned that a final agricultural package may be fabricated to once again paper over our differences,'' the groups said. The American Farm Bureau Federation and the National Grange were joined by 27 commodity and agricultural trade associations representing a wide variety of products, including meat, soybeans, nuts, avocados, raisins, peaches, cattle, corn, pork, turkeys, wheat, and fresh fruit and vegetables. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Milk production has been rising this year and so has the output of some major dairy products, according to a monthly report by the Agriculture Department. In September, butter production was estimated at 84.8 million pounds, up 4 percent from a year earlier. Total cheese output, excluding cottage cheese, was reported Tuesday at 477 million pounds, up 6 percent. Non-fat dry milk for human food was reported at 50.6 million pounds in September, up 13 percent from a year earlier. But ice cream production, at 62.9 million gallons, was down 1 percent from September 1989, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Republican state Sen. John Engler ousted Michigan Gov. James Blanchard by a razor-thin margin early today, dashing the Democratic incumbent's hopes for a third term.

Voters in the nation's capital sent Mayor Marion Barry back to private life by decisively rejecting his bid for a city council seat and electing newcomer Sharon Pratt Dixon to succeed him as chief executive. Jesse Jackson also won his first elected office Tuesday, a non-voting, unpaid ``shadow'' Senate seat from which he will attempt to persuade Congress to make the District of Columbia a state. Civil rights activist Eleanor Holmes Norton, a Democrat, was elected the district's non-voting delegate to Congress, defeating Republican Harry Singleton despite revelations that she and her husband had paid no local income taxes for seven years, beginning in 1983. Norton received 59 percent of the vote, compared with 30 percent for Singleton. District voters also narrowly rejected, 51-49 percent, a referendum that would have restored a sweeping law that required the city to provide overnight shelter to anyone who requested it. The city council scrapped the law earlier this year amid cost concerns. But the day belonged to Democrat Dixon, who captured 87 percent of the vote to 11 percent for her Republican opponent, former Police Chief Maurice Turner. She becomes the first black woman to lead a major American city. ``The people of the District of Columbia have ... sent a message clearly, unequivocally and almost universally,'' Dixon told cheering supporters. ``They have said it is time to clean house.'' Dixon also said she would seek Barry's help in calling for the resignations of all city employees he appointed. ``If he (Barry) won't cooperate in that regard ... then I am going to urge the city council to forge a partnership that allows us to do what the people of the District of Columbia clearly want,'' Dixon said. ``They want us to get rid of the waste. They want new blood. They want a government that responds and works again.'' Dixon was swept to victory with her pledge to root out corruption and waste within the city government. Her chief promise has been to cut 2,000 middle-level managers from the city payroll, a move she estimates will save $95 million. Jackson won an 11-candidate ``shadow'' Senate race with 44 percent of the vote. Many observers saw a clear link between Dixon's triumph and the defeat of Barry, who had been the dominant force in local politics since he was first elected mayor in 1978. He was convicted of cocaine possession last summer. ``One jury rendered a partial verdict in August, but today the jury of the voters issued their verdict, and issued a resounding no to Marion Barry,'' said Julius Hobson, a civic activist and former Barry aide. ``This city is tired of him and is ready for something new.'' Barry failed in his bid to win a city-wide council seat, despite his claim to have rebounded from the personal woes that led to his drug conviction and sentencing to a six-month prison term. Barry, running as an independent, finished third with 19 percent of the vote behind Democratic nominee Linda Cropp, who had 39 percent, and the incumbent, Statehood Party nominee Hilda Mason, who won 30 percent. ``I said that it was an uphill battle,'' a subdued Barry said after conceding his loss. ``I said it would be a miracle if I had won.''

DOC.HEAD: Bucking Election Trend, Oregon Voters Approve Tax Slashing Measure
DOC.TEXT: Oregonians bucked an Election Day trend and approved a property tax limit out of frustration over a state political system that is ``paralyzed,'' a leading backer of the measure says. ``People are realizing the political system is paralyzed,'' Don McIntire said Tuesday night. ``They (state leaders) just can't deal with this subject responsibly.'' With 99 percent of precincts reporting, Measure 5 had garnered 523,593 votes, or 52 percent, to 481,961 ``no'' votes, or 48 percent. Propositions aimed at slashing taxes or spending were also on ballots in Massachusetts, California, Nebraska, Utah, Montana and Colorado. All were defeated. The amendment would phase in a 1.5 percent property tax ceiling over five years instead of imposing it from the start. It would require the Legislature to replace whatever money would be lost to schools from the property tax cuts. The Legislative Revenue Office predicted the measure would cause property taxes to drop an average of 12 percent in the first year, and 45 percent by 1995, when the phased-in reduction was complete. Measures to limit property taxes have been on every Oregon statewide general election ballot except one since 1978. Voters defeated all of the earlier plans. This time, McIntire said, Oregonians sent a message to their state politicians that they no longer believed promises that the issue would be addressed. John Marshall of the Oregon School Boards Association, which opposed Measure 5, warned that school programs were facing ``major amputation'' as a result of Measure 5. Sponsors said the plan would protect the school system by giving lawmakers plenty of time to come up with money to replace the property taxes. Opponents, including most of the education establishment, said requiring the Legislature to replace the money as the tax ceiling declines would impose huge burdens on the state treasury. The good news, as far as most Oregon educators was concerned, was that voters rejected another ballot measure that would have granted $2,500 tax credits to allow parents to choose any school they liked: public, private or even church-related. The Legislative Revenue Office estimated the state's cost for replacing the money lost to schools would be $791 million in the 1991-93 budget period and rise to almost $3.2 billion in 1995-97. The school cost replacement money would consume almost half the entire state general fund by the 1995-97 budget period, according to the estimate.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbents Win Re-election in South Dakota
DOC.TEXT: Republican Larry Pressler won a third U.S. Senate term by his narrowest victory margin since he was first elected to Congress in 1974. ``That looks pretty good to me,'' Pressler said after winning re-election over Democratic businessman Ted Muenster, who launched a furious last-minute advertising campaign seeking to tap anti-incumbency sentiment by charging Pressler was ineffective and out-of-touch with constituents. With 93 percent of precincts reporting, Pressler had 126,123 votes, or 52 percent; Muenster had 108,360 votes, or 45 percent; and independent candidate Dean Sinclair had 6,113 votes, or 3 percent. In other races, Republican Gov. George Mickelson and Democratic U.S. Rep. Tim Johnson handily won re-election. Mickelson received 141,195 votes, or 59 percent, in defeating Democrat Bob Samuelson, a Democrat, who had 97,939 votes, or 41 percent. Johnson captured more than two-thirds of the vote in winning a third term in Congress. With 93 percent of the precincts counted, the congressman had 161,124 votes, or 68 percent, to Republican challenger Don Frankenfeld's 77,464 votes, or 32 percent. A ballot measure designed by an environmental group to require that large-scale landfills get legislative approval passed. With 85 percent of the state's precincts reporting, the garbage proposal was approved by 54 percent of the voters. But voters narrowly rejected a companion measure that would have further restricted the mining of precious metals in the Black Hills. Fifty-two percent of voters rejected the mining restriction.

DOC.HEAD: Engler Edges Blanchard, Levin Sweeps To Victory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Engler winning, new vote totals, background. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Republican John Engler ousted Michigan Gov. James Blanchard by a razor-thin margin today, ruining the Democratic incumbent's quest for a third term. With 99 percent of the precincts reporting, Engler had squeaked past Blanchard, 1,253,469 votes to 1,240,535, a margin of only 12,934 votes. Blanchard campaign spokeswoman Katie Wolf said early today that a recount was likely. A beaming Engler told cheering supporters and his staff this morning: ``I know we've won this. Wake me up when you know the margin.'' Engler is the first Michigan challenger to unseat an incumbent governor since Republican George Romney ousted Democrat John Swainson in 1962. In the Senate race, with 99 percent of the precincts reporting, Democratic incumbent Carl Levin had 1,450,319, or 58 percent. His challenger, Bill Schuette, had 1,036,169 votes, or 42 percent. Schuette blamed the outcome in part on the nationwide slump in Republican popularity following the October wrestling over the federal budget in Congress. Democrats, who held a 60-50 edge in the Michigan House going into the race, picked up one seat, unofficial returns showed. Blanchard's campaign was plagued by missteps. One of his television commercials was criticized as racist; he was criticized for dumping his 78-year-old lieutenant governor, Martha Griffiths; and his ex-wife wrote a book accusing Blanchard of having an extra-marital affair with the woman who is now his second wife. Early figures showed the Republicans keeping their narrow 20-18 edge in the state Senate. The Democrats kept their 11-7 edge in the state's 18-member congressional delegation.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with Republican winning Michigan governor's race; Bush in Oval Office but making no comment; party reaction. Picks up 9th graf pvs `Republicans picked ...' SUBS grafs 20 and 23 pvs to DELETE now-redundant first references to Black and Brown.
DOC.TEXT: Democrats today celebrated their gains in Congress and the takeover of governors' offices in high-growth Sunbelt states. They swiftly proclaimed the midterm election results ``a vote of no confidence in President George Bush.'' Republicans countered with the biggest prize of all as Pete Wilson kept the California governorship in GOP hands. The GOP also made inroads in the Northeast and industrial Midwest, electing governors in Michigan, Ohio and Massachusetts. In an election framed by fear of recession and war, by unhappiness with taxes and politicians, governors of both parties took a beating. That wasn't true in the House and Senate, where most incumbents won and where the 102nd Congress will look a lot like the late, unlamented 101st. ``We've got a lot to smile about,'' said Democratic National Chairman Ron Brown as he surveyed the midterm returns on CBS' ``This Morning.'' He mentioned takeaway wins for governorships in Florida and Texas, and said Bush ``campaigned heavily for 18 candidates and 14 of them lost.'' Bush spent the morning in the Oval Office and offered no comment. But the Republicans' chief spokesman, Charles Black, said the GOP had bested the trend for midterm losses, and insisted, ``It's a good day for the president.'' Of the 32 senators who sought re-election, 31 won easily. Only Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz lost - to liberal college professor Paul Wellstone. In the House, the re-election rate for incumbents was 96 percent. With several House races still to be decided, the likely outcome would give the Democrats a 268-167 majority, a gain of nine seats - including Vermont socialist Bernard Sanders, who's expected to side with the Democrats. The three fastest growing states - California, Florida and Texas - entered the election with Republican governors. The Democrats captured Florida and Texas, while the Republicans held on to California, Illinois and led the way into the post-Dukakis era in Massachusetts. As usual, some races were too close to call even hours after the polls closed. John Engler brightened the morning after Election Day for Republicans when he won the Michigan governor's race, ousting Democratic incumbent James Blanchard. That left three gubernatorial races undecided - Minnesota, Arizona and Nebraska. A half-dozen House seats were unsettled, as well, and in three of them Democratic incumbents were trailing. Lawton Chiles of Florida and Texas State Treasurer Ann Richards led the Democratic assault on statehouses crucial to next year's redrawing of political maps to follow population shifts to the Sunbelt. Wilson won the multimillion-dollar battle with Democrat Dianne Feinstein for California's top job. With 98 percent of the vote counted, Wilson had 49 percent of the total to Feinstein's 46 percent. Republicans picked up some statehouse of their own, electing governors in Ohio, where George Voinovich defeated Anthony Celebrezze; in Massachusetts, where William Weld edged out conservative Democrat John Silber; Vermont, where ex-governor Richard Snelling reclaimed his old job, defeating Peter Welch. But Democratic gains were more widespread. Joan Finney rode voter anger against GOP Gov. Mike Hayden to victory in Kansas and businessman Bruce Sundlun unseated Republican Gov. Edward DiPrete in Rhode Island on his third try. Democrats won formerly Republican statehouses in Oklahoma and New Mexico. Former Republican Sen. Lowell Weicker, always a maverick, was elected governor of Connecticut as an independent. In Alaska, former GOP governor Walter Hickel was running as an independent and leading two opponents for the governorship. The Democratic-dominated Senate emerged unscathed. Challenges once thought formidable were swept aside by well-financed incumbents. But the night had its terrifying moments for Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., whose anticipated easy ride to a third term ended up a cliffhanger before he outlasted rookie Republican Christine Todd Whitman. She capitalized on virulent anti-tax sentiment. Generally, it was not a good night for Democrats with presidential ambitions. Along with Bradley's scare, Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York received a disappointing 53 percent of the vote against a blundering Republican and a little known Conservative who were never seen as more than fighting for second place. Two other would-be presidents, Democratic Sens. Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and Joseph Biden of Delaware rolled over token opposition. Sen. Sam Nunn of Georgia was re-elected without opposition. Winning more easily than expected were Republican Sens. Jesse Helms of North Carolina, Mark Hatfield of Oregon, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, Democrats Daniel Akaka of Hawaii, Paul Simon of Illinois, Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, James Exon of Nebraska, Carl Levin of Michigan and John Kerry of Massachusetts. In Minnesota, Boschwitz spent more than $7 million, more than seven times Wellstone's budget. House GOP whip Newt Gingrich also had a scare. The outspoken Georgia conservative, who abandoned Bush when the president was seeking support for a budget compromise that increased taxes, narrowly edged Democrat David Worley. ``If the election for president were tonight, George Bush would lose,'' said the DNC's Brown. ``More than anything else this election has been a vote of no confidence'' in Bush. ``This is not a referendum on George Bush,'' countered GOP strategist Edward J. Rollins. ``He runs for re-election in 1992.'' The results did nothing to strengthen Bush for 1992. During the campaign, the president made 115 stops for Republicans and White House aides said his appearances raised $80 million. Particularly devastating to Bush was the loss in his adopted home state of Texas, where millionaire oilman Clayton Williams lost the governorship after spending $8 million of his own money. Florida's results also hurt Bush, who campaigned three times for Gov. Bob Martinez to no avail. The GOP's Black, filling in for ailing GOP National Chairman Lee Atwater. Black, who sought to minimize the damage, called the results ``an anti-Congress trend rather than an anti-president trend.'' ``We beat the historical averages in House races, Senate races and governorships by taking very minimal losses in yesterday's election,'' Black said. ``So, it's a good day for the president.'' In all, eight states will gain and 13 will lose seats when House districts are reapportioned to reflect population shifts enumerated in the 1990 Census. Democrats will control the process outright - holding the governor's office and both legislative chambers - in at least five of the states gaining House seats. The biggest winner will be California, gaining seven House seats. Florida will pick up four and Texas three. The only state where the GOP gained a redistricting monopoly was Vermont, where it won't matter. Vermont has only one House seat and that seat was captured by Sanders, who defeated Republican congressman Peter Smith. A record number of women sought office this year, but with mixed results. Richards and Finney were elected goverors and Whitman ran far stronger than even she could have dreamed. But challenges to Democratic senators by congresswomen Lynn Martin of Illinois, Claudine Schneider of Rhode Island, and Pat Saiki of Hawaii failed to live up to expectations. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., was an easy winner and the Senate remains 98 men and two women. All three congresswomen who sought Senate seats were replaced in the House by men. The highest profile black candidate was Harvey Gantt, the Democrat who challenged Helms in North Carolina. Gantt ran ahead in the polls, but on Election Day, Helms swept to victory. The number of blacks in the House increased by two to 25. William Jefferson was elected to the seat formerly held by Rep. Lindy Boggs, D-La., and Gary Franks of Connecticut will become the first black Republican in the House since 1935. In the District of Columbia, Sharon Pratt Dixon won the race to succeed Marion Barry as mayor. Barry, recently sentenced to six months in jail on a cocaine possession charge, failed in his bid for election to the city council as an independent. Voters in California, Colorado and Kansas City, Mo., approved measures limiting the terms politicians can serve. The ``Big Green'' initiative in California was voted down 2 to 1 and environmental ballot proposals also lost in Oregon and Missouri. Massachusetts voters rejected a $2.6 billion tax rollback.

DOC.HEAD: Beating Incumbents Old Hat for Michigan Governor-Elect
DOC.TEXT: When it comes to beating incumbents, governor-elect John Engler wrote the book, or at least the term paper. The 42-year-old Republican launched his political career in 1970 by beating an incumbent state House member after writing a college term paper on the subject while a student at Michigan State University. Engler defeated an incumbent state senator in 1978, but the biggest coup came in Tuesday's nip-and-tuck governor's race when he ousted two-term Democrat James Blanchard. Engler's victory returned the governor's office to GOP hands for the first time since 1982 and marked the first time an incumbent governor had been bounced out of office since 1962. Engler's mother, who appeared in campaign ads, said she thought he might be headed for higher office. ``I was always telling everybody when he was 2 years old, `He's going to run for president,''' said Agnes Engler. Engler grew up on the family's cattle farm near Beal City where hard work was a way of life for the seven children. When he wasn't working, he was reading or trying to get elected to a leadership post at school or in Future Farmers of America. Engler was active in dorm government at Michigan State, where he graduated in 1970. Fighting to have guests of the opposite sex visit was a major goal, he said, recalling how he invented a curtain to hang in doorways to skirt the university rule requiring open doors. He was married to Colleen House in 1975 and divorced in 1987. They had no children. Engler became Senate majority leader in 1984. ``He works. The guy will work and work and work,'' said Republican Sen. Richard Posthumus. Engler was a strong majority leader who was able to keep Senate Republicans voting together, but often was an obstructionist, said Sen. Mitch Irwin, a Democrat. ``John changes his mind and looks for every technical way to adjust and sneak out of a deal and go back on his word.'' What that really means, Engler said, is that he is a strong negotiator. ``I'd say we've been aggressive and have pursued an agenda, we have been innovative and novel in developing approaches to legislation.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Bolster Redistricting Advantage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf to show California legislative results. Subs 14th graf to update with Washington results.
DOC.TEXT: Democrats bolstered their huge redistricting advantage by adding two big prizes - Florida and Texas - to the list of states where they hold a lock on redrawing political lines for the next decade. Besides taking the governorships in those two states - considered key because together they stand to gain seven U.S. House seats - Democrats added Rhode Island, Oklahoma and New Mexico to their remapping monopolies on Tuesday. Republicans won a crucial redistricting battle by taking the California governor's race. The GOP needed it to keep a role in drawing lines for the seven new House seats California is expected to gain, because Democrats easily retained control of the Legislature. The GOP also scored victories by winning the Ohio and Illinois governorships, but Democrats clearly will have the national edge on the process of reapportioning the 19 House seats that will change hands due to population shifts of the 1980s. Advantages won Tuesday should help cement Democrats as the House majority party for at least another decade. Democrats also said the Florida and Texas wins would boost their 1992 presidential hopes. ``We feel better about the prospects of fair districts when the pen is in Democratic hands,'' said Paul Tully, political director for the Democratic National Committee. ``These are not only net victories but victories in places that because of their population growth will grow more important to the future of this country and also to the presidential race,'' Tully said. According to preliminary Census Bureau figures, eight states will gain and 13 will lose seats when House districts are reapportioned next year. Democrats will control the process outright in at least five of the states gaining House seats. Despite the anti-incumbent mood thought to be sweeping the country, voters appeared unwilling to turn out their state legislators. Millions of dollars were spent on legislative races this year due to their importance in the redistricting picture, but few chambers changed hands. The GOP turned back Democratic efforts to take over the senates of New York, Pennsylvania and Ohio. Redistricting power will be shared in all three states, which will lose House seats in 1992. ``This proves the Republican Party is alive and well despite the doom and gloom predicted,'' said New York's state Senate Republican leader, Ralph Marino. Democrats fended off Republican efforts to take over the state senates in Illinois and Florida and the lower chamber in Pennsylvania. The GOP was trying to wrest control of the Oregon House from Democrats, too. Arizona's gubernatorial race was up for grabs, as the lead seesawed throughout Election Night. Meanwhile, the GOP lost the Indiana House, but Republicans kept control of the state Senate. Democrats captured control of the state Senate in Arizona. A Democratic effort to gain control of the Washington state Senate hinged on absentee ballots in two neck-and-neck races. In Michigan, Republicans kept control of the state Senate. By losing in the governorships in Texas and Florida, the GOP lost its say in how political maps will be drawn for those ne House seats. Similar gubernatorial wins in Rhode Island, Oklahoma and New Mexico gave Democrats absolute control there, too. The House delegations in those states won't change, but Democrats can aim to draw districts that protect their House incumbents and perhaps endanger GOP lawmakers. The political lines for state seats are at stake as well. Another victory for Democrats came in Kansas, where they ousted a Republican governor and gained control of the state House. Kansas will lose one House seat. Election Day began with Democrats controlling 69 of the nation's 99 legislative chambers, and that margin was on track to change little. More than 6,100 legislative races were decided across the country, but the focus of national party organizations was about 50 races in 10 states in which chambers were held by narrow majorities. The Democrats were in position to draw districts that in 1992 could pad their House majority, now at 258-175 with two vacancies, by a dozen seats or more beyoe Tuesday. The other five House seats are expected to go to Virginia, North Carolina, Georgia, Washington and Arizona. Democrats already had a redistricting monopoly in Virginia and kept their sole control in North Carolina and Georgia. A nonpartisnd the gains madan commission draws the map in Washington. Among the 13 states losing seats, New York will suffer the most - giving up three. Pennsylvania, Ohio, Michigan and Illinois are to lose two seats each. Losing one will be Massachusetts, New Jersey, West Virginia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Iowa, Kansas and Montana.

DOC.HEAD: Freight Train Derailment Halts Amtrak Service
DOC.TEXT: A freight train partially derailed today, blocking rails and interrupting both north- and southbound Amtrak passenger service along the East Coast, authorities said. Eleven cars of a southbound, 96-car Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Co. freight train slipped off the tracks about eight miles north of this rural northern Virginia town, a spokesman for the railroad said today. ``There are no hazardous materials in any of those cars and no one was hurt,'' RF&P Director of Labor Relations William E. Griffin said. The cause of the derailment wasn't immediately known, he said. Several freight cars toppled, damaging both the north- and southbound rail lines, Amtrak spokesman Cliff Black said. The accident about 6 a.m. halted the Amtrak Silver Meteor, bound from Miami and Tampa, Fla., to New York. ``Passengers are being off-loaded onto buses, which will take them to Washington,'' Black said. About 300 New York-bound passengers were to pick up other trains in Washington, he said. Two Amtrak trains originating in Richmond were canceled, and passengers were bused to Washington, Black said. The freight the train was carrying included paper and ground limestone, officials said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, bgng: But Democrat, to UPDATE with Blanchard losing Michigan governor's. Picks up 7th graf pvs, In Massachusetts
DOC.TEXT: Here are some highlights of Tuesday's election:
DOC.HEAD: GOVERNORS' RACES
DOC.TEXT: Three Republican incumbents lost as voters in 36 states elected governors. Democrat Ann Richards was the victor of the hotly contested Texas race, defeating Republican Clayton Williams. Former U.S. Sen. Lowell Weicker, running as an independent, won in Connecticut. In Florida, Democrat Lawton Chiles unseated Republican Gov. Bob Martinez and Rhode Island Gov. Edward DiPrete was defeated by Democrat Bruce Sundlun. Democrat Joan Finney, an abortion opponent, ousted Republican Gov. Mike Hayden in Kansas. But Democrat Dianne Feinstein lost the California gubernatorial race to Republican Sen. Pete Wilson, and in Michigan, Senate Republican Leader John Engler narrowly upset two-term Democratics Gov. James J. Blanchard. In Massachusetts, Republican William Weld won his race against Democrat John Silber. Illinois Republican Jim Edgar defeated Democratic rival Neil Hartigan. In Georgia, Democrat Zell Miller grabbed the seat given up by a retiring Democrat.

Democrats retained control of the Senate as incumbents showed their strength. In the most closely watched contest, conservative Republican Sen. Jesse Helms of North Carolina defeated Democrat Harvey Gantt, a liberal who was the first black mayor of Charlotte. In a surprisingly close race, Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley of New Jersey defeated Republican challenger Christine Todd Whitman, a virtual unknown in her first statewide bid. Democratic Sens. Paul Simon of Illinois and Carl Levin of Michigan fought off their Republican challengers. The GOP retained all three seats where its senators were retiring. Rep. Robert Smith defeated Democrat John Durkin in New Hampshire, Rep. Hank Brown beat Democrat Josie Heath in Colorado and Rep. Larry Craig of Idaho won over Democrat Ron Twilegar.
But in Minnesota, incumbent GOP Sen. Rudy Boschwitz lost to college professor Paul Wellstone, a political neophyte.
DOC.HEAD: HOUSE RACES
DOC.TEXT: Democrats grabbed nine seats from the Republicans and GOP candidates captured three previously Democratic seats. Voters elected the first socialist to the House since 1929 and the first black Republican since 1935. In Vermont, socialist Bernard Sanders defeated GOP Rep. Peter Smith and Connecticut Republican Gary Franks, who is black, dashed the comeback hopes of former Democratic Rep. Toby Moffett. An upset in Wisconsin cost 32-year veteran Democrat Robert Kastenmeier his seat. It went to a former Madison newscaster, Scott Klug. Five-term Rep. Denny Smith of Oregon was defeated in his second round with Democrat Mike Kopetski, who had narrowly lost to Smith two years ago. Virginia GOP Rep. Stan Parris lost to Democrat James Moran, and in Florida, Democrat-turned-Republican Bill Grant was soundly defeated by Democrat Pete Peterson. Maryland Democratic Rep. Roy Dyson, troubled by character questions, was ousted by Republican Wayne Gilchrest. In Minnesota, six-term GOP Rep. Arlan Stangeland was defeated by Collin Peterson in a heavily agricultural district. Rep. Newt Gingrich, the combative No. 2 House Republican leader, barely survived his rematch against Democrat David Worley in a suburban Atlanta district.

DOC.HEAD: Voinovich Elected Governor; Casino Issue Fails
DOC.TEXT: The comfortable margin by which Republican George Voinovich appeared to have defeated Democrat Anthony J. Celebrezze in the governor's race surprised even the victor. ``Wow, what a victory,'' a beaming Voinovich shouted to a roomful of supporters in Columbus. Unofficial returns showed Voinovich received 1,924,404 votes, or 56 percent, compared with 1,528,414 votes, or 44 percent, for Celebrezze. Among the ballots still to be counted were ballots arriving from soldiers in the Persian Gulf. Voters soundly defeated an initiative to allow casino gambling in the city of Lorain. Voinovich replaces Democrat Richard Celeste, who leaves office after two consecutive terms, the most allowed by law. ``We fought the good fight. It came up short. I accept it. I have faith in the voters,'' Celebrezze said as he conceded defeat. In congressional races, Democrat Charles Luken edged Republican J. Kenneth Blackwell in the 1st District. Luken succeeds his father, Thomas, who is retiring. Republican John Boehner defeated Democrat Gregory Jolivette in the 8th District to succeed Donald Lukens. Lukens lost in the Republican primary after being convicted of having sex with a teen-ager. He resigned last month. Republican David Hobson beat Democrat Jack Schira in the 7th District. The incumbent, Michael DeWine, was elected lieutenant governor. Voters re-elected 18 other congressional incumbents.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting to CORRECT cycle designator
BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Republican Arne Carlson, who wasn't even on the ballot 10 days ago, defeated Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich by a tiny margin today to win the wildest Minnesota governor's race ever.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting to FIX category code
Virginia Democrats Take 6-4 Advantage in House
DOC.TEXT: Alexandria Mayor James P. Moran Jr. ousted Republican Congressman Stanford E. Parris, giving Democrats the majority of Virginia's seats in the House of Representatives for the first time in 24 years. The other nine incumbents held on to their seats Tuesday. Democrats now hold six of the state's 10 House seats. Ten years ago, Democrats held just one House seat. ``It's a great turnaround,'' said state Democratic Chairman Paul Goldman. ``We put a lot of effort into the Moran campaign.'' Moran, who made his support for abortion rights a key campaign issue, received 88,470 votes, or 52 percent, to 76,391 votes, or 45 percent for Parris in the 8th District race. In the only statewide race, Republican U.S. Sen. John W. Warner won a third term by a landslide over independent Nancy B. Spannaus, an associate of imprisoned political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. Warner got 872,764 votes, or 82 percent, while Mrs. Spannaus received 196,161 votes, or 18 percent, according to unofficial returns. ``I'm very honored and I accept the tallies with great humility,'' Warner said. ``The voters turn to experience'' in difficult times such as the present, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Goddard, Symington Battle For Governorship
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with new figures and with election officials saying runoff certain; Picks up 6th graf pvs, ``Almost 7,000..''
DOC.TEXT: Republican Fife Symington nursed a tiny lead over Democrat Terry Goddard early today in a nip-and-tuck race for governor, but the margin was so thin that election officials said a runoff was certain. Symington, a millionaire developer, led Goddard, former Phoenix mayor, by about 3,589 votes with 99 percent of 1.04 million votes counted. Legislators approved a constitutional amendment require runoffs in races in which no candidate receives a majority of the votes, but no laws are in place to implement a runoff. Officials say it could be next spring before a runoff is completed. An estimated 300 ballots were reported missing from a Phoenix precinct considered Goddard territory and nearly 2,000 absentee ballots remained to be counted. Almost 7,000 votes went to write-in candidates, including Max Hawkins, a former aide to impeached Gov. Evan Mecham. Hawkins entered the race after the primary, saying he wanted to offer an anti-abortion alternative. Arizona's four GOP and one Democratic congressmen won by margins of 57 percent and larger. Neither of Arizona's two U.S. senators was up for re-election, and none of the state's congressmen faced more than token opposition. Secretary of State Rose Mofford, a Democrat, was elevated to fill Mecham's term but didn't seek one of her own. Mecham lost out in the GOP primary. Mofford will likely remain in office until a runoff is held or the race is otherwise decided. Voters defeated two ballot measures that attempted to create a paid holiday honoring Martin Luther King Jr. One King plan went down by a 3-1 margin, as expected. The other, expected to win narrowly, lost by about 11,000 votes. Observers attributed the defeat to a report that the National Football League would move the 1993 Super Bowl from Arizona if the measure failed. ``They tried to leverage the public and that just won't work,'' said Phoenix Mayor Paul Johnson. Other propositions rejected included one to boost the pay of state legislators by 60 percent to $24,000 per year and a $6 billion, 10-year boost in education spending. Voters approved an initiative to use $20 million of Arizona Lottery money each year to acquire land for wilderness areas or parks. They also approved a victims rights plan.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: This is another take in the running series.
DOC.TEXT: Here is a partial list of candidates who have won their races in the general election.
BULLETIN: (AP) - Nelson, Dem, elected Governor, Nebraska. BULLETIN: (AP) - Studds, Dem, elected House, District 10, Massachusetts.

DOC.HEAD: Fusion Scientist Hides From Television Cameras, Attends Review
DOC.TEXT: A panel of scientists today began reviewing Utah's National Cold Fusion Institute, with a member saying their study of the controversial research would be open and objective. As the meeting got under way, electrochemist B. Stanley Pons - who along with British colleague Martin Fleischmann claims to have produced nuclear fusion in room-temperature experiments - ducked from television cameras after being spotted sitting on the back row. All the meetings are closed. A sign posted outside the door of the meeting room stated: ``It is required that only those persons who have signed a National Cold Fusion Institute confidentiality agreement attend this review.'' The panel, hired by the state Fusion Energy Advisory Council, is comprised of Stanley Bruckstein, a professor of chemistry at State University of New York at Buffalo; Loren G. Helper, a chemist from Alberta, Canada; Dale F. Stein, president of Michigan Technological University; and Robert Adair, a professor of Physics at Yale University. Stein, who was also a member of the original Department of Energy fusion panel, said although that group recommended against federal funding for the project, he would remain objective. ``I was very open and objective as a member of that panel,'' he said. He said the group would Fritz Will, director of the institute, said he was pleased with the selection of scientists and predicted the review would move smoothly. ``This is no different from any other scientific review,'' he said. ``The only thing that makes this one different is the attention of the media because it involves cold fusion.'' Will said Pons was expected also to attend Thursday's meeting of the state Fusion Energy Advisory Council, which is reviewing the state's expenditure of $5 million in cold fusion research. Last year, the claim by Pons and Fleischmann that they had created energy through so-called ``cold fusion'' created a sensation in the scientific world. Experts had said that it was believed the fusion of atoms could be achieved only at extremely high temperatures. But controversy erupted when many other scientists said they could not duplicate the Utah scientists' findings. The furor erupted anew last month when Pons and Fleischmann failed to appear at a meeting of the fusion council. The pair's attorney, C. Gary Triggs, said at the time they were reluctant to divulge much information because they were working on a new patent application, but council chairman Raymond Hixson noted the state held any patents and, in any event, all council members were sworn to secrecy. Fusion, which powers the sun and stars, creates energy by combining, or fusing, two hydrogen atoms into a heavier helium atom. By contrast, fission, which powers conventional nuclear plants, creates energy by splitting atoms. Fusion long has been sought as a potential source of cheap, safe and virtually inexhaustible energy.

DOC.HEAD: Some Kahane Mourners Vow Revenge; Funeral In Jerusalem Turns Violent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to update with funeral violence in Jerusalem, picking up 3rd graf pvs, `The alleged...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Followers of Rabbi Meir Kahane shook their fists and vowed revenge at the funeral of the assassinated militant leader. Police stepped up security at Arab and Israeli diplomatic offices and Jewish newspapers. Mainstream Jewish leaders in New York and Israel, where the body of the 58-year-old anti-Arab extremist was flown for burial today, appealed for calm. But the funeral procession in Jerusalem turned violent today when scores of people broke away from the march to smash shop windows and chase Arabs down nearby streets. Kahane supporters moved from shop to shop, asking owners whether they employed Arabs before smashing windows. Along the procession's route, one terrified Arab ran down the street, followed by several Kahane loyalists shouting ``Death to terrorists!'' Near the cemetery, an Arab was beaten to the ground and members of Kahane's Kach movement tried to block an ambulance from arriving. The alleged assassin remained in serious condition at Bellevue Hospital. El-Sayyid A. Nosair, 34, of Cliffside Park, N.J., was identified as a Moslem immigrant from Egypt who repaired air conditioners for the city of New York.
