Police said they had not established any links between Nosair and terrorist groups. ``There will be revenge. We believe in revenge,'' said Sol Margolis, president of Kach International, the U.S. arm of Kahane's extremist Israeli party, as thousands of mourners thronged a Brooklyn synagogue for his funeral. ``We don't buy that crap of turning the other cheek. There will be hell to pay for this affront,'' he said Tuesday. ``Revenge!'' said several signs written in red Hebrew letters outside the synagogue. ``Death to Arabs!'' a small contingent shouted. Mourners also took up the cry ``Never again!'' - the slogan of the Jewish Defense League, formed by the Brooklyn-born rabbi in 1968 to take up arms against anti-Semitism in the United States. The slogan refers to the Holocaust. Police stepped up security at the U.N. missions for Israel, Saudi Arabia and Egypt, El Al Israel Airlines offices and several Jewish newspapers. Dr. M.T. Mehdi, president of the American-Arab Relations Committee, said of the threats of reprisals, ``I hope this is just hyperbole, more rhetoric.'' Zaheer Uddin, president of the New York unit of the Islamic Circle of North America, condemned the assassination but said it should come as no surprise. ``He lived by his sword and died by it,'' Uddin said. ``We hope that Mr. Kahane's assassination will be the last act in the cycle of violence and counterviolence.'' The Israeli government appealed for peace as well, and police and army reinforcements spread out in Israel and the occupied territories to head off revenge attacks. Two Arab deaths on Tuesday were linked to Kahane's slaying. Kahane, who campaigned to drive all Arabs from Israel as an extreme right-wing member of the Jewish state's Parliament, was shot from four feet away Monday night after addressing a Zionist group at a Manhattan hotel. Nosair was shot in the neck by a postal police officer as he fled. He was charged with murder and other offenses. The New York Times today quoted an unidentified law enforcement official as saying Nosair denied shooting Kahane when he came out of sedation. His wallet included an ad from a Jewish newspaper for Monday night's event, officials said. Nosair immigrated in 1981 and took U.S. citizenship last year, authorities said. His American wife converted to Islam and the couple had three children. A motive has not been established, police said. ``What we have and all we know is that we have a lone gunman who committed a homicide in New York,'' said Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli. The identification numbers on the murder weapon, a .357-caliber revolver, had been filed off, making it difficult to trace, police said. Mainstream Jewish leaders, many of whom reviled Kahane for such acts as a fatal firebombing in 1972 that was linked to the JDL, appealed for restraint. ``The bullet that killed Rabbi Kahane was the opening of what might fearfully be a wave of terrorism, and collectively we stand against it,'' said Rabbi Max Shreier, one of a stream of speakers at the funeral. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said, ``We don't see this as a time for revenge. Now is the time for restraint.'' ``The guilty person should be tried and punished under our laws,'' said Rabbi Irwin Groner, president of the Rabbinical Assembly. ``But we urge that no further violence be perpetrated.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Democrats Lead in Governor Races but GOP Takes California, Michigan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf pvs, bgng: In Arizona, to UPDATE with runoff called
DOC.TEXT: Democrats won hard-fought governor's contests in Florida and Texas but the GOP countered with major victories in California and Michigan and a stunning upset in Minnesota. In California, Sen. Pete Wilson, the Republican, pulled ahead to capture the governorship of the nation's most populous state, narrowly defeating Democrat Dianne Feinstein, the former mayor of San Francisco. In Minnesota, Republican state auditor Arne Carlson staged a narrow, upset victory over Gov. Rudy Perpich after a tumultuous campaign. Carlson became the GOP candidate when nominee Jon Grunseth dropped outof the race just nine days before the election after a series of accusations involving alleged sexual misconduct. In Michigan, Senate Republican Leader John Engler narrowly upset Gov. James J. Blanchard, who was vying for a third term in a sagging auto economy. By mid-morning, Democrats had won in 18 states and Republicans in 15, while independents won two others. Republican George Voinovich snatched the governor's chair from Democratic control in another large state, Ohio, defeating state Attorney General Anthony Celebrezze Jr. In Illinois, the victory of Republican Secretary of State Jim Edgar kept the governorship in GOP hands. Edgar defeated Democratic Attorney General Neil Hartigan to succeed four-term Republican Gov. Jim Thompson. Edgar said he had made clear in his campaign that cutting taxes now would hurt education in the state. ``I think people like to have a public official who will level with them before the election and not surprise them after the election,'' he said. In most governor's races, however, Tuesday's tide was Democratic. In one of the narrowest of victories, Nebraska Democratic businessman Ben Nelson defeated incumbent Republican Gov. Kay Orr, who had sought a second term as the state's first female governor. A recount was possible. In Arizona, Republican real estate developer Fife Symington held a whisker-thin lead over Phoenix Mayor Terry Goddard, a Democrat. Elections officials said a runoff would be held because neither candidate had received more than 50 percent of the total votes cast, a requirement for election in Arizona. Democratic Gov. Rose Mofford will remain in office in the interim. Oregon elected a woman, picking Democratic Secretary of State Barbara Roberts over Republican Attorney General David Frohnmayer. She said voters were ``fed up with politicians giving them fluff'' and appreciated what she said was her ``tell-it-like-it-is style.'' Being a woman helped, she said. ``Voters really trust women. They think they are honest and straightforward. I think there is a comfort level with women in politics now,'' she said. In Massachusetts, Republican William F. Weld came from behind to defeat maverick Democrat John Silber, on leave as president of Boston University. Weld called his victory ``a referendum on big government,'' high spending and high taxes of the kind he said characterized the administration of outgoing Democratic Gov. Michael Dukakis. ``They've really been spending money on Beacon Hill like drunken sailors and that's why people went Republican,'' Weld told ABC-TV today. Former Democratic Sen. Lawton Chiles defeated first-term GOP Gov. Bob Martinez in Florida. Chiles' support for abortion rights appeared to help him against the antiabortion governor. But Chiles gave credit to a grassroots campaign that limited campaign contributions to $100 a person and to voter unhappiness with ``government gridlock.'' ``I think it's a vote by people that know government today is not working,'' Chiles told ABC. Kansas state Treasurer Joan Finney unseated Republican Gov. Mike Hayden, even though her anti-abortion stance lost her the support of feminist groups. In Texas, Ann Richards, also her state's treasurer, defeated oil millionaire Clayton Williams, whose campaign was marked by campaign gaffes and an 11th hour disclosure that he failed to pay any federal income tax in 1986. Richards said the result showed ``the strength of government is based on the power of the people, not the power of money.'' Williams hushed supporters who booed her name and said, ``I will always cherish the faith that you had in me.'' In Nebraska, Republican Gov. Kay Orr, the only woman governor seeking re-election, was locked in a tight battle with Democrat Ben Nelson. President Bush campaigned heavily for both Martinez and Williams in the closing days of the campaign. ``To the degree that George Bush was a factor, he was a burden,'' said Ohio's retiring Gov. Richard Celeste, head of the Democratic Governors' Association. ``We have an opportunity to do what was inconceivable six months ago - that is, defeat a Republican president.'' Larry Sabato, a University of Virginia political scientist, said the governors' races were not a referendum on Bush but ``have major implications for him, his re-election race and his party. This has got to be a major disappointment for Bush and the Republicans.'' Democratic Gov. Robert P. Casey Jr. was a big winner in Pennsylvania. Auditor General Barbara Hafer had gone after him for signing two bills restricting abortions. In Rhode Island, Republican Gov. Edward D. DiPrete was resoundingly defeated by Democrat Bruce G. Sundlun. DiPrete, governor since 1984, lost support when the state's economy went into a steep decline. In Vermont, where Democratic Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin is stepping down, voters returned her Republican predecessor, Richard Snelling, to office. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, a potential Democratic presidential candidate for 1992, breezed to victory over millionaire economist Pierre Rinfret, who alienated the GOP establishment with his attacks on fellow Republicans. Former Republican Sen. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. was elected governor of Connecticut as an independent and said, ``I hope we sent a message that dirt is out of politics in the state of Connecticut.'' He defeated two members of Congress, Republican John G. Rowland and Democrat Bruce A. Morrison. Another longtime Republican, former Interior Secretary Walter Hickel, also was elected governor as an independent in Alaska. In Maine, incumbent Republican John McKernan edged former Democratic Gov. Joseph Brennan. Democrat Bill Clinton, who has been governor of Arkansas for 10 of the past 12 years, was easily elected to another term over first-time candidate Sheffield Nelson. Democratic incumbent Roy Romer quickly put down a challenge by conservative think tank founder John Andrews in Colorado. Georgia's Democratic lieutenant governor, Zell Miller, moved up to the governor's chair with an easy win over state House Minority Leader John Isakson. Iowa was a Republican victory, with incumbent Terry E. Branstad turning back the challenge of state House Speaker Don Avenson. Avenson focused on Branstad's antiabortion views. GOP incumbent Judd Gregg likewise survived in New Hampshire, defeating former Democratic State Chairman J. Joseph Grandmaison. Republican Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. defeated black state Sen. Theo Mitchell in South Carolina. Maryland's Democratic governor, William Donald Schaefer, was a runaway winner over William S. Shepard, a diplomat from a Washington suburb who chose his wife, Lois, as his running mate. Democrat Bruce King was elected governor of New Mexico for the third time, defeating businessman Frank Bond. King previously won the office in 1970 and 1978. David Walters, defeated four years ago in a bid to be governor of Oklahoma, made it on his second try. Democratic Govs. Ned Ray McWherter of Tennessee, Mike Sullivan of Wyoming, John Waihee III of Hawaii and Cecil Andrus of Idaho were re-elected, as were Republican Govs. Guy Hunt of Alabama, George Mickelson of South Dakota and Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin. Nevada's acting governor, Robert J. Miller, was elected to the office.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: insurance industry.
DOC.TEXT: Nov. 4 Green Bay (Wis.) Press-Gazette on the farm bill: There is no more bedeviling piece of federal legislation than the 1990 Farm Bill. It is a complex tangle of economic, political, social and even philosophical issues, served up as a House-Senate compromise covering national agricultural policy for the next five years. In general, the $41 billion bill seems headed in the right direction. First, it cuts more than $13 billion in subsidies for agricultural products. Second, it contains economic, scientific and environmental strictures designed to reduce federal costs and to do less damage to the environment, according to those who put the bill together. ... Obviously, a bill so complex won't please everyone. ... Our long-term hope is that U.S. agriculture be weaned off federal assistance as soon as possible and to as great an extent as possible. That is no easy task. Phasing out subsidies and supports has a serious impact on every segment of the huge agri-business industry. And there is an impact on the nation itself. Food production is part of the nation's muscle. It can be used as a bargaining chip or a weapon. Setting policies that will safeguard production and encourage innovation without favoring corporations at the expense of family farms is as tough a legislative job as there is. Sen. Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who chaired the House-Senate conference committee that shaped the measure, said the 1990 bill offers farmers greater choices than earlier legislation. The major choice for many farmers is in deciding whether or not to drop out of support programs to take their chances on the vagaries of the market. A package that encourages, or even allows, such choices seems to us an improvement over policies of the past. --- Oct. 31 The Telegraph, Nashua, N.H., on the firing of Air Force Gen. Michael Dugan: George Bush, sensitive guy that he is, has arranged to have (Air Force Gen. Michael) Dugan retired at four-star rank on Jan. 1, specifically so Dugan can get a fatter pension after pay raises for generals take effect at the start of the new year. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney removed Dugan as Air Force chief of staff in September after he divulged military contingency plans in the Persian Gulf. ... Normally, Dugan would have been demoted to major general and retired on an annual pension of $60,000. Now his pension will be about $77,000 per year. So much for the hard decisions and the tough reprimands. ... The Senate grumbled, but it has OK'd the deal. ... Taking extra good care of one's ``career rewards'' is still the mode on Capitol Hill. --- Nov. 3 The Arizona Republic, Phoenix, on South Africa: The gestation of what President F.W. de Klerk hails as a ``new South Africa'' may seem interminably long to those impatient for progress in the moves to make dramatic changes in that country's social and political structures. But it must be remembered that neither ... de Klerk nor black activists promised an overnight miracle when they began their dialogue. The birth of a nation or what in this case might be called a rebirth does not occur in a day or two. The peace process, which commenced earlier this year with the release from prison of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela and the legalization of the ANC, is following a realistic timetable. Little by little, the pillars supporting the long-standing platform of white supremacy are being knocked down. Much remains to be done, of course. One problem is that the leaders of the black factions have failed to present a united front in talks with the government. They expend their energy fighting each other instead of working together to find ways to replace apartheid with a democratic system. Given time, however, tensions should ease. Patience is critical to the birth of a new South Africa. --- Nov. 6 Le Figaro, Paris, on U.S. economic and political woes: At regular intervals, specialists of all types announce the decline of the American empire. This was a theme that surfaced with the launching of Sputnik, during the war of Vietnam, and the first energy crisis. Each time, however, the United States succeeded in picking itself up. Again today, the signs of a mini-crisis ... are multiplying. The value of the dollar - a symbolic thermometer - fell under the 5-franc barrier (Monday). The popularity of George Bush, which peaked at the beginning of August, has fallen in an impressive manner the last three months. Why this sudden worry? Is it fear of war? Doubtless the progressive awareness of the dangers of open conflict plays its role in the present disenchantment. However, polls show American policy remains popular: 65 percent of American citizens approve the United States' engagement in Saudi Arabia. Thus, it's the economy and domestic policy. American opinion begins to recognize that (the country) is living above its means. The battle between Congress and the president over the budget showed citizens ... the seriousness of the problem. Reducing the federal budget deficit has become a necessary imperative. All of a sudden, American opinion searches its soul. It suspects politicians of lying. A phenomenon we know well. It's almost the same these days on both sides of the Atlantic. Nevertheless, for George Bush, the hardest things remain to be done. First to win the battle of the Gulf. Then to wake up the American decision-makers who appear hypnotized by a cobra of a different type: Japan. ---
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: type: Japan.
DOC.TEXT: Nov. 6 The New Straits Times, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on the Persian Gulf: U.S. Secretary of State James Baker is spending this week canvassing European and Arab allies to determine the circumstances under which they will support military action against Iraq. So, with a large degree of certainty, one can say there will be no fighting in the Gulf for at least another week. That is about the only sure thing in the storm simmering in the Gulf. Oil prices and stock exchanges have been on a wild roller-coaster ride in the past three months, propelled by rumors, aggressive bluster, peace feelers. A lot of the hawkish noise from both armed camps has been part of a requisite demarcation of entrenched lines and positions. But three months after Iraq's engulfing of Kuwait, there has been little appreciable change in the situation. ... For the moment, Iraq is still adamant about regarding Kuwait as its newest province, but there have been indications that Iraq will be amenable to negotiations and an agreement which will either leave it with territory which will justify the costs of the invasion or a guarantee that Iraq will not be attacked. Here is the sticking point, because the forces arrayed against Iraq must stick by the basic position, an unconditional withdrawal before there can be talks about anything else. The economic sanctions against Iraq will hurt, but precedents have shown that a determined population, with belt-tightening, can hold out for a long time. ... A war will not just involved blood spilled in Iraq, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, but will also possibly spill over into Jordan, Israel, Turkey or Syria; not to mention the threat of terrorism in other parts of the world. Which is why one hopes mediators can still find common ground to explore or one side will soften its positions. If both sides refuse to blink, the odds will increase that at some point, one side will close patience and decided to back up talk with muscle. --- Nov. 6 The Daily Telegraph, London, on the Persian Gulf: After apparent wavering in the determination of both Western and Arab countries to make Saddam Hussein yield Kuwait without conditions, the American and British governments are rightly telling the world that, fundamentally, nothing has changed. Iraq shows no sign of withdrawing from the emirate, whose people and culture it continues brutally to suppress. It has failed to agree to the other basic demand of the international community, the release of all hostages. Saddam still considers his foreign prisoners useful as a means of disturbing and confusing Western public opinion. President Bush's exasperation with the Iraqi leader's brutality (and) this week's tour of the Middle East and Europe by ... Secretary of State (James Baker) ... are timely reminders that force remains the most likely, indeed, almost certainly the only, means of gaining Iraq's compliance with the resolutions of the United Nations. No sane person could be enthusiastic about the prospect of a war in the Middle East. But it seems almost impossible to anticipate a satisfactory outcome of the Gulf crisis without the West making good its promise to free Kuwait by force of arms, since Iraq will not retreat peacefully. --- Nov. 7 Straits Times, Singapore, on Britain and the European Community: (Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's) attitude has gone beyond the realm of cultural idiosyncrasy. It has, in fact, become a highly contentious issue. The resignation of her deputy, Sir Geoffrey Howe, is yet another indication of how her stand on Europe could affect her leadership of the Conservative Party and possibly the party's prospects in the next general election. ... The tide, this time, might run against her. Perhaps, as Liberal Democrat leader Paddy Ashdown says, ``Europe will be the anvil on which Mrs. Thatcher's government will finally be broken.'' That would be a pity, given what she has done to turn Britain around by putting British industry and business on its feet again and curbing runaway labor unions. More than anything else, she has redefined the common ground in British politics, forcing a vast array of politicians and pressure groups to show their true colors. It is an irony that all the good work should today be put in jeopardy by an unspoken and inexplicable notion that belonging fully to Europe means that Britain will belong less to itself. The truth is that only by being a vital part of the new Europe can Britain hope to maintain the standards of living at home and the influence abroad which makes the country what it is. --- Oct. 31 NRC Handelsblad, Amsterdam, Netherlands, on the English Channel tunnel: The Channel Tunnel is a tangible proof of the unification of Europe. The decision of (British) Prime Minister (Margaret) Thatcher and (French) President (Francois) Mitterrand in February 1986 to build a tunnel underneath the Channel paired a historic vision with the courage to take business risks. The tunnel is entirely privately financed, mostly by Japanese banks, and for a long time it has been unsure if the construction would ever be completed because the costs were getting more and more out of hand. ... The United Kingdom may be physically connected with the continent, in many other aspects Mrs. Thatcher is stubbornly hanging on to British isolation. ... The connection with the main stream of the European platoon on the road to unity threatens to disappear from sight due to this anachronistic attitude. ... Now Europe unfortunately still has to switch lanes midway in the tunnel. ---
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Roundup
Indian Prime Minister Loses Vote of Confidence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series, ADDS there were 8 abstentions. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh lost a vote of confidence in Parliament today, ending 11 months in office troubled by increasingly violent religious and political upheavals. He was defeated by a vote of 346 to 142, according to United News of India and Press Trust of India. There were eight abstentions. Singh was expected to submit his resignation to President Ramaswamy Venkataraman within hours. After the vote, Singh's former allies who turned against him approached him on the floor and shook his hand. The vote came at the end of an 11-hour debate in which Singh was accused of leading the country deeper into class divisions, failing to control prices and ignoring separatist insurrections in its border states. Before the vote, Singh, who claimed he had tried to hold the country together, appealed to Parliament to preserve India's secular government. His chief rival, fellow secular politician Chandra Shekhar, replied that Singh should stop shedding ``crocodile tears'' and resign to spare the country more bloodshed. At least 368 people have been killed in Hindu-Moslem riots in the past two weeks when Hindu fundamentalists defied Singh and pressed ahead with their campaign to replace a Moslem mosque with a Hindu temple in northeast India. A right-wing Hindu party withdrew its support for Singh's government, forcing him to seek a vote of confidence in Parliament. While the debate was under way, a 17-year-old schoolboy burned himself to death in New Delhi to protest the government's opposition to the temple plan. Sanjeev Goel's death was the first case of self-immolation related to the religious issue. In the last two months, at least 150 upper-caste students have died in suicides or protests against the government's efforts to reserve nearly half of all government jobs for low-caste Hindus. The two issues grew into serious crises for Singh and alienated him from many members of his own party. ``It is not the government which has to be decided on today. It's the principle,'' Singh said, speaking in Hindi. ``The question before us is whether anyone's religious view is above the constitution, whether this country will be divided on religion.'' During the debate, police fired tear gas to disperse upper-caste students protesting near Parliament against the job policy. There were no injuries. Chandra Shekhar, a left-leaning political veteran who led the defection within Singh's own Janata Dal party, has staked a claim to replace Singh as prime minister. Such a move would at least temporarily avert new elections. Singh called Chandra Shekhar's move ``political opportunism.'' Chandra Shekhar, addressing Parliament immediately after Singh, appealed to the prime minister to give up. ``Is the state of the country better than it was 11 months ago? Hasn't terrorism increased? Haven't prices risen? Hasn't tension in society increased?'' he asked. The religious riots and job protests added to Singh's other problems. Separatist insurrections in Kashmir and Punjab escalated after Singh took office. Fuel and food prices soared. An economic liberalization plan stalled. The prime minister bogged down in trying to hold together a fragile coalition of communists, Hindu fundamentalists and his own faction-ridden, centrist Janata Dal. The Hindu right-wing Bhasatiya Janata Party deserted Singh two weeks ago when its leader was arrested while marching to Ayodhya to supplant a mosque with a temple. The party leader, Lal Krishna Advani, said their opposition to the government did not stem only from the temple issue. ``In 11 months (Singh) has not ... even been able to keep his ministers together. What can this government take pride in?'' Advani asked during the confidence debate. Singh's Janata Dal broke apart Monday with long-time rival Chandra Shekhar leading the revolt that included several Cabinet ministers. On Tuesday, Chandra Shekhar won the support of ex-Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, whose Congress Party is the largest in Parliament. Gandhi lost the prime minister's job to Singh in last year's elections.

DOC.HEAD: US to Remove All Fighter Aircraft From Philippines
DOC.TEXT: The United States said today it will withdraw all of its fighter aircraft and 1,800 Air Force personnel from the Philippines next year. A Pentagon statement said Richard L. Armitage, the presidential special negotiator on U.S. basing arrangements with the Philippines, informed Philippine Foreign Secretary Raul S. Manglapus of the decision today. Armitage also told Manglapus that the United States has decided not to station a squadron of new-generation F-15E fighter aircraft at Clark Air Base next year as originally planned. The F-15Es were to replace F-4E aircraft in the 3rd Tactical Fighter Squadron at Clark. The F-15Es will instead be based in Alaska, the announcement said. The administration announced last April that it would remove the 90th Tactical Fighter Squadron of the 3rd Tactical Fighter Wing at Clark in May 1991. Wednesday's announcement means the wing's second squadron, the 3rd Tactical Fighter Squadron, also will be removed instead of being replaced by the F-15E squadron. ``The net effect of this decision is that by some point in 1991, the United States will have no fighter aircraft permanently based in the Philippines, and more than 1,800 U.S. military personnel will have departed,'' the announcement said. The Pentagon public affairs office said it could not immediately determine how many U.S. aircraft will be withdrawn from the Philippines as a result of the announcement. The Pentagon said the decision was not a result of U.S.-Philippine negotiations on the future of U.S. forces in that country. It said the move was ``influenced though not dictated by'' the Philippine government's publicly expressed position that the U.S. fighters should be removed by September 1991. U.S. allies are being told of the decision and assured that the removal of the fighter aircraft ``in no way diminishes our commitment or ability to meet our responsibilities in the Pacific,'' the announcement said.

DOC.HEAD: Funeral Procession for Kahane Turns Violent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with details on violence, DELETE reference to lawmaker Zalman Shoval, who was not present. Pickup 16th, `Some Kach...'
DOC.TEXT: A raucous funeral procession for militant Rabbi Meir Kahane turned violent today when hundreds of people broke away from the march to smash shop windows, beat Arabs and stone police. In a shopping district near the central bus station in Jewish west Jerusalem, Kahane supporters moved from shop to shop, asking owners whether they employed Arabs before smashing windows. A terrified Arab ran down the street, followed by several Kahane loyalists shouting ``Death to terrorists!'' Police reported some Palestinians were hurt in scattered attacks along the procession's route. One Arab was beaten to the ground near the cemetery in Givat Shaul, and a passing Israeli and two soldiers tried to help him. When he appeared to revive, members of Kahane's Kach movement tried to block an ambulance from arriving. Police reports said one policeman was injured in the melee. Elsewhere along the procession route, hundreds stoned a television building, and a mounted policeman trying to disperse the rioters was hit by a stone and fell off his horse, Israel radio said. Hundreds of police reinforcements had been deployed to prevent violence between Arabs and Kahane's followers during the funeral procession by 18,000 people, but authorities did not interfere during the window-breaking rampage. The main procession of men in yellow Kach T-shirts and ultra-Orthodox Jews in black coats moved through downtown Jerusalem. Organizers with megaphones led chants of ``Death to the Arabs!'' and ``Death to Arafat!'' the PLO leader. Vans carrying yellow Kach flags led the marchers. During the earlier memorial service, one Kach activist vowed to avenge the slaying of Kahane, who was fatally shot after a speech at a Manhattan hotel on Monday night. ``Revenge ... the right to speak will be spoken by a knife,'' he told the crowd of thousands jammed into a Jewish seminary. Security officials, apparently worried by the Kach threats of violence, deployed police outside the homes of Palestinian leaders. ``We will not allow any riots, and provocations will be stopped immediately,'' said Jerusalem Police Commander Arieh Bibi. Science Minister Yuval Neeman of the ultra-rightist Tehiya Party was turned away from the memorial service amid shouts of ``leftist, leftist.'' Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz of the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party, entered the hall under heavy police escort. Neeman later told Israel's army radio he had come to represent the government. ``I meant to eulogize Rabbi Meir Kahane, may God avenge his blood,'' Neeman said, using a traditional Jewish phrase in cases of violent death. ``The rabbi was a proud Jew and warrior ... apparently the anger should directed at the killers,'' Neeman said. Kahane and his anti-Arab Kach movement have been hostile toward the political establishment which shunned them. With Kahane's death, ultra-rightists and religious parties are expected to compete for the votes of his followers. At the burial site, the Givat Shaul cemetery, hundreds of mourners awaited the funeral procession. Those awaiting the coffin included legislators Rehavam Zeevi of the ultra-right Moledet Party. Some Kach followers there carried placards reading ``Transfer,'' a euphemism referring to Kahane's key demand, the ouster of all Arabs from Israeli-held territories. The Kahane killing has been denounced by Israeli leaders from across the political spectrum, and some voices warned that it could lead to a wave of political assassinations. ``This is the danger engulfing us now - that Kahane's murder will spark a dizzy cycle of further murders,'' the mass-circulation Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper wrote in its editorial. On Tuesday, hours after word of the Kahane killing spread, two elderly Arabs were gunned down in a West Bank village, and police said the slayings may have been prompted by Kahane's murder. Kahane, 58, preached a violent doctrine of Jewish power. His organizations -the Jewish Defense League in New York and the Kach movement in Israel - were known for political violence. After immigrating to Israel in 1971, he built a small, but passionately loyal following, although he was shunned by the political establishment. Israel army radio said today that the assassination changed Kahane's image in Israel. ``The Israeli media that once avoided covering him is now devoting a good deal of the time explaining his dogma,'' the radio said.

DOC.HEAD: British Customs Receives Reward from American Investigators
DOC.TEXT: British officials on Wednesday received a $2.8 million reward from the United States for aiding a money laundering probe linked to ousted Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega. The Customs and Excise office raided the headquarters of a bank in London and seized records, including details of accounts held by Noriega, his wife and children. The action was taken as part of ``Operation C-Chase,'' a two-year investigation begun in 1986 into laundering of profits from South American drug cartels. ``We are trying to get to the syndicates and the way to do that is to go for their assets,'' U.S. Deputy Treasury Secretary John Robson said in presenting the check to Customs office chairman Sir Brian Unwin. The moneywill go toward Britain's anti-drug budget, the office said. In a case stemming from the probe, Luxumbourg-based Bank of Credit and Commerce International pleaded guilty to money laundering-related charges last January in Tampa, Fla., and agreed to forfeit $14 million. Others sentenced in the BCCI case included Noriega's former personal banker. Noriega surrendered to U.S. authorities in January and is being held in a federal facility near Miami charged with drug trafficking violations.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Hangs Herself After Being Told to Cut Back on TV
DOC.TEXT: An 11-year-old girl hanged herself after being told by her parents to stop watching so much television, a newspaper reported. Belinda Kau Kler was discovered hanging from the ceiling of her brother's bedroom late Monday, a blanket fastened into a makeshift noose, according to a report in the daily Malay Mail. She was pronounced dead on arrival by a doctor at a private clinic where she was taken by her father, Harchand Singh, the paper said. The newspaper quoted the girl's uncle, Kartar Singh, as saying he believed his niece was only trying to attract attention, not kill herself. Miss Kler was watching television Monday night when her parents reprimanded her and told her to spend more time studying, the newspaper said. She then locked herself in her brother's room, and was later discovered by her father. Police said were investigating and had not yet classified the death a suicide.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Adopts Unprecedented Resolution to Move Out of Capital
DOC.TEXT: Legislators adopted a resolution Wednesday recommending that Parliament and other government offices move out of Tokyo to help ease overcrowding and spiraling land prices in the capital. The concentration of political, economic and cultural activities in Tokyo has drawn millions to the city from the fading countryside, putting a strain on its environment and driving land prices to unprecedented levels, the resolution said. In case of a major disaster under such crowded conditions, city functions would be paralyzed, it added. The resoution was adopted by both houses of the Diet, Japan's parliament. ``As a basic measure to rectify this distortion, we should avoid concentration, and to establish suitable functions of politics and administration for the 21st century, proceed to relocate the Diet and the government,'' the resolution said. Although it does not have the force of law, it urges the government to ``make efforts to realize the aim of this resolution.'' An officer of the House of Councillors, Teruaki Oka, said the resolution ``aims to reverse the concentration of everything in one point, which causes rising land prices. All members of Parliament except Communist Party members supported the resolution, he said. Moving Japan's capital has been a subject of debate since the 1960s. The government decided last year to move 76 government agencies out of Tokyo. Roughly one in four of Japan's 120 million people lives in Tokyo or the surrounding area, according to government figures.

DOC.HEAD: US Looks To Gorbachev For Backing Against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III turned to the Soviet Union on Wednesday to support sterner measures against Iraq as the Bush administration acknowledged a worldwide economic boycott was inadequate to force Saddam Hussein's invaders out of Kuwait. At the top of Baker's agenda is determining if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has strongly urged that a diplomatic solution to the crisis be sought, would support a U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force. Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen told Baker on Tuesday in Cairo that Beijing would not block such a resolution. However, the Chinese minister stressed his government's preference for a political settlement. Baker needs at least as much from Gorbachev, whom he sees at the Kremlin on Thursday, before the United States makes its move in the Security Council for a resolution authorizing force and another demanding Iraq permit the resupply of the beleaguered U.S. and British embassies in Kuwait, the only two still defying Iraq's order to shut down. After more than three months of a trade cutoff and other sanctions, the Iraqi president has not budged in his determination to hold on to Kuwait as an annexed province. President Bush and Baker had expressed confidence that once the sanctions bit, the Iraqi leader would have to reassess. But a senior U.S. official who flew here with Baker from Turkey acknowledged that, despite a battery of 10 Council resolutions, that point had not yet been reached. Among them is a demand Saddam release his grip on Kuwait, an oil-rich emirate at the northern tip of the Persian Gulf. ``The sanctions are having an effect,'' he said. ``We've never disputed that. I think the question is are the sanctions yet having an effect that would alter Saddam's political calculus, and lead him to withdraw peacefully and otherwise fully implement the resolutions. We're obviously not yet to that point.'' As he left Ankara, Baker said, ``We would all like to see a peaceful, diplomatic, political solution to this problem. At the same time, it is the view of our President and the United States that we cannot rule out the use of force.'' He added that ``credibility of the United Nations is at stake.'' One step Baker took in Cairo was to assure Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak of U.S. logistical support to help get the 14,000 Egyptian troops in Saudi Arabia into combat if there was a war. Gorbachev's special Middle East envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, was more positive about the chances for peace, saying there had been a ``big difference'' in the tenor of his discussions with Saddam between a first meeting in September and a second on Oct. 27. ``In the second meeting, there was not mention (by Hussein) that Kuwait is part of Iraqi territory.'' Primakov told reporters at a Kremlin reception. ``I put it like this to him: `If you do not withdraw, you will face a military strike against you... He said that he was in a position to do something. I am still optimistic.'' Primakov said he did not think the United States opposed his search for a diplomatic solution. ``I don't think they are against them. I reported to President Bush and explained to him what I have in mind, and I didn't see that he was against it.'' Waiting for Baker at Sheremetyevo Airport outside Moscow was Alexei Obukhov, the Soviet official in overall charge of efforts to complete a treaty to reduce the non-nuclear weapons the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact have deployed in Europe. Obukhov handed Baker a sheaf of papers, which the Secretary of State began to read before climbing into his limousine. On Tuesday, a group of U.S. arms control specialists arrived here to try to put the finishing touches on the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty to be signed in Paris at a summit meeting Nov. 19-21. The negotiators are also working on another treaty to reduce U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Pad House Majority
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-5 beginning, `Democrats seemed ... ' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Democrats winning 267 seats, just 3 races left undecided. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `While the...'
DOC.TEXT: Democrats padded their House majority in turbulent elections that cost several veterans in both parties their seats and threw a scare into others, including Republican Whip Newt Gingrich. Roughly 96 percent of incumbents were re-elected Tuesday, but some big names, including Rep. Robert Kastenmeier, a Democratic House subcommittee chairman, felt the wrath of burgeoning voter disgust with government. Democrats were assured of a net pickup of nine seats - strengthening their majority to 267 in the 435-member House and heightening their ability to override President Bush's vetoes. In addition, the election of a socialist who will line up with the Democrats for organizational purposes gives them an effective majority of 268. Republicans won 164 contests and led in the remaining three races. In those contests, two incumbent Democrats trailed slightly, while the third battle was over an open seat held by a Republican who retired. While the GOP loss was well below the historic average of 27 for a party holding the White House in midterm elections, it left them with their lowest House numbers since 1982. House Democratic leaders touted the results as evidence that voters accepted their pitch about tax fairness and had identified the Republicans more as the party of the rich. ``The results are clear: George Bush cannot win the Congress and must no longer rule by veto,'' said Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. ``Next year, he must come to Capitol Hill with an action plan for reviving the economy and reworking the system to the benefit of working families.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said a strengthened Democratic majority will carry a mandate to undertake ``a serious review of our national health delivery system.'' But GOP House campaign chief Ed Rollins said he didn't think either party should feel comfortable with the results. ``I don't think the anti-Washington mood ends today,'' Rollins said. ``Even though a lot of incumbents are not being defeated, they're being scared. They're not getting the 60 percent margins they had two years ago.'' Notwithstanding the generally standpat nature of the results, history was made in several respects: -Bernard Sanders, the socialist former mayor of Burlington, Vt., ousted incumbent freshman Republican Peter Smith to become the first socialist in the House since Victor Louis Berger of Milwaukee, Wis., six decades ago. Sanders handily defeated Smith, who publicly disagreed with Bush's position on taxes when the president appeared with him at a campaign event. -Gary Franks, an alderman from Waterbury, Conn., became the first black Republican to serve in the House since Oscar De Priest of Illinois during the Depression. Franks vanquished former Democratic Rep. Toby Moffett for a seat vacated by a Republican. -Voters in New Hampshire's 2nd District elected Democrat Dick Swett, an architect, over one-term incumbent Republican Chuck Douglas - the first time a Democrat has won that seat since 1912, the year the Titanic sank. Although the Democrats kept intact the majority they have held in the House since 1954, the results of several contests showed an underlying voter restiveness. In Kentucky, three-term Rep. Carl Perkins won a razor-thin victory over Republican Will T. Scott, a former circuit judge, by a margin of only about 2,000 votes. Gingrich, the fiery second-in-command House GOP leader, nearly lost his rematch against Democrat David Worley in a suburban Atlanta district. Gingrich had led the opposition to the bipartisan budget deal reached by Bush and Congress. Kastenmeier had been in the House for 32 years, but was ousted by a 37-year-old former Madison newscaster, Scott Klug. Kastenmeier was chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on courts. In Oregon, an incumbent tainted by the savings-and-loan scandal also went down to defeat. Five-term Rep. Denny Smith was defeated in his second round with Democrat Mike Kopetski, who had narrowly lost to Smith two years ago. The S&L mess also helped bring down six-term Rep. Charles Pashayan Jr., R-Calif. Farmer and businessman Calvin Dooley, a 36-year-old Democrat, won narrowly, in part by pointing to Pashayan's receipt of $26,000 from Lincoln Savings and Loan Chairman Charles Keating. Pashayan later returned the money. Minnesota voters ousted Republican Rep. Arlan Stangeland, a congressman since 1977, and replaced him with Democrat Collin Peterson. Stangeland, who is married, was stung by reports that he had used his congressional credit card to make hundreds of telephone calls to and from the home of a female lobbyist. Peterson, 46, supports the death penalty and a constitutional amendment limiting abortions. Conservative Republican Stan Parris decisively lost his seat in the Virginia suburbs of Washington to Alexandria Mayor James Moran, who had made Parris' anti-abortion stand a major issue. ``The bad news is, in 1974, I got run over by a train called Watergate,'' Parris said. ``Now, it very much appears the same train 16 years later is going to run me over again. The good news is, there is life after government.'' In Pennsylvania, attorney Rick Santorum shocked seven-term Democratic Rep. Doug Walgren's bid for re-election from an affluent district in Pittsburgh. Santorum emphasized anti-incumbent themes like the congressional pay raise and special-interest political money. And in Maryland, five-term Democratic Rep. Roy Dyson, a member of the Armed Services Committee, was beaten by Republican Wayne Gilchrest, a high school teacher seeking public office for the first time. It had been revealed during the campaign that Dyson avoided service in the Vietnam War by claiming conscientious objector status - in contrast to his hawkish defense views since entering the House. In the St. Louis suburbs in Missouri, two-term Republican Jack Buechner was edged out by Democrat Joan Kelly Horn. Buechner said he would request a recount in light of the 52-vote victory margin. Republican challenger Charles Taylor edged Democratic Rep. James M. Clarke by fewer than 4,000 votes in a western North Carolina district that perennially features one of the country's tightest congressional races. Taylor, a former state senator, was beaten narrowly by Clarke two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Only Oregon Keeps Tax Revolt Alive
DOC.TEXT: In Massachusetts and five other states, voters rejected ballot measures that would have taken giant whacks out of taxes or government spending. Only Oregon kept the embers of the tax revolt alive. Oregon voters left state educators quaking by approving Measure 5, which will phase in a 1.5 percent ceiling on the property tax rate by 1995. It will cause property taxes to drop an estimated 45 percent by 1995, and would require the Legislature to replace whatever money would be lost to schools from the property tax cuts. But elsewhere, Massachusetts residents rejected a proposed $2.6 billion tax rollback to 1988 levels. It would have been the largest voter-initiated state tax cut in U.S. history. Opponents had charged that the cuts would hamper such state services as day care, elderly programs, and police and firefighter training. Officials said the measure could shut down college campuses and bankrupt some school districts. ``They wanted change but (the petition) went too far,'' said University of Massachusetts political scientist Paul Watanabe. Californians, who started the national tax revolt movement 12 years ago when voters approved Proposition 13, narrowly turned down a ``Son of Jarvis'' initiative. The measure would have required a two-thirds legislative or popular majority for new taxes. California voters also rejected two measures that would have increased the state tax on alcohol. Nebraskans voted against a 2 percent limit on annual state and local budget increases. Montanans defeated a highly unusual ballot measure that would have scrapped their state income, property and sales taxes in favor of a ``transaction charge'' of 1 percent on all financial dealings. Neither backers nor opponents seemed sure whether it would have raised or lowered taxes. But Montana voters also rejected an initiative that would have raised the state cigarette tax 140 percent to 43 cents a pack, the highest in the nation, in an effort to curb smoking in ``Marlboro Country.'' In Utah, voters heeded dire warnings of fiscal distress from state educators and refused to abolish the state sales tax on food. And Colorado voters narrowly rejected a measure requiring voter approval for any state or local tax increase. A similar proposal was soundly defeated in 1988. Don McIntire, chief proponent of the newly approved Oregon tax limit, said he thinks Oregonians are frustrated with state government's inability to tackle the property tax question. ``People are realizing the political system is paralyzed,'' McIntire said. ``They (state leaders) just can't deal with this subject responsibly.'' But John Marshall of the Oregon School Boards Association warned that school programs face ``major amputation'' as a result of the vote.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett Resigning as Drug Policy Director
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs with minor editing.
DOC.TEXT: William J. Bennett is resigning as the nation's drug policy director, the White House announced today, saying he had helped produce ``a turnaround'' in Americans' attitudes towards drugs. President Bush will accept Bennett's resignation in a ceremony at the White House on Thursday, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Administration sources revealed his departure plans Tuesday night and Fitzwater confirmed them. Bush is not yet ready to name a successor, Fitzwater said. He denied that Bennett was leaving because of threats to his family, saying Bennett ``has lived with threats of a kind ever since day one of the job.'' Bennett, the former secretary of education, became the nation's first director of drug control policy last year at the outset of the Bush administration. ``The president feels that Bill Bennett has provided extraordinary leadership and service to the country during his tenure as drug czar,'' the spokesman said. ``Two years ago this country viewed this problem as impossible to deal with and with no end in sight,'' said Fitzwater. ``Today there has been a turnaround. There is strong bipartisan support in the Congress for drug programs and there is growing evidence that society is beginning to turn away from the drug scourge.'' Earlier, an administration source said Bennett was leaving after 18 months in office with a feeling of accomplishment. ``He set out to do a task, he's done it, and he's seeing the fruition of it,'' the source said Tuesday. ``Now he's going on to the next phase of his life.'' The source said Bennett has no new job lined up. The source said Bennett also has been subject to increasing threats to his safety recently. Bennett, 47, designed the nation's anti-drug strategy, which focuses heavily on drug users as the fuel that keep international gangster organizations in business. His plans devoted about 70 percent of the money to law enforcement, the rest to treatment and education. But treatment programs grew the fastest under Bennett's guidance. The voluble Bennett has used his job of director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy as a bully pulpit, much as he did when he was education secretary under President Reagan. He traveled the nation, praising anti-drug activists and urging tougher drug laws and novel punishments as well as treatment and education programs. He was critical of Congress when it tried to change his plans and called calls for drug decriminalization ``stupid and morally atrocious.'' One reason Bennett is leaving is concern for his safety and that of his wife and young sons, the source said. ``There have been some threats, bomb threats, personal threats,'' the source said. On a recent swing through Alaska, where he campaigned for a ballot measure to re-criminalize marijuana, a third bodyguard was assigned. The source said the concerns ``have been building. I've seen it start to eat away at him.'' When Bennett was confirmed in March 1988, many said fighting the war on drugs would prove a hopeless task. But he said in ceremony in September that progress had been made, that ``the drug problem - in general, nationwide - is no longer getting worse, and in some very significant aspects it is now getting better. Not victory, but success.'' The ceremony called attention to signs that the drug crisis, particularly the cocaine problem, appeared to be abating. Cocaine prices were higher and purity levels lower, emergency room cases were fewer and Americans were turning against illegal drugs of all kinds, polls found. Bennett said that as cocaine supplies were restricted, violence among dealers could increase with ``more dogs chasing fewer bones.'' But he said the overall signs showed the problem is ``certainly not getting worse.'' In recent months, Bennett has found himself urging the public to keep its attention focused on the drug war and not be diverted by the Persian Gulf crisis and other issues. ``It is possible for a great nation to take care of its own kids and its own principles in more than one place at one time,'' he said. Bennett said he was unsure how long he expected to stay in his job, but said, ``I'll tell you, there's more for me to do, that's for sure.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Hostages Will Be Freed If London Restores Syrian Ties
DOC.TEXT: British hostages held in Lebanon will be freed if London restores relations severed with Damascus four years ago amid allegations of Syrian involvement in terrorism, a government newspaper said Wednesday. In a front-page editorial, the Tishrin daily accused British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's government of blocking efforts to free the four Britons, who are among 13 Westerners held by pro-Iranian Moslem extremists. The editorial, signed by the newspaper's editor-in-chief, Mohammed Kheir Al-Wadi, said Britain ``has not done a thing for the release of the missing hostages.'' ``Had the British government been concerned about its citizens, it would have reconciled with Syria,'' he wrote. ``Such a move will create the appropriate atmopshere for Syria to look for the hostages and secure their release.'' It was the first time the government-controlled news media has openly linked the hostage issue to renewing diplomatic ties ruptured in November 1986 after London blamed Syria for an attempt to blow up an Israeli jetliner at Heathrow Airport. In London, a spokesman for the Foreign Office said: ``Syria is an important country in the Middle East and we would like better relations, but there are obstacles.'' The spokesman said Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd ``has quite deliberately refused'' to specify what Britain's conditions are for renewing ties. Last month, Hurd said the 1986 El Al affair remained the main obstacle. Syria has denied it was involved in the terror attempt, calling it an Israeli plot to damage Syria's image in the West. The Tishrin editorial repeated the claim that Syria was set up. ``When this became apparent to Western governments, they improved relations with Syria, except for Mrs. Thatcher who moved in the opposite direction,'' it said. The United States recalled its ambassador from Damascus after the British accusations. But he was sent back a few months later, mainly to follow up on American hostages in Lebanon. Tishrin referred to a recent European Community vote, taken under British pressure, to maintain a ban on arms sales to Syria and keep restrictions on the number of Syrian officials in Europe. ``The British government's intransigence and confrontational attitudes ... are delaying the solution of acute problems,'' it said. Syria is the main power-broker in Lebanon, with 40,000 troops deployed in the civil war-plagued country. Damascus also is a close ally of Iran, which backs Shiite Moslem factions holding the Western hostages. In addition to the Britons, the hostages are six Americans, two Germans and an Italian. American Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest held. Syria was involved in the release of American hostages Robert Polhill and Frank Reed in April, and Irishman Brian Keenan in August. The editorial deflated speculation that a British hostage, possibly Anglican church envoy Terry Waite, would be freed following London's restoration of ties with Iran in September. Waite, 51, disappeared in Beirut on Jan 20, 1987, while trying to negotiate the release of American hostages. The other missing Britons are Alec Collett, 68, a New York-based journalist; John McCarthy, 33, a reporter for the London-based World-Wide Television; and Jack Mann, 76, a former air force pilot who had been living in Lebanon for two decades. The Revolutionary Organization of Socialist Moslems claimed it executed Collett in retaliation for U.S. air raids on Libya. It released a videotape purporting to show him hanged, but no body was produced.

DOC.HEAD: 120 More Hostages to Go Free; 74 Japanese Hostages Fly Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with White House saying Brandt, other envoys being used, Thatcher comment. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `Secretary of...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY10
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today it would free 120 more hostages, most of them Germans but including a few Americans, and 74 Japanese nationals flew to freedom after three months of captivity in Iraq. The official Iraqi News Agency said 100 Germans would be freed at the intervention of former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt, who met with President Saddam Hussein today. The report said the move reflected the Baghdad government's ``appreciation for the German policy which does not support trends toward war.'' It said 20 hostages of other nationalities would be freed as well, including an unspecified number of Americans, Britons, Italians and others. The announcement did not say when they would be freed. But the release of the Japanese hostages who left Baghdad today had been announced only a day earlier. The White House said today that former foreign government officials who have traveled to Baghdad on hostage-freeing misions ``are being used'' by Saddam for propaganda purposes. Presidential spokeman Marlin Fitzwater, speaking to reporters, specifically mentioned Brandt's trip. He also accused Saddam of ``toying with the emotions'' of the families of captives. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that ``time is running out'' for Saddam and force will be used unless he withdraws soon from Kuwait. ``He has been warned,'' she said in a speech to lawmakers. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, meanwhile, said the use of military force against Iraq cannot be ruled out. Baker is on a weeklong mission sounding out allies on their willingness to go to war. He was in Turkey today and will stop in Moscow, Paris and London. He told reporters in Ankara that the United States seeks a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis. But he added that ``we cannot rule out the possible use of force before we see that the matter is resolved peacefully.'' Baker also denied reports he gave Iraq an ultimatum to get out of Kuwait in the next two weeks. The reports by Israel army radio and stations in Luxembourg and Monte Carlo said Baker had asked his Chinese counterpart, Qian Quichen, to tell Saddam Hussein that U.S. forces would attack if he didn't comply. Baker met with Qian in Cairo, Egypt, on Tuesday. Qian indicated to Baker on Tuesday that Beijing would not stand in the way of any U.N. vote authorizing a military strike to force Iraq out of Kuwait, U.S. officials said. But Qian, who met for two hours with Baker in Cairo, did not explicitly approve sending troops into action. ``We'll have to wait and see,'' Qian told reporters. China is one of the five U.N. Security Council members with veto power over resolutions. Qian met with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak today. U.S. officials said Mubarak agreed during a meeting with Baker that ``a partial solution'' to the Persian Gulf crisis was unacceptable, that U.N. resolutions demanding an Iraqi withdrawal be implemented fully. The officials insisted, however, that Baker had not discussed a timetable with Mubarak for any attack. Iraq seized oil-rich Kuwait on Aug. 2 and then annexed it. The United Nations responded by mandating an embargo on trade with Iraq and ordering it responsible for war damages. The Japanese hostages who were freed today left Baghdad aboard a Japan Air Lines charter flight with former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who secured their release. Japanese Embassy officials said the plane would make at least one refueling stop en route to Tokyo, but would not say where. Iraq had said 77 Japanese nationals were free to go, but only 74 wound up leaving with Nakasone. The embassy officials, requesting anonymity, said three Japanese businessmen who had been given permission to leave changed their minds and decided to stay on in Baghdad to finish their businesses. ``They opted out,'' one embassy official insisted. ``The Iraqis did not change their mind, the three businessmen did.'' Japanese officials denied there was any link between Iraq's agreement to free its citizens and the government's abandoning of a plan to deploy troops to the Persian Gulf. Despite the European Community's disapproval of individual hostage-freeing missions, such trips are becoming increasingly common.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Arrests Members Of Yahweh Sect in Racketeering Indictment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from prosecutor, one murder described as part of initiation rite, arrest total increases by one; and to CORRECT Yahweh's age tth graf pvs, `But as...'. SUBS 12th graf, `They chose...', to do 55. Picks up 8elete now-redundant first reference to Lehtinen. Clair is cq for man's name in 8th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The founder of a black religious sect who calls himself the son of God and at least 12 followers were arrested today on an indictment accusing the group of 14 murders, including the slaying of a ``white devil'' as an initiation rite. Yahweh ben Yahweh, born Hulon Mitchell Jr., was arrested in New Orleans, according to his Miami attorney, Ellis Rubin. A top lieutenant, Judith Israel, also known as Linda Gaines, was taken into custody in Atlanta. FBI agents swept the Miami-based group's ``Temple of Love'' and took seven members into custody there, said Rubin. p.m. Index:
Market -26 cents Index 168.70 -1.51 American Stock Exchange 1p.m. Index:

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: This time, The Hunk didn't flunk. John F. Kennedy Jr. told his bosses in the district attorney's office Wednesday he passed the state bar exam on the third try. ``I am pleased by this news,'' said District Attorney Robert Morgenthau. ``We never doubted that he would pass.'' Kennedy's passing grade on the July exam means he gets to keep his job as an assistant district attorney, and that he will get a $3,000 raise to $33,000 a year. When he is formally sworn in as a member of the New York bar, he will get an additional $1,000. The raises are standard at Kennedy's level, said office spokesman Gerald McKelvey. Kennedy joined Morgenthau in 1989 after graduating from New York University Law School. It was announced Friday that Kennedy had passed the Connecticut bar exam, but that would not have saved his job, which carries a proviso of three strikes and you're out. Kennedy, son of the slain president, has been listed as ``one of the 50 most beautiful people in the world'' by People magazine and one of the sexiest men by US magazine. His sister, Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg, passed the bar exam on her first try, and was recently admitted to New York practice. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Operation Desert Shield troops will no longer heave pails of sand to pump themselves up, thanks to actor Arnold Schwarzenegger. He rounded up 50 tons of weightlifting equipment for the U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. ``After learning that soldiers were using makeshift weights to keep fit, he spearheaded a campaign to secure donations from companies who manufacture aerobic and weightlifting equipment,'' publicist Charlotte Parker said Wednesday. More than 100,000 pounds of dumbbells, bench boards, leg presses, leg extensions, power squat racks, cycle machines and tread mills have been donated, Schwarzenegger's publicist said. The exercise equipment will be shipped in time for Thanksgiving. The actor is chairman of President Bush's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. --- BROKEN HILL, Australia (AP) - Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, told inquisitive school children Wednesday she has to mind her royal manners because the media dogs her footsteps. Broadcasting to 180 students over a radio network spanning thousands of miles of outback, the duchess was quizzed by seven pupils on the talkback system called School of the Air. A group of students also came to the school studio especially for the one-day royal visit to this small mining center of Broken Hill. ``You always have to remember that they're there watching,'' she responded when asked what she thought of the media attention she attracts. ``If you trip up down the steps, they'll criticize you for tripping down the steps, so you have to be careful.'' The duchess, the wife of Britain's Prince Andrew, sidestepped other questions, including how much money she has and which horse she backed in the Melbourne Cup, Australia's premier racing event that she attended the day before. --- PARIS (AP) - Prince Karim Aga Khan, the Ismaili Moslem spiritual leader and one of the world's richest men, was given France's highest civilian honor Wednesday for his philanthropic works. ``France pays homage to a long continuity of eminent service rendered to humanity,'' President Francois Mitterrand said in bestowing the title during a private ceremony at the Elysee Palace. The Aga Khan, 57-year-old spiritual leader of 15 million Ismaili Moslems in 25 countries, lives near Paris and is famed for his stable of race horses. His philanthropy includes farm funding, road building and other development projects in Africa and Asia. --- VIENNA, Austria (AP) - Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal was given an honorary doctorate Wednesday by Vienna University. Students proposed awarding the 81-year-old Holocaust survivor the doctorate in philosophy, said University Rector Karl Wernhart. Wiesenthal said his 4{ years in a Nazi concentration camp made him realize that ``survival is a privilege.'' He vowed to continue to work for justice and freedom and to remain ``a voice of all those people whose mouths were closed forever'' in Nazi death camps. Wiesenthal, by his own reckoning, has brought some 1,100 Nazi fugitives to justice since the end of World War II. His most celebrated triumph was helping the Israelis in 1960 to capture Adolf Eichmann, the architect of the Holocaust.

DOC.HEAD: Three Convicted in Nation's Largest Cocaine Seizure
DOC.TEXT: Three men were convicted in connection with the nation's largest cocaine seizure on record, but the jury deadlocked on charges against three other defendants. Prosecutors said they would seek a retrial for the three not convicted. The federal jury deadlocked Tuesday 8-4 in favor of conviction. The case stemmed from the September 1989 seizure of 20 tons of cocaine in a warehouse in suburban Sylmar, 25 miles northwest of downtown. U.S. District Judge Terry J. Hatter Jr. declared a mistrial for Hector Tapia Anchondo, 39; Hugo Fernando Castillon Alvarez, 33; and Miguel Garcia Chavez, 35. Sentencing for the other three defendants was set for Jan. 28. Each faces a maximum prison term of 10 years to life and fines up to $4 million. The jury returned guilty verdicts on all charges against Carlos Tapia Ponce, 69, and his two sons-in-law, Jose Ignacio Mauricio Monroy Iniguez, 37, and James Romero McTague, 42, the only U.S.-born defendant. During the trial, which started Sept. 19, prosecutors characterized Tapia, a retired Mexican customs inspector, as ``the overseer and patriarch'' of the drug trafficking ring that used big-rig trailers to ship 77 tons of cocaine from El Paso, Texas, to the Sylmar warehouse before the raid. A Nov. 19 hearing was scheduled to set a new trial date. Each defendant except Chavez was charged with one count of conspiracy and one count of possession with intent to distribute the cocaine. McTague also was charged with possessing and intending to sell 44 pounds of cocaine, which was the sole charge against Chavez. At the time of the seizure, federal officials said the 20 tons of cocaine was the largest amount of the drug ever impounded by authorities, and that it represented about 5 percent of estimated annual global production of the drug. The street value of the seized cocaine was estimated by authorities from $2 billion to $20 billion. Authorities also seized $12 million in cash during the raid.

DOC.HEAD: Selma Mayor Suffers Heart Attack on Election Day
DOC.TEXT: Joe Smitherman, the seven-term mayor of Selma, underwent successful treatment Wednesday for a blocked coronary artery after suffering a heart attack, hospital officials said. Smitherman was mayor during the 1965 civil rights marches and again had to deal with months of racial protests earlier this year over the firing of the city's first black school superintendent. He was admitted to University Hospital on Tuesday afternoon complaining of chest pains, hospital spokesman Hank Black said. Smitherman, 60, suffered a heart attack, but doctors successfully cleared a blocked artery Wednesday with a tube, Black said. He said Smitherman was in fair condition and could return home in a few days.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to include fact that Roberts defeated Frohnmayer.
DOC.HEAD: Barbara Roberts Got Late Start in Oregon Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Roberts never made it a secret she wanted to be the first woman governor of Oregon. But she didn't expect to be running for the job this year. She jumped into the race after Democratic Gov. Neil Goldschmidt unexpectedly announced in February he wouldn't seek a second term. Roberts, a Democrat, moved to fill the void. On Tuesday, she defeated Republican Dave Frohnmayer. Roberts, 53, grew up in a small Willamette Valley town and ended up in Portland, where she began her political career. Her first exposure to the Capitol was in the early 1970s, when she helped get a bill passed requiring special education classes for emotionally handicapped children in public schools. She launched the effort because the older of her two sons is autistic. She was a divorced mother ``with two kids and no child support,'' she says. ``I found out that I could come into that process and literally change the lives of thousands of kids,'' she says. She got help in her lobbying from veteran Democratic state Sen. Frank Roberts of Portland, and they eventually married. Barbara Roberts' first elective office was a post on a Portland-area school board in 1973. She served an appointed term as a Multnomah County commissioner and in 1980 won the first of two terms in the Oregon House. In her second term, she was the first woman to be House majority leader. Roberts was elected secretary of state in 1984 and easily won re-election in 1988. The state constitution prohibits a third successive term, and she had her eye on running for governor in 1994. Roberts is energetic and a vigorous campaigner. She established familiarity with voters after crisscrossing the state on the speech circuit many times as secretary of state. She's an unabashed liberal who emphasizes concern for the downtrodden. She says she rejects the label, however, if it's meant as support of higher taxes and more regulation of business. Her Republican opponent, Dave Frohnmayer, portrayed her as a free spender with budget-busting plans. Roberts' candor sometimes left supporters nervous. Months ahead of the election, she endorsed a controversial ballot measure to shut down the state's only nuclear power plant. Later, she came out for a hard-fought measure to impose strict recycling standards on packaging. Frohnmayer opposed both.

DOC.HEAD: Dixon Asks All Barry Political Aides To Resign
DOC.TEXT: Mayor-elect Sharon Pratt Dixon on Wednesday wasted no time acting on her pledge to overhaul the District of Columbia government, urging that all of Mayor Marion Barry's political aides quit. ``I am going to indicate to the mayor that I would like for him to ask for the resignations of all the political appointees,'' Dixon said in the aftermath of her landslide victory over Republican nominee Maurice Turner. ``If he won't cooperate in that regard ... then I am going to urge the city council to forge a partnership that allows us to do what the people of the District of Columbia clearly want.'' The mayor-elect did not elaborate on what type of legislative action she would seek from the council, but that 13-member panel has in recent weeks passed bills designed to limit Barry's spending authority during his last days in office. Several legislators said they were worried Barry would reward friends and political cronies with pay raises and city contracts while he still had the power to do so. Barry, who was defeated in his bid for a seat on the city council, said during his concession speech Tuesday that he intended to cooperate in the transition to the Dixon administration. However, he declined to provide specifics and refused comment Wednesday on Dixon's request for the departure of his political lieutenants. Barry has appointed about 200 of his aides to high-paying government posts. Many of Barry's top aides are also career government workers and are eligible under city personnel rules to take other government posts if Dixon wishes to replace them. Dixon, who won with 86 percent of the vote to Turner's 11 percent, becomes the first black female to lead a major American city. She won after promising sweeping reform in a government many believe is bloated and inefficient, including a pledge to cut 2,000 middle-level managers from the district's 48,000-member work force.

DOC.HEAD: Over Breakfast With Black Leaders, Pik Botha Preaches Peace
DOC.TEXT: At an unusual prayer breakfast, South African Foreign Minister Pik Botha urged three black African leaders Wednesday to ``join hands'' in regional cooperation. Botha, who represented President F. W. de Klerk, addressed the heads of state as ``my African brothers'' during the informal meeting, which was punctuated by joking and laughter. The breakfast host was Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda, head of the seven-nation Frontline States, a regional bloc that once led efforts to end apartheid in South Africa. The other two leaders were President Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique, who maintains close contacts with South Africa, and President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, the current chairman of the 51-member Organization of African unity. President Bush sent a congratulatory message, saying the meeting ``marks a new era in Africa.'' The get-together over eggs, bacon and croissants signaled a further easing of tensions between white-led South Africa and its anti-apartheid neighbors. Zambian officials said it was made possible by de Klerk's recent steps toward dismantling apartheid, including legalizing the African National Congress, freeing political prisoners including the ANC leader Nelson Mandela, and lifting the state of emergency in black townships. The ANC, outlawed for 30 years in South Africa, had its headquarters in the Zambian capital of Lusaka until early this year. Kaunda, once one of the most vocal African critics of apartheid, said the theme of the meeting was ``peace, unity and reconciliation.'' Botha told the black African leaders that South Africa could help economic development in the largely impoverished region, adding: ``We in Africa must join hands and move closer together.'' ``South Africa must play its rightful role in southern Africa and we are ready to play that role,'' Botha said. Ugandan President Museveni said he got the idea for such a meeting from a prayer breakfast he attended with U.S. congressmen two years ago. He wanted to organize something similar, he said, but as he was not a good Christian he asked Kaunda to be host. Three other African heads of state, Quett Masire of Botswana, Pierre Buyoya of Burundi and Metsing Lekhanya of Lesotho, were invited but did not attend.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Sets Nov. 15 Launch Date for Atlantis
DOC.TEXT: NASA today set Nov. 15 as the launch date for space shuttle Atlantis and its classified cargo, a spy satellite that needed last-minute repairs and caused a one-week flight delay. Atlantis had been scheduled to blast off Friday on the secret military mission. But the Air Force last week delayed the flight because of undisclosed problems that arose during cargo testing. The satellite aboard Atlantis reportedly is to spy on Iraqi forces. Liftoff is scheduled for sometime between 6:30 p.m. and 10:30 p.m. EST; the exact time will not be divulged until nine minutes beforehand. Atlantis was supposed to carry the spacecraft into orbit in July, weeks before Iraq invaded Kuwait, but hydrogen leaks grounded the shuttle. During the standdown, the satellite reportedly was modified for information gathering in the Persian Gulf. Atlantis was cleared for flight during an Oct. 24 fueling test that found no significant leakage. The shuttle Columbia, also crippled for months by leaking hydrogen, was found to be free of dangerous leaks during a similar test last week. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to send Columbia on a long-delayed astronomy mission in early December. The seven-man crew has endured four launch attempts since May, three of which were halted by leaking hydrogen in the final hours before liftoff. NASA likes to have at least three weeks between missions so flight data can be analyzed. Officials have said they will try to shorten that period by about a week so Columbia can be back before Christmas, and the agency can shut down certain operations for routine maintenance and avoid holiday pay. Before hydrogen leaks crippled two of NASA's three shuttles, the space agency had planned nine launches for 1990. Six will be achieved if Atlantis and Columbia go up as planned.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Leader to Visit Germany to Sign Treaty, Seek Economic Aid
