DOC.TEXT: Enjoying enormous popularity among Germans but facing problems at home, Soviet President President Mikhail Gorbachev plans to spend the first anniversary of the Berlin Wall opening looking for economic help. Gorbachev, scheduled to arrive in Bonn on Friday, is likely to be heaped with praise for his role in ending the Cold War. He may get a cooler response to his requests for support for reform efforts. He is believed to be seeking more credits from Germany to help the Soviet transition to a market economy and modernize nuclear power plants, among other programs. But German businessmen who were eager to rush into partnerships with the Soviets last year, are more cautious now with reports of growing Soviet unrest. ``The Soviet Union's internal development is so unclear that it does not create a good climate for investments,'' says Karl-Hermann Fink, managing director of the German East-West Trade Committee. ``We are heading for trouble. This is too much, too fast,'' said Heinrich Vogel, head of the Federal Institute for Soviet and International Studies. ``Nobody knows who will stand behind what is decided in Moscow.'' On Friday - the anniversary of the first openings in the wall that divided Berlin - Gorbachev is scheduled to sign a Soviet-German treaty that includes a non-aggression pact and other provisions for financial and technological help for the Soviet Union. On Saturday, Gorbachev plans to visit Chancellor Helmut Kohl's hometown of Oggersheim near the Rhine River for informal talks. Although economic issues are likely to dominate the two-day visit, other topics likely to be raised include the fate of Soviet soldiers who have deserted in what used to be East Germany. The 20-year accord Gorbachev and Kohl plan to sign Friday is one of the most expansive agreements ever worked out between the two nations. The countries will pledge not to use force against each other and to respect the boundaries of all countries in Europe. The treaty also creates the framework for German financial and technological help for the Soviet Union, and for intensified political and cultural ties. Both nations have strong historical connections, in peace and in war. Writers Aleksandr Pushkin and Johann Goethe became close friends in Weimar. Novelist Ivan Turgenev called Germany his ``second fatherland.'' Russian writer Boris Pasternak studied philosophy in Marburg. For Germans, Russia represented a land of great economic opportunity with wide-open spaces their nation lacked. Catherine the Great, the German-born ruler of Russia at the end of the 18th century, invited her former countrymen to settle land along the Volga river. Their descendants, repressed under Stalin, now number in the millions. Many want to emigrate to Germany. The 1922 Treaty of Rapallo, which outlined close military and political consultations between Germany and the young Soviet state, alarmed the rest of Europe. The word ``Rapallo'' still signifies something sinister. Strong economic links emerged again with the foundation in 1949 of the Communist state of East Germany, which became the Soviet's largest trading partner. Moscow was reluctant to agree to the Oct. 3 German reunification, but agreement finally came in July. Now, some of Germany's European allies are worried about its relationship with the Soviet Union. The French press referred to the July meeting between Gorbachev and Kohl in the Soviet leader's hometown of Stavropol as ``Stavrapallo.'' Germany has sought to reassure its western neighbors its interest in the Soviet Union in no way reduces the commitment to European integration. ``Germans have a special responsibility for their eastern neighbors,'' said historian Juergen Kocka. ``We should take care of the east, but not so that it disassociates us from the West.''

DOC.HEAD: Manhattan Getting Its First Driving Range ... Sort Of
DOC.TEXT: An urban golfer's paradise is being planned for a tree-lined spot in the East River under the shadow of a psychiatric center, a sewage-treatment plant and the Fire Department's training academy. It is a first for Manhattan. Sort of. The new course is to be on Randalls Island, which sits in the East River but is considered part of the borough of Manhattan. Golf came to the city in 1895, when the nation's first public course was opened at Van Cortlandt Park. But that's across the river and in the Bronx. The links plan approved by the Parks and Recreation Department last week calls for a driving range, pro shop and 36 holes of miniature golf on 17 acres of Randalls Island. The American Golf Corporation got the go ahead for the project, which the company says will cost $2.7 million. The city expects to make up to $500,000 a year in revenues. ``The area is underused now, and the golf center will be a terrific addition to the city park system,'' said Parks Commissioner Betsy Gotbaum, who dismissed concerns that the complex will take space away from ball fields and playgrounds. ``We aren't going to cut down any trees and we aren't going to take away any ball fields for children,'' she said. ``What we're doing is simply letting the golfers of Manhattan have their day.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0739, AM-Postal Grade transmitted Nov. under a Washington dateline, may wish to use the following story
DOC.TEXT: An Associated Press story Nov. 5 on the Postal Service's performance record may have left the erroneous impression that overnight mail and Express Mail are the same thing. The story reported that the first independent test of the Postal Service found that 80.61 percent of mail intended for overnight delivery arrived on time. That figure applied only to regular first class mail that is designated for overnight delivery in the region where it is mailed. More distant points are scheduled for second- or third-day delivery. Express Mail, a special higher-cost service in which the Post Office guarantees next-day delivery across most of the nation, was not considered in the test conducted by the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Tanker Goes Aground Near Honolulu; Freed Later With No Sign of Leak
DOC.TEXT: A 730-foot tanker carrying more than 10 million gallons of oil products ran onto a reef and was aground for nearly 11 hours before tugboats freed it in a rising tide today, authorities said. There was no immediate sign of a spill. A pump room of the single-hull Star Connecticut took on 15 feet of water in the accident Tuesday night, but the flooding was controlled and a Coast Guard helicopter lowered pumps to the ship, said Lt. Kent Youel, a Coast Guard spokesman. The ship ran aground a mile south of Barbers Point, about 10 miles west of Honolulu. The Star Connecticut, owned by Texaco, had just left an offshore mooring and went aground about a mile away, Youel said. After it was freed this morning, commercial divers checked the underside of the ship for damage, Youel said. Their findings would determine where the ship would be taken, he said. The tanker ran aground shortly after leaving the Orion Independence refinery at Barbers Point. The Coast Guard's main goal was to unload the oil, various types totaling about 250,000 barrels, from the ship as quickly as possible, Youel said. The grounding is near where another tanker, the Exxon Houston, broke free from its offshore mooring in 1989, ran aground and spilled 33,000 gallons of oil that fouled the shore. Aboard the Star Connecticut were low sulphur oil, high sulphur oil, light naphtha oil and black oil, Youel said.

DOC.HEAD: Relief Crews Sent to Latest Quake Zone
DOC.TEXT: Search teams and relief aid were dispatched to remote sections of southern Iran on Wednesday following a powerfu earthquake that killed at least 22 villagers and left more than 12,000 homeless, Tehran radio reported. The report, monitored in Nicosia, said most of the victims were children less than 12 years old who were sleeping when the quake struck Tuesday evening. The radio said 100 people were seriously injured. The crisis further strains Iran's relief agencies, still reeling from a major quake in northern Iran in June which killed an estimated 50,000 people. The temblor shook 18 villages around the city of Darab, about 600 miles southeast of Tehran, the official Islamic Republic News Agency said. The U.S. Geological Survey said initial readings put the magnitude of the quake at 7.0 on the Richter scale. Iran's Geophysics Center of Tehran University said it measured 6.6. The news agency's casualty toll was slightly lower than the radio report, suggesting the count was ongoing. It said two of the villages, Qareh-No and Do-Borj-E Fourk, were razed. They had a combined population of more than 6,300 people. Tehran television said the other villages sustained 60 percent to 90 percent damage, and that seven villages were without potable water. The radio reported that schools, communication centers and police offices were flattened. Roads to the villages were blocked. Rescuers worked round-the-clock searching for survivors, while helicopters flew in blankets and tents and carried those injured to hospitals, IRNA said. Earthquakes of 6 on the Richter scale can cause widespread, heavy damage. A earthquake of 7 is considered major. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. For example, a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. A quake measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale struck northern Iran on June 21, killing an estimated 50,000 people and leaving 500,000 homeless. IRNA said the region hit by Tuesday's quake was rocked with aftershocks, the strongest of which measured 5.6 and came almost an hour after the main quake. President Hashemi Rafsanjani sent Vice President Hamid Mirzadeh to the region after allocating $13 million for disaster relief. Rafsanjani, who visited the northern Gilan and Zanjan provinces, said only half of the homeless from the June quake have found permanent shelter. He urged officials to speed up reconstruction before temperatures plung below freezing in the coming weeks. Earlier this week he ordered all his ministers to visit the stricken areas in the north to help speed up reconstruction.

DOC.HEAD: Economy Fears Help Defeat Pro-Environment and Anti-Tax Measures
DOC.TEXT: Voters may be enraged at wasteful government, high taxes and a fouled environment, but ballot contests decided in 26 states showed they're not about to rock the economic boat to solve those problems. Environmentalists had hoped to buoy their cause with ``Big Green,'' a sweeping California proposal that would have imposed a wide and unprecedented array of restrictions on offshore drilling, pesticide use and air pollutants. Instead, ``Big Green'' was done in Tuesday by big bucks: a $10 milliion campaign against it by various industries that apparently convinced Californians that the potential cost of the measure would be a crushing new burden in a sagging economy. The measure was trounced by nearly a 2-1 margin. And except for Pacific Grove, Calif., where voters approved a $1.2 million bond to protect a butterfly preserve, environment-related ballot issues took beatings practically everywhere else: in New York, Oregon, Missouri and Washington. Meanwhile, residents of Massachusetts and six other states rejected stringent anti-taxing, anti-spending measures, apparently heeding warnings from educators and local officials that the resulting school and municipal cuts might be even worse than the disease of government waste. Oregon, however, passed a tough anti-tax measure. Voters narrowly approved Measure 5, which will phase in a 1.5 percent ceiling on the property tax rate by 1995. It will cause property taxes to drop an estimated 45 percent by 1995, and require the Legislature to replace whatever money would be lost to schools from the property tax cuts. In all, Americans decided 236 statewide ballot questions Tuesday and scores of local contests. Arizonans may have lost their shot at being host to the Super Bowl in 1993 after rejecting a proposal to make Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday a state holiday. National Football League Commissioner Paul Tagliabue recommended Wednesday that the game be played elsewhere after Arizonans decided to remain one of just three states without a formal holiday honoring the slain civil rights leader. Alaskans recriminalized private use of marijuana for the first time in 15 years, while Maine voters abolished tough blue laws forcing big stores to shut on Sundays. Florida voters decided to become the first state to make a three-day wait on gun purchases part of their constitution. Washington, D.C., voters turned back an attempt to restore the right of homeless people to city-financed overnight shelter. Santa Clara County, Calif., rejected a stadium bond intended to lure the baseball Giants from San Francisco, while San Franciscans approved a measure allowing unmarried couples to register their relationships with city officials but without conferring formal new benefits. Seattle voters retained spousal benefits for unmarried companions of municipal employees. Disgruntled Staten Island residents, long in the shadows of other New York City boroughs, decided to study possible secession from the Big Apple. Among other significant ballot measures:
DOC.HEAD: ENVIRONMENT
DOC.TEXT: -In New York, a $1.97 billion environmental bond lost narrowly despite the strong backing of Gov. Mario Cuomo. -Voters in Washington rejected a proposal mandating land-use plannin throughout the state. -Oregonians voted down strict recycling rules as well as a proposal that would have shut down the Trojan nuclear plant, the state's only nuclear power plant. -Missouri voters rejected a ``Natural Streams'' initiative to regulate development along scenic waterways in the Ozarks. -South Dakotans turned down limits on mining in the Black Hills, but approved regulating large-scale garbage dumps. -Besides ``Big Green,'' Californians rejected the ``Forests Forever'' plan, which would have limited widespread logging. -But Arizonans and Minnesotans approved dedicating portions of state lottery proceeds to preserving the environment.
DOC.HEAD: TAXING, SPENDING
DOC.TEXT: -Massachusetts residents disapproved a $2.6 billion tax rollback to 1988 levels. It would have been the nation's largest voter-initiated state tax cut. -Californians narrowly defeated Initiative 136, dubbed ``Son of Jarvis.'' The measure - named for the co-author of Proposition 13, which started the nationwide tax revolt 12 years ago - would have required a two-thirds legislative or popular majority for new taxes. Californians also rejected two measures that would have increased the state tax on alcohol. -Montanans turned down a measure that would have replaced their state income, property and sales taxes in favor of a ``transaction charge'' of 1 percent on all financial dealings. But they also rejected a measure boosting the state cigarette tax 140 percent to 43 cents a pack, which would have been the nation's highest. -Utah voters refused to abolish the state sales tax on food. -Nebraskans voted against a 2 percent limit on annual state and local budget increases. -Coloradans rejected a measure requiring voter approval for any state or local tax increase.
DOC.HEAD: TERM LIMITS
DOC.TEXT: -Californians voted to limit the number of terms state politicians can serve to a total of six years - three terms - for Assembly members and eight years - two terms - for state senators. The eight-year limit also applies to statewide officers. The measure also eliminated the legislature's pension program and cut its operating budget about 40 percent. They defeated another measure, backed by consumer advocate Ralph Nader and Common Cause, to limit statewide officers to eight consecutive years and allow legislators only 12 consecutive years in each house. -71 percent of Coloradans voted for a limit of eight consecutive years for holding a single state office. -Kansas City, Mo., residents limited city council members and the mayor to two consecutive four-year terms. Council members can run again after sitting out a term.
DOC.HEAD: EDUCATION
DOC.TEXT: -In a race considered critical by the nation's education establishment, Oregon defeated a plan to give up to $2,500 tax credits to allow parents to send their children to any public or private school they wish, or to teach them at home. -Arizona residents turned down a proposal to increase spending on education by about $6 billion over 10 years. -Kansans defeated a plan shifting much of the governing authority of existing state education boards to the legislature. -A Nebraska voted narrowly not to repeal a recently enacted school finance reform package that featured higher sales and income taxes in order to shift reliance away from property taxes.

DOC.HEAD: 1990 Election in Brief
Party Switcher's Supporters Don't Follow Him
DOC.TEXT: A congressman who switched to the Republican party last year, thinking his southern Democratic supporters would defect too, found out he was wrong. Rep. Bill Grant lost his bid for re-election Tuesday when Democrat Douglas ``Pete'' Peterson defeated him in the race for Florida's 2nd District. Complete unofficial results showed Peterson had 101,615 votes, or 57 percent, to Grant's 76,518 votes, or 43 percent. Grant was seeking a third term. Eight of 10 voters in the district are registered Democrats, and both parties sakey to whether ow the race as a ther southern Democrats would be willing to defect to the GOP. Congress' inability to pass a budget and reduce the deficit during much of October contributed to Grant's defeat, Peterson said. ``The country came to a stop and Bill Grant was a part of that,'' Peterson said. ``The party switch was a factor, but mainly it was the way he did it.'' ---
DOC.HEAD: Hahn - That's Kenneth P. - Nabs County Assessor Race
DOC.TEXT: County Assessor John Lynch frequently reminded voters that County Supervisor Kenneth Hahn supported him for re-election. But come Tuesday, Kenneth P. Hahn ousted Lynch from office. Confused? The county supervisor and Lynch's challenger share the same first and last nameraft flew over the Station One Hotel before plunging into the ocean, said Navy spokesman Cmdr. Steve Honda. The plane was not carrying any bombs, Honda said. Ron Welch and Greg White were working on a car in front of White's apartment when the A-6 roared overhead. ``It was flaming fully,'' said White. Lorraine Fortier, 24, was at the Station One Hotel. ``I was in my room when I heard this loud sound,'' said Ms. Fortier. ``I've been here a couple weeks so I was used to the noise the jets make taking off over the hotel and I knew this was not right.'' Ms. Fortier rushed to her balcony in time to see the jet slam into the ocean. ``I saw this big flash of light - this big fireball - hit the water and that was it.'' Part of the plane's canopy and an ejection seat fell onto the beach, Honda said, but no one on the ground was hurt. The Navy started an investigation, Honda said. The pilot was taken to Virginia Beach General Hospital for observation and released within an hour, according to t. Terry Evans, a spokesman for the Atlantic Fleet Naval Air Force. The bombardier-navigator was taken to a clinic at the Oceana base where he was treated for cuts and released, Evans said. He said their names would not be released.

DOC.HEAD: Nearly Two-Thirds of the Country Sat It Out
DOC.TEXT: Civil engineer Jim Allerton of Seattle didn't vote. ``It's just sleazeball A or sleazeball B,'' he said. College student Jennifer Toledo didn't vote. ``I don't believe in Santa Claus. I don't believe in the tooth fairy. I don't believe in politicians,'' she said. Food service manager Jim Madzinski didn't vote. ``Honestly, I'm not registered,'' he said. ``The last thing I want to do is get pulled in for jury duty.'' These Americans were among the estimated 110 million adults who sat out Tuesday's election. They far outnumbered the 76 million who voted. Were they sending a message? The experts aren't sure. Some see anger in the low turnout; others just see indifference. Curtis Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, who provided the turnout estimates, said voter turnout rose ``in places where there was something important to decide.'' In places where the public saw only messages framed by political consultants and sensed that nothing real was at stake, turnout was down, he said. Bruce Buchanan, a University of Texas political scientist, read it somewhat differently. It's not that non-voters are turned off, Buchanan said, but that they are untouched by government. ``Most people in America come close to regarding politics as very distant from their lives,'' he said. ``It's just not an urgent matter.'' People are more likely to tune in when a president is being elected, Buchanan said. Turnout always rises in presidential years. But Buchanan says it is wrong to assume that non-voters share similar reasons for their failure to vote. Some are kept away by barriers such as registration requirements and poll closing hours, he said. Some feel impotent, frustrated, certain their vote can't make a difference. And some, especially young adults, 18-24, feel politics simply has no relevance to their lives. ABC News polled 1,028 likely non-voters. It said the non-voters expressed the same concerns about the course of the country and the prospect of war as those who vote. Six in 10 said it is not true that all politicians are alike; they said that it does matter who is elected. Among the non-voters who were registered, 30 percent said time constraints would keep them from voting; another 22 percent cited health. Whatever the reasons - some people think the United States simply conducts too many elections for too many offices - turnout is lower in this country than in any democracy in the world. This year, Gans calculates, the figure will be about 36.3 percent, the same as four years ago. Across America on Election Day, talking to Associated Press reporters, non-voters tried to give their reasons. Most had a ``they're-all-bums '' quality. ``Why bother?'' asked Skyp Krantz, 43, of Dayton, Ohio, who earns $9,000 a year as a record store clerk. He said he has never voted. ``No matter who is voted in, once they are elected, they do what they want or worse, what somebody with a lot of money wants.'' In Albuquerque, N.M., appliance salesman Robin Smedley, 36, abdicated purposely. ``I can voice my opinion by having no opinion at all,'' he said. Kim Cruea, 26, a nanny who cares for four children in Indianapolis, wasn't registered. But even if she were, she said, ``with all these horrible campaign commercials, I wouldn't know who to vote for. They make everyone sound so horrible.'' In Madison, Wis., college student Kevin Moore, 25, seemed to confirm Buchanan's theory about the unaffected young. ``I'm just not interested,'' he said while waiting to cross a street on his bicycle. ``I don't think anyone running for office can do anything for me.'' In Traverse City, Mich., sewing store manager Beverly Kozacek ticked off her reasons on her fingers. ``I did not vote because of the way the campaigns were run,'' she said, bending an index finger. ``I did not vote because I did not like any of the candidates running ...'' ``You know I could have voted,'' she said. ``I drove right by the polling place and said, `I will not turn in.' There was just so much negative everything this year.''

DOC.HEAD: Revolutionary Spirit Gives Way to Anger and Disillusionment
With AM-Revolution Day, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Strolling arm-in-arm and carrying red carnations in a Revolution Day parade, retired schoolteachers Lina Solomanaya and Olga Stoyanovskaya appeared to be in a holiday mood. They weren't. ``All my life I've been deceived,'' Mrs. Solomanaya said. ``I was a Communist and I believed what they told me. I raised my children that way, too. I sent them to the Pioneers and the Communist Youth League. ``We have begun to open our eyes only in the last few years. We know what happened in 1917, and we can see what it has brought us. We just can't pretend anymore that it was right.'' The Nov. 7 holiday traditionally has glorified the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution with a military parade through Red Square. But on Wednesday, in addition to the Red Square parade, tens of thousands of Soviets marched through Moscow and other cities in counter-demonstrations expressing anger and disillusionment. Increasingly, Soviet historians and politicians are publicly declaring the revolution a failure. Some call it a noble, but unsuccessful, experiment. Others call a criminal coup that blocked the country's evolution toward parliamentary democracy. Mrs. Solomanaya, 61, and Mrs. Stoyanovskaya, 55, marched with more than 5,000 people behind banners with slogans such as ``Nov. 7: A Day of Mourning for Russia.'' The rally began a few blocks from Red Square, outside the Communist Party headquarters, where radical politician Lev Shemayev told the crowd: ``We no longer want to be guinea pigs in the giant experiment forced on us by false Bolsheviks for the past 73 years.'' It ended about one mile away at the apartment building where dissident physicist and 1975 Nobel Peace Prize winner Andrei Sakharov lived before his death last December. Along the way, Mrs. Solomanaya and Mrs. Stoyanovskaya explained why they have lost faith both in revolutionary ideology and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``For 73 years, we thought we were moving to a brighter future - and we never got there,'' said Mrs. Solomanaya, who taught literature in a Moscow high school. ``They promised us free medical care, free educations, good pensions. But all we got was crumbs,'' added Mrs. Stoyanovskaya. Passing a row of embassies, the two friends said Western countries have a higher standard of living, more freedom and less fear. They complained that sugar is rationed in Moscow, butter and eggs have disappeared from state stores, and shopping is humiliating. Mrs. Solomanaya said long lines have put the Soviet people in an ``evil'' mood. ``We are irritable, annoyed, vexed, because every step in our lives has become difficult,'' said Mrs. Stoyanovskaya, a former English teacher. Both women said Gorbachev failed to revive the economy. ``Gorbachev brought us free speech, which was something we never expected, and we have to thank him for that,'' Mrs. Stoyanovskaya said. ``But Gorbachev is like a weather vane, turning whichever way the wind blows. First he supported the 500-day (economic reform) program. Then he rejected it. He is pressured by the right, and he gives in.'' Mrs. Solomanaya said she is now pinning her hopes on reformers in the Russian republic government, led by President Boris Yeltsin, because they are willing to take more resolute steps toward economic reform. But she said she expects conditions to worsen before getting better. ``We are tired of socialism, communism, internationalism,'' she said. ``All we want is a better life - not another `ism.'''

DOC.HEAD: Voters in ``Butterfly Town USA'' Decide To Save Monarch Habitat
DOC.TEXT: The migratory haven of thousands of majestic monarch butterflies has been saved at the ballot box as voters here approved bonds to purchase a habitat for the insects. Measure G, a $1.2 million bond issue, required two-thirds vote to pass. Sixty-nine percent of voters favored the measure, and 31 percent voted against it. Developers and property rights groups opposed the revenue bond issue to purchase and set aside a 2.7-acre habitat in this community known as ``Butterfly Town USA.'' But lovers of the graceful insect argued that protecting privately owned Diveley Grove would help save the butterfly population that winters in the grove and protect the town's love affair with the orange and black butterfly. ``I just can't image Butterfly Town USA without butterflies,'' said Ro Vaccaro, member of the Friends of the Monarch. The grove of Monterey pine and eucalyptus trees is one of the few remaining monarch wintering grounds in the western United States. On the second Saturday of each October, school children dress as butterflies and march through this seaside Monterey Peninsula town of 16,000, spreading colorful wings to usher in the fall butterfly season. The issue will raise the property tax rate by 1.5 cents per $100 of assessed valuation - about $15 a year on a $100,000 home.

DOC.HEAD: Official, Unofficial Slogans of Revolution Day
With AM-Revolution Day, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Some of the official and unofficial slogans for Wednesday's Revolution Day parade:
OFFICIAL SLOGANS ``Through diversity to unity and consensus.'' ``Long live the 73rd anniversary of the Great October Socialist Revolution.'' ``Communists! Fight for full renewal of the party, for humanitarian and democratic socialism'' ``Comrades! Legality, economic progress, spiritual rebirth - these are the main goals of our politics.'' ``Citizens of our multi-ethnic society! The future of the U.S.S.R. will be the unity of sovereign republics! Long live the new union agreement!''

UNOFFICIAL SLOGANS ``President and Supreme Soviet of the USSR - Resign!'' ``Nobel Prize to Gorbachev, Ration Coupons to Russia!'' ``October 1917 - Beginning of the chain of bloody crimes of Bolshevism!'' ``(Defense Minister Dmitry) Yazov and his criminal generals - Resign!'' ``The army and people are indivisible!'' ``True sovereignty to Russia!'' ``Armed forces for Russia!'' ``Security for Yeltsin!'' ``Freedom for political prisoners!'' ``Return illegally obtained Communist Party property to the people!'' ``Put Russian enterprises under the authority of the Russian government, Yeltsin, Silaev and others!'' ``Give jobs back to those illegally fired!''

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Man Indicted on Murder Charge in Death of Federal Judge
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; minor editing thruout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department today announced a 70-count indictment against a Georgia man for the mail-bomb killings of a federal appellate judge and a Savannah civil rights lawyer. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and FBI Director William Sessions announced the indictment, which was returned in Atlanta against Walter L. Moody Jr. Moody, 56, is charged with mailing package bombs last December that killed Circuit Judge Robert S. Vance and Savannah, Ga., city alderman and civil rights lawyer Robert E. Robinson. Both Vance and Robinson suffered fatal injuries by the force of the blasts when they opened packages mailed to them less than a week before Christmas. Moody, of Rex, Ga., is charged with murder of a U.S. judge, which carries a maximum penalty of life in prison. He also is charged with sending package bombs to the court where Vance sat, the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta, and the Jacksonville, Fla., office of the NAACP. Other charges alleged that Moody, who is in custody on another federal case, mailed assassination threats to all of Vance's colleagues on the 11th circuit. Six of the charges against Moody carry sentences of up to life imprisonment, including allegations he mailed package bombs with the intent to kill. The bombs found in the Atlanta courthouse and the Jacksonville NAACP office were removed without causing any injuries. Thornburgh said the bombings ``strike at the heart of our American concept of the rule of law.'' ``Those who would seek to attack the integrity and sanctity of our legal system through violent behavior would undermine the very foundations of our democracy,'' he said. Vance died after opening a package that was mailed to his home in Mountain Brook, Ala. Moody and his wife, Susan, previously were accused of conspiracy and obstruction of jusice in an alleged scheme to induce a federal court in Macon, Ga., to vacate Moody's 1972 conviction for unlawful possession of a pipe bomb. Moody was convicted of the explosives charge after a pipe bomb went off in his home, injuring his then-wife, Hazel. He served two years in federal prison for the conviction. Moody and his wife were accused in July of persuading witnesses to sign false affidavits and give false testimony. During the current investigation, there were reports that agents seized 17 25-cent stamps showing the American flag over Yosemite National Park from the purse of Susan Moody. All four mail bombs bore the Yosemite commemorative stamps. Several news organizations received the letters from a group calling itself Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System, which threatened to kill lawyers, judges and NAACP officials. Investigators said the letters bore similar markings and were sent from locations in Georgia. In the letters, the group claimed it ``assassinated Judge Robert S. Vance and attorney Robert Robinson in reprisal for atrocities'' to a white women who was robbed, raped and murdered in Atlanta in 1988. The letters also expressed anger over a school desegregation case in DeKalb County, Ga., in which Vance participated as a judge. The appellate panel ordered the school system to transfer white teachers to schools with predominantly black student populations.

DOC.HEAD: Ballot-Box Surprises Befuddle The Experts
DOC.TEXT: A handful of key races this year demonstrated once again that polling may be more art than science. While most pr-election surveys were reliable, voters provided enough ballot-box surprises to befuddle the experts. New Jersey's popular Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley got a scare from a political unknown who took 49 percent of the vote. Sen. Jesse Helms, the combative conservative Republican from North Carolina, burst the bubble of liberal Democrats - and exulted over his 6-point margin of victory. And in Michigan, Republican John Engler pulled off a stunning upset that blindsided even his own pollsters. Was Engler's razor-thin defeat of two-term Democratic Gov. James J. Blanchard a surprise? ``Without a doubt,'' said John Wilson of American Viewpoint, who did Engler's polling. Two weeks before the election, American Viewpoint said 53 percent of the voters were backing Blanchard, 33 percent Engler and 14 percent undecided. Wilson attributed the dramatic shift to complacency by Blanchard and the challenger's tenacity and good organization in getting out the vote on Tuesday. Engler is ``just not the kind of guy that loses,'' said Wilson. ``It was against all the odds.'' Pollsters rarely admit to mistakes. There are as many explanations as races when the pulse-takers are confounded. The Bradley contest is a good example. The former Rhodes Scholar and professional basketball star was considered untouchable in New Jersey and a good bet for a presidential bid somewhere down the road. Ironically, some believe his own popularity may have cost him support. ``He's an incredibly popular candidate,'' said Janice Ballou, polling director of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University in New Jersey. ``Some people voted against Bradley to send a message even though they liked him'' because they were confident he would survive, she said. To Wednesday morning quarterbacks, the message was clear: no taxes. Bradley was burned by a decidedly unpopular tax program pushed by Democratic Gov. Jim Florio, who was not on the ballot. Two weeks before the election, the Eagleton Institute said Bradley's lead over Republican Christine Todd Whitman was 62 percent to 26 percent with 12 percent undecided. But Ms. Ballou said her organization saw the tide shifting - sort of. A week before the election, after Ms. Whitman stepped up her television ads, she cut the lead almost in half. Bradley was ahead 50 to 33 percent, with 17 percent undecided. Then Eagleton, which had not budgeted any more money for the race, stopped polling. ``Maybe retrospectively we should have continued to do it,'' Ms. Ballou said. ``That's a tough call.'' The Helms contest, perhaps the most closely watched in the nation, had its own unique dynamic. Helms, who makes many a conservative look moderate, stepped up his attacks in the closing days on Harvey Gantt by branding his Democratic challenger a supporter of racial quotas. Gantt was the first black mayor of Charlotte and made no secret of his liberalism. ``Probably some white voters had second thoughts about voting for Harvey Gantt. Race certainly played a role in that,'' said Neil Newhouse of the Republican polling organization the Wirthlin Group. On election night, Helms came out 6 percentage points ahead and gloated over the turnaround from late polls that showed him trailing by as much as 9 percentage points. ``There is no joy in Mudville tonight,'' Helms told gleeful supporters. ``The mighty ultra-liberal establishment ... and commentators and columnists have struck out again.'' Sometimes even candidates rely too much on polls. Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., said he felt confident staying in Washington for much of the campaign homestretch because of what his pollsters were telling him. ``We thought frankly that based on what we were seeing ... that things were going pretty well,'' Gingrich said Wednesday. He won by less than a percentage point.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Take Back Nebraska Governorship
DOC.TEXT:
Patience has become the political bedfellow of Ben Nelson, who was not ready to claim victory Wednesday after narrowly defeating Republican Gov. Kay Orr. ``Obviously, I'm elated, but I've got to tell you until those absentee ballots are counted, I'm waiting,'' said Nelson, who had to wait two months last spring before he was declared the victor by 42 votes in the Democratic gubernatorial primary. With all but about 9,500 absentee ballots counted, Nelson had 286,608 votes to Orr's 281,827. A recount would be required by state law if Nelson's margin of victory dwindled to less than 1 percent of his total votes. The absentee ballots will be counted beginning Thursday when all 93 county canvassing boards meet. Secretary of State Allen Beermann said he expected the absentee ballots to follow the pattern of the counted votes. But Nelson, 49, wasn't taking anything for granted in his first bid for public office. ``It's not over until it's over,'' said Nelson, an insurance attorney from Omaha. Orr, 51, the state's first woman governor and the nation's firest Republican woman elected governor, refused to concede defeat in her bid for a second term. ``Obviously it doesn't look very optimistic, but we think we owe it to the more than 23,000 volunteers to make sAM-Infotechnology
