DOC.HEAD: Convicted Computer Hacker Doing Time Answering Lawyers Telephones
DOC.TEXT: A computer hacker is answering telephones for the Boston Bar Association as the penalty for unleashing a rogue virus into a nationwide computer system. Robert Morris, 24, a former Cornell University student, began the work several weeks ago, said Francis Moran, executive director of the bar association. In May, Morris became the first person convicted under the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act, which makes it a felony to intentionally gain unauthorized access to federal computers. A federal judge sentenced Morris, who lives in Cambridge, Mass., to 400 hours of community service and three years' probation. He was fined $10,000. As an experiment on Nov. 2, 1988, Morris used a Cornell computer to unleash a rogue program, called a ``worm,'' into a nationwide network linking 180,000 computers. He was later suspended from Cornell. Prosecutors alleged Morris, son of the National Security Computer Center's chief scientist, did at least $165,000 worth of damage. Morris is appealing his conviction.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Population Down, but Rural Total Up
DOC.NOTE: For release at 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The nation's farm population dipped again last year, but more people than ever were living in small towns, distant suburbs and the rest of rural America, the government reported Wednesday. Farm people declined by 150,000 to an estimated 4,801,000 in 1989, a decrease described by the report as ``not a statistically significant difference'' from 1988. The new estimate put the farm population at 1.9 percent of the U.S. total of more than 248.2 million people, the smallest share on record. In 1980, the 6.05 million on farms represented 2.7 percent of the 221.7 million people in the United States. And at the turn of the century, the 1900 census showed 29.9 million living on farms, 39.3 percent of the population of 76 million. The annual report was released by the Census Bureau of the Commerce Department and the Economic Research Service of the Agriculture Department. Overall, the rural population was estimated at more than 66.2 million, up from just under 64.8 million people in the 1988 survey. The rural population includes those in living in the open countryside and small towns not in the suburbs of large cities. Large cities and their suburbs, plus towns of 2,500 or more, are considered urban. As used in the report, the farm population consists of those living on farms in rural areas, but does not include the relatively few who live on farms in urban areas. A farm is defined as a place that sold agricultural products worth $1,000 or more in the previous year. Felicia LeClere of the Economic Research Service, one of the authors, said there were no real surprises in this year's figures. ``The things that have come out have been long-term trends, and none of them has been surprising,'' she said in a telephone interview. LeClere cautioned that all the figures are subject to revision when the official 1990 census results are available next year. She is confident that the annual figures are on track, however. Department officials have noted the increase in rural population - rising by 12 million people since 1950 - and point out that urban sprawl and a willingness of city workers to commute greater distances have been important factors. One possible effect of the 1990 census is a reclassification of some of these distant areas from rural to urban. That could show up later as a slowdown in rural growth. The report said the largest share of the rural population, about 44 percent, continues to be in the South. That has been the case since the first U.S. census was taken in 1790. ``Although the regional distribution of the rural population changed only slightly in the last 40 years, the regional distribution of the farm population shifted markedly,'' the report said. In 1950, one-third of all farm people lived in the Midwest and slightly more than half in the South. ``A rapid decline in the Southern farm population, rather than growth in the Midwest's farm population, reversed the regional rankings,'' the report said. ``Half of the total farm population now lives in the Midwest, and less than a third lives in the South.'' Other observations in the report included: -Farm people continue to be older than the non-farm population in general, with a median of 38 years in 1989, compared with 32.5 years for non-farm. A median age means half of the people are older, half younger. Non-farm refers to urban plus rural non-farm people. -Last year 97.4 percent of farm residents were white, and 1.8 percent were black, compared with 84 percent white and 12.5 percent black in the non-farm population. The remainder were described as of other races. -Only 2.9 percent of the farm residents were of Hispanic origin. -Nearly 69 percent of the farm residents 15 years and older were married and living with spouses in 1989, compared with 55.4 percent of the non-farm people.

DOC.HEAD: Vermont Artist Wins Annual Duck Stamp Competition
DOC.TEXT: An artist from Vermont won the Interior Department's annual duck stamp competition Wednesday with her entry showing a pair of King Eider ducks. Nancy Howe of East Dorset, Vt., was selected from among 626 contestants who had entered the contest that determines the design of the 1991-92 stamp. Wildlife artists from around the country annually compete for the right to have their design on the stamp. Ms. Howe, 40, will receive a pane of her winning stamp. Although the government provides no monetary reward for the design, a number of artists have earned as much as $1 million from the sale of limited-edition prints, according to officials of the Fish and Wildlife Service, which sponsors the contest. The sale of duck stamps have earned $350 million for the Interior Department since 1934 with much of the money going to preserving millions of acres of wetlands and wildlife refuges. The stamps must be purchased by any hunter of waterfowl who is 16 years of age. But the artistic stamps also attract stamp collectors and thousands of people who buy them to financially support federal wildlife conservation programs.

DOC.HEAD: Surprises For Some Who Have Been Eying The White House
With AM-Election Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ambitious Democrats with White House dreams won their re-election campaigns but some will have to deal with home-state problems and live down embarrassingly small victory margins. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, who has kept himself on everyone's list of presidential hopefuls for most of a decade, managed only 53 percent of the vote. In neighboring New Jersey, Sen. Bill Bradley anticipated a landslide but got only 51 percent against a political unknown. ``That doesn't look like presidential timber in 1992 to me,'' said Charles Black, communications director of the Republican National Committee. History shows close races or even losses at the state level don't drive a spike through a politician's heart. Richard Nixon rebounded from losing the presidency and then the California governorship and went on to win the White House. And National Democratic chairman Ron Brown said that two years from now, ``I can't imagine that anybody will be asked what perentage did you win by the last time you ran.'' Regardless of his margin, Cuomo must deal with massive budget problems in his home state before turning his sights on Washington. He kept quiet Wednesday. Bradley, once a national voice on tax policy, kept mum through much of this fall's congressional debates on the topic and became a target of backlash against Gov. Jim Florio's tax increases. ``Voters were sending a message to Florio through Bradley,'' said Larry Sabato, an election expert at the University of Virginia. Bradley on Wednesday declared again that his only plans were to serve another six years as New Jersey senator. His media adviser, Michael Kaye said the closeness of this year's race will be quickly forgotten. ``He's not a candidate in 1992 and if he becomes a candidate at a later date, they sure won't go back six years and replay what happened in his race in 1990,'' he said. Exit polls by CBS in both New Jersey and New York showed a plurality of voters thought Cuomo and Bradley would not make good presidents. A big margin didn't guarantee a clear path to the primaries. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas won handily with 57 percent of the vote. But along the way he promised he'd serve his four-year term. He'd have to break that promise to seek the presidency in 1992. Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., was re-elected to his House seat. He ran for president in 1988 and then was elected the House Majority Leader after promising not to run for the White House again in 1992 - a pledge other House Democrats have said they'd let him break. Prospects of another run for the Democratic nomination by Tennessee Sen. Al Gore certainly weren't hurt by the fact he got 70 percent of the vote. ``Now that it's over, I'll sit down and think about running (for president), but I don't have any plans,'' Gore said. ``I haven't ruled it out at all.'' Sen. Tom Harkin of Iowa became the first Democrat ever re-elected in his state. On Wednesday, Harkin seemed to have the 1992 Iowa caucuses in mind. ``I intend to be active in the next couple of years in the presidential process,'' he said. Democratic chairman Brown claimed Wednesday that Bush, who seemed invincible a few months ago, looked beatable in 1992. ``I believe yesterday was a referendum on the leadership of George Bush. he failed that test. It was, in effect, a no confidence vote for his ... domestic agenda.'' ``He said, `Send us more Republicans.' The American people sent him more Democrats. I think George Bush is frankly hurt,'' Brown said. But Black responded that ``Bush wasn't on the ballot yesterday.'' If he had, and had faced the likes of Cuomo or Bradley, ``they would have had their clocks cleaned,'' he said. On the Republican side, some winners probably had thoughts of succeeding Bush in 1996. The eventual presidential ambitions of Republican Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, certainly were not dampened by his 62 percent margin in that important state. Republicans also took over the governorship of several long-time Democratic states, creating a new class of potential presidential candidates.

DOC.HEAD: Tourists Get to See the Real Destructiion at Studio
With AM-Studio Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hollywood tourists took a close-up look Wednesday at a scene of destruction requiring no special effects: the gutting of the Universal Studios backlot. Leaving promptly at 9:30 a.m., trams full of visitors rolled around smoldering remains of sets from such popular films as ``The Sting,'' ``To Kill a Mockingbird'' and the ``Back to the Future'' series. ``The show must go on. The show will go on,'' said one tour driver who gave his name as Larry. ``The idea is to show you all of our backlot, only a small portion was actually damaged.'' The only big attraction not operating the day after the blaze was the King Kong exhibit featuring a fire-belching ape with banana-breath. Studio officials said the attraction should be open in a few days. Some visitors said the fire gave the tour, the third most popular theme park in the nation, added appeal. ``It encouraged us to come,'' said Carolyn Garrahan of Cape Cod, Mass., who took the tour with her husband, Tom. ``We wanted to see the damage. We wanted to see what's left of the place.'' Chris Bridge, who traveled with his family of four from Australia, came to Universal City especially for the studio tour. ``We saw all the smoke last night,'' he said. ``It was a great show. Much better than the elections.'' The studio reeked of smoke and a few visitors complained of the acrid smell. Indeed, tour driver Larry made light of some of the damage. ``We have a lot of great picture-taking opportunities on the tour today,'' he said with a laugh. One attraction that was not functioning was a home facade from which flames normally leap through windows. That facade wasn't damaged by the Tuesday night blaze, but other sets burned like kindling. ``We've lost the sets, but the area will live forever on films,'' a guide told visitors. More than 5 million tourists visited the studio tour last year, and trams were filled to capacity Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: McKernan Re-Elected; Sunday Sales Ban Repealed
DOC.TEXT: Voters made few changes in Maine's political scene, but the state's commerce was changed dramatically by the repeal of a ``blue law'' banning sales on Sunday. U.S. Rep. Joseph E. Brennan, who's a former governor, failed Tuesday in his attempt to unseat Republican Gov. John R. McKernan. Voters re-elected U.S. Sen. William S. Cohen and six-term U.S. Rep. Olympia J. Snowe, both Republicans. The Sunday sales question was forced to a vote through a petition drive bankrolled chiefly by the state's major shopping malls and department stores. Supporters of the repeal argued that citizens should be allowed to decide for themselves whether they want to shop on Sundays. The opposition was led by small-store owners, who feared competition from larger businesses. They argued repealing the law would commercialize a day that families can spend together. Maine and North Dakota are the only states outlawing sales on Sundays. Maine's law closed stores with at least 5,000 square feet of floor space, except between noon and 5 p.m. on Sundays between Thanksgiving and Christmas. Brennan's congressional seat went to Democrat Thomas H. Andrews, a state senator who handily defeated David F. Emery, a former congressman and Reagan administration official.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Flip-Flops `Uncle Buck' and `Evening Shade' Schedule
DOC.TEXT: ``Uncle Buck'' and ``Evening Shade,'' two new CBS situation comedies, will swap places on the network's schedule, CBS announced Wednesday. ``Evening Shade,'' in which Burt Reynolds heads an all-star cast in the comic doings of a small Arkansas town, will move to 8 p.m. EST Monday, leading off the network's strong sitcom lineup that night. ``Uncle Buck,'' a spinoff from the like-named theatrical hit, will move into the 8 p.m. EST Friday slot. The television version stars Kevin Meaney. The network has picked up both series for an entire season. The move followed a trial run for ``Evening Shade'' on Monday, where the series won the highest rating of any program on any network in the time period this season, said CBS senior executive for program planning, Peter Tortorici. ```Uncle Buck' has been successful in attracting a broad and younger audience to CBS, and we feel that it will continue to grow in strength on Fridays at 8 p.m., a time when kids clearly control the dial,'' Tortorici said. ``Evening Shade'' takes its new time slot Nov. 19. ``Uncle Buck'' will air in its old time slot Nov. 12 and in its new slot Nov. 16.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Sets Nov. 15 Launch Date for Atlantis
DOC.TEXT: After months of delays, NASA will try to launch Atlantis next Thursday with a Pentagon spy satellite that reportedly will gather intelligence information in the Persian Gulf. NASA, meanwhile, also reported Wednesday that a special investigative team found no pattern in a series of accidents involving shuttle equipment. Atlantis was supposed to blast off in July with the spy satellite, but the shuttle was grounded by hydrogen leaks. During the grounding, the spacecraft reportedly was modified to spy on Iraqi forces. NASA had rescheduled the launch for Friday after a fueling test last month found Atlantis to be free of dangerous leaks. The Air Force last week delayed the flight, however, because of undisclosed problems that arose during cargo testing. Columbia, also crippled for months by leaking hydrogen, was cleared for flight during a similar fueling test last week. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to send Columbia on its long-delayed astronomy mission in early December. Columbia's seven-man crew has endured four launch attempts since May, three of which were halted by leaking hydrogen in the final hours before liftoff. Improperly installed seals accounted for some of the leakage in the engine compartment. The investigative team, led by veteran astronaut John Young, identified nine accidents involving shuttle equipment during the past 13 months, said William Lenoir, head of NASA's space flight program. In one case, workers left a 9-foot-long, aluminum beam in Atlantis' engine compartment last month, resulting in minor damage. ``They couldn't find a common thread that said the training was bad or the workers were sleepy or they were overworked,'' Lenoir said. Although the team found ``sometimes we're a little sloppy,'' the conditions observed did not differ from findings of earlier investigative boards during the past 1{ years, Lenoir said. The team recommended that more technicians be trained in specialized rather than generic jobs, and that communications be improved among workers, Lenoir said. ``A couple of the techs that they talked to felt like mushrooms ... that we perhaps don't often enough let the whole workforce know the big picture,'' Lenoir said. The team also stressed the need for realistic scheduling, Lenoir said. Before hydrogen leaks crippled two of NASA's three shuttles, for example, NASA planned nine launches for 1990. Six will be achieved if Atlantis and Columbia go up as planned. Shuttle director Robert Crippen said the 1991 flight schedule still was being finalized. ``We're trying to lay out the flights, using the experience base that we've had in the past, so we can be more realistic and anticipate some things that are taking longer than what we'd planned,'' Crippen said.

DOC.HEAD: In Some Cases, Money Wasn't Everything
DOC.TEXT: Money wasn't necessarily everything in this year's elections as some low-spending candidates ousted incumbent governors and members of Congress. As usual, however, the overwhelming majority of incumbents, with their huge fund-raising ability, were victorious. One of the highest profile races saw Sen. Jesse Helms buying massive TV time and defeating Democratic challenger Harvey Gantt. The Republican senator had raised $11 million, as of the mid-October deadline for federal financial disclosure reports, to Gantt's $6 million. ``The overwhelming campaign finance advantage held by congressional incumbents dominated and controlled the races,'' said Fred Wertheimer, president of the campaign finance watchdog group Common Cause. In some races, however, winners upset better-financed opponents - notably Paul Wellstone over Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz in Minnesota, former Sen. Lawton Chiles ousting Republican Gov. Guy Martinez in Florida, and Democratic challenger Joan Finney beating Gov. Mike Hayden in Kansas. In Rhode Island, the tables were turned with Republican Gov. Ed DiPrete being outspent 2-1 - and defeated - by Democrat Bruce Sundlun. In Texas, Democrat Ann Richards beat Republican oilman Clayton Williams despite Williams' heavy spending, incl million of his own money. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., withstood a challenge from wealthy businessman James Rappaport after Rappaport poured more than $3 million in personal loans into his campaign. Kerry, who reported raising more than $5 million as of mid-October, still outspent Rappaport, who had raised $3.7 million by the same time. ``Today in Massachusetts, we have proven that money can't buy you a U.S. Senate seat,'' Kerry said after winning. The outcome in the New Jersey Senate race was noteworthy for how close challenger Christine Whitman came to defeating incumbent Democrat Bill Bradley - despite Bradley's huge spending edge. Bradley, who spent $12.6 million to her $1 million, according to figures supplied by their campaigns, won by just two percentage points. In a case similar to Bradley's, Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga, barely kept his seat against a much poorer challenger. By mid-October, the incumbent had raised $1.3 million against $274,000 for Democratic challenger David Worley. ``Worley had problems with money. He might have been able to beat Gingrich easily'' with better financing, said Sabato. But the overall pattern of incumbents raising the most money and holding their seats held true. In the Florida governor's race, Chiles defeated Martinez although Chiles imposed a $100 limit on donations to his campaign. While Martinez had a 2-1 money edge over Chiles, the Democrat - by virtue of his reputation as a former senator - was in a better position to do without the extra money than most challengers would need. In Minnesota, Wellstone beat Boschwitz after a campaign in which the senator raised nearly $5 million by mid-October to less than $800,000 for Wellstone. ``Our campaign really relied on the shoe leather power of just volunteers,'' Wellstone said. Victories such as Wellstone's ``show that money is not always the price of admission. Special circumstances mean that voters do what they want to do,'' said Larry Sabato, a professor of government at the University of Virginia. Across the country, however, only 13 of 406 House members who had sought reelection were defeated, not counting two undecided California races. Several of the 13 heavily outspent their victorious opponents, including Reps. Bill Grant, R-Fla.; Roy Dyson, D-Md.; John Buechner, R-Mo.; Doug Walgren, D-Pa., and Robert Kastenmeier, D-Wis.

DOC.HEAD: Backers and Opponents of `Big Green' Continue War of Words
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists say they are already preparing for 1992 following the defeat of California's landmark ``Big Green'' environmental initiative. ``It's going to be a longer battle than we'd hoped,'' said Susan Birmingham of the U.S. Public Interest Research Group. ``The challenge for us is to keep pounding away.'' Backers and opponents of Big Green offered conflicting explanations for its proposal's defeat Tuesday. State Chamber of Commerce President Kirk West, co-chairman of the campaign against the initiative, said he thought his forces ``convinced the voters that it tried to do too much, covered too many subjects.'' But environmentalists said voters defeated ``Big Green'' because of unfounded fears fostered by opponents that it would hurt their pocketbooks. Activists vowed to press their cause. ``Big Green'' would have provided $300 million in bond money to buy and preserve ancient redwood forests. It aimed to slow global warming by curbing auto and other emissions. And it would have banned oil development in state waters and barred pesticides suspected of causing cancer. Proponents, who spent $4.5 million, said the initiative would have saved Californians several billion dollars a year in energy and health costs. Corporations, including major oil companies based outside the state, spent $10 million condemning the measure as an economic disaster. Its controls would have increased gas, electricity and food prices while falling short of environmental cleanup goals, they said. Three other environmental proposals were toppled along with Big Green, which lost by a nearly 2-to-1 margin. Fifty-three percent of the voters opposed ``Forests Forever,'' which would have restricted clear-cutting of forests and authorized $740 million in bonds for the purchase of old-growth redwoods. Two industry countermeasures to ``Big Green'' and ``Forests Forever,'' with far weaker controls on timber and pesticides, were also soundly rejected. Polls showed that the maze of four conflicting initiatives confused voters, a hazard that analysts predicted could lead to general rejection of the measures. ``I don't think that anybody who voted against `Big Green' voted for polluted air or cancer-causing chemicals,'' said Bob Hattoy of the Sierra Club. State Attorney General John Van de Kamp, also a primary sponsor of the measure, said voters were almost universally conservative when it came to spending money on new programs because ``of a confluence of events.'' ``I think the invasion of Kuwait, the beginning of the recession, the national budget crisis, the state budget crisis - all those things have scared people,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Throws Out 223 Over-the-Counter Drug Ingredients
DOC.NOTE: Eds: In 5th graf ``hyoscyamine'' is CQ
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration banned 223 ingredients in over-the-counter drugs Wednesday, saying manufacturers had offered no proof they were effective for problems they were supposed to treat. The ingredients ranged from pine tar in dandruff fighters through dehydrated garlic in digestive aids to aspirin in medications for external use. The FDA did not ban the ingredients entirely, just in certain uses. For example, aspirin may still be used in products for pain relief taken internally, because it has been shown to be effective pain reliever. The over-the-counter drug industry said most of the ingredients already had been withdrawn, but some familiar drugstore and supermarket products still will be affected, the agency said. For example, Tegrin Lotion, sold for use against psoriasis, may no longer contain allantoin. Also Packers shampoo and soap may not contain pine tar, and Donnagel, used to treat diarrhea, may no longer include atropine sulfate, hyoscyamine sulfate and scopolamine hydrobromide. The ban becomes effective in six months. The agency said none of the ingredients posed a safety problem in any of the banned uses. The ruling is part of an 18-year-long review of about 300,000 nonprescription products that were on the market in 1972. As part of its effort to complete that review, the agency last week proposed to ban 111 drug ingredients in over-the-counter diet products. Most companies have stopped using those ingredients, industry officials said. Manufacturers have been on notice since May that the agency wanted to ban the list of 223 ingredients, and most have reformulated their products, said Jack Walden, a spokesman of the Nonprescription Drug Manufacturers Association. ``Overwhelmingly, this is a housekeeping action,'' he said. ``The industry long ago came into compliance ... It affects products now on the market very, very little.'' Dean Siegal, a spokesman for Block Drug Co. Inc., which makes Tegrin Lotion for psoriasis, said the company has been reformulating its product and expects to have a new one out soon. ``This is not new news,'' he said. But Walden said that some companies disagree with the FDA's assertion that the action was being taken ``based on the absence of substantive comment or failure to submit new data.'' ``Some of our companies disagree that they failed to submit data and are in contact with FDA on this matter,'' Walden said. He did not identify those companies, the products or ingredients. Other banned ingredients are used in, among other things, topical acne drug products, antiperspirant products, cough and cold medications, laxatives, nailbiting and thumbsucking deterrents, poison treatments asnd drug products used to help people stop smoking. Within a few months, the agency expects to be about halfway through the massive review of nonprescription products it began in 1972, said spokeswoman Bonnie Aikman.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives, Labor Quarrel in Opening Legislative Session
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, in a fighting mood amid talk of a move to oust her, on Wednesday defended her brake on the European Community's drive toward closer unity. ``You don't secure the sort of Europe we want by a policy of always going along with what others propose simply for fear of being left out,'' Mrs. Thatcher said in a major speech after the opening of a new yearlong session of Parliament. ``We want to work closely with our European friends ... but we also want to preserve our national currency and the sovereignty of this House of Commons,'' she said. On the gulf crisis, she declared: ``Time is running out for Saddam Hussein. ... Either he gets out of Kuwait soon or we and our allies will remove him by force and he will go down to defeat.'' Rank-and-file Conservative Party legislators waved their programs in support as Mrs. Thatcher rose to address the Commons for the first time since her deputy, Sir Geoffrey Howe, resigned last Thursday in protest of her combative stance on Europe. Howe, who remains a legislator, listened impassively from near the back of the packed rows of leather benches behind the prime minister. Opposition leader Neil Kinnock twitted Mrs. Thatcher that her ``government is divided right through the middle.'' ``The British people will get rid of you at the general election as soon as you have the guts to call it!'' he shouted, struggling to make himself heard above the jeers of Conservative legislators. The bad-tempered exchanges erupted hours after Queen Elizabeth II opened the parliamentary session with the traditional glittering pageantry. The monarch, dressed in a flowing white gown and red robe and wearing the jewel-encrusted imperial crown, outlined an exceptionally light legislative program for the coming year in a speech written by the government. Proposals included a measure to permit privately financed road building and new anti-terrorism legislation for Northern Ireland. The government also will reintroduce a bill that would allow it to try suspected Nazi war criminals. The measure was previously defeated in the unelected House of Lords. The slim legislative program would leave Mrs. Thatcher free to call an election next year, a year before her third five-year term expires. However, with a dispute over the pace and extent of European union - on top of economic troubles - the Conservatives are running as much as 20 points behind Labor in opinion polls. The annual election among Tory legislators for the party leader - who is automatically the prime minister - is set for Nov. 20. Mrs. Thatcher moved it from Dec. 5, and the new date was widely seen as a move to cut short campaigning time for rivals. But the half-dozen potential heavyweight rivals, who include Howe and ex-Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine, have said they will not challenge this year. They apparently fear they cannot get sufficient votes. Mrs. Thatcher, isolated 11-to-1 in the European Community, rejected a plan approved at a summit meeting last month for a single currency and closer political ties. She sees the moves as a surrender of Parliament's sovereign powers.

DOC.HEAD: Who Guitarist Pete Townshend Divulges His Bisexuality
DOC.TEXT: Pete Townshend, guitarist for The Who, has divulged his bisexuality in a interview in a new book in which he says ``I know how it feels to be a woman.'' Townshend, who has been married to Karen Astley since 1966 and has three children, revealed that he has been involved in homosexual relationships in the past. He made the statements in the new book, ``Rock Lives: Profiles and Interviews,'' a collection of interviews by music writer and radio host Timothy White. ``I know how it feels to be a woman because I am a woman,'' Townshend said in an interview with White that ran on White's radio show in September 1989. ``And I won't be classified as just a man.'' Townshend said his aversion to the macho rock star ethos surfaced publicly in the ``Rough Boys'' song on the 1980 album, Empty Glass. Townshend called the song a ``coming out, an acknowledgment of the fact that I'd had a gay life, and tht I understood what gay sex was about.'' ``It was a real acknowledgment of the fact that I'd been surrounded by people that I really adored - and was actually sexually attracted to - who were men. And that side of me that responded to those people was a passive side, a subordinate side.'' Townshend, who was surprised to find a strong female audience with his solo LP, said he believes he drew women because he was ``honest. Not necessarily by saying, `I am gay.' But just by being honest about the fact that I understand how gay people feel and I identify.''

DOC.HEAD: Karpov, Kasparov Wind Down American Segment of Chess Tournament
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Game 12 expected to end about 10:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The last U.S. game of the world chess championship began Wednesday with organizers and aficionados declaring the American segment of the tournament a success. Defending champion Garry Kasparov and challenger Anatoly Karpov were tied at 5{-5{ before Game 12 began. Each of the players won one game. There were nine draws. ``There was a lowered expectation about turnout when we started but we've been delighted at how many people showed up from all over the world,'' said Adam Black, a spokesman for championship organizers. ``Interest has not waned. People have called and come from all over.'' The second half of the championship begins Nov. 24 in Lyons, France. The first player to gain 12{ points wins the championship and $1.7 million of a $3 million purse. Opening ceremonies in France were scheduled for Nov. 23. Serious chess players and casual observers, paying $25 to $100 for tickets, crowded the Hudson Theater and adjoining Hotel Macklowe in midtown Manhattan during each of the 12 games in New York. Several analysis rooms, where chess grandmasters explained and dissected moves, were filled almost every night. About 500 journalists covered some or all of the games. Grandmaster Patrick Wolff, who did commentary during the matches, said the biggest surprise was the disparity in the games. Wolff said that the first four games could be considered the best first four games in world championship history. But games six through nine were ``terrible,'' he said. The final games were a slight improvement, Wolff said. Chess experts had expected Kasparov to maintain a substantial lead over Karpov, but Karpov surprised them by more than holding his own, Wolff said. The two, known for their dislike of one another, nonetheless were polite during the 12 matches in New York. ``They've been cordial to each other,'' said Wolff. ``Of course they don't like each other but they've played so much they're used to each other.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Say They Have A New Mandate In Congress
With AM-Election Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf and inserts new penultimate graf, If those, to clarify total party strength in the House; inserts 3 grafs Foley comment after 2nd graf pvs, With House
DOC.TEXT: Democrats pointed Wednesday to their strengthened majorities in the House and Senate as evidence of a new mandate to carry their ``fairness'' theme forward in 1991. With House Democrats padding their 259-176 edge by an expected nine seats and Senate Democrats expanding their majority by one in Tuesday's elections, the party held its tightest grip on legislative power in more than a decade. ``I think the issue of fairness and balance of burden sharing was well received,'' said House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., and that will be reflected in any new tax legislation that may arise next year. Foley said in a telephone interview that he was not predicting new taxes, but added: ``Some would predict the surcharge on million-dollar incomes has not disappeared from the scene.'' He said Democrats also saw the election results as impetus to pursue their agenda of health care, education and infrastructure improvements in the coming session of Congress. Republicans dismissed any notion that the outcome represented a mandate. They said their losses were a victory of sorts because they fell short of the level normally suffered by the party that holds the White House in non-presidential elections. The Democrats also took aim at President Bush. ``Americans read George Bush's lips yesterday, and they made it clear they didn't like his message,'' said Rep. Beryl Anthony, D-Ark., chairman of the House Democratic campaign committee. ``All over the country, voters snubbed candidates Bush campaigned for, showing Bush has no coattails,'' Anthony said at a post-election news conference. Democratic National Committee Chairman Ron Brown called the congressional budget debate that ended barely a week before Election Day the most significant issue in this year's voting, and in particular the idea of taxing those most able to pay. ``George Bush clearly demonstrated that they are on the side of the rich and we are on the side of the working man and woman,'' said Brown, reiterating a familiar theme that the party believes is working to its advantage. Brown said Democrats owed their success to an agenda that calls for aid for education, jobs and health care. ``Voters looked to Democrats to fight for the bread-and-butter issues that Bush finds so distracting and beneath him.'' The results reflect ``an anti-incumbent sentiment, and the incumbent who turned out to be the biggest target was the president,'' said Sen. John Breaux, D-La., head of the party's Senate campaign arm. House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., said the losses weren't ``due to any kind of national trend, I don't think, or issue, so much as it was something about (each) individual member.'' But Michel added: ``It sure as heck doesn't make the job any easier'' of carrying forward Bush's legislative agenda in the next two years. Democrats also were gleeful at the close call suffered by Rep. Newt Gingrich, the combative No. 2 Republican leader in the House. Gingrich won by less than 1,000 votes, and his Democratic opponent, David Worley, requested a recount. The ambush by Worley clearly caught Gingrich by surprise. One GOP official said the Georgian's polls showed him ahead with 57 percent support just a few days before the election. ``Newt Gingrich now becomes target No. 1 for 1992 if he wins the recount,'' Anthony said. The outcomes in two California districts remained up in the air, with two Democratic incumbents - Reps. Doug Bosco and Jim Bates - trailing by narrow margins. If those seats were to fall the way they were leaning, the final House lineup for the 102nd Congress would be 268 Democrats and 167 Rpublicans. Several races remained subject to possible recounts, including the 52-vote margin by which Joan Kelly Horn, a Democrat, appeared to have defeated two-term Republican Rep. Jack Buechner. In the Senate, the only shift was in Minnesota where college professor and political unknown Paul Wellstone dealt a stunning upset to two-term Republican incumbent Sen. Rudy Boschwitz. That left the Democratic majority at 56 to 44.

DOC.HEAD: Wilson Elected California Governor; Big Green Environmental Measure Fails
DOC.TEXT: California's new governor, Republican Pete Wilson, is heading to the capitol in Sacramento surrounded by Democrats in most top state offices and facing a hostile Legislature. With a handful of precincts and an estimated 500,000 absentee ballots remaining to be counted Wednesday, Wilson had 3,473,487 votes, or 49 percent, to Democrat Dianne Feinstein's 3,287,109 votes, or 46 percent. Three minor party candidates divvied up the remaining 5 percent. But Democrats increased their majorities in both houses of the Legislature, won five other statewide offices and were leading narrowly in a sixth statewide race. In state and local ballot propositions, voters said ``No'' - no to environmental initiatives, no to all state and most local tax increases, no to an unprecedented number of bond issues, and no to the existing leadership of the Legislature. The omnibus ``Big Green'' environmental initiative, Proposition 128, was defeated by a 2-1 margin. Big Green was a sweeping plan to phase out cancer-causing pesticides, ban chemicals that harm the ozone, and reduce emissions of gases that contribute to global warming. But voters also rejected two alternative initiatives by timber and agricultural interests and Proposition 130, a parallel forest protection measure. Penny-a-drink and nickel-a-drink alcohol tax increases, a statewide sales tax hike for anti-crime programs and 12 of 14 statewide bond issues were defeated by voters in the first massive rejection of statewide bonds in California history. Santa Clara County voters rejected a proposal to raise utility taxes to finance a stadium to lure baseball's San Francisco Giants. Altogether, 22 of the 28 statewide propositions were turned down. Of all of the high-profile statewide initiatives, the only one that passed, Proposition 140, had a strong negative message to politicians of both parties. Proposition 140 will force every current member of the state Legislature out of office by either 1996 or 1998, eliminate legislative pensions and slash the Legislature's budget and staff by about 40 percent. For the 57-year-old Wilson, who unsuccessfully sought the governor's office twice before, in 1978 and again in 1982, before switching to a successful race for the U.S. Senate, his victory is not without some dark political clouds. Wilson faces an estimated deficit of $500 million to $2 billion in the state budget he must submit five days after his Jan. 7 inauguration. And he faces a Legislature in which leaders of both parties fought the term limits measure which Wilson endorsed. As close as the governor's race was, the race between Democrat Arlo Smith and Republican Dan Lungren for attorney general was tighter. The winner may not be known for another week. With 99 percent of the vote counted, Smith led Lungren 47 percent to 46 percent. Election officials said as many as 500,000 absentee ballots, which traditionally favor Republicans, remained to be counted. Controller Gray Davis and Secretary of State March Fong Eu, both Democrats, were also re-elected. Davis defeated Eu's Republican son, Matt Fong, for controller. Democratic challenger Kathleen Brown, the daughter of former Gov. Pat Brown and sister of former Gov. Jerry Brown, defeated Republican incumbent Thomas Hayes for treasurer. Although Democrats won the lion's share of California races Tuesday, Wilson's victory as governor gives Republicans hope for some gains in 1992, since he will hold veto power over the new districts which must be drawn next year to reflect population shifts in this year's federal census. California's congressional delegation will increase from the current 45 to 52 or more seats in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett To Leave Drug Czar Job This Month, White House Confirms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf bgng, `Dogoloff said,' to FIX to 20 months in office, sted 18
DOC.TEXT: William J. Bennett is resigning as the first director of the Office of National Drug Control Strategy after leading what the White House called ``a turnaround'' in the battle against the drug scourge. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush will formally accept Bennett's resignation in a ceremony at the White House on Thursday. Fitzwater denied that the resignation was prompted by threats, saying that Bennett ``has lived with threats of a kind ever since day one of the job.'' A successor for the job has not been named, the spokesman said. Bennett leaves office only two weeks after another senior administration official, Secretary of Labor Elizabeth Dole, became the first member of Bush's cabinet to resign. Bennett, a former secretary of education, became director the nation's anti-drug efforts at the beginning of the Bush administration. He helped to coordinate some 27 departments and agencies involved in the drug war. ``The president feels that Bill Bennett has provided extraordinary leadership and service to the country during his tenure as drug czar,'' said Fitzwater. ``Two years ago this country viewed this problem as impossible to deal with and with no end in sight,'' the spokesman said. ``Today there has been a turnaround. There is strong bipartisan support in the Congress for drug programs and there is growing evidence that society is beginning to turn away from the drug scourge.'' However, leading House Democrat John Conyers, Jr. of Michigan said Bennett ``was the personification of a drug strategy of the last 10 years that failed.'' Conyers, chairman of the House Government Operations Committee that created the drug office, said Bennett's resignation ``provides the opportunity for someone without Bennett's partisan politicizing, more sensitive to the problems of the chronically addicted, minorities, and the poor in urban areas, and cognizant of the need for economic rather than military foreign drug assistance.'' An administration official who ask not to be identified said that Bennett feels he ``has done all that he told the president he would get done. He feels he's done what he came to do in the job and it was time to get on with his life.'' Lee I. Dogoloff, executive director of the non-governmental American Council for Drug Education, said that Bennett's plans to leave ``have been rumored for some time'' among groups in America's war on drugs. ``It's not surprising,'' said Dogoloff. ``I talked to him several months ago and he said then that he had not taken a lifetime assignment.'' Dogoloff said that many in the field give Bennett high marks for accomplishment during the 20 months since he was confirmed as the nation's first drug czar. The position was created in the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988. ``He can feel good that the numbers are turning around in the drug war,'' said Dogoloff. ``We haven't solved the problem, by any means, but the data shows it is getting better.'' Recent reports show that the number of patients treated for drug overdose in the nation's hospitals has gone down and that there is a reduction in the purity of cocaine available on the streets. Dogoloff said that professionals regard these as important signs that the drug problem ``is trending downward.'' Threats against Bennett have intensified in recent days, but an official said they have always been there. ``There was a nut who called in, and there were bomb threats when he was in Alaska,'' he said. ``They did beef up security some.'' Bennett campaigned in Alaska for a law that would make illegal the possession of small amounts of marijuana. ``I don't think these threats influenced his decision to leave. He's tough as nails. But he does have a family,'' said the official. ``Anybody who has that job is a target,'' said Dogoloff. Bennett is married and has two small children. Published reports have suggested that Bennett's replacement may be former District of Columbia superior court judge Reggie Walton, who is now associate drug control director for state and local affairs in Bennett's office. The Washington Times said former D.C. police chief Maurice Turner, defeated Tuesday in a bid for Washington mayor, is also a possible candidate for the job.

DOC.HEAD: Burned Studio Lot Held Some of Hollywood's Most Famous Sets
With AM-Universal Fire
DOC.TEXT: An arsonist visited Hollywood's biggest fantasy factory with a dose of reality, a backlot inferno that destroyed some of Universal Studio's historic sets. Tuesday night's fire destroyed New York Street, where parts of ``The Sting'' were filmed, and the ``Dick Tracy'' facades. Brownstone Street and Courthouse Square, where Michael J. Fox rode his jet-powered skateboard in ``Back to the Future Part II,'' was damaged. Surviving tour attractions included the simulated earthquake ride, the shark-snapping Jaws exhibit, the flash flood area, the parting of the Red Sea, the ice tunnel, the ``Psycho'' house and Bates Motel. Also untouched by flame were such famous television and movie locations as Colonial Street, where Beaver Cleaver and Marcus Welby lived, the fictional town of Amity and the area where ``Murder, She Wrote'' is filmed, the Six Points, Texas, Old West section and Little Europe, where the 1930s film ``Frankenstein'' was filmed. Warner Bros., Paramount and Goldwyn have suffered devastating fires over the years, and Universal was equally vulnerable. Film studios, with their wooden sets baked dry by the sun, are a firefighter's nightmare. Fortunately, firefighters were able to save all but four acres of the 420-acre complex. Universal has operated continuously from its opening on March 15, 1915, pouring forth entertainment that ranged from two-reel Westerns to ``E.T. The Extra-Terrestrial,'' the biggest mneymaking film in history. The studio also has produced thousands of television shows, from ``Leave It to Beaver'' to ``Murder, She Wrote.'' From its earliest years, Universal profited by showing tourists how movies are made. Founder Carl Laemmle charged 50 cents for tourists to stand on a platform and watch silent movies being made. Millions each year now pay $22 ($16.50 for children) to experience the Universal Studios Tour. A German immigrant, Laemmle opened his studio on 230 acres of mountainside ranch five miles north of Hollywood, persuading the city of Los Angeles to let him call it Universal City. The hillsides were ideal for Westerns, and there was ample space to build sets for spectacles such as ``The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' and ``The Phantom of the Opera.'' The studio grew, but Laemmle was never able to match the class products of MGM, Paramount, Fox and Warner Bros. The company stumbled along, saved from bankruptcy by Deanna Durbin in the '30s and Abbott and Costello in the '40s. After MCA, a former talent agency, acquired Universal in 1962, the studio's rickety bungalows were bulldozed, giving way to a tall glass building known as the Black Tower. Sound stages were modernized and attractions built to enhance the studio tour. Two hotels, an amphitheater, a multi-screen movie theater complex and restaurants now stand atop the summit of the studio. Universal television has long been a steady moneymaker. The film division has had ups and downs, but periodically produces block busters like ``E.T.'' ``Jaws,'' ``Back to the Future,'' ``The Sting,'' ``Animal House,'' ``On Golden Pond,'' ``Smokey and the Bandit'' and ``Twins.'' Universal has remained the most picturesque of all studios with its sprawl of sets, ranging from the big city streets used for ``Dick Tracy,'' the town square of ``Back to the Future,'' the Bates Motel of ``Psycho,'' plus waterfalls, lagoons, western towns and cowboy trails.

DOC.HEAD: New Prime Minister Lifts Pakistan's State of Emergency
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif lifted Pakistan's 3-month-old state of emergency on Wednesday, his first day on the job. The emergency, which gave the army sweeping powers to suspend individual rights to maintain law and order, was imposed on Aug. 6 - hours after Benazir Bhutto's government was dismissed for alleged corruption. In a speech broadcast on state television and radio, Sharif said he wanted the new government headed by his right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance to begin in ``an open atmosphere of human freedom.'' ``Democracy and fundamental rights are synonymous. There is no justification for continuing the emergency during the tenure of an elected government coming to power with the support of the masses,'' Sharif said. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan declared the emergency shortly after ejecting Ms. Bhutto's government on charges of corruption, incompetence and abuse of power. He cited internal and external threats. The emergency would have expired in another month. Sharif, a wealthy 41-year-old industrialist, was a protege of Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, who ruled Pakistan for 11 years until his death in a still unexplained plane crash in August 1988. As chief minister of eastern Punjab, the powerhouse of Pakistani politics, Sharif was Ms. Bhutto's chief rival during her 20 months in power. He orchestrated the alliance's overwhelming victory over Ms. Bhutto and her populist Pakistan People's Party in the Oct. 24 parliamentary elections. Sharif was elected prime minister on Tuesday, commanding two-thirds of the 217-member National Assembly, or the lawmaking lower house of Parliament. He was sworn in later that day as the head of Pakistan's fifth freely elected government in 43 years. With the transfer of power completed, Sharif said the emergency was no longer necessary. ``It does not behoove an elected prime minister to depend on the crutches of extraordinary laws to maintain law and order in the country,'' he said in the speech, delivered in the Urdu language.

DOC.HEAD: Dubcek Says He Feels `No Resentment' Against Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Alexander Dubcek, deposed as Czechoslovakia's Communist Party leader in the 1968 Soviet invasion, said Wednesday he felt no anger against the current Kremlin leadership. ``My presence here as well as the changes that take place in Czechoslovakia are ... due to the changes in the Soviet Union,'' said the 68-year-old Dubcek, who became the Czechoslovak parliament speaker after last November's ouster of the nation's Communist government. The invasion by Soviet troops and other Warsaw Pact soldiers ended Dubcek's careful attempt at democratization known as the ``Prague spring.'' He was expelled from the Communist Party and eventually found a job as a mechanic with a state-owned forestry firm. ``I don't feel any personal resentment,'' he said, citing Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's reform efforts. ``The Soviet Union is no threat. ... We should focus on what we have in common and not on what divides us,'' he said. Dubcek, who was invited to the Netherlands by Dutch Parliament, will be meeting with Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers and Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek on Thursday. Czechoslovakia is especially interested in Dutch electronics and pollution control expertise, Dubcek said. Like many other Eastern European countries, Czechoslovakia struggles with environmental problems linked to antiquated industry.

DOC.HEAD: Winter-Like Weather in West, Record Cold on Plains
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell across the West and around parts of the Great Lakes on Wednesday, and temperatures fell to record lows on the central and western Plains. At midday, snow showers extended across southeastern Utah, southern and central Colorado, the western Texas Panhandle, northwestern Montana, the Idaho Panhandle and west-central Oregon. Four inches of snow fell at Alamosa, Colo., during the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST. Six inches of new snow covered the ground at Monticello, Utah, at daybreak. In eastern Arizona, Fort Defiance on the Navajo reservation collected 6 inches of snow by midday, and in the White Mountains 4 inches fell at Pinetop and 2 inches collected at Show Low. Heavy snow and storm warnings and watches were issued for parts of Colorado and New Mexico. Around the area of snow, a thundershower developed over southeastern Arizona, rain fell over the northern Pacific Coast and over west-central and southwestern Texas, and freezing rain fell over northwestern Texas and southeastern New Mexico. During the night, wind gusted to 62 mph near Albuquerque, N.M. Snow also fell over Upper Michigan, north-central New York state and north-central Pennsylvania. Rain reached from southern New York state across northern Ohio and southeastern Lower Michigan. Wednesday's record lows on the Plains and surrounding areas were 1 at Casper, Wyo.; 5 at Cheyenne, Wyo.; 15 at Colorado Springs, Colo.; 9 at Grand Island, Neb; 4 at Norfolk, Neb.; 3 at North Platte, Neb.; 10 at Omaha, Neb.; 2 at Scottsbluff, Neb.; and 8 at Sioux City, Iowa. Record lows elsewhere were 18 at Klamath Falls, Ore., and 4 at Winnemucca, Nev. In Alaska, wind gusted to 63 at Kodiak during the morning and to 75 the night before. Wind was expected to gust to 65 mph at Valdez and in nearby areas, dropping the wind chill index to 25 degrees below zero. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 17 below zero at West Yellowstone, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 8 at Lander, Wyo., to 88 at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Indictment Sought for Alleged Japanese Terrorists in USO Bombing
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor on Wednesday sought the indictment of two alleged Japanese terrorists for the bombing of a USO club in 1988 that killed an American servicewoman and four others, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. Assistant Prosecutor Alfonso Barbarano requested the indictment of Junzo Okudaira, 43, and Fusako Shigenobu, 45, reputed members of the Japanese Red Army, the dispatch said. The two have been fugitives for years. The U.S. servicewoman and four Italians were killed and 15 people were wounded when a car bomb blew up in front of the USO Club in Naples on April 14, 1988. Investigators believe Okudaira has been involved in other terror attacks, including one on the U.S. Embassy in Rome in 1987 that did not injure anyone. Shigenobu has been identified as the leader of the Japanese Red Army, which is linked with terrorist groups in Lebanon. The Naples bombing coincided with the second anniversary of the U.S. bombing of Libya. That attack was in retaliation for what the U.S. government called Libyan support of terrorism.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Minister Says Thatcher Unbalanced, May Be Possessed
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's information minister, reacting to a saber-rattling speech Wednesday by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, said she was mentally unbalanced and possessed by the devil. In a statement carried by the official Iraqi News Agency, Minister Latif Nassayif Jassim said Mrs. Thatcher's statements in general on the gulf crisis were hysterical in tone and did not befit the office of prime minister. Her speeches, ``filled with rancor and hatred toward the Iraqi people, and her continued calls for beating the drums of war unequivocally show beyond a shadow of a doubt that this woman ... has lost her mental balance,'' the statement said. Jassim said the only explanation for a woman advocating war was that ``the devil has found a comfortable dwelling within her mind and conscience.'' The Iraqi minister said his country viewed Mrs. Thatcher's statements with ``disdain and indifference,'' and that her popularity in Britain would not be boosted by fighting or calling for war. In Parliament on Wednesday, Thatcher warned Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that he will face a military strike if he does not withdraw his troops from Kuwait. ``The implacable message of this House must be: Either he gets out of Kuwait soon or we and our allies will remove him by force and he will go down to defeat with all the consequences,'' she said. ``He has been warned.'' Britain has about 10,000 troops with 120 tanks in Saudi Arabia, as well as 10 warships enforcing the U.N. trade embargo imposed on Iraq after it seized Kuwait on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Sotheby's Auction Deflates Art Price Balloon
DOC.TEXT: A Sotheby's auction of contemporary art brought in $19.9 million, about half the amount expected in an end to a recent price explosion, the auction house said. Sotheby's had expected the Tuesday sale to bring $39.6 million to $52 million. ``The contemporary art market over the last few years has been a price explosion, and what we have seen tonight is a return to price levels of about November 1988,'' said Diana Phillips, a spokeswoman for Sotheby's. The sale of 34 works of contemporary art brought prices back to earth, Phillips said. Forty three other pieces did not draw minimum bids and were not sold. The highlight of the auction was a 1961 work by American artist Robert Rauschenberg, ``Third Time Painting.'' It fetched $3.08 million from a private European collector, said Phillips. The estimate on the Rauschenberg was revised downward Monday, from $4-$5 million to $3-$4 million. The Rauschenberg, showing a clock, a chain, a shirt and a broken bottle neck, is combines oil, paper, fabric, wood, metal and glass. The sale of other works also reflected the soft market, pulling down prices that increased about 20 times since 1984, most dramatically in the past two years, Phillips said. The second highest price of the evening - $2.6 million - came for French painter Jean Dubuffet's ``Maison Sondee,'' a 1961 Paris scene. The oil on canvas was bought by a Chicago dealer. The third highest priced work, auctioned for $2.3 million, was another Dubuffet, ``Vaches Au Pre.'' The oil on canvas painted in 1954 depicts one of Dubuffet's favorite subjects, cows. The American painter Cy Twombly's 1967 oil on blackboard, ``Untitled,'' sold for $1.9 million. ``Most of the sale was bought by private collectors who are serious and committed,'' Phillips said. ``The speculators who have been present during the price explosion were completely absent from tonight's activity.'' ``Many of the lots that did not sell were by artists whose works have gained quickly in value over the last few years,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush May Meet With Gorbachev in Paris This Month
DOC.TEXT: President Bush probably will meet with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Paris this month, the White House said Wednesday. The meeting would come during a five-nation trip that also will mark the first visit to Czechoslovakia by an American president. It would be Bush's fourth summit with Gorbachev, following talks in Malta, Washington and Helsinki. While no date has been set for a meeting with Gorbachev, Bush will be in Paris from Nov. 18 until Nov. 21, when he flies to the Middle East to visit U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia and confer with leaders there and in Egypt. In Paris, Bush will attend the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and sign a treaty to cut non-nuclear forces in Europe. Bush will leave Washington Nov. 16, flying overnight to Prague and arriving there early the next day. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the president would express strong support for the democratic revolution in Czechoslovakia and throughout Eastern Europe and deliver a major speech about the democracy movement. Bush also will make brief remarks in Wenceslas Square, where hundreds of thousands of people gathered last November to begin the so-called Velvet Revolution, which led to the overthrow of the country's hardline communist rulers. Fitzwater noted that Czechoslovakia is suffering economic problems compounded by a reduction in Soviet energy deliveries and the loss of Iraqi oil. ``We're working through various international financial organizations to help Czechoslovakia bridge this energy gap and I'm sure this will be part of the discussion,'' Fitzwater said. En route to Paris on Nov. 18, Bush will stop in Germany for several hours to visit the city of Speyer and to visit with Chancellor Helmut Kohl at his home in suburban Oggersheim.

DOC.HEAD: Many More Reserve Combat Forces Likely to be Sent to Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Many hundreds more combat troops from the Marine Corps Reserve are likely to be ordered to active duty for Operation Desert Shield, an official said Wednesday. The Marines on Tuesday said 824 reservists, including 633 combat specialists, were being activated to become part of a specially tailored 5th Marine Expeditionary Brigade that is undergoing desert warfare training in California. Those were the first combat reserve forces to be put on active duty in the Persian Gulf crisis. Col. Russell Appleton, head of manpower policy and planning at Marine Corps headquarters, said in an interview Wednesday that reserves will be used to help form expeditionary brigades to replace units scheduled to rotate out of the gulf area. The Marines have not said when the first units deployed in Desert Shield will return home, but it appears some may be brought back after serving about six months. Appleton said the call-up of reservists for the 5th Marine Expeditionary Brigade is a model of how Marine combat reserves are expected to be used for Desert Shield. ``You're seeing the tip of that spear'' of reserve deployments, he said, adding that he could not comment on any reserve call-ups beyond those announced Tuesday. ``Fifty-seven percent of our force is overseas,'' he said. ``If you've got to replace that force then the math says there aren't enough active duty units out there to do that,'' and so a sizeable number of reserves will be needed. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has authorized the Marines to call as many as 3,000 reserves to active duty for 90-day periods.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Kills Three Near Unoccupied Militia Office
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded Wednesday near the unoccupied office of a Syrian-backed militia in east Beirut, killing three people and injuring seven, police said. Members of the Syrian Social Nationalist Party left the office only hours before the explosion of more than 100 pounds of dynamite packed into a sedan. The group occupied the office in the predominately Christian sector after the Oct. 13 downfall of rebel Christian Gen. Michel Aoun. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing in the Aukar area. The office belonged to Christian warlord Samir Geagea's militia until Jan. 30, when Aoun's forces ousted Geagea's troops from the Metn mountains. A police spokesman who cannot be named under standing rules identified the victims as the owner of a bakery and his two children. Among the injured were three Lebanese reporters working for the conservative daily Ad-Diyar. The police spokesman said investigators estimated 110 pounds of dynamite was concealed in the trunk of the beige-colored car that carried no plates. He refused to give further details. The office is in the suburban district of Aukar, about six miles northeast of Beirut. The suburb is the site of the closed American Embassy. Syria has about 40,000 troops in Lebanon under an Arab League mandate.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President's Wife to Visit Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle's wife Marilyn will visit the Soviet Union this month to foster better understanding and cooperation between Soviet and American disaster response organizations, it was announced Wednesday. She will help lead a delegation composed of officials from various domestic and international disaster preparedness and relief agencies. The vice president's office said the trip, Nov. 14-20, was the result of an invitation from the Soviet government.

DOC.HEAD: Hrawi Sets 10-Day Deadline to Unite Beirut
DOC.TEXT: President Elias Hrawi's government on Wednesday set a 10-day deadline for Christian and Moslem militias to withdraw from Beirut so that the city can be reunited as a demilitarized zone. Unifying the war-battered capital, divided into Christian and Moslem sectors since April 1975, is a key element in an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end Lebanon's protracted civil war. A statement issued after a two-hour Cabinet meeting said the final stage of creating a demilitarized ``Greater Beirut'' will begin on Saturday and is scheduled for completion Nov.19. The major militias on both sides agreed to withdraw their fighters and weapons from the city after the Syrian Army crushed Christian Gen. Michel Aoun on Oct. 13, removing the main obstacle to the peace plan. But Wednesday's statement was the first time the government has set a deadline for the reunification process that began immediately after Aoun was defeated in a fierce eight-hour battle that left at least 550 people dead. In the last few weeks, much of the Green Line that divided the capital has been dismantled and there are no longer any restrictions on travel between the Christian eastern sector and the Moslem west side. Wednesday's statement did not specify the exact boundaries of ``Greater Beirut.'' But earlier statements by government officials said it would extend from the Dog River north of Beirut to the Damour River south of the city, and six to nine miles inland from the Mediterranean. The government did not say what would happen if its deadline was not met. But the Syrians, the main powerbrokers in Lebanon, have 40,000 troops in the country and have pledged Hrawi all the backing he needs to implement the peace plan. Hrawi is trying to rebuild the Lebanese Army, for years fractured along sectarian lines. At present, military sources said he has an effective combat force of only about 9,000 Moslem troops under his army commander, Gen. Emile Lahoud. Until he can reunify the army, which had a nominal overall strenth of about 42,000, Hrawi will be dependent on the Syrians for his military muscle. Although the main militias have gone along with the plan to demilitarize the capital, most are hesitant about handing over their weapons and disbanding so state authority can be extended over more of the country. The main militias are the right-wing Christian Lebanese Forces, a pro-Syrian splinter faction called the Lebanese Forces-Executive Authority, the pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem Hezbollah or Party of God, the rival Syrian-backed Shiite Amal movement and the Druse Moslem Progressive Socialist Party. Wednesday's statement said: ``Any attempt to obstruct or stall the process of creating Greater Beirut will be dealt with severely. There shall be no tolerance.'' It said Justice Minister Edmond Rizk had been authorized to take legal procedures to confiscate $116 million and several million French francs in local and foreign bank accounts held by Aoun and his aides. Aoun took refuge at the French Embassy on Oct. 13 and France has granted him asylum. But the government has said he will not be allowed to leave before he faces trial on a variety of charges, including the alleged theft of $75 million of state funds.

DOC.HEAD: Supporter Makes Appeal on Behalf of Ex-Guatemalan Dictator
DOC.TEXT:
A supporter of retired Gen. Efrain Rios Montt has lodged a last-ditch appeal to block Sunday's presidential election because the former dictator is barred from running, an official said Wednesday. Rios Montt was banned by the courts because the constitution bars candidates who previously took power by force. The latest appeal is given little chance of success. Prior to the ban, polls showed Rios Montt as the leading candidate for president, winning support among voters tired of corruption and crime. The director-general of voter registration, Felix Castillo Milla, said he has passed the petition for nullification to the Supreme Electoral Tribunal. The tribunal has three days to act on the petition, which was filed by Francisco Fuentes Parra, a legislative candidate who supports Rios Montt. President Vinicio Cerezo, who finishes his five-year term Jan. 14, is the first civilian elected president in 17 years in this country shaken by a leftist guerrilla insurrection for the past three decades. Rios Montt headed a military junta that overthrew President Fernando Romeo Lucas Garcia, an army general elected as president in March 1982. The military forced Rios Montt out of power in August 1983. Rios Montt has accused Cerezo of planning to fix the elections in favor Alfonso Cabrera Hidalgo, the presidential nominee of Cerezo's centrist Christian Democrats.
Rios Montt claims he was robbed of victory when he ran for president on the Christian Democratic ticket in 1974, with the election fixed to put conservative Gen. Eugenio Kjell Laugerud in power. The former dictator has now broken with the Christian Democrats. He has been trying to run at the head of a ticket by a three-party conservative coalition.

DOC.HEAD: Engler Says Narrow Win Still a Mandate
DOC.TEXT: Gov.-elect John Engler said Wednesday that he defeated Democratic incumbent James Blanchard because Michigan voters wanted property tax cuts and better schools. ``That's what winning is all about. Winning is the mandate,'' Engler said of his 19,134-vote upset of Blanchard. ``The taxpayers have spoken out. They want more of a tax break and parents want better schools for their kids.'' The victory made Engler, the state Senate majority leader, the first challenger in 28 years to bounce out an incumbent Michigan governor. It returned the governor's office to GOP hands after Blanchard's two terms of Democratic rule. Final unofficial returns showed Engler with 1,279,745 votes to 1,260,611 for Blanchard. Blanchard delayed his concession until 19 hours after the polls closed, saying he wanted to double-check the vote tallies. But at a brief appearance at the Capitol in Lansing, Blanchard said it appeared Engler's slim margin would hold up. He offered his congratulations and said he accepted the voters' decision. ``The job of being governor is a great challenge, a great responsiblity. anything I can do to make the transition smoother I will do,'' Blanchard said. The final margin was the smallest since the 8,618 margin of the 1952 gubernatorial contest. In the Senate race, with 99 percent of the precincts reporting, Democratic incumbent Carl Levin defeated Republican challenger Bill Schuette by a 58-to-42 percent margin.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Military Helicopter Disappears in Sea Off Corinth
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with police saying wreckage found, no survivors spotted, Pentagon statement. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Army transport helicopter carrying three crewmen crashed Wednesday night in the sea between Corinth and Athens, officials said. No survivors were found. A spokesman for the Athens Region Control Center that monitors Greek air traffic said the UH-1 Huey helicopter vanished from radar screens at 6:20 p.m. in the Saronic Gulf near Corinth, about 47 miles west of Athens. An officer of the Isthmia port police said rescue vessels found wreckage near the islet of Evreos in the Saronic Gulf. ``They found fragments, but there are no signs of survivors,'' he said by telephone, speaking on condition of anonymity. The helicopter was based at Hellenikon U.S. Air Force base near Athens, the traffic control spokesman said, also speaking on condition of anonymity. Two Army warrant officers and a sergeant were on board the aircraft, the Pentagon in Washington said. The copter was enroute to Athens from Spain when it crashed, the Pentagon said. The semi-official Athens News Agency, however, quoted unnamed Greek military sources as saying the helicopter was flying in from Italy when a malfunction forced it to land at the island of Othoni, just north of Corfu. The helicopter's mechanic repaired the malfunction and the helicopter refueled at Corfu before departing for Athens, military sources said.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: renovations approved.
DOC.TEXT: Senate: Incumbent Claiborne Pell, D, defeated U.S. Rep. Cladine Schneider, R. House: New delegation 1 D, 1 R; old delegation 2 R. Legislature: New state Senate, trend, 45 D, 5 R; new state House, trend, 87 D, 13 R; old state Senate 41 D, 9 R; old state House, 84 D, 16 R. Propositions: off-track betting theater in Pawtucket defeated; harness-racing track in Burrillville defeated; bond for roads and bridges approved.

Senate: Incumbent Strom Thurmond, R, defeated retired CIA official Robert Cunningham, D. Governor: Incumbent Carroll Campbell, R, defeated state Sen. Theo Mitchell, D. House: New delegation 4 D, 2 R; old delegation 4 D, 2 R. Legislature: New state Senate 34 D, 11 R (one seat vacant); new state House 78 D, 41 R, 1 independent (two seats vacant, two undecided); old state Senate, 34 D, 12 R; old state House, 82 D, 42 R.

House: For the one at-large seat, incumbent Tim Johnson, D, defeated Don Frankenfeld, R. Legislature: New state Senate 18 R, 17 D; new state House 46 R, 24 D; old state Senate 20 R, 15 D; old state House 46 R, 24 D. Propositions: Legislative approval for large-scale dump permits approved; mining restrictions defeated.

DOC.HEAD: Late Polls, Congressional Adjournment Helped Helms, GOP Says
DOC.TEXT: Aides to Sen. Jesse Helms said Wednesday that the incumbent's victory showed that he represents North Carolina's conservative values. For his part, defeated Democrat Harvey Gantt said he may have underestimated the impact race would have in the election. ``I think that it just shows ... that the people in this state are traditional conservatives and that Sen. Helms represents their traditional family values,'' said Helms' spokeswoman Beth Burrus. ``I think with the strong voter turnout, you can definitely say that the people in this state want Sen. Helms representing them. ``It was a classic campaign between a conservative and a liberal. The turnout (which topped 60 percent) gave you a true picture of what North Carolina wanted.'' Gantt, who's black and a former Charlotte mayor, said he knew that race would be a factor but did not realize it would be such a key factor. ``We have always factored in the fact that race would probably play a role in this election ... we obviously may have miscalculated on how much it would play a role,'' Gantt said at a news conference in Charlotte. He said he had pledged not to raise race as an issue. ``And we didn't. Sen. Helms did,'' he said. State Republican Party Chairman Jack Hawke said late polls and the late adjournment of Congress that gave Helms only eight days of full-time campaignin helped fire up the Helms forces. ``All we heard out in our areas was that Helms couldn't be beat,'' Hawke said. ``People would want to know why we were so worried because Helms was going to win. ``But then there was that late poll that showed Helms behind by 8 percent, and all of a sudden people were calling us asking what they could do,'' Hawke said. ``And just about the time people were starting to get interested, Helms came back from Washington and got our people stirred up.'' State Democratic Party Chairman Lawrence Davis said the Gantt campaign, despite the loss, had helped pull together factions within the party. ``I think we're more unified today than we've been in a long while,'' Davis said. ``People are disappointed, to be sure, but you don't have the bickering we had after 1988 when groups were pointing fingers at each other.'' Gantt's 48 percent share of the vote was the same as former Gov. Jim Hunt, who lost to Helms in 1984. On Tuesday, Helms garnered 1,080,208 votes to 974,701 for Gantt. In the end, Hawke said, voters saw the Senate race in conservative and liberal terms. ``I think if Gantt had been a little more of a moderate, Helms would have been in real trouble,'' Hawke said. ``But the choice was between two people who were at opposite ends of the spectrum.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Says West's Stance in Gulf is Hypocritical
DOC.TEXT: Black nationalist Nelson Mandela on Wednesday accused the West of hypocrisy and prejudice in responding to Kuwait's occupation, saying Iraq is being singled out because its people are ``brown-skinned.'' Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, said Western governments had made no objections when U.S. forces invaded Grenada or Panama and had tolerated the Israeli occupation of Arab territory. ``But now, the whole of the West is screaming and sending armies'' because of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Mandela said. He emphasized that he did not condone Iraq's actions and expressed hope the confrontation could be solved peacefully. Mandela, however, suggested that Iraq was being treated differently because its people were ``brown-skinned.'' During his international tours to raise support for his organization, Mandela has generally avoided comments apt to stir controversy on matters unrelated to his anti-apartheid struggle. However, while in the United States earlier this year, he praised Cuban leader Fidel Castro for his support and expressed approval for Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The comments upset many Americans. In Paris on Wednesday, Mandela also said he had received a positive response from President Francois Mitterrand to his request that France help finance housing, jobs and education for ANC members and their families as they resume their lives in South Africa after exile or imprisonment. The ANC is the leading South African group opposing the white-led government of that country. Mandela conferred for 40 minutes with Mitterrand at the close of a three-week trip to Asia and Europe. Speaking to reporters after the talks, he declined to single out France for criticism in regard to the Persian Gulf crisis. But he said: ``We reject the hypocrisy of the West.'' France has deployed 13,000 soldiers in the Persian Gulf region as part of the multinational force. More than 25 countries, including the United States, have sent troops there to counter Iraq.
