Mandela said he is not worried that South Africa might be pushed out of the world spotlight because of the crisis and the gradual dismantling of apartheid, South African's system of racial separation. He said the leaders he met during his trip responded positively to his appeal for aid, although he declined to give details. He also declined to comment on the government's handling of the criminal case against his wife, Winnie. She faces charges in connection with the abduction and killing of a teen-age black activist. ``I am convinced of my wife's innocence, and I welcome the charges,'' Mandela said. ``For the first time, she will have a chance to defend herself.'' Mandela, freed in February after 27 years in prison, reiterated his position that economic sanctions against South Africa should remain in effect, despite the numerous reforms by President F.W. de Klerk. Mandela said the international sanctions should end only when the last vestiges of apartheid are gone and the black majority has full voting rights. The ANC and other opposition groups are now negotiating with the government to give majority blacks a say in the country's political system.

DOC.HEAD: Rioters Clash With Police, Beat Arabs As Kahane Buried
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with police saying 13 rioters arrested, statement by Shamir, edits to conform. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JRL7
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of supporters of slain Rabbi Meir Kahane rampaged through Jerusalem on Wednesday, shouting ``Death to Arabs!'' as the anti-Arab crusader was buried. Kahane, 58, was shot to death Monday by an Arab-American in New York. The rioters attacked Arabs, smashed shop windows and clashed with police after breaking away from a funeral procession of thousands of Israelis, some of whom toted assault guns. Police reported four Palestinians and two policemen were injured, and hospital officials said two of the Arab victims were stabbed. Israel radio said many more Arabs were injured in beatings. Jerusalem police said they arrested 13 rioters. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir appealed for restraint, saying in a statement on Israel radio that ``those harming security and public order first of all harm Israel and assist our enemies.'' Near the Givat Shaul cemetery where Kahane was buried, a civilian and two soldiers tried to help an Arab who lay unconscious. A crowd of Kahane supporters shouted: ``He's dead, he's dead, the dirty Arab is dead!'' As the stricken man showed signs of life, the crowd tried to hold back an ambulance. Police forced them back. While Israeli politicians of every stripe condemned Kahane's murder, a debate in Parliament still brought out mixed emotions over the Brooklyn-born rabbi who espoused violence and the mass expulsion of Arabs from territories ruled by Israel. The establishment shunned him for his extreme anti-Arab views, but a chief rabbi and two Cabinet ministers came to the funeral. The Parliament that had outlawed him as a racist stood in silence for him on Tuesday. Both officials and newspaper editorials warned Kahane's murder could worsen violence between Jews and Arabs. ``This is the danger engulfing us now - that Kahane's murder will spark a dizzying cycle of further murders,'' the daily Yedioth Ahronoth wrote. ``The fear is that this act of murder will intensify the racist tendencies of our two people,'' Police Minister Roni Milo said. But he added a warning: ``The state of Israel, as a democratic state, will defend its citizens and will cut off the hand of those who wish them ill.'' Police brought in hundreds of reinforcements to prevent violence, but supporters of Kahane's anti-Arab Kach faction ran though the streets attacking Palestinian passers-by and shops employing Arab workers. The angry Kach followers also stoned an Israeli television crew, beat the reporter with the crew, and tried to invade Israel TV headquarters. Hadassah Hospital spokeswoman Ruth Mekel said one policeman was hit on the head with a stone and the other was knocked off his horse. One Arab ran through a shopping mall chased by several Kach loyalists who shouted ``Death to terrorists!'' A shopkeeper gave him refuge and police rescued him. Kahane, who led the militant Jewish Defense League in New York, immigrated to Israel in 1971 and later founded Kach to spread his call for expelling all 2.5 million Palestinians from Israel and the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. He openly encouraged his supporters to retaliate for attacks on Jews by assaulting Arabs at random. Police said more than 15,000 Israelis took part in the procession or the funeral at a yeshiva, or Jewish seminary, run by the Kach faction. Men in the black hats of Orthodox Jews mixed with Kach men wearing the movement's yellow T-shirt. Frenzied followers waited outside the yeshiva, shouting ``Meir, Meir!'' as the rabbi's coffin arrived after a flight from New York. Thousands of American Jews attended a memorial to Kahane on Tuesday in New York. At the Jerusalem funeral, Kach activist Yekutiel Ben-Yaakov echoed the vow of revenge voiced by Kahane's supporters since his death. ``We will let our friend the submachine gun talk for us. We will let our friend the knife talk for us,'' Ben-Yaakov told the thousands jammed in the streets around the yeshiva. The procession took three hours to wind along a major boulevard to the municipal cemetery. Marchers carried blue-and-white Israeli flags and yellow banners emblazoned with the Kach symbol of a clenched fist set in the Jewish Star of David. Some supporters waved signs saying ``Transfer,'' a euphemism for Kahane's call to expel the Palestinians. Science Minister Yuval Neeman and Absorption Minister Rabbi Yitzhak Peretz came to the funeral, along with Israel's chief Sephardic rabbi, Mordechai Eliahu. In his eulogy, Eliahu appealed to the mourners to leave vengeance to God. Neeman, an ultra-rightist, was turned away amid shouts of ``leftist, leftist!'' He told Israel's army radio he had come to represent Shamir's government. ``I meant to eulogize Rabbi Meir Kahane, may God avenge his blood,'' Neeman said, using a traditional Jewish phrase in cases of violent death. In Parliament, conservative lawmaker Hanan Porat of the National Religious Party recalled that it was traditional to refer to the dead as holy. ``All the same,'' he added, ``I confess that it is not easy for me to talk about Rabbi Meir Kahane, of blessed memory, as holy. That's not easy for me.''

DOC.HEAD: Goddard, Symington Battle For Governorship
DOC.TEXT: Republican Fife Symington nursed a tiny lead over Democrat Terry Goddard early today in a nip-and-tuck race for governor but the margin was so thin that a recount - and a runoff - are likely. Symington hoped for an outright victory. ``Frankly, I think we're going to do it but it's not sewed up right now,'' he told supporters at 3:30 a.m. ``I think it would be in everyone's best interest if we went to bed.'' Goddard gave his troops a similar message. With all but six of 1,958 precincts reporting, Symington led Goddard by 3,589 votes out of more than 1.03 million counted. More than 10,000 votes went to seven write-in candidates, including Max Hawkins, a former aide to impeached Gov. Evan Mecham aide. Hawkins entered the race after the primary, saying he wanted to offer an anti-abortion alternative. Some of the uncounted precincts were from rural counties where Goddard was running ahead of Symington. And an estimated 300 ballots were reported missing from a Phoenix precinct considered Goddard territory. Hundreds or thousands of absentee ballots remained to be counted. Even if Symington's lead held up, it appeared to be too little to forestall a runoff mandated by the state constitution for elections in which no candidate gets an absolute majority. Goddard, a former Phoenix mayor, had been heavily. But Symington, a millionaire Phoenix developer, spent almost twice as much as Goddard. And the state has 91,000 more registered Republicans than Democrats. The Legislature has never passed laws to implement a runoff and elections officials estimate it could take months before one could be held. The state's sitting governor, Rose Mofford, is supposed to leave office in early January, but would likely stay on if a runoff is required. Mofford, who succeeded Meacham after he was impeached. Neither of Arizona's two U.S. senators was up for re-election, and none of the state's congressmen faced more than token opposition. Symington and Goddard, both Harvard graduates from prominent families, shared pro-choice stands on abortion and supported a Martin Luther King state holiday, which voters rejected Tuesday. Symington, 45, complained that Goddard raised city taxes and fees as mayor. Goddard pointed to Symington's directorships of two savings and loans that later failed and suggested in television commercials that Symington's development company was in financial trouble.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Opposition Unites
DOC.TEXT: Several activist groups united Wednesday as a nationwide opposition movement and warned of a possible comeback by former Communist rulers. In a statement covering the front page of the mass-circulation daily Romania Libera, the Civic Alliance said the Communist Party was recovering from last year's revolution that drove it from power. One Alliance source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the coalition intended to begin a nationwide investigation to determine the exact role of former Communists in the governing National Salvation Front. He gave no further details. The Front took power during December's revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. It then won a landslide victory in May elections and controls about two-thirds of the seats in Parliament. Its leader, Ion Iliescu, became Romania's president. Opposition groups have accused Iliescu, a former Ceausescu minister, of maintaining old totalitarian structures under a different name and of secretly holding Communist beliefs. Iliescu has repeatedly denied the charges. Ludovic Tarca of the Timisoara Society, one group in the Alliance, said the new coalition would ``breathe new life into the civil opposition.'' ``We want not power itself, but to keep those in power in check, whatever their party, and correct their mistaken policies,'' Tarca said. Other members said the group might become a political party in the future. The new Civic Alliance includes the intellectual Group for Social Dialogue, the Timisoara Society, the Nov. 15 group from the central city of Brasov and other non-parliamentary groups. Its membership also lists well-known opposition figures, such as Bucharest Student League President Marian Munteanu and former dissident writer Ana Blandiana. The Timisoara Society - named after the Western city where the December revolution began - has demanded that former high-ranking Communists be banned from public office. Union leaders have also mounted a series of strikes in recent months to demand the ouster of former Communists. They say the ex-Communists have retained power in the bureaucracy and impeded reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Recovering Assassination Suspect Followed Confusing Path in Life
With AM-Israel-Kahane, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Conflicting stories emerged Wednesday about El Sayyid Nosair as the alleged assassin of radical Rabbi Meir Kahane began to recuperate from a bullet in the neck. Nosair, whose condition improved from serious to fair Wednesday, was described by many acquaintances as a man who kept to himself. But New York Newsday reported one former employer fired him partly because his efforts to convert fellow workers to Islam interfered with his work. Nosair, 34, of Cliffside Park, N.J., was shot by a U.S. postal police officer after he allegedly killed Kahane, an anti-Arab, ultraright-wing Zionist, Monday night. Nosair was charged with murder, attempted murder, assault, unlawful imprisonment, and criminal possession of a weapon and of a defaced weapon. The murder weapon, a .357 Magnum revolver, had its identification numbers filed off. Newsday cited sources it did not identify as saying Nosair had no arrest record and neither the FBI nor the CIA had heard of him before Kahane was shot. Tuesday, FBI agents and police removed a file cabinet, several boxes and a target drawn on white plasterboard from Nosair's home. Records in this country showed Nosair was born in Port Said, Egypt, on Nov. 16, 1955, and graduated from a college in Cairo, where he studied industrial engineering. However, Gen. Ahmed Zaatar, an assistant to the interior minister of Egypt, said Wednesday that government records in Port Said showed no record of a man born there with that name, or spellings close to it. Immigration records indicate Nosair entered the United States through New York on a visitor's visa July 14, 1981; married a U.S. citizen, Caren Ann Mills, in 1982; became a permanent resident of Pittsburgh in 1983 and became a naturalized citizen in September 1989. The New York Post said Nosair met the woman he married at a Pittsburgh mosque. Newsday said they met while taking night classes at a university there. Nosair's first job in Pittsburgh was as a diamond setter at St. Clair's Jewelers. ``He came here as a very naive, very nice young man from a foreign country,'' said Barbara Ausman, his supervisor. ``And he had a very high opinion of himself.'' His goal, she told Newsday, was to get rich and return to Egypt. Ausman said Nosair had tremendous national pride as an Egyptian and seemed reluctant to adjust to American customs. Ausman said Nosair was fired from the jewelry store in 1983. ``We dismissed him for two reasons: in part because of his lack of ability to develop his skills,'' she said. ``But also because he would consistently try to convert people to his way of religion.'' In 1986, Nosair moved to Jersey City, N.J. Debra Ragab, 39, superintendent of a Jersey City apartment complex where the family had lived, said the murder charge was ``a surprise to us, to everybody,'' including Mrs. Nosair. The Nosairs moved to Cliffside Park about a year ago with their daughter, Nora, 11, and two sons, Abdul Aziz, 7, and Abdul Rahman, 5. Nosair used a relative's New York City address, however, to obtain a city job in April 1988 as a heating and air conditioning repairman.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Gov. Race Headed For Runoff
DOC.TEXT: The political ghost of impeached Gov. Evan Mecham is haunting Arizona politics again, forcing a gubernatorial runoff between Republican Fife Symington and Democrat Terry Goddard. The problem is that no one knows how or when to hold the runoff because the law requiring one doesn't deal with the specifics. As a result, officials say, Gov. Rose Mofford will have to stay on as a caretaker after her term expires in January. Mrs. Mofford, the secretary of state, was elevated to the governor's office when Mecham was impeached and ousted two years ago. She did not seek a term of her own. Mecham lost out in the GOP primary in a comeback bid. Arizona voters also defeated two ballot measures that attempted to create a paid holiday honoring Martin Luther King Jr. In the governor's race, Symington, a millionaire developer, led Goddard, a former Phoenix mayor, by 4,296 votes. With all but one precinct reporting, Symington had 522,320 votes and Goddard had 518,024. But with more than 11,300 write-in votes for seven minor candidates, Symington won't have more than 50 percent of the votes cast, as needed. The requirement, inspired by Mecham's 1986 win in a three-way race and added to the state constitution in 1988, forces a runoff between the two top vote-getters unless on candidate gets an absolute majority. Officials have to resolve about 5,200 questioned ballots and finish tabulating the write-ins before they can issue an official statement, but Assistant Secretary of State Karen Osborne said a runoff is likely. ``The figures all point to that,'' Secretary of State Jim Shumway agreed. Political leaders, meanwhile, huddled over a possible special session to write laws for a runoff. Among the questions is whether an annual January purge of voting roles would disenfranchise would-be voters and whether those who registered too late for Tuesday's election should be allowed to vote in the runoff. There are logistical problems as well. Because of past complaints involving minority voters, changes in Arizona voting laws must be reviewed by the U.S. Justice Department. One of the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday plans went down by a 3-1 margin, as expected. The other, expected to win narrowly, lost by about 11,000 votes. Observers attributed the defeat to the possibility that the National Football League would move the 1993 Super Bowl from Arizona if the measure failed. ``They tried to leverage the public and that just won't work,'' said Phoenix Mayor Paul Johnson.

DOC.HEAD: Former Vermont Gov. Wins Back Job
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Richard Snelling will get the chance to do things his way again when he takes back his old office in January. Despite leaving office while the state faced a $35 million deficit, Snelling campaigned on the theme that his successor, Democratic Gov. Madeleine Kunin, had mismanaged the state's finances. Snelling, a Republican, was governor from 1977-84. With all precincts reporting, Snelling had 109,195 votes, or 52 percent; Democrat Peter Welch, a former state senator, had 97,101 votes, or 46 percent. Kunin did not seek a fourth two-year term. Snelling is assuming the helm of a state struggling with a sagging economy, which he says is in recession. He predicted he will have to work with the Legislature to bail the state out of a pending deficit that could climb higher than $20 million this fiscal year. But he sets about the task armed with a successful business resume. Snelling, 63, was born in Allentown, Pa., one of nine children who learned about politics from their father, a scientist. ``Every major political event during my childhood was debated at the family table,'' Snelling recalled recently. ``Can you imagine nine kiddies around the table with a guy with two (doctorates) at the head of the table saying, `Why did you say that? What's the proof of that?''' He received a degree in government and economics from Harvard University in 1948. After leaving Harvard, Snelling bought a bankrupt Philadelphia seed and garden supply company with his life savings of $10,000. Two years later, the company went bankrupt again. But he went on to make millions after founding Shelburne Industries, a ski equipment and power tool company, in 1958. His children now control the company. That same year he entered the Vermont Legislature, where he served for two more terms in the mid-1970s and rose to become majority leader of the Vermont House. In 1966, Snelling ran for governor against Democrat Philip Hoff and lost by about 21,000 votes. He went on to win the post 10 years later and held onto the job until stepping down in 1984. Snelling returned briefly to the public scene in 1986, running unsuccessfully for the U.S. Senate against Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt. He lost by more than 56,000 votes. Referring to his political losses, Snelling said, ``In both cases, what I told myself was that it would be nice to win, but the civic duty was being the champion of a point of view. When I started running 1{ years ago, it was a similar thing.'' Snelling has said that as governor, he plans to work to create more jobs in the state, revamp education funding to provide poperty tax relief and control state spending.

DOC.HEAD: VRS, Joint Venture on Exit Polls and Projection, Works - With A Hitch
DOC.TEXT: A new joint venture by the four networks for exit polls and projections got its trial by fire on election night and proved again an ancient political adage: You win some, you lose some. ``We made projections in 80 to 85 races last night,'' Warren Mitofsky, executive director of the Voter Research and Surveys project, or VRS, said Wednesday. ``On calls, we were outstanding. I've never made that many close calls in one night. I've never had to,'' said Mitofsky, who headed CBS' election unit for more than 20 years. But a national exit poll, a kind of snapshot of the electorate and its attitudes which other news organizations bought from VRS, wasn't distributed because of technical difficulties. ABC, CBS, NBC and CNN each have paid $3 million for exit polls and projections through 1992 in all Senate, House and governor's races, as well as some state and local races of national interest. Tuesday night, VRS called 67 Senate and governor's races. CNN, which previously had never had fast access to exit poll results, ``was pleased with the output of VRS in making state race calls and, by and large, with the state race analysis,'' said Tom Hannon, CNN's elections unit chief and a board member of VRS. The national exit poll of voter attitudes, a component of the House races' exit poll, wasn't finished in time for Wednesday's editions of The New York Times, The Washington Post and USA Today, the only newspapers which bought it. There were 14 newspaper among about 60 non-member news organizations which bought state poll results from VRS, the cooperative said. Mitofsky said the national poll delay stemmed from the ``weighting'' of data to reflect national proportions. ``In other words,'' Mitofsky said, ``if the Northeast is a fourth of the nation, you want the Northeast to be a fourth of the poll. And you can follow that down to the precinct level. ``In applying that weighting, we ran into some computer programmng errors,'' he said. ``The poll could have been used without weights at all, but we didn't think that was the best use of the data.'' The poll was released to the three newspapers in time for Thursday's editions, VRS officials said. Mitofsky and other VRS officials said time constraints contributed to VRS' problems. VRS was conceived as a cost-saving cooperative venture between competitors, and negotiations to establish it began after the 1988 elections but concluded only in February of this year. ``We did this whole project in five months less than I told everybody we needed to do it,'' Mitofsky said. ``I think the fact that we got a late start needs to be weighed into that equation.''

DOC.HEAD: Cruise Missile Test Canceled
DOC.TEXT: The test of an American cruise missile over northwestern Canada was aborted in midflight Wednesday because of technical malfunctions, officials said. Maj. Luigi Rossetto of the Canadian forces base at Cold Lake said the test was canceled because of technical problems between the cruise missile's guidance system - which was being tested - and the B-52 carrying the weapon. The B-52 returned to base, K.I. Sawyer Air Force Base in the upper peninsula of Michigan, where the missile's guidance system will be examined. Rossetto said no further tests on the missile were planned, but that more may be held in the spring on other cruise missiles. The tests are permitted under a Canada-U.S. agreement signed in 1983 and renewed in 1988. They have drawn protests from peace groups and the Northwest Territories government, and a demonstration was held Wednesday at the Alberta legislature in Edmonton. Military officials say the Canadian North is ideal for the tests because the terrain is similar to that of the Soviet Union. A simulated launch sequence began about 12:30 a.m. EST when the B-52 bomber carrying the missile reached the Beaufort Sea, 1,360 miles northwest of Edmonton. The flight path turned south from the Beaufort along the Mackenzie River Valley into Alberta, where the test was terminated about 3:30 p.m. EST. The test was originally scheduled for Oct. 30, but was postponed five times because of technical problems and poor weather.

DOC.HEAD: Bradley Offers No Excuses for Slim Winning Margin
LaserPhoto ASB1
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bill Bradley said Wednesday that his narrow victory reflected voters' anger at higher state taxes and a campaign that failed to talk about people's main concerns. ``You're in this job, you're in the line of fire,'' he said. ``In good times you ride, in bad times you take the hit. I offer no excuses at all.'' Bradley defeated Republican Christine Todd Whitman by slightly more than 50,000 of the2 million votes cast in the race. But the two-term senator said he would have done nothing differently and refused to discuss the $2.8 billion tax package imposed by Gov. Jim Florio that fueled the anger. ``I sensed no deep-seated attack on me for something I had done. Maybe it's for what I needed to do,'' Bradley said the day after he defeated Mrs. Whitman with 50 percent of the vote to her 47 percent. She made the principal issue of her campaign Bradley's refusal to comment on Florio's tax plan. ``What people want is for politicians to talk about problems that really affect people's lives,'' Bradley said, like finding quality education and coping with housing, health care and fuel costs. ``I think the campaign generally on both sides did not engage those issues.'' ``My sense is that the senator didn't take his constituents seriously,'' said Richard Roper, director of the Council on New Jersey Affairs at Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School. ``I'm suggesting his agenda should have had a bit more depth in view of his years in the Senate.'' Overall, though, Roper discounted the effect of the campaign on Bradley's long-term political prospects, including the presidency. Bradley repeated Wednesday that he was firm about completing his six-year term. ``I don't think that the public cares a great deal about re-election margins,'' said Anita Dunn, spokeswoman for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee in Washington. She cited the example of Gary Hart's slim 1980 Senate victory. ``In the 1984 New Hampshire primary, I didn't hear a lot of voters saying he barely squeaked through in Colorado,'' she said. Michael Kaye, Bradley's California-based media consultant, predicted that Bradley's near-miss would quickly be forgotten. ``He's not a candidate in '92,'' Kaye said. ``And if he becomes a candidate at a later date, they sure won't go back six years and replay what happened in his race in 1990.'' Kaye said the campaign may have failed by emphasizing Bradley's record on the environment and children. ``It was not pertinent to what people were feeling and what their anger was,'' Kaye said. Mrs. Whitman, speaking at a Statehouse news conference, accused Bradley of ``not talking to the issues voters wanted to hear.'' Kaye said Bradley's advisers made an early decision not to comment on state taxes and even when they realized that position was hurting them, they didn't budge. ``We felt either way it was a loser,'' Kaye said. On the stump, Bradley tried to reassure voters about what he was doing in Washington on their behalf. But he admitted he might not have been able to convey on a broader scale that he had their problems at heart.

DOC.HEAD: President Calls Candidates
DOC.TEXT: President Bush telephoned nearly 50 candidates around the country Wednesday to offer either congratulations or condolences, officials said. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush was calling both winners and losers, ``wishing them every success in the years ahead.'' Bush made no public appearances. Fitzwater said Bush would continue making calls.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Rejects Trial for Peru's Garcia in Prison Massacre
DOC.TEXT: Congress narrowly voted Wednesday not to bring criminal charges against former President Alan Garcia for his role in the 1986 massacre of 250 rebel prisoners. After two days of often bitter debate, the Chamber of Deputies voted 80-75 not to try Garcia, who left office on July 28. More than 80 congressmen spoke during the session. The case involves the bloody repression of riots at three maximum-security Lima prisons. Police and soldiers who put down the June 1986 riots killed 250 prisoners, mostly members of the Maoist Shining Path guerrilla group. An investigation later found that many of the prisoners apparently were executed after they surrendered. The votes in support of Garcia came mainly from his own center-left Aprista Party, which controls 55 seats in the 180-seat Chamber. Most other votes came from members of President Alberto Fujimori's Change 90 party. Garcia could have faced jail if brought to trial on charges involving the massacre. As a senator and former president he cannot be prosecuted in a criminal court, but he earlier offered to waive his immunity if Congress voted in favor of a trial. A minority report issued after a Senate investigation in 1987 blamed Garcia and his Cabinet for the killings. The report said Garcia's decision to cede control of the situation to the military led to the massacre. After Garcia left office, Congress began a new investigation of Garcia's role in the massacre. He has said repeatedly the investigation was aimed at damaging him politically. He is still under investigation by a second congressional committee for the possible misuse of public funds while in office. Many congressmen of Fujimori's Change 90 party had been expected to support Garcia in the vote. Party members earlier voted to pay debts left by Garcia's government. Though strongly opposed to Fujimori's economic policies, the Apristas have mounted almost no effective opposition since he came to power July 28. Only 36 years old when he took office in 1985, Garcia was the youngest president in Peruvian history. The constitution bars presidents from holding office for two straight terms, but Garcia is an early favorite to be elected again in 1995. However, he would be prohibited from running again under a bill introduced in the Senate on Tuesday to limit presidents to one term in office.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf with two grafs, no comment from Berendzen's attorney
DOC.HEAD: Former American University President To Get $1 Million For Giving Up Tenure
DOC.TEXT: Richard Berendzen, who resigned as president of American University after allegations that he had made obscene telephone calls, will receive a $1 million settlement from the school for giving up his tenure as a professor, university sources said Wednesday. The Washington Post said the settlement was authorized by the university's trustees last Friday, but that it was not final. Anita Gottlieb, a spokeswoman, would not discuss the settlement, saying ``the university as a policy does not discuss financial arrangements between the university and its employees. That's the same with the president or a secretary.'' She said, however, that ``as of January, there will be no relationship between the university and Richard Berendzen.'' The university's executive committee met in closed session on Friday. Sources confirmed the $1 million sum was ``in the ballpark.'' Berendzen last April resigned the presidency of the Washington university he had held for 10 years and has not been actively involved in administrative affairs. But he continued to hold tenure. His salary had been about $140,000 a year. Susan Allen of Fairfax, Va., told police that Berendzen's calls began in March after she placed an advertisement for home child care in the Post. She said Berendzen graphically discussed fantasized sexual relations with children. Police traced the calls to the university president's office. Berendzen entered the sexual disorders clinic at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore and later pleaded guilty to two misdemeanor counts and was placed on probation. The hospital said in a statement that ``the phone calls appeared to have been a troubled attempt to make sense'' out of sexual abuse Berendzen suffered as a child. It said Berendzen ``is not a pedophile and has no pedophilic interests. He does not have a sexual disorder.'' Berendzen characterized the calls as ``inappropriate and grotesque'' and apologized to Ms. Allen. She has filed suit, asking $4 million from Berendzen and $7 million from the university. Richard Marks, Berendzen's attorney, said the account of the settlement with the university ``contains material inaccuracies,'' but he declined to say what they were. ``I don't think it's appropriate to confirm or deny speculation as it appears in the media,'' Marks said.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota's Wellstone Promises to Press Liberal Agenda
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota's new senator-elect said Wednesday he'll press his liberal agenda with the same ``fast-paced Paul'' style that produced his stunning upset of two-term Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz. ``I go to Washington with a pretty strong belief that things need to be changed, that things need to be shaken up,'' said Paul Wellstone, a Democrat. Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich was also bounced out of office, losing to Republican Arne Carlson, the state auditor who campaigned just two weeks. Carlson, 52, replaced the party's nominee who was driven from the race by allegations of sexual improprieties. Wellstone, 46, a political science professor, captivated Minnesota voters with his infectious enthusiasm and a campaign run by a covey of young volunteers, who Boschwitz credited with the race's dramatic turnaround. Republicans once considered Boschwitz's seat one of their safest. ``I thought he was going to be re-elected and I thought he was going to be re-elected by more than a squeaker,'' said Republican U.S. Rep. Bill Frenzel, who's retiring after serving Minnesota's 3rd District for 20 years. Wellstone got 52 percent of the vote Tuesday to Boschwitz's 48 percent with 99 percent of the state's precincts reporting. Wellstone had 881,712 votes to Boschwitz's 828,432. ``My opponent ran a very aggressive and capable and resourceful campaign,'' Boschwitz said Wednesday when he conceded the race. ``He outhustled us.'' The GOP campaign also suffered from intraparty turmoil in the Independent-Republican gubernatorial race, Boschwitz said. The governor's race was rated by many observers as the most negative ever in Minnesota. Perpich was roundly criticized for publicizing divorce disputes of his first GOP opponent, Jon Grunseth. Before Grunseth dropped out of the race nine days prior to the election, he accused Perpich of orchestrating allegations about skinny-dipping with teen-age girls that drove him out. Perpich, governor for 10 years, declined to analyze why he lost. ``It's behind me,'' he said. ``We gave it all we could. We worked very, very hard. It happens. Who knows why? This is not an exact science.'' Boschwitz outspent Wellstone 7-1, but the liberal activist crisscrossed the state for months in a ramshackle bus and captured the attention of voters with funny television commercials that brought him national attention. College students thronged to his cause. His youthful workers and supporters rocked the Capitol rotunda Wednesday with chants of ``Senator Wellstone, Senator Wellstone'' when he arrived to claim victory. ``Politics is indeed not about money ... but the improvement of people's lives,'' Wellstone said. ``These guys pulled it off. These guys did it.'' He expects to be a very outspoken member of the Senate in the mold of liberal gadfly Howard Metzenbaum, an Ohio Democrat. Metzenbaum often irritates colleagues by blocking special interest bills and relentlessly pursuing liberal causes. ``I intend to go there and move quickly. ... I intend to be a fast-paced Paul,'' Wellstone said. Boschwitz, who celebrated his 60th birthday Wednesday, said he'll return to Minnesota and go into some business other than the Plywood Minnesota chain of home-improvement centers that made him a millionaire before he entered the Senate in 1978. Plywood Minnesota is run by his four sons and wife, Ellen.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Lawyer Condemns Prosecutor for Bloody Photo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Contents may be offensive to some readers.
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for a winery worker convicted of killing seven people condemned a prosecutor for showing a jury Wednesday a naked, bloody photograph of one of the victims. Prosecutor Peter Bumerts pinned the photo of the dead 8-year-old girl to a board near the jury box during the penalty phase of Ramon Salcido's trial. Bumerts apologized to the jury ``for the difficulty you have in looking'' at it. One of Salcido's lawyers, Marteen Miller, decried the move as a tactic to imply his client sexually assaulted the girl, which was never proved. ``The very fact that there are seven victims, and one happens to have her legs spread and her genitalia showing, that's going to the depth of the barrel as far as I'm concerned,'' Miller said outside of the courtroom. ``This is just a red herring.'' Salcido, 29, was convicted Oct. 30 of killing his wife, two of his three daughters, his mother-in-law, her two daughters and a co-worker. He also was convicted of attempted murder, including slashing his third daughter's throat, during a rampage April 14, 1989. The jury must now decide whether Salcido gets the death penalty or life in prison without parole. The prosecution wants Salcido sent to the gas chamber. The defense has flown Salcido's mother in from Mexico to testify Thursday for sparing her son's life. While a jury typically might not heed a killer's mother, in this case ``she lost her grandchildren, whom she loved very much,'' defense attorney Bill Marioni said. The defense also called a former warden to testify that a convict such as Salcido could be held safely in prison, and a jail guard, Kenton Dunkle, who testified Salcido was ``congenial'' and ``a good inmate.'' The photo of the girl, Salcido's sister-in-law, was not shown earlier in the trial. Bumerts said the photograph illustrated Salcido's callousness because he removed the girl's underwear and wiped his knife on it after slitting her throat. Outside the courtroom, Bumerts said the photo ``shows the insensitivity to human life that Mr. Salcido had. I think the jury needs to remember who the victims in this case were.'' ``Nonsense, absolute nonsense,'' said Miller. ``If you believe that, I'll sell you some ocean view property in Arizona.'' Judge Reginald Littrell told the jury there was no finding of sexual abuse in the case but allowed the photograph to be shown.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Gesture for Harmony Disrupted on Soviet Holiday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 6 `Gray skies' to ADD dropped word `troops.' Picks up 7th pvs, `For the...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB5,4,6,1,9
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev soght political harmony by joining a Revolution Day march Wednesday but the mood was broken when a man brandishing a hunting rifle fired two shots in Red Square before he was hauled off. A group of plainclothesmen wrestled with the gunman, who shot in the air and into the ground before he was carried away. No one was reported hurt, and the chairman of the KGB security police indicated the man was deranged. Besides the traditional military parade in Red Square, hard-line Communists and radical reformers marched in Moscow and other Soviet cities shouting slogans and carrying banners critical of Gorbachev's moderate reforms. Gorbachev, struggling to forge a mainstream consensus in an increasingly polarized society, said his reforms were ``understood and accepted by the people.'' ``We all now stand a real chance to transform our society into a normal, healthy, just and ulimately prosperous society through the second great revolution,'' Gorbachev proclaimed from atop Lenin's Mausoleum on the 73rd anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution. Gray skies and snow flurries cast a somber mood as the Soviet armed forces sent 8,500 troops and 250 armored vehicles thundering across the cobblestones of Red Square. For the first time, the Soviets showed off a mobile SS-25 intercontinental ballistic missile capable of hurling a nuclear warhead 6,300 miles. The system has been deployed since 1985. The theme was peace, however, and Gorbachev joined his political foes, Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin and Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov, in leaving the mausoleum and joining a civilian march that began after the military parade. It was the first time Soviet leaders actually walked in the march, the state news agency Tass reported. The three men, along with Defense Minister Dmitri Yazov, Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov and others laid red flowers at Lenin's tomb. The mood was broken by the markedly conservative tone of the subsequent civilian marchers consisting of an estimated 100,000 marchers organized by Moscow Communist Party chief Yuri Prokofiev. Some carried portraits of dictator Josef V. Stalin, whom Gorbachev scorned in his remarks, and two carried photographs of naked women, suggesting variously that current leaders had ravished or neglected the country. Other banners said: ``President: In our house, there is no butter, no meat and no peace.'' ``Gorbachev, you are scoring points abroad, but losing at home.'' About four minutes after Gorbachev went back on top of the Lenin mausoleum, two shots were heard above the marching music. Plainclothes police, hundreds of whom line Red Square during such public events, apparently grabbed the man as he leveled a sawed-off hunting rifle toward the mausoleum about 80 yards away, according to Tass. One officer shoved the man's arms up as one shot went off, then others swarmed around and forced the barrel toward the ground as the second shot was fired, said Rafik Nishanov, a parliamentary leader who was on the mausoleum. More than a dozen plainclothesmen surrounded the 38-year-old Leningrad resident and carried him horizontal into the adjacent GUM Department store, as seen in a tape released by the Tass video unit. KGB Chairman Vladimir Kryuchkov, asked at a Kremlin reception whether the man was sane, replied: ``Not in our our opinion ... but we are investigating.'' The national evening television newscast ``Vremya'' broadcast videotape of the man being taken off by plainclothes security. After the official demonstration, Yeltsin addressed about 10,000 protesters who gathered near Communist Party headquarters, marched past the KGB and ended up near the home of the late physicist Andrei Sakharov, the Nobel Peace laureate. Yeltsin and Popov also joined another more radical counterdemonstration that entered Red Square two hours after Gorbachev and other leaders left. Those demonstrators demanded Gorbachev resign. ``The country is on the verge of a civil war,'' said one of the organizers, Telman Gdlyan. He also compared the government with a ``fascist'' regime. Tass said his remarks ``insulted the Soviet president.'' Official parades were held in other big cities, although anti-Communists tried to ban or disrupt some of them. In the Baltic republic of Lithuania, locally organized defense units clashed with Soviet paratroopers who reportedly tried to storm a conservatory in Vilnius, the independent Baltic News Service reported. In neighboring Latvia, army troops were deployed to ``protect'' the official parade. In the third Baltic republic of Estonia, the official parade was nearly ignored and no counterdemonstration was held, the report said. Thousands packed Leningrad's Palace Square, where the 1917 revolution was centered, for a protest after the official parade. In the Ukrainian capital of Kiev, the military parade proceeded peacefully, said a visiting U.S. scholar. About 5,000 people met later for an anti-Communist rally. In the Caucasian republic of Georgia, where non-Communists won recent elections, the military parade was held on an army base. Officials canceled part of an official parade in Azerbaijan out of fear it would turn into a protest, Tass reported. In Moldavia, where recent ethnic strife has left at least four dead, the capital Kishinev was quiet with no parade. But in the eastern region where Slavic separatists are opposed to Moldavian nationalism, tens of thousands of people staged pro-government rallies, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: HBO Dominates Cable Award Nominations
DOC.TEXT: Home Box Office dominated the 12th Annual ACE Awards nominations for excellence in cable television, garnering more than a quarter of the entries announced Wednesday. HBO movies, specials and other programs made up 100 of 361 nominees. The cable network Showtime and TNT tied for second with 31 nominations each. The Arts & Entertainment Network had 30 nominations for third place. HBO's ``Tales from the Crypt'' won the most nominations of any single project with 12. ``Dream On,'' another HBO program, was second with 10. About 26 awards will be presented in a live, prime-time telecast Jan. 13 on cable channels, including BET, Discovery, The Family Channel, Ha! The TV Comedy Network, Lifetime, Nick at Nite, TBS Superstation and TNT, the National Academy of Cable Programming said. Presentation of the rest of the awards will not be televised.

DOC.HEAD: Wrestler Fined for Scuffle with Cameraman
DOC.TEXT: Andre Roussimoff, better known as wrestler Andre the Giant, was fined $100 and ordered to pay $233 in damages to a television station over a scuffle with a cameraman last year. Roussimoff was found guilty of criminal mischief in a non-jury trial. A judge fined the 7-foot-4, 540-pound wrestler Tuesday. Roussimoff was charged in a scrap with former KCRG-TV cameraman Ben Hildebrandt, just after Roussimoff was defeated in a professional wrestling match in Cedar Rapids. He contended Hildebrandt videotaped the match without permission, but the cameraman said he was just shooting crowd scenes when the wrestler put him in a head lock. Hildebrandt was treated for minor injuries and later left the station to work on a congressional campaign. The judge found Roussimoff innocent of assault charges, saying the wrestler didn't mean to harm Hildebrandt. The damages, to be paid to KCRG, are to reimburse the station for fixing the camera.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Haitian President Wants Dec. 16 Elections Canceled
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Former President Leslie Manigat, who was ousted in a 1988 coup, said Wednesday he would sue officials for barring him from running for the presidency. He also said the Dec. 16 elections should be canceled. The country's Electoral Council on Tuesday disqualified Manigat from running for president next month based on an article of the constitution that says the president ``may not be re-elected'' unless five years have passed between terms. The council barred 11 other presidential hopefuls from the race, including many officials of the oppressive Duvalier regime that ruled this poor Caribbean nation for 29 years. Fourteen candidates remain. In a statement read to the press, Manigat said the elections should be declared ``null and void'' because he never resigned from the presidency and he had not completed his term in office. He said these factors made the constitutional article cited by the Electoral Council inapplicable. Manigat was elected Jan. 17, 1988, in what are generally considered army-rigged elections, held after a massacre at the polls the previous November canceled the balloting. Most Haitians stayed home and did not vote in the January elections, fearing for their lives. Although he was regarded a puppet of the army, Manigat was ousted six months after taking office and deported. A former history professor, he has lived in exile in the United States until his return in October. The interim government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot tried several times to deny him re-entry permission for ``reasons of state.'' ``The injustice the council has committed will fall on its head,'' said Manigat. He called for ``a vast national protest'' against the decision. Election officials said the 1987 constitution did not make provisions for coups. Thus, the issue of Manigat's eligibility to run for president is not completely clear. ``Manigat must accept that he is an ordinary citizen and conform his desire to the reality of the electoral law,'' said human rights activist Jean-Claude Bajeux, who co-leads a socialist party. Roger Lafontant, who was the head of brutal Tonton Macoute militia that enforced the Duvalier rule for nearly three decades, was also barred from running for president on technicalities under the election law. He said Tuesday he would appeal the decision to the Supreme Court. In 1987, the barring of Duvalierists led to the killing of 34 voters at the polls in the aborted election. Many Haitians worried the new disqualifications would provoke the revenge of Duvalier supporters. But there have been no incidents. There are 200 to 300 observers already in the country as part of an international team from the United Nations and the Organization of American States that is to monitor the elections. The Duvalier dictatorship ended when Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile in France in 1986. But Haiti has continued to be plagued by political violence. The current government is the fifth since Duvalier was deposed.

DOC.HEAD: Amoco Pipeline Leaks More Oil Than Expected
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil that leaked from an Amoco pipeline and fouled 35 miles of the Chariton River totaled 44,000 to 66,000 gallons, officials said in an estimate up sharply from earlier figures. The oil may spread south another 20 miles, reaching the Missouri River by Thursday, the state Department of Natural Resources warned Wednesday. The Chariton River runs from Iowa to the Missouri River. Amoco Corp., which owns the pipeline, originally estimated that Monday's oil leak sent 21,000 gallons into the river in north-central Missouri, fouling about 10 to 15 miles. William Palmer, a spokesman for the state agency, said the spill's effect, not its size, made it very significant. ``Each spill is different; the Chariton River is very low, which concentrates the effect of the oil on wildlife,'' he said. The agency also advised cities that may have to shut off water intakes because of the oil to immediately pump as much water into reservoirs as possible. Dave Abshear, an Amoco spokesman, said oil company officials believe there has been no damage to fish or wildlife. ``That's untrue,'' Palmer said. ``We have seen dead fish and stressed fish coming to the surface and gasping for air. We're very concerned about mammals and fur bearers and waterfowl migrating at this time.'' The Department of Conservation stocked the river with otters in recent years. Several nearby state wildlife refuges attract thousands of migrating waterfowl, and some of them pass over and use the Chariton. Amoco work crews were on the scene of spill Wednesday with vacuuming equipment. The company said the cleanup could take about a month and Amoco would cover all costs.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed when Freight Trains Smash into Each Other
DOC.TEXT: Two freight trains collided Wednesday, killing four crew members and injuring two others, officials said. The Santa Fe Railway trains crashed about 4:10 a.m. A westbound train left a siding too early and smashed into a passing eastbound train, said Santa Fe spokesman Mike Martin. Four locomotives and at least six freight cars derailed. Diesel fuel from a locomotive ignited but firefighters prevented the blaze from spreading. The collision left Santa Fe's main transcontinental line blocked until sometime Thursday, said police Sgt. Tim Slane. About 100 gallons of spilled diesel fuel was mopped up, but removal of the wreckage could not begin until National Transportation Safety Board investigators arrive from Washington, Slane said. The wreck occurred in an area of light industry in Corona, a city of 61,000 in Riverside County, about 45 miles east of Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Ecumenist Nominated To Top Church Council Post
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Joan Brown Campbell, a leader in the Christian unity movement, has become the first woman minister nominated for chief executive of the National Council of Churches, it was announced Wednesday. A search committee recommended the 58-year-old minister as the new general secretary of the council, the country's largest ecumenical organization. Founded 40 years ago, the council includes most major U.S. Protestant and Eastern Orthodox denominations. The nomination goes before the council's general board at a meeting Nov. 14-16 in Portland, Ore. While other nominees may be offered from the floor, historically the search committee's choice has won election. A native of Youngstown, Ohio, Ms. Campbell holds ministerial credentials in the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) and American Baptist Churches (U.S.A.). She is currently U.S. staff officer of the World Council of Churches. Offering prayers for the ``vision and the spiritual strength'' to handle the new task, Ms. Campbell said, ``Never during the 20 years that I have worked within the ecumenical movement have I sensed a time when unity was more urgent. We are a nation on the brink of war, faced with increased racism and economic insecurity.'' She would succeed James A. Hamilton, a council staff member and United Methodist layman who has been interim general secretary since July 1, 1989. While Ms. Campbell would be the first woman minister in the post, it was held between 1974 and 1984 by an ordained Presbyterian elder, Claire Randall.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Gov.-elect Taking Reins; Simon Sees Landslide as Mandate
DOC.TEXT: Gov.-elect Jim Edgar began taking the reins of state government Wednesday, and Paul Simon said his own landslide may turn some heads in the U.S. Senate, where liberalism has been considered out of vogue. After his narrow victory over Democrat Neil Hartigan in Tuesday's election, Republican Edgar said he would begin work on cabinet appointments and other personnel decisions by naming a transition team. Democrat Simon, who trounced Lynn Martin, a Republican congresswoman, said: ``I think the margin of victory really does say that someone who stands for the things that I stand for can win and not just eke out a victory.'' With 98 percent of precincts reporting, Simon had 2,076,358 votes, or 65 percent, and Martin had 1,120,717 votes, or 35 percent. ``It says something to my colleagues who are concerned about whether they can vote for or against some social legislation, whether it is politically acceptable to say we ought to be doing more in education, health care and the environment, and have government play a more leading role than has been the trend,'' Simon said. Edgar repeated his campaign assertions that the state will face a tight budget. He hopes to shift about $100 million in state money next year to provide more money for mental health, child-abuse prevention, prisons and other programs. Edgar said he was fortunate to win in an election that saw heavy Republican losses in the Illinois House and the shift of a congressional seat in northwest Illinois from the GOP to the Democrats. With 98 percent of precincts reporting, Edgar had 1,634,524 votes, or 51 percent, to Hartigan's 1,537,174 votes or 48 percent. Edgar succeeds four-term GOP Gov. Jim Thompson, who's stepping down. In other major races, Republican Lt. Gov. George Ryan was elected to the secretary of state post being vacated by Edgar, but Democrat John Cox defeated Republican John Hallock to capture the congressional seat Martin is vacating. Hallock had been favored until he was battered by publicity about a child-support dispute and a ticket for driving 107 mph. Democratic victories in state legislative races also gave the party a veto-proof 73-45 majority in the state House of Representatives with reapportionment to be considered next year. Two congressional Democrats, veteran Frank Annunzio of Chicago and freshman George Sangmeister of Mokena, also survived stiff challenges as their party widened its majority in the state's congressional delegation to 15-7.

DOC.HEAD: Documents Quote Hirohito as Saying He Feared Coup
DOC.TEXT: The late Emperor Hirohito said shortly after World War II that he had not opposed attacking the United States because he feared civil war might otherwise break out in Japan, according to documents released Wednesday. In an eight-hour conversation with aides about his role before and during the war, Hirohito also rejected the Japanese tradition that reveres the emperor as a living god, according to a transcript reported by Japanese media. The conversation was held in spring 1946, when Allied Occupation forces were considering whether to charge the emperor with war crimes. The discussions appear to have been part of preparations by aides for a possible trial. The Japan Broadcasting Corp. said the transcripts were recorded by Hirenari Terasaki, a former diplomat. Terasaki also translated for the emperor in some of his meetings with Douglas MacArthur, supreme commander of the Allies during the postwar occupation of Japan. The broadcasting corporation said that when Terasaki died, the transcripts of the conversation were given to his daughter, Mariko Terasaki Miller, who lives in the United States and recently rediscovered the documents. ``If I had tried to veto the beginning of the Pacific War, a coup d'etat would have occurred, and my trusted aides would have been killed. My life also could not have been guaranteed,'' Hirohito said. He was referring to fears of an uprising in Japan's powerful military. ``Even if that were acceptable, a violent civil war would have occurred, resulting in a tragedy several times worse than the recent war (World War II), and leading to circumstances that the war would not have ended. I believe that Japan would have been destroyed,'' Kyodo News Service quoted the transcripts as saying. He appeared to be referring to the possibility of a civil conflict between those Japanese who favored going to war and those who did not. Japanese officials met and decided to attack the United States shortly before the bombing of Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941. The radio network quoted Hirohito as saying he did not halt the war later because he feared the public might believe the government had given in to the United States, despite Japan's strong army and navy. Before he died in January 1989, Hirohito made few public statements about his role during the war. However, he had consistently said he did not intervene in the war plans because he could not, as a constitutional monarch, interfere in decisions made by the government. ``To my knowledge, I have not heard him say that (refer to a possible coup) before,'' said Otis Cary, a professor at Kyoto's Doshisha University and an acquaintance of the emperor. In contrast, Cary said, Hirohito took a strong role in 1936 in putting down a coup attempt within the army. ``But by December 1941, the situation was so tight. The military had complete hold on the government,'' Cary said in a telephone interview. ``The emperor just held his peace.'' The transcript quoted Hirohito as telling the five aides that it was ``troubling'' for him to be referred to as a living god. ``Biologically, I have the same body as ordinary people, so I am not a god,'' Kyodo quoted the transcripts as saying. Although Hirohito is considered to have renounced his divinity in a New Year's message in 1946, Japanese rightists have maintained he did not explicitly deny his prewar status as a Shinto God in the Japanese translation of those remarks. The comments were originally written in English and probably intended primarily for Western consumption. Critics charge that next week's enthronement ceremonies for Emperor Akihito, Hirohito's successor, will violate Japan's postwar constitution by once again linking the emperor with the Shinto religion. Akihito's formal coronation has been delayed more than a year by an official period of mourning.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Says Parent Company Determined To Keep Publishing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 10th graf, `Lisa Robinson ...' to ADD other newspapers owned by same company.
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News said Wednesday that top officers of its Chicago-based parent company remain determined to keep publishing the tabloid in the face of a 2-week-old strike. Tribune Co. Chairman Stanton Cook and President Charles Brumback visited the newspaper Tuesday and also reaffirmed support for Daily News management, the newspaper reported. Labor leaders contend the Tribune Co. provoked the strike to try to break the unions and, failing that, fold the money-losing newspaper. Brumback conceded some advertisers pulled out and distributing the newspaper was a major problem. But he said during a meeting with senior editors, ``This is a great city and a great franchise for us,'' the News said. He also said departed advertisers were saying, ``If you win, we'll be back with you.'' Brumback said claims that he and Cook were calling the shots were ``baloney,'' adding that publisher James Hoge was in charge and that ``this is a New York situation and it will be solved by the Daily News management in New York.'' A group of clergymen, expressing concern over the economic and social damage of the strike, came to the News building Wednesday to urge the News to return to negotiations with its unions. The clergymen criticized union violence but aimed most of their barbs at the company. Speaking for a clerical ``Coalition of Conscience,'' the Rev. James A. Forbes Jr., senior minister of Riverside Church, said that the tactic of hiring permanent replacements for striking employees ``seriously undercuts management's claim to be bargaining in good faith.'' Rabbi Balfour Brickner of the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue said the group wanted to meet with Hoge to offer help in ending the strike. Lisa Robinson, a spokeswoman for the News, said, ``This company is not anti-union. We have negotiated for the better part of this year and continue to be open to the bargaining process. That is the place to resolve differences with the parties directly involved.'' The Tribune Co. also owns the Chicago Tribune and The Orlando Sentinel. The News, the nation's third-largest metropolitan daily, has been publishing during the strike, which began Oct. 25. The newspaper says 150 of 350 Newspaper Guild editorial workers have returned to work. The newspaper is difficult to find in many areas of the city. Dozens of newsstand owners say they stopped carrying the News because of threats. The strike began when a dispute involving the drivers' union led some deliverers to walk off the job. The News responded by bringing in replacement workers and the strike spread to eight of nine other unions, representing 2,100 workers who had been without contracts since March 30. The News insisted during negotiations that it could not survive without ending what it called union featherbedding.

DOC.HEAD: Yiddish Musical Revue Opens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned.
DOC.TEXT: A musical revue with specialized appeal, ``Those Were the Days,'' has opened at Broadway's Edison Theater. About two-thirds of the show, which arrived Wednesday, is in Yiddish. There are little stories in English, introducing songs sung in Yiddish. Or jokes in English - except for a Yiddish punchline. The five performers have charm. Mina Bern, a senior citizen, sings and talks with sweet spunk. Robert Abelson, also silver-haired, has enough voice to sing a creditable ``Largo al Factotum'' from ``The Barber of Seville.'' Bruce Adler has the dance steps to propel himself around the stage to ``traveling music'' as fast as a unicycle rider. Eleanor Reissa and Lori Wilner were effective, particularly as hungry, poor boys in a duet that translates as ``Who Will Laugh First?'' Act 1 included songs and stories from an Eastern European Jewish settlement ``in the time of cobblestone pavement and horse-drawn carriages.'' The scenes, unrelated, sound like the Yiddish raw material for ``Fiddler on the Roof.'' There was the couple who wanted to marry but her mother thought a tailor wasn't good enough and his father deplored her lack of dowry. Both parents gave in. Act 2, titled ``The Music Hall,'' had more lively music, with fewer introductions and less English. Some songs were familiar to an older audience, even one that didn't know Yiddish: ``I Wish I Were Single Again,'' ``My Yiddishe Mame,'' ``Bei Mir Bistu Schoen'' and, of course, ``Those Were the Days.'' Reissa directed and choreographed as well as performing. Gail Cooper-Hecht is credited with the many costumes. Moe Septee produced in association with Victor H. Potamkin, Zalmen Mlotek and Moishe Rosenfeld.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq: Will Free 120 Hostages; Thatcher Warns `Time Running Out'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 14 `In Iraq's' to UPDATE with arrival of 74 Japanese hostages at Tokyo, details. Picks up 15th pvs, `State Department...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,4
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Wednesday promised to free 120 hostages, including a few Americans, but U.S. officials blasted Saddam Hussein for his ``cynical'' use of the captives and the foreign envoys who have been seeking to free them. At the United Nations, diplomats said the United States is sounding out member countries on a Security Council resolution that would authorize the use of U.N. military force against Iraq. If such a measure is adopted, it would be an unprecedented step in the history of the United Nations. But the text of the resolution has not yet been circulated to other Security Council members because Secretary of State James A. Baker III is overseas trying to line up support for it, said the diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We know they've got it on paper, but it would be absurd for them to pass it (the text) around until they've got all the crucial support lined up,'' said one official. Baker, off on a weeklong tour that has already taken him to the Mideast, is now in Moscow. In Washington, a Pentagon source said late Wednesday that the Bush administration has decided to send additional armored divisions soon to beef up the 230,000 U.S. and 70,000 other multinational forces in Saudi Arabia. The source said most of the troops and tanks would come from Europe. Earlier, in some of her strongest remarks of the 3-month-old Persian Gulf standoff, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher warned Saddam that ``time is running out'' for a peaceful solution. Mrs. Thatcher told British lawmakers they must send the Iraqi president the message that ``either he gets out of Kuwait soon or we and our allies will remove him by force and he will go down to defeat with all the consequences.'' ``He has been warned,'' she added. The Iraqi information minister denounced Mrs. Thatcher, saying she was mentally unbalanced and possessed by the devil. In a statement carried by the official Iraqi News Agency, Minister Latif Jassim said Mrs. Thatcher's statements were ``filled with rancor and hatred toward the Iraqi people'' and did not befit the office of prime minister. He said ``her continued calls for beating the drums of war unequivocally show beyond a shadow of a doubt that this woman ... has lost her mental balance. ... The devil has found a comfortable dwelling within her mind and conscience.'' Her saber-rattling sent oil prices surging upward. At the New York Mercantile Exchange, a key market, contracts for December delivery of light sweet crude oil were up $2.68 at $35.31 per barrel a the close of the session on Wednesday. In Iraq's latest round of hostage-freeing, 74 Japanese nationals arrived Thursday in Tokyo from Baghdad. Their arrival was televised nationally. The official Iraqi News Agency said 100 Germans and 20 other foreigners, including an unspecified number of Americans, Britons and Italians, would be released. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said U.S. officials had not yet been notified about plans to free any Americans. He denounced Iraq's ``cynical bartering'' of captive foreigners, who were trapped by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iraq did not say when the 120 would be freed, but suggested it would be soon. The announcement marked the second time in two days Baghdad agreed to release a large group of captives in response to an appeal by a former foreign leader. The White House on Wednesday took aim at such missions, saying the foreign envoys were being manipulated by Saddam. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater singled out former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt, who interceded on behalf of the Germans, and former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who won the Japanese hostages' freedom. ``Clearly, these people are being used. And we want to point that out in the strongest terms,'' Fitzwater said. He accused Saddam of ``cynical attempts at propagandizing this situation'' in a bid to ``build legitimacy for his government.'' Iraq still holds hundreds of Japanese and German hostages, along with other ``guests'' from other countries. Japan denied having changed its gulf stance to win its citizens' freedom, but word that the Japanese hostages would be freed came Tuesday, just came as Tokyo said it was abandoning its proposal to send Japanese troops to the gulf region. The Iraqi news agency said the German hostages would be freed to reflect ``appreciation for the German policy, which does not support trends toward war.'' Baker, meanwhile, told reporters in Turkey that the United States ``cannot rule out the possible use of force'' in the gulf. Later, he flew to Moscow, where is is to hold talks Thursday with Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Baker is trying to win a Soviet commitment to go along with a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force in the gulf region. He won a similar pledge a day earlier in a meeting with the Chinese foreign minister, U.S. officials said. The Soviet Union and China are both permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, and their support would be essential for any new anti-Iraq resolutions. Gorbachev's envoy Yevgeny Primakov, who has met with Saddam twice in the past two months, said he told the Iraqi leader he would be attacked if he did not leave Kuwait. ``I put it like this to him: `If you do not withdraw, you will face a military strike against you,''' Primakov told reporters Wednesday at a Kremlin reception. In other developments: -A U.S. military source in Bahrain said Navy warships diverted the German vessel Red Sea Europa last weekend after chemicals intended for Iraq were found aboard, in violation of the global sanctions. The source, who demanded anonymity, did not know what the chemicals were. -Iraq calls the hostages its ``guests,'' but it apparently means paying guests. The Dutch government said Wednesday it had paid part of a $50,900 hotel bill for Dutch hostages being held at a luxury hotel in Baghdad. A Foreign Ministry spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Dutch government was billed despite earlier Iraqi assurances that the foreigners would be put up for free.

DOC.HEAD: Shipwrecked Firefighters Saved by Pilot Seeking Whales
DOC.TEXT: Three firefighters battling sharks after their boat sank on a fishing trip were rescued when scientists flying in search of whales spotted their makeshift raft in the Atlantic. Mike Davis, John Kaplan and Al Bourgeois left Mayport Tuesday to go fishing. One of two motors on their 30-foot fishing boat broke down and the other one failed. Soon, waves came along that flipped the boat and tossed the men into the water. The boat sank. Davis was in a wetsuit and had his spear gun, so he began swimming the 16 miles to shore. He encountered sharks. ``One shark was real excited about me,'' Davis said. The 9-foot predator followed him until Davis, 37, struck at the shark with his spear and it swam away, he said. Meanwhile, Kaplan, 35, owner of the lost boat, and Bourgeois, 30, clung to a raft of coolers, life jackets and marker floats. Twice, boats passed within 30 yards of them. Kaplan fired a pistol into the air, but the people on the boats were blaring music and, apparently oblivious of the men, passed them by. The pair drifted for four hours when Chris Slay, a researcher from the New England Aquarium searching in an airplane for whales with two other scientists, spotted Kaplan and Bourgeois. The plane's pilot, Hugh Rawls, contacted the Navy, which called the Coast Guard. ``It we hadn't had professional observers, we would have never seen them. They looked like a speck,'' Rawls said Wednesday. ``Those poor fellows were hanging on to an ice chest.'' ``Seeing that plane pass us and then turn around - that was like being born again,'' Bourgeois said. Ten minutes later a helicopter plucked them from the sea. During the search for Davis, Coast Guard Petty Officer 2nd Class Martin Callender was in the bow of a boat when he saw a flash in the water. It was the sun glistening off Davis' fluttering fins. ``I found him because of his fins. I don't think I would have seen him otherwise,'' said Callender. Davis was found about 1{ miles southwest of the other two men. All three men were in good condition. They said they'd like to meet whoever saved them, and maybe throw a party with the pilot as guest of honor.

DOC.HEAD: Man Charged in Mail Bombings that Killed Judge, Civil Rights Leader
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 15th graf pvs bgng, `Defense attorney,' to UPDATE with quotes from O'Ferrell's attorney
DOC.TEXT: A reclusive Georgia businessman with a history of criminal charges was charged Wednesday with mailing package bombs that killed a federal judge and a civil rights lawyer. Walter L. Moody Jr., 56, long the prime suspect in the case, was accused of mailing bombs last December that exploded when they were opened by their recipients, Circuit Judge Robert S. Vance and Robert E. Robinson, a Savannah alderman and civil rights lawyer. The bombs bore marked similarities to one that Moody was convicted of possessing in 1972, according to federal authorities. The indictment, announced in Washington by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and FBI Director William Sessions, also accused Moody of mailing similar bombs to the Atlanta court where Vance sat and the Jacksonville, Fla., office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Those bombs were defused without causing any injuries. The 70-count indictment returned by a federal grand jury in Atlanta also accused Moody of sending assassination threats to Vance and his colleagues on the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals and mailing a tear-gas bomb to the NAACP regional office in Atlanta. Six of the charges, including murder of a federal judge, carry sentences of up to life imprisonment. He also was accused of transporting explosive material with the intent to kill and mailing the bombs with the intention to kill. Thornburgh called the bombings acts that ``strike at the heart of our American concept of the rule of law.'' ``Those who would seek to attack the integrity and sanctity of our legal system through violent behavior would undermine the very foundations of our democracy,'' the attorney general said. The indictment capped a massive investigation conducted by the FBI, postal inspectors and other federal law enforcement agencies that involved a meticulous examination of millions of court documents, bomb fragments and other physical evidence. Moody has been known to be a prime suspect in the case since February when FBI agents searched his home in Rex, Ga. The FBI also searched the home and business of Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, an Enterprise, Ala., junk dealer who had written numerous letters to the 11th Circuit. Thornburgh refused to comment when asked if the indictment meant that O'Ferrell had been cleared as a suspect. But the attorney general noted that the indictment charges that Moody acted alone. Asked if he expected any more charges, Thornburgh said: ``Not soon.'' Defense attorney Bruce Harvey said he planned for Moody to plead innocent to the charges, ``There's absolutely no question about that.'' O'Ferrell's attorney, Paul Harden of Evergreen, Ala., said FBI and Justice Department authorities told them officially Wednesday that O'Ferrell was ``no longer a suspect and that he is out of the case.'' Describing O'Ferrell as a ``very religious person,'' Harden said he was ``happy and content'' at the turn of events. ``He just thanked God it was over.'' Vance died Dec. 16, 1989 after opening the parcel at his home in Mountainbrook, Ala. Two days later Robinson, an NAACP leader, was mortally wounded when he opened a package that had been sent to his law offices, the same day a bomb was found at the 11th Circuit courthouse in Atlanta. The next day another bomb was found at the NAACP office in Jacksonville. The pipe bombs contained the same brand of powder and had improvised detonators made with the barrels of ball-point pens, according to the indictment. Moody was also charged with sending a Dec. 21, 1989 letter to an Atlanta television anchorwoman threatening to kill more NAACP leaders. The indictment also accused Moody of sending letters in August 1989 to the 11th Circuit and 14 television stations around the country threatening poisonous gas attacks on large population centers. Neither Thornburgh nor Sessions would say whether the killings were racially motivated, although the FBI director had indicted earlier that race was a possible factor in the case. Moody has been in federal custody since July when he and his wife, Susan, were indicted on charges of trying to suborn perjury and tamper with witnesses to induce a federal court to vacate his 1972 conviction. Moody and his wife, who has petitioned for divorce, are scheduled to be tried Nov. 27. Friends have described Moody as a loner. A psychiatric evaluation ordered since his indictment last summer concluded that between 1967 and 1988, ``there may be reasonable cause to believe'' he suffered from mental illness. The 1972 conviction arose from charges that Moody made the bomb with the intention of sending it with an extortion note to an automobile dealer who had repossessed his car. Moody was acquitted of manufacturing the bomb but found guilty of possessing the device, which exploded and seriously injured his first wife. A 1983 trial of attempted murder charges against Moody ended in a hung jury.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Circulating Resolution Authorizing Use of U.N. Force in Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs to UPDATE with other developments. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The United States has prepared a Security Council resolution authorizing the use of U.N. military force against Iraq, a step unprecedented in the history of the United Nations, diplomats said Wednesday. The U.S. Mission has not circulated the text to other Security Council members because Secretary of State James A. Baker III is overseas lining up key support for it, the diplomats said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We know they've got it on paper, but it would be absurd for them to pass it around until they've got all the crucial support lined up,'' said one official. U.S. officials in Washington who were close to the situation, also speaking anonymously, confirmed the account. One State Department source, speaking privately, insisted, ``There is no U.S. draft on use of force at this point.'' A document is not technically a ``draft,'' however, until it has been introduced before the council. Baker said in Turkey that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 ``is, after all, the first real crisis of the post-Cold War era, and it is very important that when the United Nations takes action and passes resolutions, those resolutions and the act be implemented.'' Iraq has defied 10 Security Council resolutions. They include demands that it free all hostages, withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait and permit the restoration of Kuwait's government. ``Obviously, we want to see a peaceful, diplomatic and political solution to this problem,'' Baker said, but added: ``It is the view of our president and the United States that we cannot rule out the possible use of force before we see that the matter is resolved peacefully,'' he said. Baker flew to Moscow on Wednesday to continue his diplomatic initiative on the Persian Gulf crisis, which includes rallying support for the use of U.N.-sanctioned military force. He then travels to Paris and London.
