Despite a strong financial offer by Jersey City, officials said the exchanges' 120-year history in New York's financial industry was a deciding factor. ``New York is the financial capital of the world and ... if the deals were comparable, we belonged here,'' Commodity Exchange Chairman Martin Greenberg said. ``There were citizenship concerns.''

DOC.HEAD: EC Proposal Falls Far Short of U.S. Demands, GATT Round Still at Risk
DOC.TEXT: The gap between the European Community's plan to cut farmers' subsidies and demands by the United States and other major farm exporters threatens to stall talks to overhaul world trade. An official of the 14-nation Cairns group of major agriculture exporting countries called the EC proposal ``very disappointing.'' ``It's a minimalist position,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. After 10 hours of bargaining Tuesday, EC agriculture and trade ministers agreed to a proposal for a 30 percent cut in subsidies for major crops over 10 years, beginning in 1986. Some reductions have already been made. With the proposal, the EC will become the final major trade partner to submit an offer to the trade talks, a four-year effort by more than 100 countries to lower international trade barriers. The United States has proposed 75 percent cuts in farm income supports and 90 percent reductions in export subsidies over a 10-year period beginning in 1991. The EC proposal does not cut export subisidies, which make it easier for Europeans to sell their more expensive goods on world markets. The ministers, who had failed in six previous attempts, worked under intense international pressure to come up with an offer. Argentina, one of the Cairns countries, had threatened to walk out of the broader Uruguay Round of trade talks if the EC did not make a proposal soon. Other nations were seen moving in that direction. The United States and other agriculture-exporting countries regard farming as the key to success in the talks, which cover 15 areas ranging from textiles, telecommunications and services like banking. The Uruguay Round, held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, is scheduled to end with a final set of meetings next month. EC officials fended off criticism that their proposal falls short. ``It's a good, solid and sound proposal,'' said Ray MacSharry, the top EC farm official. He said the Community plan was ``more realistic'' than the far deeper cuts suggested by the United States and others. He called on the other countries to make equally realistic offers. ``What I would say to the other partners is: `Match this before you argue with it,''' MacSharry said. Italian Trade Minister Renato Ruggiero said: ``It would be a grave error on the part of our partners to judge that the position of the Community is not a position of great openness and ambition.'' Last month, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills had dismissed the trading bloc's proposal as inadequate. ``If we used that 30 percent figure, the United States could raise its levels of support and protection,'' she said in Geneva. Tuesday's agreement ended a nearly month-long impasse on the EC bargaining position. British Agriculture Minister John Gummer said the Community's drawn-out discussions showed its trading partners that further cuts would be very hard. ``It is clear from the negotiations that the European Community (does) find reductions in support extremely difficult,'' he told reporters. France and Germany had prevented agreement on an EC proposal by insisting on a series of guarantees that the cuts would not be too severe on farmers. In the end, the ministers adopted a list of assurances that promised not only to compensate farmers for income losses, but also to make sure that imported goods could not be sold more cheaply than home-grown products. The agreement also pledged to limit the impact of the reductions on poor regions of the Community and to soften proposed cuts in olive oil and other products widely grown in Mediterranian countries.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Savings & Loan Posts Big Loss
DOC.TEXT: Columbia Savings & Loan posted a $352 million loss for the third quarter, indicating further hemorrhaging at what was once the nation's most profitable thrift. The collapse of the nation's junk bond market helped bring Columbia's losses to $1.4 billion for the last five quarters. The loss for the third quarter amounted to $16.83 a share. In the first nine months of the year, Columbia had a loss of $781.8 million, or $38.37 a share. Columbia's junk bond collection, once estimated at $4 billion, is now worth slightly more than half that amount. The thrift's latest loss, reported Tuesday, further increases the ultimate cost to taxpayers should Columbia fail and be seized by the government. Experts have projected that taxpayers would be forced to pay between $500 million and $1 billion to cover the savings and loan's federally insured deposits. Normally, Columbia would have been seized long ago. But regulators have been working with thrift management to sell its junk bonds privately so the government might escape being saddled with them. In the third quarter, the market value of Columbia's bonds plunged by $226 million, a drop that Columbia chief executive Edward Harshfield called unprecedented. Harshfield stressed that the thrift has sufficient cash to meet depositors' demands. Because of the huge numbers of companies that have defaulted on the risky, high-yield junk bonds, their market value has been severely diminished.

DOC.HEAD: Black Journalists Rescind Offer To Sell Mailing List to News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with firebombing that may be tied to strike; picks up 4th graf pvs, `There was... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Striking Daily News workers have pressured a black journalists' organization into rescinding its offer to provide the newspaper's management with a list of potential replacement workers. The National Association of Black Journalists - which had agreed to sell its list for $400 - withdrew the offer Tuesday. Meanwhile in Brooklyn, a grocery store was firebombed early today, and the owner said he recently had received threats not to sell the Daily News, officials said. The fire, set off by a Molotov cocktail, caused extensive damage to the store and slightly injured three firefighters, said Fire Department spokesman Lt. Frank Martinez. An incendiary device was thrown into the same store Friday but caused no damage, said Sgt. Edward Burns, a police spokesman. The owner, Salah Zamzemi, told police he had received threats and had not been selling the newspaper, according to Burns. No suspects have been found in either incident, Burns said. Dozens of local newsstand owners say they have received warnings not to carry the Daily News. At least one newsstand has been firebombed. The decision by the black journalists' group was announced by its president, Thomas Morgan, after striking workers held three news conferences, sent him a telegram and telephoned him. ``There was a perception that this was seen as furthering management's position. That was never our intention,'' Morgan said. ``We still feel our members have the right to make up their minds about this issue.'' The News had sought to buy membership lists from the black journalists group, the National Association of Hispanic Journalists and the Asian-American Journalists Association. Representatives of the two other groups said they refused. ``We understand why the journalists' associations might not want to offer even the appearance of taking sides in the dispute,'' said James Willse, editor of the News. The first of 2,100 workers in nine unions struck the News on Oct. 25 over what they said were unfair labor practices. Union members at the News, whose normal circulation of 1.09 million made it the nation's third-largest metropolitan daily, had been working without contracts since March 30.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Paley Estate Executors May Opt to Sell CBS Holdings
DOC.TEXT: A heavy tax liability may prompt the sale of the late William S. Paley's 8 percent stake in the media giant CBS Inc., a published report said today. The Wall Street Journal said a sale seems likely because the Paley estate, valued at about $550 million, must raise $190 million to cover tax obligations. A sale of such a large block of CBS stock could rekindle speculation about a takeover of CBS, which has long been the subject of such rumors. Paley, the longtime chairman of CBS who built the company over 60 years, died last month. Much of his estate including 1.9 million shares of CBS stock valued at nearly $300 million is to be divided among his six children. But the Journal said people familiar with the situation said the Paley estate's executors may take a vote next week on whether to sell the CBS holdings. ``We will probably sell that whole block to pay the bills,'' the story quoted someone identified only as a person with knowledge of the estate's finances. A sale would mean the Paley family would cease owning any part of the company Paley founded in 1928 and could put a large chunk of CBS stock into the hands of a single buyer, the story said. CBS president and chief executive Laurence A. Tisch controls Loews Corp. and its 24.9 percent stake in CBS and analysts say his holdings is likely to insure that no unfriendly takeover of CBS could occur. At the same time, analysts feel Tisch is unlikely to expand his stake in the company becaus of federal regulations that govern a ``change of control'' of the company. CBS currently enjoys an exemption from rules barring owning TV and radio properties in the same market, but that exemption would be lost if a new owner would acquire a 25 percent stake in the company. Company executives say privately that Tisch is committed to improving CBS' performance in the primetime TV ratings and that he is not likely to sell his stake until he accomplishes that task. Media analysts note that the depressed state of media stocks, uncertainty over whether the major TV networks will be allowed to have a financial stake in more of the programming that they run and the prospect of a continuing weak advertising environment make it an inopportune time for a sale.

The stock market declined slightly today in a carryover of sporadic selling from Tuesday's session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 4.95 to 2,480.20 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 272 up, 466 down and 458 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 16.88 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said the market appeared to be on hold awaiting the results of a quarterly offering of bonds and notes by the Treasury, which began on Tuesday and continues through Thursday. The refunding encompasses a record $34.25 billion in securities with lives ranging from three years to just under 30 years. Investor demand for that enormous supply apparently has been bolstered by expectations of new moves soon by the Federal Reserve toward a relaxation of its monetary policy. Talk has spread in the past week or so that the Fed is worrying more about countering the effects of recession and less about combating inflationary pressures. USF&G dropped ] to 11~ in active trading. The company announced a cost-cutting plan and reduced its quarterly dividend from 73 cents a share to 25 cents a share. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped .37 to 169.84. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .81 at 291.34. In Tuesday's session the Dow Jones industrial average fell 17.08 to 2,485.15. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by about 8 to 7 on the NYSE, with 697 up, 769 down and 505 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 141.13 million shares, compared with 147.51 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Indicates Change in Policy Over Most-Promising Oilfield
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng indicated willingness Wednesday to give foreign companies a role in developing China's most-promising oilfield, so far closed to foreign involvement. The official Xinhua News Agency said Li made the statement during a meeting with the president of Japan's Mitsubishi Corp., Shinroku Morohashi. ``Morohashi said that Mitsubishi has a great interest in expanding economic cooperation with China, especially in the electric power, oil, chemicals and transport industries and personnel training,'' Xinhua reported. Morohashi specifically mentioned the Tarim Basin in northwestern China's Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, saying Mitsubishi ``is ready to participate'' in oil development there, Xinhua said. ``Li responded by saying these items hold great potential for cooperation,'' Xinhua reported. ``He said he hoped that the two sides would not only cooperate in new and big projects, but also in the technical transformation of China's old enterprises.'' A Mitsubishi spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Li gave ``a very good impression'' that arrangements could be worked out for joint projects in the Tarim Basin. But he said the officials did not discuss details or a possible timetable. Testing has indicated that the 560,000-square-kilometer Tarim Basin is rich in oil and natural gas deposits. The official China Daily said the region is ``very likely to become the country's major oil and natural gas production center.'' The newspaper said experts estimate the Tarim Basin has 12 billion tons of oil and gas reserves. China previously has allowed foreign involvement in offshore drilling and exploration of small onshore deposits in the south, but has been very protective of the Tarim Basin holdings, said Edward Chow, spokesman for the U.S.-based Chevron Oil. He said several foreign companies are interested in oil development in Xinjiang province, but they insist on arrangements that would give them equity in the Tarim Basin oilfield if it eventually can support commercial projects. Chinese officials have refused to allow such arrangements because they want to control the natural resources of the Tarim Basin, oil industry experts say. Chow said a foreign company willing to provide services and technology without demanding equity in the Tarim Basin fields would have the inside track in dealing with the Chinese. ``A lot of companies are interested, but they want different ground rules,'' Chow said.

The stock market gave ground today in a carryover of sporadic selling from Tuesday's session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 12.38 to 2,472.77 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 7 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 432 up, 780 down and 489 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 44.15 million shares at midmorning. Analysts said the market appeared to be on hold awaiting the results of a quarterly offering of bonds and notes by the Treasury, which began on Tuesday and continues through Thursday. The refunding encompasses a record $34.25 billion in securities with lives ranging from three years to just under 30 years. Investor demand for that enormous supply apparently has been bolstered by expectations of new moves soon by the Federal Reserve toward a relaxation of its monetary policy. Talk has spread in the past week or so that the Fed is worrying more about countering the effects of recession and less about combating inflationary pressures. Browning-Ferris Industries fell 1 to 23\ on top of a 6-point plunge Tuesday, when the company reported a 55 percent quarterly earnings decline. USF&G dropped \ to 12 in active trading. The company announced a cost-cutting plan and reduced its quarterly dividend from 73 cents a share to 25 cents a share. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost .83 to 169.38. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.05 at 291.10.

DOC.HEAD: CF&I Steel Files For Reorganization
DOC.TEXT: CF&I Steel Corp. and nine subsidiaries filed petitions for reorganization Wednesday under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. Frank Yaklich Jr., president and chief executive officer, said the company will continue to operate during reorganization. CF&I, baseed in Pueblo, is a major producer of steel products for energy, transportation and agricultural markets. ``We filed Chapter 11 to resolve some financial problems,'' he said. ``This action was taken only after all other options had been exhausted. I want our employees, customers, shareholders and suppliers all to know that CF&I is a survivor and that we are confident CF&I will emerge from this new challenge a stronger, better company,'' Yaklich said. The company's move toward bankruptcy protection began after it was unable in September to make a $12.3 million payment on its pension plan, an underfunded liability estimated at about $140 million. Since then, it has missed an October quarterly payment of $1.8 million. A Chapter 11 filing gives a company a reprieve from its bills, including such things as pension plan payments, while working out a way to stay in business. The company blamed a series of outside economic problems that occurred at the same time, including a deterioration in the energy industry in 1982 and 1983 that led to a downsizing of the company. The company said the downsizing dramatically increased the number of retirees, and reduced its ability to fund the plan. CF&I said it will seek to terminate the plan in the future. The company said if the plan is terminated, obligations to current and future retirees would become the responsibility of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp., the government agency that insures private pension funds.

DOC.NOTE: $adv12
For release Monday, Nov. 12, and thereafter
With LaserPhoto
DOC.HEAD: City Fears Loss of Preeminence As Europe's Financial Capital
DOC.TEXT: Currencies like the lira, mark, or franc could go the way of communism in Europe. A plan adopted by the big European industrialized countries would create a single currency controlled by a common central bank as part of a move toward monetary and economic unity in the continent. The ``City,'' Europe's largest financial center, wants in on the deal. But Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher opposes the current proposal, and that upsets some City economists and businessmen who worry they could be left in the cold. London is considered an anchor in the global trading day, which starts in Tokyo and ends in New York. But already, ``the center of gravity of the European financial system is shifting away from us towards Paris and Frankfurt, and the City is rather nervous about this,'' said Alan Budd, a Barclays Bank economist. Experts say resisting moves toward currency union would erode Britain's largest industry. Financial services account for nearly 20 percent of the gross domestic product and support 12 percent of the nation's jobs. So-called ``invisible trade,'' including banking, finance, insurance and business services, earned more than half of Britain's foreign earnings of nearly $390 billion last year. Kenneth Wright, a director of the British Invisible Exports Council, said: ``We're worried.'' Currency union has emerged as the focus of a long-running, deeply divisive debate within the governing Conservative Party over Britain's role in the 12-nation European Community. At a summit meeting in Rome last month, 11 of the leaders voted to begin the second stage of European Monetary Union on Jan. 1, 1994. That stage includes the establishment of a European central bank, followed by the creation of a single currency. Britain recently fulfilled its commitment to the first stage by entering the EC's exchange rate mechanism. Under the mechanism, Britain's pound sterling is allowed to fluctuate no more than 6 percent from an agreed-upon exchange rate. But Mrs. Thatcher voted no to a commitment to stage two, saying it was premature to set a date when the community still hasn't decided exactly what the second stage will entail. ``The fact that the 11 other members of the community are spearheading the (EMU) move ahead means the City ought to be part of it,'' Sir Michael Butler, chairman of Hambros Bank Ltd., said. Being left out ``certainly would have adverse effects,'' he said. A committee made up of 18 City heavyweights and chaired by Butler has agreed unanimously that Britain should play a full part in the creation of EMU and its operation. Wright said the City backs a plan advanced by Mrs. Thatcher and Chancellor John Major for a ``hard ECU'' - a European currency unit that would be used as an alternative 13th currency. That plan, developed by Butler and a colleague, envisions the common currency evolving into a single currency after some years. But if European leaders decide on one new currency to replace the existing 12 right away, that would be acceptable to his industry, Wright said. ``The majority of the City does want to be a part of monetary union,'' he stressed. Butler sees little sentiment in the financial district to support Mrs. Thatcher's reluctance to join a European central bank or to abolish the pound sterling. London's preeminence as a financial center already faces rising competition, and the increasing economic focus on the continent doesn't help. Commanding the attention these days are the planned creation of a pan-European, trade barrier-free marketplace of 320 million consumers by the end of 1992; the unification of already economically dominant Germany; and the rebuilding of Eastern Europe. Because London's stock market and other financial services are better automated, more sophisticated and less regulated than in other capitals, the City now handles more foreign exchange, bond and share trading than any other European city. London also is the center of European banking, with more than 500 banks; the home of the world's largest insurance and shipping markets, and a major commodities center. Monetary union would radically alter the financial services industry in Europe. There would no longer be trading, for example, between Italian lire and German marks. Bonds would be issued in the single currency, and Europe would have a uniform interest rate. If Britain stands aside, Wright said, the City would have to find ways to compete as an outsider. But many players would simply move to the continent, Butler said. An obvious effect of being an outsider would be to raise the City's operating costs, Wright said. Transactions would have to be converted into pounds, adding the cost of commissions and the delay of additional paperwork. Players also would have to cope with any differences in the regulations of the Bank of England and the European central bank. Nonetheless, at least one expert believes Britain could flourish as an offshore financial center for a unified continent. Noting Switzerland's success as a financial center outside the EC, private economic consultant Tim Congdon said, ``It isn't at all the case that if Britain refuses to take part (in EMU) that the City would become a backwater.'' He said he believes Britain could compete from the outside by continuing to offer more relaxed bank cash reserve requirements and higher interest rates.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Monday, Nov. 12

DOC.HEAD: GM Venture in Czechoslovakia Expands Automaker's Presence in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. on Wednesday announced a further expansion into Eastern Europe with a transmission and vehicle assembly agreement with the government of Czechoslovakia. GM will hook up with Bratislavske Automobilove Zavody factories in Bratislava to make 250,000 transmissions for GM's Opel AG factories in Europe. The partners also will assemble a small number of Opel cars to distribute in Czechoslovakia. GM, the largest automaker in the world, has been eyeing the former Eastern European bloc not only as an expanding market for its products but as a largely untapped manufacturing base. Within the last year, as Eastern Europe's Communist regimes began falling and new markets opened up, GM has announced manufacturing projects for Hungary, the Soviet Union and eastern Germany. In Eisenach, in the former East Germany, GM and Automobilwerke Eisenach began building Opel Vectra cars on Oct. 5, two days after German unification. The two companies plan to build automobile components later. By the mid-1990s, GM is expected to begin making the Opel Kadett four-door sedan in eastern Germany. There is a possibility a new factory will be built to handle the expected production increase that will be needed with the Kadett. The largest project by far is the $1 billion project between GM and Volga Auto Works of the Soviet Union. There, GM will supply engine control systems Volga needs to sell its Lada cars in Europe and other markets. In Hungary, GM will make 200,000 engines a year and 15,000 Opel cars in a joint venture with the state-owned truckmaker RABA, beginning in 1992. The engines are destined for GM assembly operations elsewhere in Europe and the cars initially are to be sold only in Hungary. Details of the GM-BAZ project in Czechoslovakia still must be worked out, GM spokesman Jack Harned said Wednesday. There is existing space for the new transmission and vehicle assembly work at BAZ's plants. ``There obviously will be some significant investment in equipping,'' Harned said. Chrysler Corp. has planned a joint venture to make minivans in Austria. Ford Motor Co. is looking at vehicle assembly plants in Eastern Europe, but so far is concentrating its efforts in Western Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Progress on Agricultural Trade, but Rifts in Other Areas
DOC.TEXT: The long-awaited agreement by European Community ministers on farm subsidies improved the mood among negotiators Wednesday at vital world trade talks. But not by much. ``It keeps the talks alive, although only just,'' said a source at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which is sponsoring the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations. The EC's submission of its offer to cut farm subsidies by 30 percent seems to open the way for genuine hard bargaining in the talks, which are due to finish in less than a month. ``We hope things can now change. We hope that we can make progress in the next few weeks,'' Brazilian ambassador Rubens Ricupero said in an interview. But wide rifts loom in other key sectors. Attempts to reduce trade restrictions on textiles are fraught with the most problems. Talks on new rules on services have run into late hurdles, and negotiators are struggling to find common ground in other areas. Ministers are scheduled to meet Dec. 3-7 to agree on a package of accords covering 15 sectors. Draft texts are due by Nov. 23. The talks, launched in Uruguay in 1986, are the most ambitious attempt ever to liberalize global commerce and boost world economic growth. If they fail, analysts expect a surge in protectionism and damaging trade wars. The talks have not been smooth, particularly those in agriculture. Argentina, which has threatened to walk out if trade-distorting subsidies are not slashed, dismissed the EC offer even before it was announced. Officials from the United States and Australia also termed the EC proposal unacceptable. The United States and other farm product-exporting nations want 90 percent cuts in export subsidies and 75 percent cuts in import barriers and internal supports. GATT Director-General Arthur Dunkel starts top-level discussions on agriculture Thursday. But these will merely determine whether countries will be prepared to negotiate on the EC offer, according to one source. However, another source said there was ``very, very guarded satisfaction,'' that the EC had issued a proposal at all, thus enabling talks to resume in other areas. Trade in textiles will also be the subject of secret negotiations conducted by Dunkel at GATT headquarters on Lake Geneva. Although there is consensus that existing restrictions on trade in textiles should be phased out, there is no agreement on how quickly. Developing countries want rapid action. They accuse industrialized nations, under pressure from powerful domestic textile lobbies, of lacking political will in pushing the negotiations forward. Talks to help liberalize the $600 billion annual trade in services have also hit snags. Realizing that some industries may lose long-standing benefits, the United States, and to a lesser extent the EC, have started pressing for exemptions to the planned rules, especially in shipping, aviation and telecommunications. Other difficult areas include duties against dumping, the practice of unloading goods on foreign markets at lower prices than they're sold domestically.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices closed lower on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday. Dealers said investors lacked direction and were awaiting several events this week, such as the U.S. Treasury refunding Wednesday and Thursday as well as an autumn statement to be delivered Thursday by Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 10.6 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,059.2. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 8.1 points at 1,590.8 at the close, while the Financial Times 500-share index fell 5.11 points to close at 1,096.54. Volume came to 373.7 million shares compared with 386.3 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down in Europe, Gold Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with end of trading in Europe.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mostly weaker in Europe today, hitting new postwar lows against the German mark and Swiss franc amid concerns over the U.S. economy and the election results. Gold prices were higher in generally light European trading, supported by the weaker dollar and news about the Middle East crisis. Gold is considered a safe-haven investment in times of political uncertainty. With the U.S. economy continuing its slide, the currency markets expect the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates in an effort to stimulate business activity. Lower U.S. interest rates make the dollar less appealing to foreign investors. Dealers said the dollar's losses were also fueled by news that Democrats gained in state and congressional elections on Tuesday. Democratic economic policies are perceived to be more likely to lead to higher inflation, which erodes purchasing power and could making the dollar worth less. The dollar fell in hectic late afternoon trading, briefly touching 1.4770 marks before settling at 1.4820. That still broke the previous postwar low of 1.4875 set Tuesday. The dollar fell against the Swiss currency to close at 1.2435, below the previous postwar low of 1.2505 also set Tuesday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 127.55 Japanese yen from 127.20 yen at Tuesday's close. Later in London it rose to 128.15 yen, and in New York at midday the dollar was quoted at 128.85 yen. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9760 from $1.9635 late Tuesday, and in New York at midday, sterling was quoted at $1.97035. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday: 4.9715 French francs, down from 4.9885; 1.6712 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6768; 1,113.75 Italian lire, down from 1,116.75; 1.1627 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1609. Other midday quotes for the dollar in New York included: 1.4843 German marks, 1.2485 Swiss francs, 1,113.35 Italian lire and 1.1618 Canadian dollars. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $387.25 a troy ounce, up from $380.25 late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $386.75, up from $379.50 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.51 to close at a bid $383.64. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $4.28 a troy ounce, up from $4.18 bid late Tuesday.

The stock market fell today in a carryover of selling from Tuesday's session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 17.08 points on Tuesday, dropped 28.96 to 2,456.19 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 442 up, 1,017 down and 461 unchanged. Analysts said the market appeared to be on hold awaiting the results of a quarterly offering of bonds and notes by the Treasury, which began on Tuesday and continues through Thursday. The refunding encompasses a record $34.25 billion in securities with lives ranging from three years to just under 30 years. Investor demand for that enormous supply apparently has beenbolstered by expectations of new moves soon by the Federal Reserve toward a relaxation of its monetary policy. Talk has spread in the past week or so that the Fed is worrying more about countering the effects of recession and less about combating inflationary pressures. Browning-Ferris Industries fell 1~ to 22] on top of a 6-point plunge Tuesday, when the company reported a 55 percent quarterly earnings decline. MCA dropped 1| to 61] following a big fire overnight at the company's Universal Studios near Los Angeles. MCA said it believed its loss was fully covered by insurance. USF&G slipped | to 11| in active trading. The company announced a cost-cutting plan and reduced its quarterly dividend from 73 cents a share to 25 cents a share. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 1.93 to 168.28. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.68 at 290.47. Volume on the Big Board came to 101.77 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Destroys Sets at Universal Studios; Security Guard Arrested
LaserPhotos LA19 of Nov. 6; VNY2; LA6
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with bail raised to $1 million; SUBS 12th graf, `Among outdoor...', to correct that sets destroyed or damaged, sted all destroyed. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A security guard was arrested today on suspicion of torching the historic Universal Studios backlot where Warren Beatty flirted with Madonna in ``Dick Tracy.'' Michael J. Husto, 40, of Tujunga was booked for investigation of arson and held in lieu of $1 million bail in the multimillion-dollar fire, said Deputy Rich Erickson of the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department. ``He was on duty when the fire started and after questioning he was arrested early today at the studio,'' the deputy said. ``We won't disclose a possible motive.'' Huston is an employee of Burns International Security Services, which is under contract by Universal. He had been on the job one month, said Dan Slusser, general manager of Universal City Studios. The John Landis movie ``Oscar,'' a production of the Walt Disney Co. and starring actor Sylvester Stallone, was the only film shooting on the backlot at the time of the fire, said Slusser. Actual filming had stopped for the day before the fire began and Stallone was not present. ``We lost the entire set and are going to shut down for a week to 10 days. We have to build New York Street somewhere,'' said ``Oscar'' publicist Spooky Stevens. ``We also lost 21 vintage cars, the camera equipment, props, every bit of wardrobe.'' The blaze damaged the studio tour's King Kong attraction, which features a 37-foot mechanical gorilla that appears to shake tramloads of tourists. Hundreds of firefighters backed by water-dropping helicopters put out the windblown flames about three hours after the fire broke out at the 420-acre studio, Hollywood's biggest and longest-running movie factory. Universal Studios is visited by millions of tourists each year. ``It roared through the sets like a wildfire. It's like a blowtorch when the wind pushes the fire up against these structures,'' said Los Angeles County Battalion Chief Al Bennett. Most of the damage was to the sunbaked wooden facades along the route of the studio tour, the third most popular tourist attraction in the nation. ``A lot of the streets are pretty well destroyed and are going to have to be rebuilt,'' Bennett said. Among outdoor sets destroyed or damaged were New York Street, where parts of ``The Sting'' were filmed, Brownstone Street, and Courthouse Square, where Michael J. Fox rode his jet-powered skateboard in ``Back to the Future Part II.'' The ``Dick Tracy'' set also was gutted, county fire inspector Jim Gandee said. But it was ``business as usual'' today with the first tour tram leaving on schedule at 9:30 a.m., said studio publicist Joan Bullard. She said about 20 percent of the 420-acre property was burned and estimated damage in the hundreds of millions of dollars. ``We are extremely disappointed to have lost history,'' Bullard said. But she said only one ``attraction,'' or amusement-park-like feature of the tour, was damaged - King Kong. ``The mechanical part of that works, but there was water damage and we are checking the structural integrity of the building,'' Bullard said. Fire officials said the earthquake ride also was damaged, but it worked normally today. The cause of the fire was not immediately known. One firefighter was slightly injured. Studio executives toured the $630 million theme park today to assess the damage. ``Everything looked like charcoal briquets,'' said Rusty Gilligan, who lives near the back lot. ``It was just a wreck.'' The flames, fanned by winds gusting up to 50 mph, were doused as they crept up to two film vaults. The Universal film library, which includes ``E.T. The Extra-Terrestrial,'' ``Jaws'' and ``Twins,'' is worth hundreds of millions. The film library is vital to acquisition talks between Matsushita Electrical Industrial Co. and MCA Inc., Universal's parent. Matsushita has been discussing a multibillion-dollar buyout of MCA for several months. The studio nestled in the Hollywood Hills 10 miles from downtown Los Angeles features a seven-hour journey through the backlot and includes a guided tram tour that takes viewers into sets and a simulated earthquake. About 200 Universal employees and about 160 people at two restaurants on the studio grounds were evacuated after the fire broke out at 7:18 p.m. ``We really had a fire storm. ... It's a miracle that some firefighters didn't get seriously hurt,'' Freeman said. At the nearby Universal Hilton, where the Californian Republican party had its election night headquarters, traffic tie-ups caused by the fire prevented some GOP supporters from reaching the hotel. The fire is not the first to strike Universal. In 1987, a stage used for the 1959 epic ``Spartacus'' erupted in flames. Damage was put at $2.5 million. Universal Studios, founded by Carl Laemmle, opened in 1915. It did not gain recognition until the 1920s, when it produced several now-classic silent films, including ``The Phantom of the Opera,'' and ``The Hunchback of Notre Dame.'' Universal is also home to such film classics as ``Psycho,'' ``Jaws,'' ``Out of Africa'' and ``To Kill A Mockingbird.'' Current TV shows shot at Universal include ``Major Dad,'' ``Murder She Wrote,'' ``Coach,'' ``Quantum Leap,'' ``Lassie'' and ``Matlock.''

The stock market showed a broad loss today in a carryover of selling from Tuesday's session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 17.08 points on Tuesday, dropped 40.35 to 2,444.80 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 425 up, 1,094 down and 431 unchanged. Analysts said the market appeared to be on hold awaiting the results of a quarterly offering of bonds and notes by the Treasury, which began on Tuesday and continues through Thursday. The refunding encompasses a record $34.25 billion in securities with lives ranging from three years to just under 30 years. Investor demand for that enormous supply apparently has been bolstered by expectations of new moves soon by the Federal Reserve toward a relaxation of its monetary policy. Talk has spread in the past week or so that the Fed is worrying more about countering the effects of recession and less about combating inflationary pressures. Browning-Ferris Industries fell 2[ to 22[ on top of a 6-point plunge Tuesday, when the company reported a 55 percent quarterly earnings decline. MCA dropped 1\ to 61} following a big fire overnight at the company's Universal Studios near Los Angeles. MCA said it believed its loss was fully covered by insurance. USF&G slipped | to 11| in active trading. The company announced a cost-cutting plan and reduced its quarterly dividend from 73 cents a share to 25 cents a share. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 2.58 to 167.63. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.14 at 290.01. Volume on the Big Board came to 122.65 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Rebound on Soviet Buying Rumors
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rebounded from eight-month lows Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid speculation the Soviet Union is in the market of U.S. soybeans and soybean meal. Grain futures closed narrowly mixed. Soybeans opened slightly higher following news reports the Soviet Union might have bought 200,000 metric tons of South American soybean meal earlier in the week. Speculation of Soviet interest in U.S. soybeans mounted as commercial grain dealers, including Cargill Inc., became large buyers of soybean futures contracts, analysts said. Slack export sales of soybeans and soymeal have been factors in the soybean market's recent decline, which included a drop on Tuesday to $5.75} a bushel, the lowest daily settlement of a near-month contract since mid-March. Buying interest in soybeans was limited by expectations that the Agriculture Department will significantly increase its U.S. soybean crop estimate in a report due Thursday. A survey of private grain analysts yielded average estimates of 1.84 billion bushels for the 1990 soybean crop and 7.98 billion bushels of corn compared with last month's USDA projections of 1.82 billion bushels of soybeans and 8 billion bushels of corn. At the close, wheat futures were } cent lower to \ cent higher with the contract for December delivery at $2.65} a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 1 cent higher with December at $2.30\ a bushel; oats were 1 cent higher across the board with December at $1.21 a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 6\ cents higher with November at $5.82 a bushel.

The stock market dropped sharply today, unsettled by rising oil prices and fears of war in the Middle East. Traders in the oil and securities markets appeared to believe the chances had increased of an outbreak of hostilities in the Persian Gulf. Warnings of war were seen in comments by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and a confidant of Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. The price of crude oil for December delivery jumped more than $2.50 a barrel, surpassing $35 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Otherwise, analysts said the stock market was on hold awaiting the full results of a quarterly offering of bonds and notes by the Treasury, which began on Tuesday and continues through Thursday. The refunding encompasses a record $34.25 billion in securities with lives ranging from three years to just under 30 years. But investor demand for that enormous supply apparently has been bolstered by expectations of new moves soon by the Federal Reserve toward a relaxation of its monetary policy.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Japan to Sell Parts for Petrochemical Plant
DOC.TEXT: Japan's Missho Iwai will sell $52 million in parts to Tehran for a petrochemical plant abandoned by another Japanese consortium, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported Wednesday. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the parts were for the trouble-ridden Bandar Khomeini petrochemical plant, the largest project of its kind in the gulf. IRNA said Missho Iwai and a number of other Japanese firms are to grant millions of dollars in credit to Iran in exchange for exports of liquified natural gas. Nissho Iwai will replace all components of the complex destroyed in the 1980-88 war with Iraq. Mitsui, a Japanese consortium, started building the plant in 1974 as a joint project with Iran's state-owned National Petrochemical Co. The complex was 80 percent completed in 1980, but work had to be stopped due to heavy attacks by Iraqi bombers. Mitsui refused to finish the plant after the August 1988 cease-fire on grounds that it was not economically feasible. In February, Mitsui paid Iran $900 million to pull out of the project. The French consortium Technip has been awarded the contract to finish the project.

DOC.HEAD: Siemens, Stromberg-Carlson Merge Phone Switch Operations
DOC.TEXT: Subsidiaries of German and British companies are merging their U.S. telephone switching gear operations to form the third-largest supplier of such equipment in North America, the companies said Wednesday. Siemens AG of Germany and Britain's GPT are negotiating the merger of their North American public telecommunication equipment divisions, Siemens Communications Systems and Stromberg-Carlson Corp., to chase U.S. industry leaders American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and Northern Telecom. GPT is owned jointly by Siemens and General Electric Co. PLC of Great Britain. ``It really does create a company of some merit, some credentials in the United States, and I think changes the nature of this whole third-vendor competition,'' said Van Cullens, senior vice president of marketing and business development for the new company, Siemens Stromberg-Carlson. It may take a month or two for the corporations to sign merger documents, but he said, ``We're operating on the basis that for operational purposes and practical purposes it is done.'' Volker Jung, president and chief executive officer of Boca Raton-based Siemens Communications, will be the CEO of the merged companies, they said. The new entity will design, develop, produce and sell computerized public telephone switches, packet switches and transmission systems, the companies said in a joint news release. The majority of the joint venture's 4,000 employees are in Florida,Arizona, New Mexico and New York. The sales and marketing staffs of the two companies will be merged. Stromberg-Carlson and Siemens Communications have supplied phone switching systems to several regional U.S. telephone companies.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Soars As Latest War Rhetoric Seems Real
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices shot up nearly $3 per barrel Wednesday after British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher warned that war could be near in the Persian Gulf. The surge gained momentum when a confidante of Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak said the countdown for confrontation had begun, resurrecting anxiety among oil traders that the flow of petroleum supplies would face disruptions. Traders were also responding to reports that Secretary of State James A. Baker III had given Iraqi President Saddam Hussein an ultimatum for vacating Kuwait, though Baker denied the reports. Light sweet crude closed $2.68 higher at $35.31 per barrel for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil had opened 28 cents lower at $32.35 a barrel, then moved ahead by more than $3 to the day's high of $35.45 before settling back. Contracts for delivery in later months all moved higher, many by the daily limit imposed by the exchange of $1.50 a barrel. Mrs. Thatcher's saber-rattling was directed at Saddam and came as a new session of the Parliament got under way. ``The implacable message of this House must be: either he gets out of Kuwait soon or we and our allies will remove him by force and he will go down to defeat with all the consequences,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. ``He has been warned.'' ``The market's rallied on Thatcher's comments,'' said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. The foreign reports on Baker also pushed up prices, as did the advance release of an editorial to be published Thursday by Makram Mohamed Ahmed, editor of the weekly al Mussawar magazine and a close associate of Mubarak. ``It seems like we are now entering the countdown for war which has become inevitable,'' Ahmed wrote. It was not immediately clear whether this was his personal interpretation of the crisis or the view of the Egyptian government. Regardless, the escalating words of war on Wednesday injected new life into a crude market that had been sluggish for more than a week. ``It's the whole rhetoric for the whole day,'' said Brendan Dolan, a broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``It doesn't look good right now. All signs are pointing to a confrontation.'' Other traders cited perceptions that any attack involving U.S. forces would occur after Tuesday's elections. Refined petroleum product futures and natural gas also jumped higher Wednesday. Home heating oil shot up 6.33 cents to 92.71 cents a gallon on December delivery contracts, with all later contracts higher. Unleaded gasoline rose 3.44 cents to 91.19 cents a gallon on December delivery contracts, with all later contracts moving up by their daily limit of 3 cents a gallon. Natural gas for December delivery was up 6.7 cents to $2.45 per 1,000 cubic feet. Most later contracts traded higher.

DOC.HEAD: USF&G Cuts Dividend, Announces Cuts, Reports Loss, Chairman Retires
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES in last graf with closing stock price.
DOC.TEXT: USF&G Corp. slashed its dividend and announced a $75 million cost-cutting program Wednesday on the heels of a $15 million third-quarter loss, a move cited by one analyst as good news for the diversified financial services company. USF&G said it cut its quarterly common stock dividend to 25 cents a share effective Jan. 31, 1991, down from 73 cents a share. The company also said its chairman, chief executive and president, Jack Moseley, 59, was retiring early. A successor for Moseley, who has served in those posts since 1981, has been found and will be announced in several weeks, the company said. ``The extended duration of the present trough in the property and casualty market and the economic uncertainty resulting from a general business downturn required these extraordinary actions,'' the board announced. The Baltimore-based company, which focuses on property, casualty and life insurance, said the moves were designed to conserve capital and make the company more competitive. John Bailey, a stock analyst with the Washington brokerage house Ferris, Baker Watts, said the dividend cut was expected, but the austerity program was not. ``This is a positive step because it's decisive action to deal with a difficult situation,'' Bailey said. ``I think the jury is still out on whether it will be effective.'' Except for the fourth quarter of 1989, USF&G had not earned enough to pay its dividend since the beginning of 1989, Bailey said. That hurt its ability to write new insurance coverage because it drained capital, he said. Insurance premiums move cyclically, with prices declining as more insurers enter the market and compete for business. Once prices drop low enough, however, the weaker insurers are weeded out and prices begin to rise, Bailey said. ``USF&G is in a situation that when that upswing in prices happens, they might not be able to take advantage of it,'' he said. ``With the moves they take today, they improve their position to take advantage of rising prices.'' USF&G said it would cut $75 million through layoffs and attrition at all levels and in all segments. USF&G spokeswoman Kerrie Burch-DeLuca said layoffs and other cost-cutting measures would not be announced until after the new chairman takes over. For the third quarter, the company said it lost $15 million, or 22 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $17 million, or 25 cents a share, for the same period a year earlier. Revenue in the quarter rose to $1.15 billion from $1.14 billion a year earlier. For the first nine months, USF&G earned $41.0 million, or 35 cents a share, up from $15 million, or 3 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue was $3.42 billion for the first nine months of 1990, from $3.41 billion a year earlier. USF&G reported a $5 million loss in its financial services segment and a 4.8 percent decline in its equity portfolio, which comprises 13 percent of its $11.1 billion in invested assets. USF&G also said it had put aside $18 million in its real estate loan loss reserve fund, money used to cover non-performing loans, compared with $10 million in the same period last year. USF&G, which has $13.9 billion in total assets, said it has a $1 billion real estate portfolio, including $490 million in participating mortgage loans. USF&G stock fell 10 percent Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange amid speculation about a dividend cut, closing at $12.25. It fell again Wednesday, to $11.625.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Tradesmen Get On-The-Job Training in Chicago
DOC.TEXT: Easing Poland's severe housing shortage is the idea behind a program that sent Polish tradesmen here for hands-on experience with construction equipment. The program, sponsored by the Coca-Cola Co., the AFL-CIO and the U.S. Labor Department, stems from the government's encouragement of American efforts to help Eastern Europe shift to a free-market economy. As part of the program, 10 workers from Poland have spent two months working side-by-side in Chicago with five American experts in iron-working, bricklaying, carpentry, electrical work and plumbing. They will return to Poland at the end of the week to put their new skills to work. Outside Warsaw, in the small city of Praga, they will teach their new skills to other laborers at a new center being established by the Labor Department and the AFL-CIO. The center, scheduled to open at the end of the year, will be outfitted with equipment provided by several U.S. companies. Coca-Cola is giving $150,000 to pay for the 10 workers' salaries for two years. ``This is important because it will help improve the standard of living in Poland,'' said Mirek Napiorkowski, a 38-year-old plumber from the Warsaw area who is participating. ``At present some families have waited as long as 30 years for an apartment,'' Napiorkowski said Wednesday through an interpreter. He and eight other workers selected by Poland's Solidarity union arrived in Chicago in early September, and joined Polish-speaking American workers selected by unions affiliated with the AFL-CIO. They worked on construction projects throughout the Chicago area, selected as the training site because of its large Polish population, said Michael Semrau, an assistant vice president at Coca-Cola. Housing is scarce in Poland due to a lack of materials and a work ethic shaped by nearly 50 years of Communist rule, said Ray Robertson, general vice president for the Iron Workers union. Many families live in cramped flats with relatives, waiting years for their name to be called from a waiting list for housing, he said. Robertson, who visited Poland in May with union leaders, said workers there told him their motto had been ``pretend to work for pretend wages.'' ``When we were there in May it was like stepping back 45-50 years,'' he said Wednesday. ``There were apartment buildings that were started in 1981 and still not completed.'' Many Polish construction practices are considered backward by American standards, said electrician Ziggy Kaminski, a native Pole who lives in suburban Chicago and is helping train the visitors. Unlike the United States, where electric wiring is hidden inside narrow pipes installed between walls, ``they have open wiring, just installed inside the walls, which is unsafe and doesn't look too good,'' Kaminski said. ``A lot of methods (the Poles learned) were completely new to them,'' he said. Also new to the Poles was labor relations, American style. ``We feel there is respect among the various trades as well as between worker and superintendent,'' said Marion Polinski, a 35-year-old Warsaw plumber. ``Everyone treats everyone else as a human being, not as number, therefore it enhances their production,'' Polinski said. Semrau said the program also will benefit Coca-Cola by providing skilled workers for new bottling plants it plans to open in Poland.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Cabinet Rejects Proposed Settlement of Lobster Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian board on Wednesday rejected a proposal to settle a free trade dispute between lobstermen in the United States and Canada. Canadian fishermen are allowed to keep and sell smaller lobsters than their U.S. counterparts. Representatives of the U.S. and Canadian lobster industries recently had proposed increasing the minimum size of lobsters taken along Canada's Atlantic Coast to the U.S. level of 3\ inches. The proposal also called for creating a joint U.S.-Canadian committee to discuss lobster management issues and for both countries to work together to promote and market lobsters. But on Wednesday, Canadian Trade Minister John Crosbie announced in Ottawa that the country's federal cabinet had rejected the proposed settlement. John Kearney, a spokesman for the Maritime Fishermen's Union in Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, hailed the decision. ``We have no biological reason in Canada for increasing our minimum size,'' he said. ``We have a whole range of management and regulatory measures ... that are non-existent in the United States.'' But lobster industry officials from Maine predicted a worsening of relations between the two countries because of the decision. ``For them to pull out of it means there's going to be more bickering and fighting among all the various factions of the industry,'' said William Anderson, a lobsterman from Lubec and chairman of the state's Lobster Advisory Council. To U.S. fishermen, the dispute over size is much more than academic because they compete against Canadian lobstermen who sell the majority of their catch in the United States. ``It's a big deal because so many lobsters fit into that size range. Lobsters that are just over that (minimum) measure make up the majority of the catch,'' said David Dow, executive director of the Maine Lobster Institute, a scientific and educational organization that fosters cooperation in the lobster industry. At the urging of U.S. lobstermen, President Bush signed legislation last December banning the import of live Canadian lobsters that are smaller than the minimum U.S. size. Ottawa contended the new law violated the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement and would cost the industry $30 million of its $180 million live lobster industry. But an international panel ruled in late May that the U.S. law did not violate the pact. The proposal rejected Wednesday called for increasing the minimum size of lobsters taken along Canada's Atlantic Coast to the U.S. level of 3\ inches from the crustacean's eye socket to the edge of its body where the tail begins. Currently, Canada has a range of minimum sizes from 2{ inches to 3 3-16 inches, depending on where the lobsters are caught. Some Canadian lobster industry officials were upset by their country's decision. The nation's largest lobster exporter, Clearwater Fine Foods of suburban Bedford, Nova Scotia, has long supported raising size limits for what it says are conservation reasons. ``There is no competent biologist who advises other than the desirability of raising size imits,'' company spokesman Doug Robinson told Canadian Press on Wednesday. ``The bottom line is most lobsters now caught are immature. They have not spawned,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Eases After Erratic Trading, Gold Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS Comex silver price in last graf to $4.267
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended moderately lower against most currencies in volatile trading Wednesday, bouncing off early-day lows with a buying spurt prompted by Middle East saber-rattling. Gold prices were mixed. Currency traders sold aggressively on concerns over a U.S. economic slump, which led to fears that the Federal Reserve would move to lower interest rates in order to stimulate business activity. Lower interest rates generally diminish the value of the dollar. Also pushing the dollar down was news that Democrats gained in state and congressional elections on Tuesday. Democratic economic policies are perceived to be more likely to lead to higher inflation, which erodes purchasing power and could making the dollar worth less. However, heightened fears of war in the Persian Gulf sent the dollar bouncing back. In some of her strongest remarks of the 3-month-old Iraqi standoff, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told British lawmakers Iraq will have to be removed forcefully from Kuwait if it doesn't leave peacefully. ``Dealers are still strong believers in the dollar as a refuge during times of uncertainty,'' said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer at Barclays Bank PLC. ``This market is still very very uncomfortable selling dollars with a heightened possibility of war in the Middle East.'' The dollar rose against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 128.73 yen, up from Tuesday's 128.15. In overnight trading in Tokyo, the dollar fell to 127.55 Japanese yen from 127.20 yen late Tuesday, and in London, it was quoted at 128.15 yen. The British pound rose to $1.9690 in New York from $1.9657 late Tuesday, and in earlier London trading, sterling rose to $1.9760 from late Tuesday's $1.9635. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late rates, included: 1.4874 German marks, down from 1.4927; 1.2485 Swiss francs, down from 1.2545; 4.9870 French francs, down from 5.0055; 1,116.0 Italian lire, down from 1,121.0; and 1.1671 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1630. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday, included: 4.9715 French francs, down from 4.9885; 1.6712 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6768; 1,113.75 Italian lire, down from 1,116.75; 1.1627 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1609. Gold moved erratically in domestic trading. It fell 30 cents a troy ounce to $386.30 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $386.70, up $1.10. Analysts said gold was influenced by internal market supply-demand factors that pulled it in different directions, after rising on fears of war escalation in the Middle East. In earlier trading in London, gold rose to a late bid price of $387.25 a troy ounce, up from $380.25 late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $386.75, up from $379.50 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.51 to close at a bid $383.64. Silver rose on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $4.267 a troy ounce, up 3.3 cents. In London, silver bullion rose to a late bid price of $4.28 a troy ounce, up from $4.18 bid late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Paley Estate Executors Say No Decision Made on Selling CBS Holdings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to UPDATE with closing stock price; PICK UP 6th graf, Paley, longtime ...
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. shares edged higher Wednesday amid speculation over whether executors of William S. Paley's estate will decide to sell the late CBS Inc. chairman's 8 percent stake in the media company. But CBS executives and media analysts said even if the stock were sold, chances were slim it could lead to an unfriendly bid for control of the company, a frequent subject of takeover rumors. The Wall Street Journal reported a sale of the stock seems likely, partly because the Paley estate, valued at about $500 million, must raise $190 million to cover tax obligations. Pat Gallagher, executive director of the William S. Paley Foundation and one of six executors of the Paley estate, said he could not confirm the tax liability figure but called suggestions the stock may be sold ``pure speculation.'' CBS stock closed up 50 cents at $158.62{ on the New York Stock Exchange Wednesday. It traded as high as $162 earlier in the day. Paley, longtime chairman of CBS, died last month. Much of his estate including 1.9 million shares of CBS stock valued at nearly $300 million is to be divided among his six children. But the Journal quoted unidentified people familiar with the situation as saying the Paley estate's executors may vote next week on whether to sell the CBS holdings. ``We will probably sell that whole block to pay the bills,'' one of the people, described as knowledgable about the estate's finances, was quoted as saying in the Journal account. Arthur Liman, another executor of the Paley estate, said the executors have made no decisions on how to handle the estate's tax liability. He said the executors meet regularly, but that no special meeting has been set yet on what to do with the CBS stock. Gallagher noted that the estate also includes numerous other securities and investments, including artwork and real estate, that could be used to satisfy any tax obligations. CBS spokesman George Schweitzer said even if the stock were sold, it would not be something that could affect control of CBS. CBS president and chief executive Laurence A. Tisch controls Loews Corp. and its 24.9 percent stake in CBS. That stake, combined with stock held by employees and investors who support Tisch effectively blocks any unwelcome bids for control of the company, media analysts say. State takeover laws in New York, where CBS is based, require an unfriendly bid to win the support of two-thirds of a company's common stock. ``Tisch has de facto control of CBS,'' said John Reidy, who follows the media business for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Company executives say privately that Tisch is committed to improving CBS' performance in the primetime television audience ratings where it trails NBC and he is unlikely to sell - if he ever does - before accomplishing that. The depressed state of media stocks might make them seem atractive investments. But media analysts say the low stock values stem from weak advertising revenues and restrictions that limit TV networks' financial stakes in the programming they carry, making it an inopportune time for a takeover.

DOC.HEAD: Rockwell Reports 6 Percent Increase in Quarter Profits
DOC.TEXT: Rockwell International Corp. said Wednesday its quarterly profit rose 6 percent and credited its move to diversify beyond military work. For the quarter ending Sept. 30, Rockwell said profits were $133 million, or 56 cents per share, on sales of $3.21 billion. That compares with $126 million, or 50 cents per share, on sales of $3.27 bilion for the same period last year. The company said its electronics business, the company's largest sector, was driven by commercial orders in the fourth fiscal quarter. The year's results ``confirmed the important shift in Rockwell's business, with strong contributions coming from our commercial and international markets and with electronics continuing to be our largest sector,'' Donald R. eall, chief executive, said in a statement. For the 1990 fiscal year, profits were $624.3 million, or $2.56 per share, down 15 percent from 1989 profits of $734.9 million, or $2.87 per share. But 1989 profits included a pre-tax gain of $161.5 million from the company's sale of its measurement and flow control division. Without that gain, 1989 profits were $630.9 million, or $2.47 per share. Sales for fiscal 1990 were $12.3 billion, down 1 percent from $12.5 billion during fiscal 1989. If the division sale is excluded from 1989 sales, fiscal 1990 sales rose slightly. Rockwell is involved in electronics, aerospace, automotive and graphics businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Studio Guard Arrested in Spectacular Universal Blaze
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to fix garble in 3rd graf, CORRECT damage estimate to millions, sted hundreds of millions. Pick up 6th graf, `MCA Inc. ...; Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Universal Profile
LaserPhotos LA6, LA8
DOC.TEXT: A guard was arrested Wednesday for allegedly torching the historic Universal Studios backlot, gutting sets used for ``Dick Tracy,'' ``Back to the Future'' and an unfinished Sylvester Stallone movie. Michael J. Huston, 40, of Tujunga was booked for investigation of arson and held in lieu of $1 million bail, said sheriff's Deputy Rich Erickson. ``He was on duty when the fire started and after questioning he was arrested early today at the studio,'' Erickson said. Authorities refused to disclose a possible motive. Huston is an employee of Burns International Security Services, a New Jersey firm contracted by Universal. He had been on the job one month, said Dan Slusser, general manager of Universal City Studios. ``We are all saddened as a result of this fire and arrest of one of our security officers,'' said Burns' Western States president, William Ewing. Damage to the studio, visited by 5.1 million tourists a year, was expected to be in the millions of dollars, but Slusser said it would take days to make an assessment. MCA Inc., Universal's parent company, said it believes the loss is fully covered by insurance. Although rubble continued to smolder, the studio's popular tram tour went ahead as scheduled Wednesday morning, a day after the wind-driven fire. Leaving promptly at 9:30 a.m., trams full of visitors toured the charred remains of the sets from such classic films as ``The Sting,'' ``To Kill a Mockingbird'' and the ``Back to the Future'' series. ``The show must go on. The show will go on,'' said one tour driver who gave his name only as Larry. ``The idea is to show you all of our backlot, only a small portion was actually damaged.'' In fact, the only principal attraction not operating was King Kong, featuring a fire-belching ape with banana breath. Studio officials said the attraction should be reopened in a few days. The John Landis movie ``Oscar,'' a production of the Walt Disney Co. starring Stallone, had finished filming for the day just hours before the fire. ``We lost the entire set and are going to shut down for a week to 10 days. We have to build New York Street somewhere,'' said publicist Spooky Stevens. ``We also lost 21 vintage cars, the camera equipment, props, every bit of wardrobe.'' For almost three hours Tuesday night, flames fanned by 50 mph winds spread through the 75-year-old Hollywood landmark. Firefighters extinguished the four-acre blaze shortly after 10 p.m. Among outdoor sets damaged were New York Street, where parts of ``The Sting'' were filmed, Brownstone Street and Courthouse Square, where Michael J. Fox rode his jet-powered skateboard in ``Back to the Future Part II.'' The ``Dick Tracy'' set was gutted, county fire inspector Jim Gandee said. Favorite tour attractions survived, including the simulated earthquake ride, the shark-snapping Jaws exhibit, the flash flood area, the parting of the Red Sea, the ice tunnel and the ``Psycho'' house and Bates Motel. Also untouched were Colonial Street, where Beaver Cleaver and Marcus Welby lived, the fictional town of Amity and the area where ``Murder, She Wrote'' is filmed, the Six Points, Texas, Old West section and Little Europe, where the 1930s film ``Frankenstein'' was filmed. The studio nestled in the Hollywood Hills 10 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles features a seven-hour tour through the backlot. The flames were doused as they crept toward two film vaults. The Universal film library, which includes ``E.T. The Extra-Terrestrial,'' ``Jaws'' and ``Twins,'' is worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The value of the library is vital to acquisition negotiations between Japan's Matsushita Electrical Industrial Co. and MCA Inc. Matsushita has been discussing a multibillion-dollar buyout of MCA for several months. One firefighter was slightly injured with face and hand burns. The fire was not the first at Universal. In 1987, a stage used for the 1959 epic ``Spartacus'' ignited, causing $2.5 million in damage.

DOC.HEAD: New York Times Announces Sale of Three Papers
DOC.TEXT: The New York Times Co. announced Wednesday it has agreed to sell two Kentucky daily newspapers and one Tennessee weekly to an Illinois firm. Nancy Nielsen, a New York Times Co. spokeswoman, said American Daily Publishing Company of West Frankfort, Ill., signed the agreement Wednesday to buy The (Middlesboro) Daily News and The Harlan Daily Enterprise in Kentucky, and the Claiborne Progress in New Tazewell, Tenn. Nielsen said she could not release details of the deal. The two dailies have a combined circulation of 14,000. The weekly has a circulation of 6,400, Nielsen said. The Times purchased the three papers in December 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Vacates Injunction Against Machinists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf to CORRECT second reference to Lifland; PICK UP 9th graf, At La Guardia ...
DOC.TEXT: The Eastern Airlines bankruptcy judge overstepped his authority when he blocked machinists from engaging in violent and disruptive strike tactics, a federal judge ruled Wednesday. U.S. District Judge Leonard B. Sand of Manhattan vacated an injunction that had barred certain strike activity by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers. Sand ruled that the order could have been issued by a federal or state judge, but not by a bankruptcy judge. He said the bankruptcy order violated the 1932 Norris-LaGuardia Act, which mandates that a party involved in a labor dispute cannot be granted an injunction until ``reasonable efforts'' are made to settle differences through mediation or arbitration. Eastern filed for voluntary bankruptcy several days after the machinists' unions went on strike in March 1989. The injunction by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland specifically barred machinists from disrupting Eastern's activities by shouting, holding mass pickets that blocked traffic, vandalizing property or assaulting non-union workers. ``Nothing in this opinion should be taken to be condonation of any unlawful acts committed by strikers at different airports around the United States,'' Sand said in a 23-page decision. ``Eastern is free to seek other forms of remedies in federal court and all types of relief in state court.'' Lifland had issued the injunction after holding an extensive hearing about violent strike tactics at airports in New York and Georgia. At La Guardia Airport in New York, machinists discouraged passengers from flying with the airline and tried to block non-union employees from reporting to work, according to the decision. Other strikers flooded bathrooms in the Eastern terminal and sabotaged luggage conveyer belts with glue, it said. Eastern spokesman Jim Ashlock said the airline planned to appeal Sand's ruling. Repeated calls to the union headquarters in Washington were not answered.

DOC.HEAD: 800 Jobs To Be Lost By Northrop Plant Closure
DOC.TEXT: Northrop Corp. will close its missile plant in nearby Newbury Park and eliminate 800 jobs, company officials said Wednesday. The work will be transferred to Northrop factories in Hawthorne and Pico Rivera as part of a company streamlining prompted by cutbacks in defense spending, said Northrop spokesman Tony Cantafio. ``The company has to be sized right in the current defense market,'' Cantafio said. By the end of next year, the defense contractor will have closed the 28-year-old Newbury Park plant, a unit of the company's Aircraft Division, Cantafio said. The 670,000 square-foot plant about 40 miles west of Los Angeles will be sold. ``We eliminate unnecessary duplication of functions and facilities,'' said Northrop chairman Kent Kresa in a written statement. ``We improve our ability to develop ... strategies in a defense environment that is more demanding technically and economically.'' The Aircraft Division employs about 15,000 people in California and is the chief contractor for development of the Advanced Tactical Fighter prototype YF-23. The company expects that about 400 of the people losing their jobs will take an early retirement offer, Cantafio said. Meanwhile, Northrop is consolidating management of three electronics plants. Electronics divisions in Hawthorne; Norwood, Mass. and Rolling Meadows, Ill. will be run from Rolling Meadows. No job losses are expected from consolidating the electronics divisions, Cantafio said.
